fields.headline: The best radio scene
fields.standfirst: Frequency
fields.trailText: Frequency
fields.body:
New York, 1999. Still living in the house where he grew up, cop John Sullivan (Jim Caviezel) finds an old ham radio belonging to his father, Frank (Dennis Quaid), who died back in '69.

To his amazement, he finds that the radio still works. Tuning the dial, he starts a conversation with another ham enthusiast: his father, transmitting from 30 years before. Slowly, realisation of who he is listening to dawns on John.

"What did you say your name was?"

"Frank. Frank Sullivan."

Panic and disbelief spreads across John's face.

"Is this some kind of joke? Gordo, is that you? Are you messing with me?"

"I ain't messing with you," comes the reply. "Look, I'm just trying..."

"You tell me your name is Frank Sullivan, you live in Queens, and you want to know how I call the first game in the 1969 World Series?"

"Yeah, that's exactly what I want to know."

"Gordo, if this is you, so help me... What did you say your call station or your call letters were?"

"W2QYV."

Jim looks at his radio. The letters are exactly the same.

See also: Warriors, Do The Right Thing, Private Parts, A Matter Of Life And Death

Don't see also: Sleepless In Seattle

Pointless trivia: Dennis Quaid's favourite director of all time is David Lean.

fields.headline: Who dares swindles
fields.standfirst: Last week, a sacked whistleblower won his case for unfair dismissal. And what was the crime he had exposed? Expenses fraud.  Emma Brockes  examines attitudes to fiddling the books
fields.trailText: Last week, a sacked whistleblower won his case for unfair dismissal. And what was the crime he had exposed? Expenses fraud. Emma Brockes examines attitudes to fiddling the books
fields.body:
The fraud squad

It wasn't putting pizza on his expenses that got Frank into trouble at work. Catching a taxi home from the pizza place wasn't considered extravagant either. It was Frank's decision to have the taxi park in a lay-by for half an hour while he ate his pizza that brought his expenses claim to the attention of both his line manager and the director of the company. In his defence, Frank pleaded that if he had waited to eat it at home, his pizza would have been cold (it was a snowy night in Edinburgh). He was made to refund the £50 fare and withstand a withering attack from both bosses.

Frank was a sports journalist and as such fell into a category recognised by auditors as temperamentally inclined towards what they refer to as "taking the piss". Last week, an alleged expenses fraudster was exposed when an employment tribunal upheld a suit brought by Antonio Fernandes against Netcom Consultants in Reading. Netcom was found to have unfairly dismissed Fernandes after he blew the whistle on Steven Woodhouse, the boss who allegedly asked him to sign off bogus expenses amounting to £370,000.

There is no better introduction to a business than its attitude towards expenses claims, since it relies on a combination of financial necessity and something more indefinable, something closer to what members of august old banking houses probably think of in terms of "class". The idea of having a written expenses policy, where you are told how much to spend on lunch and which class of travel to take, is still viewed with horror in certain quarters. These are the companies in which it is happily assumed that at a certain level within the hierarchy, you will enter a bubble-wrapped zone in which you can bank your income and charge all your daily expenses to the corporate AmEx. To question such a thing, as Antonio Fernandes did, is to risk looking terribly déclassé and to lose one's job.

"We are told we can use our expenses to buy anything we wouldn't be ashamed of telling our client about," says a management consultant at one of the world's biggest firms. "But nobody really checks. A couple of weeks ago a colleague tried to give a waitress a £1,000 tip. She refused but if she'd accepted, it would have gone through without question."

In companies like these, the culture of entitlement that flourished in the 80s has yet to find a more disciplined replacement, as it has in manufacturing and service industries. "It's cultural," says Matthew Davis, manager of the American Express consultancy arm that advises companies on how to manage their travel and entertainment expenses. "For example, if you tell the top people at a merchant bank: 'You are going to fly economy to New York' you might get a whole team upping and leaving. These guys are earning millions for the company. But a manufacturing industry might not be so used to five-star travel, since the margins of their corporation don't justify it."

Most cases that make it to tribunal don't involve Concorde flights to New York or deliveries of cocaine to the courier desk. If there is anything that characterises Britain's blaggers, it is their lack of ambition. Harbhajan Parwar, a trading standards officer from Birmingham, was sacked for faking petrol mileage claims to the tune of £115. He used forged documents to try to win his job back and earlier this year received a suspended prison sentence. Chief superintendent Colin Macdonald from the West Midlands was convicted, in December 1998, of filing £26,000 in bogus expenses claims based on undercover surveillance operations that never happened. He was jailed for two years and sacked from his £55,000 per year post. And in 1997, BBC administrator Penelope Jefferson received a 12-month jail sentence for an expenses fiddle of £34,000, though police estimated the total to be in excess of £100,000 over six years. Her fraud, carried out by altering the cash amounts on credit card slips and shop receipts, was discovered in a routine audit when a stationer's receipt for nearly £3,000 was found to be based on an original bill of £6.49. On another occasion, she took seven friends to lunch at a cost of £143.30, then used the receipt to claim £743.30 as business expenses.

However, it was Roger Lyons, general secretary of the Manufacturing, Science and Finance Union, who last month emerged as the most intriguing of the expenses blaggers. When his claims were broken down, it became clear that he had blown over £6,000 on assorted bric-a-brac and takeaways: a radio for the bathroom, bought because his partner couldn't stand listening to the Today programme in the bedroom, a video, an embarrassing claim for a 25p bun. He didn't sound like a man on a thieving spree so much as one enjoying a blanket expenses culture at odds with the industry he was in.

"What is acceptable to put down on expenses depends on who are seen to be the stakeholders in the organisation," says Professor Leo Murray, director of Cranfield School of Management. "If you're working in the public sector, it's quite difficult to go and lunch at the Savoy because the stakeholders are people lying on trolleys in hospital corridors."

Murray took up his position at Cranfield after working in the private sector as a manager in the consumer goods business. "I found that people were very careful with the odd penny at Cranfield. I decided to loosen it up a bit and enforce a policy that if you had to travel on a plane for more than five hours, you could travel club class."

Such enforcement of an expenses policy is becoming more standard now. "It's amazing how many companies haven't got a clue how much they spend on travel and entertainment expenses," says Mike Platt, managing director of travel management company Hogg Robinson. This is in spite of the fact that, according to a global survey carried out last year by American Express, travel and related expenses account for 7% of the total operating costs of multinational companies. This is up from 3% in 1994, ranking it as a company's third largest controllable expense and one of the most easily exploitable for expenses scams.

"We went into a company that had a policy saying you must travel economy unless there are only first-class seats available on the date and time you have to travel," Platt says. "So people were phoning up in advance and getting details of which flights were full [in the cheaper seats] and which weren't, then demanding a seat on the ones that were full." Only 51% of companies now assign tickets purely by the position of the traveller in a company's hierarchy, but it remains a delicate operation. There are egos to be tiptoed around, to the extent that British Airways has come up with a new class of travel - "business economy" - which separates executive flyers from the riffraff at the back of the plane, but with the key word "economy" in the title so it doesn't break company travel policy.

The most efficient way of auditing expenses is either by taking a percentage sample or by targeting claims over a certain value, yet according to American Express, 54% of companies still audit every single claim - at a considerable cost. In a recent survey of business travel, the average US company was shown to spend around £14 processing each expense report. You can put in machines that detect if a figure three has been made into an eight; you can conduct regular audits. But for many finance directors, it is still cheaper and less painful to close your eyes and sign.

fields.headline: Phrase makers
fields.standfirst:
Bill Bruford/Larry Coryell
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Bill Bruford/Larry Coryell
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Like Charlie Watts, the rock drummer Bill Bruford (Genesis, King Crimson, Yes) had his heart in jazz all along. Bruford even tried to persuade some of his heavy-hitting associates to lighten up to a jazzier repertoire, but since they had more business sense than that, he eventually concluded that the only way was to do it himself.

Bruford formed his highly personal notion of a fusion band, Earthworks, in 1986; Django Bates and Iain Ballamy were inventive early members. The current version is at the Pizza Express until Saturday, with the American guitarist Larry Coryell guesting until Thurs day. Bruford's sidelong, slippery tunes, with their Breckerish postbop turns, odd confections of time, percussive phrasing and sudden crash-stops, were the highly effective anchor of the show. On Monday, the just-arrived Coryell was feeling his way, but a fluid understanding between the players began to grow.

Maybe the shortage of rehearsal time led this particular configuration to fall back on folk-memories; in any case, it made for a diverting performance. Bruford sounded more like Art Blakey than usual, snare rolls dropping into tantalising pauses before the cymbal pulse scurried in, bumpy accents stretching and compressing the beat. Coryell's approach was reminiscent of the late Wes Montgomery, softly whirling bop runs giving way to driving improvisations in chords and octaves. Pianist Steve Hamilton contributed a tidal energy to the complex opener Never the Same Way Once, while the laconic melodic twists of If Summer Had its Ghosts highlighted the intriguing idiosyncrasies of the excellent, guttural-toned saxophonist Patrick Clahar: his deep, gargly warble, bagpipe-like long notes and inventive contrasts of phrase-shapes. One to catch, and probably before Coryell's four days end, because the whole show will tighten up.

Until Saturday. Box office: 020-7439 8722.

fields.headline: Personable imperfection
fields.standfirst:
Gabrielle
Shepherd's Bush Empire, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Gabrielle
Shepherd's Bush Empire, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Gabrielle shouldn't be a star, but here she is, emoting to a full Empire as if she's been waiting years for this. In many ways, she could only have happened in this country. Her voice is pleasant at best, with none of the aching highs and lows of the true (ie American) soul diva. Then there's her self-consciousness about what she considers to be "my enormous butt and huge feet", and the sunglasses worn to hide a droopy eye. To top it off, she utterly lacks the imperiousness of her US counterparts, chatting so easily that it wouldn't have seemed out of place if she'd invited us all back to her south London pad after the show. Whitney and Mariah would never permit such familiarity.

Despite this, Gabrielle is the closest thing Britain's got to a soul superstar. The album Rise and its title track are among this year's biggest hits, reinstating her after a fallow period during which it looked as if she'd never match the success of her 1993 debut, Dreams. In that time she only hit the headlines when her son's father was convicted of murdering his stepfather, an incident that led to the redemptive Rise.

Her acoustic version has people swaying to its soothing chorus: "I'm building bridges from these scenes, now I'm ready to rise again". Like many of her tunes, the sentiment is anodyne, but her warm delivery invests it with meaning. She carries the whole show, in fact, by force of personality, transforming MOR torch songs such as If You Cared into intimate slices of life by singing imperfectly and making up for it with an apologetic smile. If you want perfection, she semaphores, go see Whitney, but if you want real life, albeit glossily packaged (indeed, she's nothing short of gorgeous in floor-length white and the ubiquitous shades), I'm your girl.

The show does follow R&B tradition after a fashion, but where Houston would have a slick session band, Gabs had a comfy crew that looked like her Brockley mates; where Whitney would have 10 dancers, Gabrielle had four, frugging old-fashionedly to the Motownish new single, When a Woman. And where La Houston would have a lackey dabbing away perspiration, Gabrielle mopped her face with an inelegant blue towel. Maybe it was that towel, but by the end you felt a lot better about the world.

Until tonight. Box office: 020-7771 2000, then touring.

fields.headline: Schlock horror
fields.standfirst:
A Busy Day
Lyric Shaftesbury, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
A Busy Day
Lyric Shaftesbury, London
Rating: **
fields.body:
A busy day in London in the summer of 1800, when marriages are made in heaven and hell and old genes meet new money, turns out to be a not particularly productive evening in the theatre.

This "lost" play by the popular novelist and diarist Fanny Burney, which languished unperformed in an American library for 200 years, is a minor curiosity, of interest largely as a rare play by a woman of the period. A small production in an intimate theatre might make you warm to what is essentially a jolly courtship romp with some waggish lines, but Jonathan Church's cumbersome, overblown production doesn't succeed in making any greater claims for it and loses a great deal by not trusting the humour. Miss Eliza Watts, fostered in infancy by Mr Alderson of Calcutta, returns to London with an £80,000 inheritance to meet the family she has never known because they were too poor to keep her. But since then Mr Watts has made a fortune in the City, most of which Mrs Watts and elder daughter Peggy are wearing on their backs like gaudy peacocks.

Matters are complicated by the fact that Eliza is the love of the poor but well- connected Mr Cleveland, whose grand titled relatives despise City money and have earmarked him for the rich, well-bred Miss Percival; and complicated still further when Cleveland's wastrel younger brother decides that marriage to Eliza will pay off his debts.

It all comes out right in the end, of course, with everyone getting the partner they deserve, but the unravelling of the plot is something of an endurance test. This is a play that requires the lightest and crispest of touches. It should be like fresh linen. But Church encourages most of the cast to mug like mad. Sara Crowe's eye-rolling flibbertigibbet Miss Percival is all cheese, Ben Moor's Lord John is more flop than fop and Stephanie Beacham's snobbish Lady Wilhelmina simply booms her disapproval at both her wards and the audience like some kind of panto dame.

Leave this one to American tourists in search of costume drama.

Booking to January 2001. Box office: 020-7494 5560.

fields.headline: Hanna Schygulla
fields.standfirst:
Purcell Room, London
**
fields.trailText:
Purcell Room, London
**
fields.body:
Though best known for her acting work in the movies of Rainer Werner Fassbinder, Hanna Schygulla has also pursued a theatrical career for more than 30 years. Fassbinder casts a long shadow here too, since he and Schygulla were co-founders of the Antitheatre in Munich in 1968, and subsequently collaborated on numerous stage productions.

To kick off Scott Walker's Meltdown festival, Schygulla brought her one-woman show to the South Bank. It contained elements of cabaret and hints of French chanson, but had been conceived as a self-contained performance in character, rather than as a projection of a stage persona that one might imagine to be at least partly the performer's own. Schygulla, looking baleful in a grey silk dress, made no introductions and did not speak to the audience for the 90-minute duration of the show. Listeners were left to make of the material and her delivery of it whatever they might.

Schygulla lives in Paris and speaks French as naturally as she speaks German, and many of the songs - or recitations - were in the language of her adopted city. To give a leg up to the British, she had converted chunks of her material into English. There was extra food for thought for connoisseurs of the Schygulla-Fassbinder partnership, since the director also helped write some of Schygulla's material.

While Schygulla was often preoccupied with the themes of life's cruelty and the remorselessness of passing time and death, the musical glue was supplied by her pianist and arranger, Jean-Marie Senia. Where Schygulla's delivery remained inscrutable, Senia's accompaniment was a riot of styles and tonal colours. There were glimpses of ragtime and noisy splashes of music hall. Yet for all Senia's ingenuity, Schygulla's performance was more brain than heart.

To give a leg up to the British, she had converted chunks of her material into English. There was extra food for thought for connoisseurs of the Schygulla-Fassbinder partnership, since the director also helped write some of Schygulla's material. While Schygulla was often preoccupied with the themes of life's cruelty and the remorselessness of passing time and death, the musical glue was supplied by her pianist and arranger, Jean-Marie Senia. Where Schygulla's delivery remained inscrutable, Senia's accompaniment was a riot of styles and tonal colours. There were glimpses of ragtime and noisy splashes of music hall. Yet for all Senia's ingenuity, Schygulla's performance was more brain than heart.

fields.headline: New blood on the tracks
fields.standfirst: Why does mayor of London Ken Livingstone want senior managers at London Transport to reapply for their jobs?  Anita Chaudhuri  follows his train of thought
fields.trailText: Why does mayor of London Ken Livingstone want senior managers at London Transport to reapply for their jobs? Anita Chaudhuri follows his train of thought
fields.body:
Just imagine the shame. You've worked at the same organisation for years, fulfilling bossy, management-type duties such as yelling "Mine's a tall skinny latte" and conducting urgent internet searches involving the executive key words "sex" or "on-line pizza delivery". Then, one fine day, a scary new boss arrives. You're called in for a chat and, oh the ignominy, invited to reapply for the right to carry on sitting slumped over the same old desk.

Sound familiar? It will if you are a top manager at London Transport. Ken Livingstone has just announced that senior staff are to have their posts readvertised in an attempt to attract fresh talent. "Only those who are competent will be reappointed. We are going to bring a lot of new blood in," Livingstone says.

It is a practice that is becoming increasingly popular, particular in cash-strapped public sector organisations such as local councils and health authority trusts. Legally, they can get away with it by using that ominous phrase "due to internal reorganisation" - far cheaper than paying out hefty redundancy cheques. For employees, being invited to reapply for a job is generally a no-win situation. If they are unsuccessful, the dole queue beckons; if they do get selected, a sour taste will often accompany the victory. If the boss had really valued them, would he have invited everybody else in the business to send in their CVs?

Helena Stewart is a lecturer at a further education college who found herself in this position. "They merged two departments and changed the course syllabus, which meant I had to reapply for the same job I'd been doing for five years. The interview with the head of department and principal was a farce. I mean, can you imagine going through all that 'Tell us about your strengths and weaknesses' crap with people who have known you for years? And because I was on-site, I heard all the gossip about the other people being interviewed, who was the favoured candidate and who was bottom of the pile. In the end, I kept my old job, but only because the person who was first on the list turned it down."

Stewart felt there was pressure on her bosses not to reappoint her but "to pull someone new and brilliant out of the woodwork. Since they'd gone to all the effort of advertising the post, processing the applications and doing the interviews, I got the distinct impression they felt it would be a loss of face to give the same old person the job."

Making an interview pitch to your own boss clearly has disadvantages. As with attending an interview for an internal promotion, a candidate can be hampered by the fact that they are a known quantity. "You can't very well sit there and say 'Ah yes, I'm brilliant with budgets' when they know damn well your department was way into the red at the end of the year," says Mark MacDonald, a sales manager who had to apply for his job when the company he worked for merged with a bigger firm.

But faced with this situation, what rights does an employee have? "You could always refuse to be reinterviewed, but then you might find yourself out of a job," says Carolyn Jones, director of the Institute of Employment Rights. "Employers know that they can claim the situation has come about due to an organisational requirement. So long as they can demonstrate that they have done 'what any reasonable employer would do' to fill the post, there isn't a lot you can do. If your boss unilaterally changes your pay, hours or place of work without prior agreement, then you could sue for breach of contract. But most bosses get round it by slightly changing a job title or area of responsibility."

Jones points out that the trend is more widespread in the public sector. "Private firms are much more likely just to put you out and bring in their latest blue-eyed boy. In the public sector, at least there are procedures to follow which is why this situation has become a familiar one."

Which brings us back to Ken Livingstone. London Transport bosses can take some comfort from the fact that he will have to reapply for the job of mayor before too long.

webTitle: UK's work burden grows fastest in Europe

fields.headline: UK's work burden grows fastest in Europe
fields.trailText: Confirmation that many people in Britain work harder, faster and under more pressure than they did 10 or 20 years ago will come in a research paper later this week.
fields.body:
Confirmation that many people in Britain work harder, faster and under more pressure than they did 10 or 20 years ago will come in a research paper later this week.

The rise in the intensity of our work has been steeper than in any other country in Europe and much higher than in Germany, which saw the smallest rise out of 13 European states.

The average British household with two adults was working seven hours a week more at the end of the 1990s than in the early 1980s, according to Francis Green, professor of economics at Kent University.

Some 42% of workers felt strongly in 1997 that "my job requires I work very hard", compared with 40% in 1992. Work rates have intensified more for women than for men.

But, despite a widespread belief, this is not due to job insecurity. The cause is partly a decline in trades union power in Britain. But it owes more to new technology, to organisational changes by management which speed up work tempo and to a "call centre" culture, which now employs 400,000 people.

"The call centre is the assembly-line of the modern era," says Prof Green, who also teaches at the centre for economic performance at the London School of Economics. He compares these centres to the high pressure, 24 hour car production lines at the start of the 20th century.

Prof Green will give his findings in a lecture headed It's Been A Hard Day's Night - But Why? at Canterbury on Friday. They are based partly on his own research and partly on depth analysis of statistics in six other official workplace surveys over the last 20 years.

He dismisses media commentaries which claim people are working harder out of fear for their jobs.

"Here is where rumour fares badly in its encounter with statistical reality", says Prof Green, "There has been a remarkable overall stability in the pattern of job tenure over the last three decades.

"The average man's job lasted about 10 years in the 1970s and about nine and a half years nowadays. Women's jobs last as long as they used to.

"The actual facts make common pronouncements about 'an end to jobs for life' seem like either misguided, or wishful, thinking."

Moreover, unemployment is now lower and no evidence exists of increasing job loss fears. Both in 1986 and in 1997, some 84% of workers told surveys they saw little likelihood of unemployment.

The explanation for media hype about insecurity is "almost certainly" that it is now more strongly felt by professional workers, who are close to the media and other sources.

In 1997 just over two-thirds of professionals feared for their jobs, compared with only one-third in 1986. By contrast, among sales staff this worry dropped from nearly half to less than a third in the same period. "Only when it hits the chattering classes does insecurity seem to become an issue for public discussion," notes the professor.

On average, figures in all Prof Green's surveys show that the British working week has remained stable at around 37 hours for the last two decades.

But "the widespread sense of rising work pressure" is linked to the fact that within this average more people of both sexes are working longer as well as shorter hours.

In 1981, one person in six worked over 48 hours a week. By the end of the 1990s, this number rose to one in five. The cause of the seven-hour increase in two-adult households is partly because more wives now go out to work part time.

Prof Green's graph of Europe shows a stronger, faster rise in work intensity in Britain than anywhere else in the 1990s. In Germany, one of our key competitors, there was virtually no rise.

What lies behind this harder, faster work rate, he concludes, is the spread of management concepts, aiming to maximise the flow of work to workers.

The extreme example of this is the call centre, where time spent on refreshment breaks is often deducted from pay.

But many other companies, partly through making workers responsible for their own quality checks, have reduced "interruptions where people could slack off a bit, reduce concentration and even have a break".

Emails and mobile phones have intensified use of working time and extended work out of hours.

Suggestion schemes and consultation meetings encourage employees to find ways of working harder voluntarily.

fields.headline: Odds fellow
fields.trailText: England are a best-priced 10-11 with Chandler and the Tote to win their final Group A contest against Romania in Charleroi tonight. And Ladbrokes are offering 5-2 on the draw that would still see Kevin Keegan's squad progress to the last eight.
fields.body:
England are a best-priced 10-11 with Chandler and the Tote to win their final Group A contest against Romania in Charleroi tonight. And Ladbrokes are offering 5-2 on the draw that would still see Kevin Keegan's squad progress to the last eight.

But even a sub-standard German team exposed defensive frailties in Keegan's line-up, and punters who expect it all to end in tears for England can get 4-1 with Surrey on a Romanian win.

A 0-0 draw is on offer at 6-1 with Chandler, with a 1-1 draw at 11-2. Personal preference is for another 1-0 triumph to England at 5-1 with Chandler.

Sporting's fixed-odds speciality bets on the England-Germany game proved profitable, with England scoring from a David Beckham cross at 3-1 and the Germans fielding three substitutes as predicted at 5-4.

Sporting are quoting 6-1 on any Romanian being booked for diving in tonight's match. And their God Save the Queen special offers punters 25-1 on National Anthem winning today's 5.30pm race at Royal Ascot, and Gary Neville being seen singing the National Anthem before kick-off.

In tonight's other game, most bookies make Germany favourites to beat Portugal with a best-priced 5-4 with Coral. The Portuguese have the flair to win the game at 9-4 with Surrey, but they may be content to settle for a draw at 5-2 with Surrey.

webTitle: The secret of Kev's success is pants

fields.headline: The secret of Kev's success is pants
fields.trailText: Darren Tackle prepares for immortality after his crucial role in England's revival.
fields.body:
When the television documentary about Euro 2000 comes to be made; when we is all invited to look back with Des at the highs, the lows and the water cannons; when some tosspot journalist is wheeled out to spout on about the post-modern dynamic associated with England's away strip, let's hope the part yours truly played in the simply historic events of Saturday night is given due prominence. Yes, as my good friend and fellow television summariser Stuart Pearce would put it, Darren Tackle was very much indeed to the fore in England's preparation situation.

You will know, of course, from the wide coverage it has received in the media and that, that yours truly has been concerned on a daily basis at the highest level in the England camp, working with the players to improve a technique many an observer has described as perhaps the most woeful in the tournament. I am, of course, talking about the handling of computer games.

And yes, Darren Tackle is happy to accept a large proportion of the credit for Alan Shearer's return to form after helping him recover his self-belief with a few well chosen words as he struggled on the beginner's stage of Colin McRae's Rally 2000.

"Alan, mate," I tells him as he crashes the motor time and again on the starting grid, frustration beading up his brow. "Take it easy and relax at the console. Just imagine you're creosoting the fence."

And with those few well chosen words - in such contrast to the general knocking what England's finest has received in the papers, just for being slow and past-it - he was up and running, managing to negotiate his Ford Focus a full 200 yards from the off before crashing, would you believe it, into a fence.

"Nice brush strokes," was all he said as his video doppelganger was peeled off the lattice work. But Tackle could detect there was a new determination, a new sense of destiny if you will, in his voice as he went off chuckling to himself about the way you can always detect a Ronseal finish.

And that is not all on the yours truly front. On Friday, DT receives the summons from Badger Bonce hisself. "Brought your boots, Dazz?" Badger says when he bells me on the mobe.

"Am I in, oh great leader?" I says, trying to play it low key and that, while inside the Tackle heart was beating 10 to the dozen. Which will teach yours truly not to indulge before answering the phone too freely in one of them tubes of sniffing stuff what he bought on an away day sightseeing trip with the lads to the Amsterdam sex shops.

"No, Dazz, no, no, no," says Badger, a little too quick for my liking. "We're doing a particular routine at training this morning and we need your help."

Personally, I blame the effects of the night before (a session in a Brussels bar with our Lee and 200 of his closest mates, what was only brought to a halt when it got tear-gassed by the local dibbs). Plus it was never easy turning out in a pair of Becks's cast-off boots (the ball kept spinning off of the embroidered one-finger salute on the tongue).

Whatever, I felt I never done myself justice, playing like a right carthorse, missing sitters left right and centre. Way I performed, I don't reckon I could've hit a cow's arse with a barn door. Or any of the other items our Lee's posse had confiscated after the police raid. But Badger Bonce seemed well and truly chuffed.

"Brilliant, Dazz," he says, as I steps on the ball in front of goal with David Seaman nothing more than a spectator (literally - this was the part of the session involving just Tackle, a ball and an unguarded net). "Come on," I says, "that was pants."

"Exactly," he says. "I wanted to give Keowny and the rest of the lads a bit of experience playing against a centre-forward who plays just like Carsten Jancker."

You would have thought, after that, plus standing in for Peter Beardsley in the rehearsals for a comedy TV commercial extolling the benefits of plastic surgery, a brief or 10 would be forthcoming from the management for the big one.

Not a bit of it. Muttering something about FA blacklists after last year's Worthington Cup final, Badger tells me there's no way I can come. Watch it on telly in a bar with the jolly England fans, Dazz, he says; the view's much better, he says. Besides, he says, I might get to see that ad, the one where he plays a doctor in the delivery room and catches the ball as it gets spat out from between a pregnant woman's legs.

Yeah, I feel like telling him, and that pass is a bollocks sight more accurate than any Phil Neville's managed in the entire tournament. But I don't think of that until three hours after the match. And it was never going to be easy to buzz Badger then with my witty observation, what with the Tackle nose pressed firmly to the side of a black maria as some Belgian dibb applies the cuffs.

And no, since you ask, he didn't know who I was. But when the TV history of this tournament is produced, I predict he will.

webTitle: Thorpe set for early one-day return

fields.headline: Thorpe set for early one-day return
fields.trailText: Change is inevitable following England's nondescript showing in the triangular series in South Africa last winter, reports Mike Selvey.
fields.body:
This is the time of year when the domestic cricket programme appears to have been compiled by the Lord's pavilion cat. Apart from two inconsequential tourist matches at Fenner's and Chelmsford on Wednesday - why are Zimbabwe playing a three-day match when their purpose for remaining here is the triangular limited overs tournament? - there is no first-class cricket until a week tomorrow.

Instead the counties, including those players trying to hone techniques for the second test, will be playing an assortment of National Cricket League and NatWest matches, with the bizarre wheeze of holding some of them under floodlights at a time of year when it does not get dark until gone 10 o'clock.

It is totally in keeping with this spirit that at Lord's today the England selectors will announce their 14-man squad for the triangular series a mere 18 days before their first match and while they are still picking over the bones of the first Test.

Change is inevitable following England's nondescript showing in the triangular series in South Africa last winter, in which a degree of legitimate experimentation had to be set alongside injuries to Andy Flintoff and others.

Central one-day contracts will be awarded for the tournament, hence the early announcement so that schedules can be geared to the needs of England, but the bulk of the side will come from those already under contract: Nasser Hussain, Mike Atherton, Graeme Hick, Alec Stewart, Flintoff, Craig White, who is fit and firing again after his mystery collapse, Darren Gough and Andy Caddick.

To their number will be added one further all-rounder, Mark Ealham, who has concededed more than 37 runs only once in 11 one-day games, and two more batsmen, one of whom will be Nick Knight, a spinner or two - Robert Croft probably, together with the left-arm spinner Ashley Giles - and another pace bowler, no doubt Alan Mullally, whose capacity to bowl out of reach in tests is matched only by his straightness in one-dayers.

Now that he has started to bat his way into some kind of form, Graham Thorpe, who made himself available for the limited-overs stuff last winter but was rebuffed, ought to find his way back as the final batsman.

Otherwise, in the short term, Matthew Maynard, who caught the eye with his century at Lord's in the Benson & Hedges Cup final, could get a chance and would enhance the fielding. Looking to the longer term, there is Marcus Trescothick, the muscular Somerset left-hander who is known to be admired by the England coach Duncan Fletcher.

All of which means that from the winter there would be no place for Chris Adams, Chris Read, Mark Alleyne, Darren Maddy and Vikram Solanki. Short-termism it may seem but England do need to acquire the winning habit in limited-overs cricket, and to do so must play their best sides for the present. It is up to the youngsters to start establishing their claims.

 Gloucestershire suffered their heaviest defeat in first-class cricket yesterday when Zimbabwe rounded off victory by 524 runs on the fourth and final day of their tour match with the pace bowler Pommie Mbangwa closing on five for 23.

Possible England squad:
Hussain, Atherton, Hick, Thorpe, Flintoff, Stewart, Knight, Ealham, White, Gough, Caddick, Croft, Giles, Mullally.
fields.bodyText: This is the time of year when the domestic cricket programme appears to have been compiled by the Lord's pavilion cat. Apart from two inconsequential tourist matches at Fenner's and Chelmsford on Wednesday - why are Zimbabwe playing a three-day match when their purpose for remaining here is the triangular limited overs tournament? - there is no first-class cricket until a week tomorrow. Instead the counties, including those players trying to hone techniques for the second test, will be playing an assortment of National Cricket League and NatWest matches, with the bizarre wheeze of holding some of them under floodlights at a time of year when it does not get dark until gone 10 o'clock. It is totally in keeping with this spirit that at Lord's today the England selectors will announce their 14-man squad for the triangular series a mere 18 days before their first match and while they are still picking over the bones of the first Test. Change is inevitable following England's nondescript showing in the triangular series in South Africa last winter, in which a degree of legitimate experimentation had to be set alongside injuries to Andy Flintoff and others. Central one-day contracts will be awarded for the tournament, hence the early announcement so that schedules can be geared to the needs of England, but the bulk of the side will come from those already under contract: Nasser Hussain, Mike Atherton, Graeme Hick, Alec Stewart, Flintoff, Craig White, who is fit and firing again after his mystery collapse, Darren Gough and Andy Caddick. To their number will be added one further all-rounder, Mark Ealham, who has concededed more than 37 runs only once in 11 one-day games, and two more batsmen, one of whom will be Nick Knight, a spinner or two - Robert Croft probably, together with the left-arm spinner Ashley Giles - and another pace bowler, no doubt Alan Mullally, whose capacity to bowl out of reach in tests is matched only by his straightness in one-dayers. Now that he has started to bat his way into some kind of form, Graham Thorpe, who made himself available for the limited-overs stuff last winter but was rebuffed, ought to find his way back as the final batsman. Otherwise, in the short term, Matthew Maynard, who caught the eye with his century at Lord's in the Benson & Hedges Cup final, could get a chance and would enhance the fielding. Looking to the longer term, there is Marcus Trescothick, the muscular Somerset left-hander who is known to be admired by the England coach Duncan Fletcher. All of which means that from the winter there would be no place for Chris Adams, Chris Read, Mark Alleyne, Darren Maddy and Vikram Solanki. Short-termism it may seem but England do need to acquire the winning habit in limited-overs cricket, and to do so must play their best sides for the present. It is up to the youngsters to start establishing their claims.  Gloucestershire suffered their heaviest defeat in first-class cricket yesterday when Zimbabwe rounded off victory by 524 runs on the fourth and final day of their tour match with the pace bowler Pommie Mbangwa closing on five for 23. Possible England squad: Hussain, Atherton, Hick, Thorpe, Flintoff, Stewart, Knight, Ealham, White, Gough, Caddick, Croft, Giles, Mullally.

fields.headline: Indian police want Cronje extradited
fields.trailText: Hansie Cronje's woes deepened yesterday when Indian authorities announced their desire to have the disgraced former South Africa captain extradited to face match-fixing charges.
fields.body:
Hansie Cronje's woes deepened yesterday when Indian authorities announced their desire to have the disgraced former South Africa captain extradited to face match-fixing charges.

India's sports minister, Sukhdev Singh Dhindsa, said that his department and New Delhi police had contacted the South African government and were seeking to have Cronje flown to India.

It was Indian police who originally uncovered Cronje's involvement in match-fixing, accusing him and three team-mates of "cheating, fraud and criminal conspiracy" during a one-day series in India earlier this year.

The Indian test batsman Mohammad Azharuddin, meanwhile, has threatened to sue Cronje over claims that he is heavily involved in corruption. In his strongest defence yet Azharuddin said he also planned to take action against several former Indian players - including Sunil Gavaskar, Manoj Prabhakar and Ravi Shastri - who had implicated him in match-fixing because he was one of the few Muslim players in the national team.

"There is a lobby of jealous ex-cricketers who want me out of the team," Azharuddin said. "As far as I know, there is no such thing as match-fixing."

Indian cricket authorities have urged the International Cricket Council to punish the South African board's managing director Ali Bacher for alleging that India's World Cup win over Pakistan last year was fixed. The Indian board president, AC Muthiah, said Bacher should first have told the ICC about the allegations and he had given "Indian cricket a bad name without providing any proof".

webTitle: The lads set off a sensation in sculpture

fields.headline: The lads set off a sensation in sculpture
fields.trailText: Dave Podmore gets called in by the ECB to provide the England squad with some cultural training.
fields.body:
As someone who knows a bit about how to look after himself off the field as well as on it, Pod's been drafted into the ECB scheme set up to give the contracted England cricketers preparation for life outside the game: marketing, management, playing for Hampshire etc, plus a full programme of cultural activities.

Last weekend, when the lads suddenly found themselves with a couple of free days on their hands after Edgbaston, was the perfect opportunity to broaden a few horizons. Came the phone call from the chairman: get your arse in the minibus, Pod, and take the boys down to Tate Modern.

His lordship must have pulled a few strings as we were treated like VIPs, even getting to walk across that new bridge over the Thames.

Obviously the lads had one or two butterflies because we'd been told it wobbled about, specially early doors. But the strange thing was, as soon as I led the England bowlers on to the bridge, it stopped swinging completely. No movement whatsoever - gun-barrel straight. An incident-free crossing, except that Freddie Flintoff decked a samosa that Nass chucked to him. He carried on eating it though, swearing it had never touched the ground.

When we got to the other side, the bridge started going like a banana and they had to close it down again. It doesn't surprise me really. I've played a fair bit of charity cricket with Norman Foster and he's always managed to make it do a bit in the air - unfortunately for Fozzie, it's just done a bit too much in this case. He was in tears on the phone this morning begging me to bring the lads back as he reckons it's his only chance of putting things right structurewise.

As for the gallery itself, well I've taken part in some fairly pointless rest-day activities in my time as a professional cricketer, but walking round a derelict power station takes the biscuit. Mind you, fantastic space for corporate hospitality. It makes you wonder: if the place gets as packed as that to see the kind of stuff they've got on display, think how many more you'd attract if you offered decent facilities such as a driving range, food court etc. You could clean up, just like at Lord's where they manage to relieve punters of £38-£46 for the privilege of spending the day in a shopping mall.

Obviously, if you don't charge admission you're always going to get crowd problems. Dave Podmore's not the kind of guy to knock his fellow man, but there's no excuse for not looking smart, and I have to say that not all the rubbish at Tate Modern was up on the walls. It's no exaggeration that, of the 220,000-odd people who were there that morning, me and the lads were the only ones wearing ties with diagonal stripes.

After lunch we all went for a slash and within 10 minutes we were surrounded by photographers, film crews, and reporters asking us for interviews. Apparently we'd pissed in one of the exhibits and the fact that we were neatly dressed in blazers and slacks made the media think we were some kind of new living sculpture.

"Forget Gilbert and George", said this posey tosser with a Radio 3 microphone. "This is the decade of Goughie and Giddins and Stewie" etc etc, listing the entire squad, apart from Ramps.

Suddenly the England squad is not only at the cutting edge of BritArt but 13-8 second favourite for the Turner Prize. We haven't had many winner's cheques in the dressing-room in recent years so we're happy to take anything that comes. It's probably our best chance of silverware, with four tests against the Windies to come.

Alternatively we could send Jimmy Adams and his men home after the outrageous conduct of their supporters at Birmingham: smiling, happy, well-behaved - what sort of advert is that for international sport?

The only good thing about the three-day test was that it allowed plenty of time at the end for Blowers and Aggers to plug the Primary Club. Pod's a founder member of this fine institution, which celebrates batsmen who, for whatever reason, fail to do themselves justice.

The club's committee met last week to agree to a change in the entry rules. From now on, you are also entitled to wear the coveted Primary Club tie if you've taken a bribe to get out first ball.

webTitle: Stylish Del Piero makes sure of bubbly finale

fields.headline: Stylish Del Piero makes sure of bubbly finale
fields.standfirst: Striker makes his first start and proves Italy's  winner
fields.trailText: Alessandro del Piero makes his first start and proves Italy's winner. Roy Collins reports.
fields.body:
If Alessandro del Piero was in two minds over whether to break open a bottle of champagne or a box of Kleenex after learning that he was in the Italian team last night, the champagne was definitely off ice by the end of the evening.

Naturally Del Piero, who has been Italy's coming man longer than Jamie Redknapp has been England's, wanted to start his first game at Euro 2000. But before hitting last night's winning goal he must have got the sniffles when he saw the company he was keeping.

Italy's starting line-up last night bore no resemblance to the side that played in the previous two games here, which is the likely one to face England, assuming the latter do not lose to Romania and survive disqualification.

There was no Demetrio Albertini or Stefano Fiore to provide sweet through-balls and no Filippo Inzaghi alongside to produce a dying swan im personation to earn a free-kick opportunity for Del Piero on the edge of the box.

Instead, as a striking partner, he had to make do with Vincenzo Montella, who made his international debut only 12 months ago and who is most famous for celebrating goals by doing one of those rolling aeroplane salutes which English fans love doing to the Germans.

We almost got a demonstration of it in the 18th minute when Montella broke into the box and, ignoring Del Piero's screams in the middle, went for goal and saw an excellent effort stopped by Magnus Hedman.

Montella did provide a wonderful diagonal pass for his strike partner in the fifth minute but Del Piero gave it an almost petulant thump with his left foot and watched it go so high over the bar that Montella might have done his aeroplane impression by way of taking the mickey.

Del Piero is apparently the highest paid player in the world, putting even Roy Keane and David Beckham in the Nationwide when it comes to the pay packet league. Playing among the stiffs, even at international level, must be humiliating for a man valued so highly in monetary terms but he says: "I don't ask myself why I am not in the team. If I manage to play a quarter of an hour or so, as I did against Turkey and Begium, then I will try to play as well as I can."

He did not, in truth, look as though he was busting a gut last last night. It might have been another audition to prove that he is worthy of a place in the side but he also did not want to get injured in a meaningless match, knowing that he will surely play some part against England.

We saw none of the trademark Del Piero dribbles past defenders or those long, curving passes to team-mates from deep. Most of the time he was restricted to trying to flick on long clearances with his head, more in the manner of John Hartson than the golden boy of Italian football.

Del Piero's first real chance at goal came in the air, too, but he was not able to get enough of his head on Paolo Negro's cross and it dropped gently into Hedman's arms.

Montella, in fact, looked a more likely option as first- change striker if Italy were to need one against England. But Del Piero did start to look more animated when Fiore came off the bench in the 63rd minute and instantly provided two passes where he likes them best - on the floor and at his feet.

One led to a delightful attempted flick pass from Del Piero to Montella. Seventeen minutes from time he almost hit success when he played a one-two with Montella and looked set to score until he stumbled in the box.

It looked like being another night of unfulfilled international ambition for Del Piero until the Swedish defence made a horrendous error and he swiftly picked up the ball, swept past the last defender and stuck a brilliant winner. Sol Campbell and Martin Keown beware.

webTitle: Classy Italians tune up at ease

fields.headline: Classy Italians tune up at ease
fields.trailText: The temperature soared above 100 degrees, the enviable strength in depth of a fine squad was again proven and another victory was claimed. Yes, things are starting to look pretty good for Italy who - ale-sodden yobs and ageing Romanian footballers permitting - will stand toe to toe with England in Brussels on Saturday night to contest a place in the tournament's last four.
fields.body:
The temperature soared above 100 degrees, the enviable strength in depth of a fine squad was again proven and another victory was claimed. Yes, things are starting to look pretty good for Italy who - ale-sodden yobs and ageing Romanian footballers permitting - will stand toe to toe with England in Brussels on Saturday night to contest a place in the tournament's last four.

Sweden will head home feeling slightly aggrieved for they attacked gamely all night long and possibly deserved more than the Henrik Larsson goal 13 minutes from the end, which all-too-briefly was to ensure parity.

Fine goal that it was, it was not even sufficient to snare a point for, as the game approached its final minute, Alessandro del Piero reminded us all of his rare gifts with a marvellous rising drive from the edge of the penalty area.

The tired and aching limbs of the Swedes may have been pounding away but it was inevitable that their minds would wander, for their fate lay in the hands of others.

With their best-laid plans largely undone by their failure to overcome Turkey at the same venue last Thursday, Sweden could do no more than chisel away at a traditionally impenetrable Italian defence in the hope that if things went well for them in Eindhoven, things would go badly for Belgium in Brussels.

In truth, so much of Sweden's football in this tournament has been underpinned by anxiety and fear that the quality of their play in the opening quarter last night must have surprised even the most outlandish optimist in blue and yellow.

Italian footballers have a lethargic air about them even when they are in a hurry so, having already claimed top spot in Group B, they were their usual selves - artistic, precise and, yes, infuriatingly lazy at times. But the days of footballing largesse are virtu ally over, and if the Swedes had been anticipating a helping hand from the Azzurri they will have been disappointed.

The Italian coach Dino Zoff used the evening to blood his players who had previously been inactive, and there is no more enthusiastic a creature than one trying to impress its keeper. Zoff made eight changes to the line-up which overwhelmed Belgium; in came del Piero, Paolo Negro and Luigi di Biagio. That really is some second string.

To their credit, Sweden showed unexpected spirit and had fortune smiled on them - as it did at times in their qualifying programme - they could have been three goals to the good inside 14 highly intriguing minutes.

After Angelo di Livio had headed a Johan Mjallby effort off the line, both Yksel Osmanovski and Fredrik Ljungberg spurned marvellous openings, the latter missing dreadfully when scoring appeared to be the easier option.

But Italy eventually settled and, with their opponents pursuing a policy of reckless ambition, they were hugely effective on the counterattack. England beware.

Until his heroics at the death Del Piero had spent most of the evening providing for his partner, Vincenzo Montella, rather than pressing his claim for inclusion in the quarter-final. But Montella was wasteful with the ammunition, driving wide and then high when he should have done much better.

It did not matter. Seven minutes before the interval Del Piero finally found someone capable of adding a cutting edge to one of his incisive passes, Di Biagio arriving almost unannounced to head in his corner.

Italy promptly switched to cruise control, making light of the loss just before the interval of their captain Paolo Maldini, who was withdrawn as a precaution shortly after finding a carelessly-placed Swedish boot in his groin region.

Sweden gamely shuffled their pack, showering the pitch with substitutes like confetti at a wedding. Their bravery paid off when Larsson found the net but the sweeter, more beguiling, football still came from the Italians.

webTitle: Leeds close in on £7m target Viduka

fields.headline: Leeds close in on £7m target Viduka
fields.trailText: Leeds United last night had a bid of around £7m accepted by Celtic for their talented but troublesome Australian striker Mark Viduka.
fields.body:
Leeds United last night had a bid of around £7m accepted by Celtic for their talented but troublesome Australian striker Mark Viduka.

The Yorkshire club faxed an official offer to Parkhead yesterday and Viduka is expected at Elland Road before the weekend to discuss personal terms with the chairman Peter Ridsdale.

"We have had a written offer accepted by Celtic," said Ridsdale. "The player is currently in Japan but we hope he will be with us in the next few days."

The Leeds manager David O'Leary took advantage of being in the same Brussels hotel as his Celtic counterpart Martin O'Neill, on Euro 2000 duty with the BBC, to negotiate his second major transfer deal of the summer.

He has already signed the French midfielder Olivier Dacourt for a club record £7.2m and had an £11m bid turned down for Manchester United's striker Ole Gunnar Solskjaer.

Chris Sutton is expected to replace Viduka at Celtic after Chelsea confirmed that they had accepted a £6m offer for the striker. Chelsea have already accepted an offer of the same value from Middlesbrough and will leave it to Sutton to decide where he wishes to continue his career.

Meanwhile, the Liverpool manager Gérard Houllier confidently expects to tempt Germany's Christian Ziege away from Middlesbrough once Euro 2000 is over. The Merseyside club made contact with Middlesbrough over the weekend with an offer of £5m.

Ziege joined Middlesbrough from Milan in a £4m deal 12 months ago, but is believed to have already informed his manager at the Riverside, Bryan Robson, that he would like the opportunity to speak to Liverpool.

Ziege would be the third high-profile German at Anfield following Dietmar Hamann, who signed from Newcastle United, and Markus Babbel, who will shortly join on a free transfer from Bayern Munich.

However, Robson last night insisted that Ziege was going nowhere. "He is not for sale and Liverpool do not have enough money to buy him," he said. "There is no get-out clause in his contract which allows Ziege to talk to any club which shows interest in him."

Ziege joined Middlesbrough from Milan in a £4m deal 12 months ago, but is believed to have already informed his manager at the Riverside, Bryan Robson, that he would like the opportunity to speak to Liverpool. Ziege would be the third high-profile German at Anfield following Dietmar Hamann, who signed from Newcastle United, and Markus Babbel, who will shortly join on a free transfer from Bayern Munich. However, Robson last night insisted that Ziege was going nowhere. "He is not for sale and Liverpool do not have enough money to buy him," he said. "There is no get-out clause in his contract which allows Ziege to talk to any club which shows interest in him."

fields.headline: League clubs in £315m TV deal
fields.trailText: Armchair supporters will soon be able to watch football on every night of the week with Nationwide League games now taking place on Thursday nights as part of a new £315m deal with OnDigital and ITV.
fields.body:
Armchair supporters will soon be able to watch football on every night of the week with Nationwide League games now taking place on Thursday nights as part of a new £315m deal with OnDigital and ITV.

The deal, which begins in 2001 and lasts for three years, will see live matches broadcast on Thursdays and Sundays, with pay-per-view games played on Friday nights. ITV will also screen some Sunday matches and a highlights show as part of the deal which nets the League four times more than its existing TV package.

Thursday matches will kick off at 8pm while the Sunday matches on OnDigital will begin at 6pm to avoid clashing with Premiership games, spelling trouble for travelling fans looking to get home on Sunday nights.

A total of 20 games have been set aside for pay-per-view screening on the Fridays. League chairmen believe the contract will secure the future of all 72 member clubs.

But Leyton Orient's chair man Barry Hearn issued a warning to players and agents not to expect any of the windfall to end up in their wage packets.

Hearn said: "We must take no prisoners. We must have no agents, no salary increases - just football. Without doubt this deal has secured the future of some clubs who had been struggling and now this is the chance to start again and do things professionally.

"It is about time the clubs made a stand and look to ensuring they have a permanent future and stay alive. If the agents think they can come in and get increased wages from clubs, then they can forget it.

"And if any clubs get into trouble after this deal, then that is purely down to their own bad management - nothing else."

Huddersfield Town's director Barry Rubery also urged caution but added: "This deal is almost like a watershed. It gives us a chance to start again with more professional business practices and not to gamble money we haven't got."

fields.headline: Wednesday find their prize Jewell
fields.trailText: Sheffield Wednesday's search for a new manager seems likely to end on the doorstep of their Yorkshire neighbours Bradford City following Paul Jewell's resignation.
fields.body:
Sheffield Wednesday's search for a new manager seems likely to end on the doorstep of their Yorkshire neighbours Bradford City following Paul Jewell's resignation.

Jewell handed in a letter of resignation to the Bradford City chairman Geoffrey Richmond yesterday morning and was immediately placed on paid leave. Although Richmond has yet to accept the resignation, he is expected to call an emergency meeting of the Bradford directors tomorrow afternoon. Should Jewell leave, his likely successor is City's former Scottish international midfielder Stuart McCall.

"I've done a lot of soul-searching since the end of the season," said Jewell, who steered City to promotion 14 months ago before securing their Premiership survival on the last day of last season. "I think it's time to move on. I've taken Bradford as far as I can and I'm grateful for the chance that Geoffrey Richmond has given me. I like to think that I've repaid the faith he has shown in me and at the same time that I have proved a lot of people wrong."

As Jewell still has two years of his contract left to run, Bradford would demand a hefty sum in compensation from Wednesday, the last thing they need given their financial plight. At a conservative estimate, Wednesday are £14m in debt and Jewell is likely to be told that he will be unable to sign any player whose wage exceeds £4,000 a week.

The first task of any new manager will be to prune a squad that is awash with highly-paid players of dubious ability and temperament. Several players have already announced their wish to change clubs this summer.

The size of this task has already scared off several candidates, including the former Wimbledon manager Joe Kinnear and the former Arsenal and Bolton manager Bruce Rioch. Peter Shreeves, who has been in temporary control since Danny Wilson's sacking, now seems certain to leave.

webTitle: A crying need for speed and fury

fields.headline: A crying need for speed and fury
fields.standfirst: Euro 2000 special report
fields.trailText: Romania don't strike me as a team who will go flying about in the last minute if things are not going for them.
fields.body:
Now the euphoria of beating Germany has died down, let's forget the ridiculous talk of winning Euro 2000 and realise there is serious work to be done just to reach the next round. It will take a better performance than Saturday's to see off Romania. And, although a draw will do, the players must not think like that.

I know how easily things can go wrong if minds are unclear. Missing out with Aston Villa against Deportivo la Coruna in Europe springs to mind. We got a 1-1 draw in Spain, had the advantage of an away goal but at our place the players didn't know whether to stick or bust.

For a long while it was a stalemate and then they hit us with a sucker punch. We lost 1-0 but, if we had needed to win, I'm sure the team would have approached things differently. England must play to win tonight. If you set out for a point there is no margin for error.

I think the best approach is a high-tempo game which makes the Romanians scurry. If the tempo is slow I wouldn't fancy us. Romania can play steady-steady and suddenly expose you. So England must close down quickly and not give the ball away cheaply.

In that regard I worry whether Paul Ince's fitness levels are up to a third game in nine days. But, assuming Ince plays, I would opt for a solid midfield with Steven Gerrard and Dennis Wise alongside David Beckham, and Paul Scholes as the link man behind Alan Shearer. Provided Scholes is fully fit I would leave Steve McManaman and Michael Owen on the bench ready to chase the game if needs be.

Which is not to say England should be negative. Far from it. I would tell Wise, Gerrard and Ince to press Romania high up the field. If they get tired they can come off. Against Romania setting the tone is so important.

The Romanians will be up for it but mentally they always seem fragile. The longer we give them no encouragement the more likely their heads are to go under. They don't strike me as a team who will go flying about in the last minute if things are not going for them.

But it will not be as easy as some people think. The suspension of Gheorghe Hagi is bad news as well as good. He must be the only player who has it in his contract that he's allowed time-outs.

Romania will miss his inspiration and leadership but they could bring in a younger player with decent skill who could hurt us with his energy. They already have a tidy midfielder in Dorinel Munteanu. He has a great shot and he could thrive on the added responsibility.

Up front England must beware Adrian Ilie, a goalscorer who will take people on. But, although the Romanian centre-backs will give Alan Shearer some stick, they look susceptible to pace. When Gica Popescu played for Galatasaray against Chelsea in the Champions League he looked lightning slow.

Yet we will need to improve on Saturday to avoid defeat. I thought we were better against Portugal. It's been almost forgotten that for the first 25 minutes England were awful. It's as bad as I've seen an England side play. We were not passing well or closing down properly. Too many crosses were getting in and that has to be addressed tonight. Germany were not good enough to take advantage but Romania will be.

After that match some England fans came up to me and said: "We were lucky but who cares?" If there's one match when you're allowed to say that, it's against Germany. I would be disgruntled if I was a German but they've had their luck against us down the years.

The ideal now would be to marry the resilience and determination of the last performance with the attacking flair of the Portugal game. If England do make the quarter-finals I would not be too optimistic, principally because the Italians were able to give players a breather last night. But most importantly, let's get there first.

webTitle: Even the last resort is better than a return to Heysel

fields.headline: Even the last resort is better than a return to Heysel
fields.standfirst: Euro 2000 special report
fields.trailText: Uefa had no choice but to lay down the law.
fields.body:
Supposing several thousand people from another European country descended on, say, Mansfield and ruined its day.

First they drank heavily and then they began swearing at the locals, singling out ethnic minorities for particularly vile abuse. When the police intervened there were running street battles, with chairs thrown, windows broken and bottles smashed.

It is reasonable to assume that, on hearing the visitors were in Mansfield to watch their football team, the government of the day would be unimpressed. Promises that something would be done in future would probably not wash. Not only would the rowdy offenders be kicked out, their footballers would be told politely but firmly to go home.

Swap Mansfield for Charleroi and you have a point fast being approached by England and the ullage among their travelling fans. Normally Lennart Johansson, the Swedish president of Uefa, has the lawyer's mastery of the non-committal statement but on Sunday night he was unequivocal: any more violence when England play Romania in Charleroi tonight and the team will be thrown out of Euro 2000, lock, stock and two smelly socks.

For Kevin Keegan and his players this would be a fearful price to pay for one minute's confrontation between English and German supporters and the five minutes it took mounted Belgian police and an armoured water cannon to disperse them. After all, the scenes captured on television so far hardly bear comparison with the violence that accompanied English visits to Rotterdam, Paris, Brussels and elsewhere during the 70s and early 80s, culminating in the Heysel tragedy of 1985 when Liverpool met Juventus and 39 fans died.

This, of course, is Johansson's point. Having suffered nearly 30 years, on and off, of bad English behaviour abroad Uefa is not about to condone another generation of violence.

Some may feel that slinging England out would be giving in to the hooligans; it is an old response. But surely turning quiet towns into armed camps and causing considerable disruption to their routine activities merely because an international football is being played amounts to the same thing.

True, this does not apply only to English supporters; the Germans, Dutch and Belgians have their own hooligan problems. Yet it is an established fact that when England do not qualify for a European Championship or a World Cup the atmosphere is infinitely more relaxed.

The argument between those who would like to see potential troublemakers kept at home by the confiscation of their passports and others who see in this a denial of the basic liberty to travel unimpeded until an offence has been committed is as old as football hooliganism itself.

For several days before England and Germany met in Charleroi on Saturday German security turned back hundreds of undesirables at the Belgian and Dutch frontiers. Small wonder, then, that Alain Courtois, the director of Euro 2000, asked how it was that so many rowdies were allowed to leave an island called Britain.

Of the 800-odd English fans arrested by Belgian police some were innocent and many were guilty of being no more loud and obnoxious than the average pub on a Saturday. But what is regarded at home as an integral part of England's yob culture is not acceptable in a sedate Belgian town that believes that being able to walk along a street uninsulted and unmolested is the most civil of liberties.

It will be a pity if England have to go home to prove the point and the disgrace would do nothing for the 2006 World Cup bid but Uefa is entitled to make the stand it has. And, if Johansson is lucky, Romania will do the job for him before the prospect of English hooliganism returning to what used to be called the Heysel Stadium for a quarter-final against, of all teams, Italy darkens Euro 2000 further still.

fields.headline: England inspired and defiled
fields.standfirst:
Richard Williams on the supporters Keegan's men cannot live with or without
Euro 2000 special report
fields.trailText: Keegan's men cannot live with or without their supporters.
fields.body:
The noise from the fans, Martin Keown said as he left the pitch, gave England's players the extra yard of pace that helped carry them to victory against Germany on Saturday. "We only hear about the troubles," he said. "But the fans were superb. It was like playing a home game out there."

To Angelo di Livio, watching the scenes in Charleroi on television in Italy's headquarters, the impression was very different. "The TV pictures made me worried," he said. "It was like watching scenes from a war."

Just like a home game, or like watching scenes from a war? What the outside world saw and thought about it was one thing. For the England players, it was impossible to ignore the positive impact of their supporters.

Their encouragement had given Keown the impetus he needed when, in the 58th minute, he raced over to the right-hand touchline to smother an attempted cross from Jens Jeremies and then, when the rebound fell at the feet of the German midfielder, stretched again to block the second attempt. Jeremies's head dropped. In that moment, five minutes after his side had taken the lead, Keown had told the Germans all they needed to know about their chances of breaching England's defence.

One of the more thoughtful members of the squad, Keown was also its most effectively resolute player on a night to which resolution held the key. Yet although he was inspired by the crowd's incessant chanting, he had probably not spent too much time worrying about what those chants were saying.

He was not on the pitch, for instance, during the preliminaries to the match, when thousands of England fans sang the Dambusters' March and mimed the action of planes on their way to bomb the Germans. In all probability, many of those indulging in a gleeful playground insult were the well-dressed middle-aged pro- fessional people of whom we have been hearing so much as commentators struggle to construct a typology of the modern English football fan.

Nor was Kevin Keegan paying attention to the specific messages coming from the grandstands. A day later, he was uncomfortable enough when invited to make a general comment on the disturbances in Brussels and Charleroi during the hours before the match.

"I said what I wanted to say about it before we left England," he declared, "when I said that I wanted the fans to come out and enjoy themselves in all the right ways.

"If you look at it just purely from our point of view in the stadium, it was everything you would want an England game to be. The atmosphere, the way they got behind us, things like that. The other things that have happened saddened me. I've said that before, and I'm not going to go down that road again, because I made it very clear how I felt about it before I came out."

Then someone asked him how he responded to hearing the crowd sing "No surrender to the IRA", an anthem surely performed less in observance of its specific political message than out of a generalised desire to deliver the maximum cultural shock. "I'm sorry," Keegan replied, evidently irritated, "but I can't comment on something I didn't hear." His inquisitor gave a gesture of frustration. "You can shrug your shoulders," the coach retorted. "You may have heard it, but do expect me to take your word on that? I didn't hear it. I'm sorry."

No one, including Keegan, to judge by his air of embarrassment, was impressed by this display of selective deafness. But what a position to be in. You go into the most important match of your life - certainly in the case of Keegan, who is old enough to remember the last significant defeat of Germany, 34 years earlier - with the focus that you have been refining for a year, a year in which you have been carefully tuning out all potentially disruptive signals. You need all the help you can get and the fans give it to you. Then you are expected to turn round and condemn them.

Keegan's strategic refusal to accept the invitation said nothing about him as a man. He may have been brought up to revere Bill Shankly, but he knows that there is more to life than football. After the match, it had been a pleasure to hear the coach of England answer questions from a group of German journalists in their own language. This was a rare respite from the state-sponsored isolation to which we have been condemned by the insularity of our attitudes and the inadequacies of our education system, exemplified by the fact that out of the 16 referees controlling the matches at Euro 2000, only two - both of the British representatives - are monolinguists.

Within the England camp, the reaction to the disruption caused by their supporters in the streets of Belgium is to blank it out. Something different is happening among the Italy squad, who may meet England in a quarter-final on Saturday night in the King Baudouin stadium in Brussels, built on the site of the old Heysel, where 34 Juventus fans and five Belgians died in 1985 as a consequence of English hooliganism. Italy's players placed wreaths under a memorial plaque before their match against Belgium in the stadium last week and, not unnaturally, they are preoccupied by the subtext of a meeting with Keegan's men.

"There's a week in which to try and calm things down," Gianluca Pessotto, a current Juventus player, said at the weekend. "Maybe Uefa's warning [of expulsion] will help. And there's nothing to say that England will definitely get the result they need against Romania. But the coincidence of playing the English in Brussels is bound to raise the emotional temperature of the game." Many of his team-mates are saying that they do not want their families and friends to attend the match, if it takes place.

Meanwhile Keegan's players will probably continue to close their ears and eyes when they return to Charleroi tonight. What else can they do? Even professional observers are nowhere near unanimity on the causes, the effects or the solutions.

And at this stage, anecdotal evidence is virtually worthless. One man travels from Brussels to Charleroi on a train with English fans and calls it one of the worst experiences of his life, having been forced to listen to songs about gassing the Germans. Another arrives by car, parks near the centre, walks to the ground, chats to a few shirtsleeved policemen and can't understand what the fuss is about.

All we can be sure of is that, once again, England's presence in a major football tournament has led to the violent disruption of the lives of inno cent citizens of a foreign country and that the powers that be refuse to recognise the need for action, particularly when it might endanger their own short-term interests. "We are not the only country bidding for the 2006 World Cup with security problems of one kind of another," David Davies of the FA said yesterday, disgracefully bracketing South Africa's struggle to emerge from the legacy of apartheid with the depredations of England's affluent yob culture.

"How is it possible," Di Livio wondered, "that such an advanced nation can't shake off this plague?" Since it is unreasonable to expect players and officials to make a voluntary withdrawal, a further bout of trouble, followed by the summary expulsion of the England team, might be the only way to begin a cure.
