You need all the help you can get and the fans give it to you. Then you are expected to turn round and condemn them. Keegan's strategic refusal to accept the invitation said nothing about him as a man. He may have been brought up to revere Bill Shankly, but he knows that there is more to life than football. After the match, it had been a pleasure to hear the coach of England answer questions from a group of German journalists in their own language. This was a rare respite from the state-sponsored isolation to which we have been condemned by the insularity of our attitudes and the inadequacies of our education system, exemplified by the fact that out of the 16 referees controlling the matches at Euro 2000, only two - both of the British representatives - are monolinguists. Within the England camp, the reaction to the disruption caused by their supporters in the streets of Belgium is to blank it out. Something different is happening among the Italy squad, who may meet England in a quarter-final on Saturday night in the King Baudouin stadium in Brussels, built on the site of the old Heysel, where 34 Juventus fans and five Belgians died in 1985 as a consequence of English hooliganism. Italy's players placed wreaths under a memorial plaque before their match against Belgium in the stadium last week and, not unnaturally, they are preoccupied by the subtext of a meeting with Keegan's men. "There's a week in which to try and calm things down," Gianluca Pessotto, a current Juventus player, said at the weekend. "Maybe Uefa's warning [of expulsion] will help. And there's nothing to say that England will definitely get the result they need against Romania. But the coincidence of playing the English in Brussels is bound to raise the emotional temperature of the game." Many of his team-mates are saying that they do not want their families and friends to attend the match, if it takes place. Meanwhile Keegan's players will probably continue to close their ears and eyes when they return to Charleroi tonight. What else can they do? Even professional observers are nowhere near unanimity on the causes, the effects or the solutions. And at this stage, anecdotal evidence is virtually worthless. One man travels from Brussels to Charleroi on a train with English fans and calls it one of the worst experiences of his life, having been forced to listen to songs about gassing the Germans. Another arrives by car, parks near the centre, walks to the ground, chats to a few shirtsleeved policemen and can't understand what the fuss is about. All we can be sure of is that, once again, England's presence in a major football tournament has led to the violent disruption of the lives of inno cent citizens of a foreign country and that the powers that be refuse to recognise the need for action, particularly when it might endanger their own short-term interests. "We are not the only country bidding for the 2006 World Cup with security problems of one kind of another," David Davies of the FA said yesterday, disgracefully bracketing South Africa's struggle to emerge from the legacy of apartheid with the depredations of England's affluent yob culture. "How is it possible," Di Livio wondered, "that such an advanced nation can't shake off this plague?" Since it is unreasonable to expect players and officials to make a voluntary withdrawal, a further bout of trouble, followed by the summary expulsion of the England team, might be the only way to begin a cure.

fields.headline: Sukur's punch floors hosts
fields.trailText: The Belgian face-painting industry was in a state of disarray last night. Just as the co-hosts were finally beginning to embrace Euro 2000, their participation was brought to a premature and ultimately embarrassing exit.
fields.body:
The Belgian face-painting industry was in a state of disarray last night. Just as the co-hosts were finally beginning to embrace Euro 2000, their participation was brought to a premature and ultimately embarrassing exit.

Two goals from Hakan Sukur and some wishy-washy Belgian finishing ensured a night of Turkish celebrations throughout the southern half of the Low Countries, if not for those striving to make the tournament trouble-free.

With a quarter final against Portugal at stake the diables rouges went into their final group game knowing a draw would suffice.

Robert Waseige had insisted his side would not sit back and the Belgian coach was being truthful, judging by the ferocious pace with which they opened proceedings. For long, uneasy spells Turkey seemed incapable of getting a touch, such was the velocity of the Belgian play.

Indeed, if the co-hosts had a more incisive edge, Waseige could have been reading up on the Portuguese well before half-time. Instead, he was left scribbling into his notebook as chance after chance went astray. Presumably, shooting practice will be on the agenda at their next team meeting.

When Belgium finally breached the visiting defence, Emile Mpenza following up Bart Goor's blocked drive in the 24th minute, it was disallowed by a linesman's flag and, somewhat paradoxically, Turkey proceeded to squander the best opportunities of an opening period in which for the most part they had been out-thought and outfought.

Hakan Sukur, of all people, contrived to find the legs of Filip de Wilde after eluding his marker to manoeuvre a one-on-one against the Belgian goalkeeper. Buruk Okan followed that with what a golfer would call a shank, slicing his shot horribly wide from eight yards, and De Wilde deflected a shot from Arif Erdem over his crossbar after a magnificent run from the striker.

The relentless pace was temporarily halted late in the first half when the Danish referee Kim Neilsen - or The Man Who Sent Off David Beckham, as he is better known - pulled up with a groin injury and was replaced by the Austrian Gunter Benko. The break in momentum seemed to affect Belgium more than their opponents. Or maybe they were just feeling the effects of the overwhelming humidity that has engulfed Brussels in the last 48 hours.

It was certainly a night for sweaty palms, as well as shirts. Then, four minutes into first-half stoppage time, Hakan Sukur pounced. Alpay Ozalan sent a high ball into the penalty area and the Galatasaray forward escaped the attentions of Lorenzo Staelens and jumped above the leaden-footed De Wilde to loop a header into the empty net.

Not for the first time this tournament De Wilde was at fault, the goalkeeper flapping like a clothes line in the wind. But Hakan still deserves credit for the manner in which he attacked a ball that other strikers may have been inclined to leave. The striker is playing for a move to the Premiership or Serie A and, on this evidence, there will be no shortage of prospective buyers.

If the odd cuppa was hurled around the Belgian dressing room, Waseige's players had only themselves to blame for their earlier profligacy. After the interval there was another spell of concerted pressure, but with more than a hint of desperation this time.

Luc Nilis was finding cul-de-sacs and Marc Wilmots, their outstanding player of the past 10 days, was becoming an increasingly isolated and aggravated figure. Mpenza flashed one header wide and had another brilliantly saved by Rustu Recber. How Waseige must have longed for a goalkeeper of similar competence.

Belgium were always vulnerable to the counter-attack and so it was in the 69th minute. Suat Kaya streaked away on the right and angled a low pass for Sukur to score from close range.

De Wilde, crowning a personal nightmare, was sent off in the 84th minute after rushing out from his area and lunging wildly at Arif.

fields.headline: Euro 2000 diary
fields.trailText: Martin Keown's eccentricities, a bottle's better than a glass and Yugoslavia miss the point.
fields.body:
Martin Keown played a blinder for England on Saturday, a fact all the more remarkable after you read these two stories about the England centre-back. Once a fan went up to Keown and asked him to sign a football. "Sure," replied the affable star, before calmly putting his signature to a black panel on the ball, where no one could read it. Another time, a father walked up to Keown at the end of training. "Excuse me," he said, indicating his son standing nearby, "could we have a photo?" "Sure," replied the affable star, who grabbed the man's camera, took a picture of the bemused boy standing alone, and headed off towards the showers. Footballers, eh?

 We all know what too much drink can do to even a well-meaning football fan, and the local authorities have wisely taken steps to minimise the threat. That's why our man in Bruges, when he asked for a large beer after a recent game, was told that he could only have a small one, and it had to be served in a plastic cup. After all, you wouldn't provide a potential hooligan with strong alcohol and a dangerous glass, would you? So he changed his mind and ordered some wine, which was brought to him in its big, glass bottle with fine glasses from which to drink. Really, it makes no sense.

 After Sunday's match between Yugoslavia and Norway, the media pack rounded on Yugoslavia's coach Vujadin Boskov for his negative tactics and the blatant play-acting of his players. Quite what he was hearing through the translator, however, we don't know. Asked "Did you play dirty?", Boskov thought for a while, then replied: "It's hard to find a Yugoslav who doesn't play by both feet." Er, quite.

 Two Yugoslav fans arrived in Belgium yesterday after cycling the 1,600km from home. That might make them mad enough, but they didn't even have any tickets. "I think we will go back by bus," said one.

 They must hate journalists in Belgium: one British hack at the England-Germany game was pounced on by stewards when, at half-time, he started eating a ham sandwich. The valiant scribe didn't give in, and after a long argument with a veritable army of emblazered Uefa types, he eventually had his way. Maybe it's a meat thing: the Guardian man sitting behind him ate his cheese sandwich without interruption.

fields.headline: Euro 2000 shorts
fields.trailText: • Talk yesterday was dominated by the hooliganism seen in Brussels and Charleroi over the weekend. The Premier League took the first steps towards imposing a life ban on all those convicted of hooligan-related offences. "We'll work closely with clubs and the police to put in place the means to enforce life bans via withdrawal of season tickets and a stop on admission to grounds," said a spokesman. "The hooligans should be in no doubt they will pay a further price if they try and make the England national team suffer for their stupidity."
fields.body:
 Talk yesterday was dominated by the hooliganism seen in Brussels and Charleroi over the weekend. The Premier League took the first steps towards imposing a life ban on all those convicted of hooligan-related offences. "We'll work closely with clubs and the police to put in place the means to enforce life bans via withdrawal of season tickets and a stop on admission to grounds," said a spokesman. "The hooligans should be in no doubt they will pay a further price if they try and make the England national team suffer for their stupidity."

 Humberto Coelho, the coach of Portugal, had his own suggestion for England: "There is only one solution - send the supporters home and let the team stay," he said. Portugal will host the next European Championship in 2004. "I hope they won't be sent home," said the defender Fernando Couto. "It's not good for the tournament and it's not good for football."

 An official of the Yugoslav football association was expelled from Belgium yesterday after he was found selling black-market tickets. The official was arrested on Sunday, before the match between Yugoslavia and Norway, while in possession of 150 tickets and 150,000 Belgian francs (£2,400).

 Liverpool's Vegard Heggem will play no further part in Euro 2000 after suffering a recurrence of an old hamstring injury in Norway's game against Yugoslavia. Tottenham's Steffen Iversen broke his nose in the same game, but is expected to play against Slovenia tomorrow.

fields.headline: Life without Hagi
fields.trailText: The temperature in Charleroi touched 90F yesterday but it was not the sun that had Viorel Moldovan's cheeks burning red. After a morning work-out at the Stade Communal he was still chewing the fat with the press when Romania's team coach trundled away into the distance.
fields.body:
The temperature in Charleroi touched 90F yesterday but it was not the sun that had Viorel Moldovan's cheeks burning red. After a morning work-out at the Stade Communal he was still chewing the fat with the press when Romania's team coach trundled away into the distance.

It needed some frantic gesticulating and an impromptu bout of extracurricular training, namely a 100-yard dash, for the Fenerbahce forward to avoid incurring an expensive taxi fare. But then again, as those who remember his Coventry City days will testify, his sense of timing always has been a bit awry.

Tonight, as far as Romania are concerned, it will be Gheorghe Hagi's absence that dominates thoughts and minds.

Hagi is as important to Romania as Diego Maradona was to Argentina. Those size-five boots have been tormenting international defences for 17 years now, but tonight the talismanic Galatasaray player is suspended.

Romania's loss will be England's gain. Last Saturday, after Romania had lost to Portugal and Hagi had collected his second successive booking, thousands of fans congregated in Bucharest's Revolution Plaza to chant their hero's name. His first club, Farul Constanta, have renamed their stadium after him and when he returned from international retirement last year a group of supporters showed their gratitude by buying him a racehorse.

The six-time Romanian player of the year is so highly regarded that the national coach Emerich Ienei plans to seek Hagi's advice before naming his team an hour before kick-off.

"Only Hagi could be the substitute for Hagi," a rather gruff Ienei said yesterday. "He's an icon, a trailblazer. Of course we will miss him.

"I haven't discussed the situation with him yet but I will. It's a difficult position to be in but we will find a solution."

Ienei stayed up until late Sunday night watching the video of England's match against Germany and, diplomacy perhaps not being his strong point, he described it as "a very hard game, like a third world war".

The English, he says, pose their biggest threat from high balls. "We know their style well enough. During our preparations we have worked very hard on dealing with that particular tactic. But we beat England in the World Cup so they will be afraid of us."

But not, perhaps, as afraid as the Charleroi locals. After what seems like an eternity of flying boots and bottles, the reputation of the English game will be under scrutiny yet again this evening.

For Romania, much like Germany, Euro 2000 has been more a case of Grecian 2000. An ageing squad has become overly reliant on Hagi and several of their seasoned players can expect to be pensioned off should they fail tonight. Adding to the list of sub-plots, Ienei is also toiling against a campaign clamouring for his removal from office, only six months after he succeeded Victor Piturca.

Matters reached a head after a 2-0 friendly defeat in Greece, when the team flew home to find hundreds of fans waiting at the airport to vent their anger. The tepid offerings served up against Portugal prompted a new level of hostility among sections of the Romanian media but, at 63, Ienei comes with a reputation as a wily old tactician, his curriculum vitae incorporating Steaua Bucharest's 1986 European Cup triumph.

Furthermore, and if it counts for anything, Romania's record of not having lost to England for three decades cannot be easily dismissed.

"We have always done well against England," says Moldovan. "In my opinion, they don't have a special gift. They are dangerous from free-kicks and David Beckham crosses the ball well, but apart from that they play predictable football."

Dan Petrescu, too, is optimistic. "I would say that, even without Hagi, this is a better side than the one that beat England in the World Cup," says Chelsea's wing-back. "We are capable of knocking England out. I scored the winning goal against them in France and I would love to do the same again. But all I care about really is that we get to the quarter-finals by winning this game."

Even that might not be enough, however, if Germany find something in reserve against a Portuguese side certain of finishing on top of Group A. Already the cynics in the Romanian media are pontificating about Portugal possibly lapsing into demob-happy mode.

"It is possible they will play their reserves. I would ask them to be honest, like I always have been," says Ienei.

Tonight, if Kevin Keegan and his players get their way, and if the English fans break the habit of a lifetime, it will all be hypothetical.

webTitle: Keegan must throw the art of passing into the mixer

fields.headline: Keegan must throw the art of passing into the mixer
fields.standfirst:
England need to play keep-ball to check the
Romanian counter-attack
fields.trailText: England need to play keep-ball to check the Romanian counter-attack, reports Martin Thorpe.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan, in his tactical approach to England's games so far, has looked like a DIY novice trying to mix his own cement. Against Portugal he poured too much water into the mix and England ended up with no solidity.

Against Germany Keegan tried to firm things up but overdid the cement powder and England ended up so rigid as to be incapable of creative movement. Before tonight's game against Romania the coach will be laying it on with a trowel to his players that this time they must get the mix right or hopes of a quarter-final place will collapse.

With no Paul Gascoigne to provide a spell of individual magic, one art England must improve is their passing if they are to break through a Romania defence which has conceded only two goals in these finals - and Portugal needed extra-time to score one of those.

On Saturday England gave the ball away with alarming frequency. Luckily Germany made poor use of England's gifts. But, as Keegan's No2 Derek Fazackerley pointed out before the tournament even began: "Against quick counter-attacking teams you can't afford to give the ball away too often or else they will punish you." And Romania love to counter-attack.

To an English player, however, passing remains a job not an art. Against Germany, whenever the ball reached a red shirt it seemed to sprout a fizzing fuse. Passing the ball turned into passing the buck, to the point where England players in possession, on nervously spying a German heading their way, passed to team-mates in even worse positions just to get rid of the hot potato.

England seemed incapable of simply holding off an opponent in order to find a safer escape route, though on Saturday England's running off the ball was patchy to say the least. And when it was inventive, the man in possession invariably failed to spot the option or took so long controlling the ball that the destructive value of an early pass was lost.

Ideally a player should be aware of what is going on around him and where he might pass the ball before he even gains possession. This is akin to playing chess thinking one move ahead.

But England struggle to master even this gambit, especially at the back where the aim of too many clearances against Germany was to get the ball out the area rather than find a team-mate as well.

All this wasted possession simply invited Germany back on to England, prompting the defence to drop deeper, searching for what the England coach Les Reed calls "the comfort zone that comes with knowing there is no space behind you". As a result, Martin Keown was constantly exhorting the back line to push out.

Up front, too, possession was difficult to keep. Passes played up to Alan Shearer and Michael Owen invariably found the strikers heavily marked and with no immediate forward support from a midfield programmed to hold rather than probe.

"We definitely need to start passing the ball better," admitted Keegan on Sunday. "We pass it well in training, we just need to do it on the pitch." England have done it on the pitch already in this tournament, in the first 20 minutes against Portugal. Now they need to repeat that virtuosity against Romania while retaining the solidity of the Germany match.

Thankfully England need only a draw to qualify for the quarter-finals, though Paul Ince insists: "You know the English mentality. We never play for a draw." Either way, it must be hoped that Keegan the cement mixer has sorted out the right ingredients.

England seemed incapable of simply holding off an opponent in order to find a safer escape route, though on Saturday England's running off the ball was patchy to say the least. And when it was inventive, the man in possession invariably failed to spot the option or took so long controlling the ball that the destructive value of an early pass was lost. Ideally a player should be aware of what is going on around him and where he might pass the ball before he even gains possession. This is akin to playing chess thinking one move ahead. But England struggle to master even this gambit, especially at the back where the aim of too many clearances against Germany was to get the ball out the area rather than find a team-mate as well. All this wasted possession simply invited Germany back on to England, prompting the defence to drop deeper, searching for what the England coach Les Reed calls "the comfort zone that comes with knowing there is no space behind you". As a result, Martin Keown was constantly exhorting the back line to push out. Up front, too, possession was difficult to keep. Passes played up to Alan Shearer and Michael Owen invariably found the strikers heavily marked and with no immediate forward support from a midfield programmed to hold rather than probe. "We definitely need to start passing the ball better," admitted Keegan on Sunday. "We pass it well in training, we just need to do it on the pitch." England have done it on the pitch already in this tournament, in the first 20 minutes against Portugal. Now they need to repeat that virtuosity against Romania while retaining the solidity of the Germany match. Thankfully England need only a draw to qualify for the quarter-finals, though Paul Ince insists: "You know the English mentality. We never play for a draw." Either way, it must be hoped that Keegan the cement mixer has sorted out the right ingredients.

fields.headline: England need to summon spirit of Rome
fields.standfirst:
The make-or-break match against Romania tonight
calls for grit and discipline from Keegan's men, writes
David Lacey
fields.trailText: The make-or-break match against Romania tonight calls for grit and discipline from Keegan's men, writes David Lacey
fields.body:
If England are to reach the quarter-finals of the European Championship under Kevin Keegan they will need to recall how they qualified for the last World Cup under Glenn Hoddle. For Romania, in other words, read Rome.

A point for Keegan's team against the Romanians in the Stade du Pays here tonight will be enough, just as a scoreless draw with Italy in the Stadio Olimpico three years ago was enough. What remains to be seen is whether the England of today can summon up the powers of concentration and perform with the discipline which in the autumn of 1997 denied the Italians the win they needed to avoid a play-off for France 98.

Now Italy await the runners-up of Group B in Brussels and the burden of victory in Charleroi lies with Romania. In Euro 2000 Emerich Jenei's experienced side have defended impressively and attacked with verve and imagination. Yet they were held to 1-1 by the poor German team subsequently defeated by England and lost to Portugal in stoppage time.

This evening, moreover, the Romanians will be without the suspended Gheorghe Hagi and his ability to expose a defence at the drop of a shoulder or the bat of an eyelid. Hagi will be replaced by Adrian Mutu but Jenei can only partly make up in the physical effort of players like Constantin Galca what his team has lost in mental agility.

Yet, if England can fall back on Rome thoughts, Romania will put their trust in memories of Toulouse in the 1998 World Cup when Dan Petrescu's last-minute winner frustrated Hoddle's hopes of the draw which would have enabled his team to avoid Argentina, and perhaps elimination, in the second phase.

Petrescu is still around, along with Dorinel Munteanu and Adrian Ilie, who were more profound influences than Hagi that night. England, however, no longer have three players who contributed handsomely to the much ado about nothing-nothing in Rome - Paul Gascoigne, David Batty and Teddy Sheringham.

The combination of Gascoigne's passing, Batty's positioning and Sheringham's ability to hold the ball helped Hoddle's England anaesthetise that match in a manner which Keegan's side, despite the England coach's positive instincts, will need to emulate tonight. This does not mean simply sitting back in order to soak up Romanian pressure but it does mean keeping possession and controlling the tempo of the game.

If England continue to give the ball away as they did in the second half against Portugal and the first against Germany they will be inviting Romania to take the lead. Should this happen Keegan's attack will find out how difficult it is to hew oak with a breadknife, such is the organised obduracy of Gheorghe Popescu and his fellow-defenders.

The England coach is fully aware of what needs to be improved. "If we don't pass the ball better we will not go far," he said last night, "but the good thing is that we know we can pass it better. We showed that against Argentina, Brazil and the Ukraine.

"In this heat if your passing is better you save energy having to chase the ball. All right, we'll still be fit enough if we don't pass properly but we've got to show we can play the sort of football that wins tournaments.

"Being realistic we know what we can do and what we can't do," Keegan continued. "It's very hard these days just to go out and draw a game. Now you can't pass back to the goalkeeper so he can throw it out to a full-back."

In other words England could not kill tonight's match as Liverpool used to do in Europe, even if they had the means. But they can defend further upfield than they did against Portugal and Germany and concentrate hard on denying Romania the sort of runs from midfield which eventually undid England in Toulouse.

There Ilie proved himself adept at stealing into space between Hoddle's midfield and his back three, a situation not improved by the loss of an injured Ince, although this did bring on David Beckham and add an important dimension to the attack. Beckham, whose centres have become the stuff of life to England's progress here, could again make the difference between controlling a match and chasing it.

Assuming England are unchanged from their flag-waving win over the Germans, the ability of Dennis Wise to keep possession and play safe and of Paul Ince, the head-bandaged hero of Rome, to break up opposing movements before they reach the back four will be paramount in achieving the result Keegan needs.

Steven Gerrard, while again on the bench, could still have an important part to play and Steve McManaman, recovered from the knee injury he suffered against Portugal, may be needed if England find themselves chasing the game.

The England coach keeps insisting that Tony Adams, when fully fit, can play a further part in Euro 2000. For the moment, however, his replacement and fellow Arsenal centre-half Martin Keown is the crucial figure in Keegan's defence through his ability to spot danger early and track it down.

Sol Campbell, another hero of Rome, played better in the second half against Germany than the first,when he gave away a series of free kicks within scoring range. Such lapses may be punished more severely tonight, even in Hagi's absence.

As well as being England's toughest encounter so far it could also be the roughest. Romania are not averse to bodychecking opponents and they are apt to hold on to enemy shirts like drowning men.

The Swiss referee, Urs Meier, has declared that his favourite film is The English Patient. Beckham and Ince, each a yellow card away from missing the quarter-finals, will hope he is patient with the English.

webTitle: Italians tell loved ones to stay away

fields.headline: Italians tell loved ones to stay away
fields.trailText: Italian players are refusing to let their families attend the possible quarter-final tie against England, fearing a repeat of the 1985 disaster at the same stadium.
fields.body:
Italian players are refusing to let their families attend the possible quarter-final tie against England, fearing a repeat of the 1985 disaster at the same stadium.

The ongoing bouts of English hooliganism in Belgium have caused concern about crowd safety at Brussels' King Baudouin stadium, formerly the Heysel stadium, where 34 Juventus fans died after rioting by Liverpool fans.

The stadium was completely rebuilt and renamed following the tragedy. But memories remain vivid for the Italians, though their coach Dino Zoff has ruled out asking for the venue to be changed for Saturday's potential meeting.

Several of his team, however, are worried that, if England qualify for the quarter-finals, they will bring the hooligans with them. The midfielder Luigi di Biagio said: "I won't allow my family to enter the stadium because I would not go out on the pitch with the necessary calm. It's better that they stay in the hotel."

The captain Paolo Maldini will make a decision once it is clear England will be Italy's opponents. "I feel a bit worried and am thinking about my loved ones, for whom I've already booked the tickets," he said. "To know that they are in the middle of a crowd that could erupt into violence doesn't make me comfortable."

Italy played their first game at the stadium since the tragedy in a friendly against Belgium on May 29, the 15th anniversary of the disaster. They cannot understand that English fans are still able to behave so dangerously.

"Certain TV images disturbed me," said the midfielder Angelo di Livio. "It looked more like a war scene. Can't these English understand that football is a game?"

However, Zoff is not advocating that England be thrown out of the tournament. "We're facing a prob lem of public order that has very little to do with football," he said. "It doesn't seem right to me to ban England and I don't find it right to change the venue."

 The Football Association remains confident that England's bid to host the 2006 World Cup finals will not be harmed by the hooligan outbreaks in Belgium. The FA's chief executive Adam Crozier said yesterday it would be "very, very disappointing if that was to fall by the wayside because of the actions of a few criminals and mindless idiots. Hosting the World Cup would be a dream for almost every fan in the country."

fields.headline: Romania 3 - 2 England
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

England: Seaman, G Neville, Campbell, Keown, P Neville, Beckham, Scholes, Ince, Wise, Owen, Shearer. Subs: Barmby, Barry, Fowler, Gerrard, Heskey, Martyn, McManaman, Phillips, Southgate, Wright.

Romania: Stelea, Petrescu, Filipescu, Galca, Popescu, Mutu, Munteanu, Moldovan, Ilie, Chivu, Contra. Subs: Belodedici, Ciobotariu, Ganea, Hildan, Lincar, Lobont, Lupescu, Petre, Prunea, Rosu.

1 England kick-off needing only a point to be sure of reaching the quarter-finals. Surprisingly there is no customary punt upfield and England opt for some early passing moves before giving away possession.
3 Romania win a free-kick right on the edge of the area after Mutu is allowed through form midfield. Ilie takes and forces Martyn to make a great save diving to his left. Early let-off for Engalnd.
4 First cross from Beckham on the right, but there is no one there to meet it.
5 Romania push up again with Mutu on the left; the ball is spread wide to Contra on the right before Ilie fails to connect with the cross.
7 England free-kick. Wise sprays it wide to G Neville on the right, Romania clear and break upfield before losing possession for a goal-kick.
8 Munteanu has a crack from 25 yards but his effort is well wide of the left-hand upright.
10 England start to knock it around on the right after a lively start by Romania. Beckham fires a cross into space.
13 Ilie makes an early run onto a through-ball from deep but it runs ahead of him.
14 Romania corner, Contra takes, Keown mis-kicks but England still manage to clear. Romania still looking the more lively.
15 Petrescu does well to play in Moldovan on the edge of the area, but his shot is straight at Martyn.
16 Owen gets round the back of Filipescu on the edge of the six-yard box to meet a long throw, but he can only direct his shot into the stands.
18 Booking Chivu after he upended Beckham just when England wrer passing well. Free-kick on the right corner of the area. Beckham takes, but no one can reach the ball as it flies across goal. Sol Campbell the nearest.
20 Owen turns well to get away from his marker but his touch is too strong. Encouraging movement from the England striker.
21 Romania corner on the Romanian right.
22 GOAL! Romania 1 - 0 England From the corner, the ball goes out to Chivu on the left and his cross to Moldovan at the far post instead bounces into the goal off the upright.
25 Wise blows a shooting chance form 20 yards when his first touch lets him down and he shoots wide.
27 Owen fails to use a lovely pass from Beckham, more out of surprise that Beckham managed to find the angle.
29 England push up and knock the ball around the edge of the area but no onemanages to get in a shot.
32 Substitution Belodedici on for Popescu after Popescu injures himself trying to injure Beckham.
34 Ilie gets behind Keown and on to the end of a cross by Petrescu; no offside, but Ilie's header is straight at Martyn.
36 Chivu races away on the left, gets past G Neville and shoots from 20 yards, but luckily for England it flies over. England being comprehensively out-numbered and out-played in midfield much in the smae way as they were in the second half against Portugal.
38 England corner after Scholes just fails to meet a Beckham cross. It is cleared, pumped back in and cleared again for a goal-kick.
40 Booking Petrescu
41 Penalty: Romania 1 - 1 England Ince is brought down just as he was about to shoot with his left foot. Shearer takes to Stelea's right and puts England back on level terms.
44 England fans in full voice now after a pretty ropey start from Keegan's men. Great work by Ince ends in a free-kick to the left of the area. Contra earns himself a booking in the process. Romania clear from the corner.
45 Booking Ilie, for trying to get a penalty when under pressure form Martyn. GOAL! Scholes knocks the ball over the top to send Owen away, he rides the challenge of 'keeper Stelea, prods the ball past and his pace sees him to the far post to cut back for the goal. Half-time. Romania on top for most of the half, but England have used the evident spirit in the side to pull back and take the lead.

46 Romania kick-off the second half with England fans singing the national anthem.
47 Romania corner, played short, cleared for a throw. Romania knock it back in, but England clear.
48 GOAL! Romania 2 - 2 England England all over the place at the back. Martyn comes out to punch clear what shouild have been handled by a central defender before Munteanu fires in from just inside the area.
51 England free-kick. Beckham floats in from deep but Shearer is penalised trying to help the ball on to Scholes.
55 Quick passing by England on the left almost sees Owen away on a run but his first touch is too heavy.
57 Wise finds Beckham wide on the right, his cross is played behind Owen in the direction of Scholes, but Romania get there first.
59 Romania attack the England goal again with a succession of crosses from Ilie on the right. Offside eventually given.
60 Beckham cross towards Shearer in the six-yard box but Stelea gets there first.
61 Ilie tries a weak shot from close range but it is easy for Martyn. England living dangerously.
64 Booking Shearer for diving. And he did.
66 Galca tries a long-range shot but sends it into the crowd.
67 Substitution Heskey on for Owen.
68 Substitution Rosu on for Galca.
69 Heskey unlucky not to reach a Beckham cross, Belodedici heads clear.
70 Petrescu shoots from 30 yards; he keeps it down but Martyn is behind it.
71 Booking Filipescu, after felling Heskey just as he was setting off on a run.
74 Ilie waltzs into the penalty area, Keown blocks and then clears the rebound. Substitution: Galea on for Ilie.
75 Substitution Barmby on for Wise.
77 Mutu's shot forces Martyn to the ground to save as Moldovan races in for the rebound.
79 Scholes finds Barmby on the left, he finds Heskey for a one-two but his shot goes well wide.
81 Substitution Southgate on for Scholes, signalling a change of tactics for England as they seek to hang on to what they have got.
84 Romania corner. England clear and break with Shearer and Heskey. Munteanu tackles for a throw.
88 Penalty Romania 3 - 2 England Nightmare! Moldovan is brought down by P Neville and Ganea puts it past Martyn with ease.
90 England throw near the corner flag, Romania clear. England frantic now and win a free-kick on the left. Beckham takes and tries to find Shearer but he misses it and Stelea gets there first. Full-time. Romania 3 - 2 England England are out.

fields.headline: Just be sure it fits
fields.standfirst: Tread carefully or you will find yourself starting a course that doesn't suit, says Jeremy Hoad
fields.trailText: Tread carefully or you will find yourself starting a course that doesn't suit, says Jeremy Hoad
fields.body:
If you are thinking about doing a postgraduate degree there are some basic questions you should ask yourself. Why do I want to do a postgraduate course? What sort of course should I consider? How will the course be funded? How do I get the best out of the course? How will the course fit in with my life? This article focuses on shorter courses and provides some guidance to help you answer these questions.

The sort of course you choose depends on what your intentions are. The vast majority of postgraduates are not locked away in some mythical ivory tower doing pure research leading to a PhD or DPhil. They are studying shorter masters courses and diplomas, which are often intended to provide a specific training. These can be directly related to your previous undergraduate degree, to give you more detailed and advanced knowledge of the subject.

Alternatively, they can enable you to retrain in a new area or develop skills and knowledge relevant to your work or career. Diploma courses usually last six to nine months and masters courses may last one or two years.

Before you consider doing a postgraduate course you must ask yourself why you want to do it. And, more importantly, you must answer yourself honestly.

Courses may be entirely taught (PG Dip), have a small research element (MA and MSc), act as a training in research techniques (MRes) or be pure research (MPhil). Most shorter postgraduate courses provide a training for work and some are aimed at equipping you for further study or research.

There are many different reasons why you might want to study at postgraduate level, but the three main categories people fall into are academic, vocational and drifting.

Academic reasons are often the most obvious for continuing in or returning to higher education. You may have developed a keen interest in a particular subject and want to advance your knowledge. This can be for career reasons leading to work in a university, or it may simply be that you want to extend your learning and expand your knowledge for pleasure. You can, of course, do both.

Vocational factors are often easier to identify where a course and qualification provides specific career benefits. For example, diplomas in social work, counselling or law all provide clear career benefits and training. Masters courses also may be explicitly vocational and can provide a fast route to enhancing your previous qualifications and giving you an advantage in the job market. Examples include an MA in town and country planning and the MSc in transport engineering.

Drifting is unfortunately a common reason for people doing postgraduate courses, and can often lead to a bad experience. You may feel that doing a postgraduate course is a "natural" progression from an undergraduate degree. You may find yourself doing a course because of general inertia, indecision or the desire to postpone other decisions.

So it is crucial that you identify what your motivations are so that you can get the best out of your course. Masters courses (and diplomas) are intensive, rewarding and often provide clear career benefits.

They can also be stressful, demanding and frustrating. If you are not sure what you want to get out of your course it can make your life very difficult.

It is important to choose carefully. The reputation of the institution, its location, the course content and duration all have to be considered. Be careful about course titles as well, since courses with the same title may be very different in content or level.

For example, a masters in computing and information technology at one institution may be targeted at experienced people from industry or those with an undergraduate degree in the same subject. At another institution it may be targeted at those wishing to retrain with completely different backgrounds and little or no knowledge of computing.

The National Qualifications Framework initiative, coordinated by the Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education (QAA), is developing proposals for bringing greater clarity, comparability and simplicity to postgraduate courses. The NPC is monitoring this and has had considerable input to the proposals.

Funding your course will usually be the most challenging thing for you to resolve. Most postgraduate students fund themselves. Grants are available through the various research councils, but these are intensely competitive and will never meet the demand for funding. Also, postgraduate students do not qualify for student loans. The only exception is if you intend to do a Postgraduate Certificate in Education (PGCE) to train as a teacher.

There is a scheme organised through a number of high street banks (Barclays, Royal Bank of Scotland, Co-operative Bank and the Clydesdale) which can offer support. This is for government-subsidised Career Development Loans (CDL) which are for a maximum of £8,000. But don't be misled, these are commercial loans for courses which offer career benefits or training and can be limited to the legal or health care professions.

The repayments are not linked to salary and start one or two months after the course finishes. Fees also vary dramatically with no standard level. The Department for Education and Employment (DfEE) sets a recommended rate each year (£2,740 for 2000-2001 for students from within the EU) but many courses cost considerably more than this. For example, MBA courses can cost £10,000 or more. Ask about funding when contacting departments and check with a university careers service for information on charitable sources, trusts and scholarships.

Make sure that you also find out about any additional fees you might need to pay on top of the base rate for the university. You must take account of departmental research fees, laboratory fees and specific course costs, which may run into hundreds of pounds. The NPC believes that course costs should be transparent and all-inclusive; but until this happens, be wary of hidden fees.

For shorter courses it is particularly important that you remain focused and make the most of your time. Even a year or two can pass very quickly, and if you delay or get distracted it is very difficult to make up lost time.

One thing that must never be overlooked is the impact of a postgraduate course on your life. Remember that the course you choose is a means to an end. It is not an end in itself. Student life can often seem very attractive - but that should not be your reason for studying.

You must consider how you will fit your course into your life. If you are in your early twenties and intend to become a postgraduate immediately after finishing your undergraduate degree, you are less likely to have other commitments.

Bur if you have a partner, children and another job, it will be harder to incorporate studying into your life. Postgraduate courses can be very time-consuming and intensive. Be realistic about your situation so that you don't face problems half-way through.

Most postgraduates (over 60%) are studying part-time, and if you aim to do this it is not necessarily an easier option than full time study. If you are working your employer may subsidise your course or offer time off for training.

Whatever you decide to do, and wherever you decide to do it, make sure you know why you are doing it. If you are clear about this and are realistic about your expectations you should have a rewarding and successful time as a postgraduate student.

fields.headline: PhDs in juggling life
fields.standfirst: Donald MacLeod reveals the perils of part-time study
fields.trailText: Donald MacLeod reveals the perils of part-time study
fields.body:
Inspiring, motivating - or a "self-imposed sentence of unremitting hard work for five or six years"? The ups and downs of life on a PhD seem intensified for anyone who tries to do it part-time. Part-time postgraduate courses are the fastest growing sector of higher education, but you might not guess that from the very limited attention they receive. And it is clear from the first-hand accounts in How I got my postgraduate degree part time - published by Lancaster University's School of Independent Studies and the Guardian - that some students feel they are being taken for granted and treated by universities as second-class citizens in both teaching and facilities.

Avril Horseford, for instance, felt many part-time students fail to become integrated into their universities: "I attended many lectures outside business hours and was sometimes required to use half-closed buildings without canteen and library facilities. Not being taught in an adequate learning environment can easily lead to the feeling that you are a second-rate student receiving a second-rate product."

She was not alone in identifying a support group as a crucial factor that could mean the difference between success and failure. Members of her group of part-timers shared articles and references they researched. For others, like Tanya Richardson, forming a group was a personal "lifeline" and added depth to her academic work. "As a part-timer with limited contact time with tutors and other students, the academic experience can, I think, be essentially isolating." She sought out a couple of kindred spirits and met weekly for a meal and discussions that were both social and productive.

Juggling the demands of a job, family and PhD places students - and their families - under considerable strain. Rachel Jones confesses there was a period of six months when her job as a university administrator became very demanding, and she resented the way this interfered with her studies.

"This was a stressful time and I coped by trying to keep a strict time division between the job and the PhD. I didn't have much time or energy for anything else, and it adversely affected my relationship and family life. My partner said I was difficult to live with during this time because I was on a short fuse."

For many PhD students, embarking on the course comes after long hesitation or after a crisis. Martyn Halsall, a former Guardian journalist, waited until he had left the paper and was working for a Church of England diocese before he felt he could undertake his MA in creative writing. "I could not see how in-depth discussion of literary influences could necessarily co-exist with the 'But we need you in Newcastle' demands of a newspaper's ever frenetic news desk." Part-time means a long time. As Antonia Dodds points out, a PhD is now likely to take eight years.

"I don't have much money and can't afford a mortgage. This can feel like I am putting my life on hold, especially when I compare my situation with peers who are climbing the career ladder." Add a baby, as Katherine Sargant did, and the situation becomes worse. She paid a lot of attention to her son but her adult relationships suffered. Eventually, she decided to suspend her studies.

So why on earth do they do it? The "lust for learning" also comes through in the book, though that needs to be balanced by learning to stand up for your own views. When Caroline Gattrell presented her research on an aspect of women's studies at a seminar it aroused such feeling that students started shouting at each other. Another time she was strongly attacked by academics, whom she felt were prejudiced.

She found herself weighing up the personal cost of a part-time PhD, but decided eventually to continue. The student networks she had formed gave her the confidence and determination to carry on. "The 'lows' of doing a part-time PhD are inevitable, but temporary. They do pass . . . Yes, it is worth it after all."

 How I got my postgraduate degree part time (ed. Nicole Greenfield) is published on Thursday by the School of Independent Studies at Lancaster University and the Guardian, price inclusive of postage and packaging. Tel: 01524 593430 or write to Independent Studies (books), Lonsdale College, Lancaster University, Lancaster, LA1 4YN or email: IndStud@lancaster.ac.uk.

fields.headline: Citizenship
fields.trailText: Citizen Taylor rounds up the best of the web
fields.body:
Learning Landscapes
***
Aimed at: everyone

Schools that registered for the London Electricity National School Grounds Week will already have received lesson ideas from the charity LTL. If not, this site is worth bookmarking for next year.

CAB Advice Guide
****
Aimed at: everyone

The CAB's searchable directory enables visitors to research topics such as health, taxes, elections and welfare benefits. It is extensively cross-referenced and includes separate information for Scotland.

Citizen 21
****
Aimed at: everyone

Instigated by the campaigning group Charter 88, Citizen 21 describes itself as a "one-stop shop" for citizenship studies. The approach is participative and questioning. A Citizen 21 schools pack is free to download; links and books are also recommended.

Citizenship Foundation
****
Aimed at: teachers

An excellent introduction to the teaching of citizenship, as well the issues it raises, successful case studies and competitions (such as mock trials sponsored by the Bar and Motorola's young people's parliament) that pupils can enter. Resources will be added in the near future.

Imagine London
***
Aimed at: everyone

A potentially fruitful starting point for schools within Greater London, this project, supported by the King's Fund, invites young people to contribute ideas about what makes the city a healthy or unhealthy place to live. The full extent of the resources is not immediately apparent - some of them are only readable in PDF format - but the concept is a valuable one and, if it proves a success, may be extended to other urban areas.

Institute for Citizenship
***
Aimed at: teachers

The Institute has pioneered a number of citizenship education projects at all key stages. Not all of them are available here, and some have to be paid for, but by the time citizenship becomes a compulsory part of the national curriculum in 2002 the IoC will be well prepared.

News Wise
***
Aimed at: teachers

A series of lesson plans, last updated around a year ago, which analyse newspaper coverage of issues such as the murder of Stephen Lawrence, what children should be taught, world debt and children's rights. The presentation is text-based and therefore initially uninvolving, but the site still offers a number of interesting lines of inquiry.

Constitutional issues
****
Aimed at: older students, teachers

An excellent primary source for laws on human rights, elections, civil rights, freedom of information and race equality, as well as information on royalty and the Church. Some of the documents are too complex for use in the classroom, but summaries are often available in PDF format.

Web governments
***
Aimed at: everyone

Probably the easiest way to reach other countries' governmental sites, this should be useful if you want to compare another country's constitution with the British system. Most of the sites are at least partially in English and many spell out their definition of citizenship.

fields.headline: Shaping up?
fields.standfirst: Seismic changes are on the way for youth services. Will they bring radical improvement, or simply spoil a diverse and delicately-balanced system?
fields.trailText: Seismic changes are on the way for youth services. Will they bring radical improvement, or simply spoil a diverse and delicately-balanced system?
fields.body:
Imagine scouts swearing allegiance to David Blunkett instead of the Queen. Fanciful, perhaps, but not totally preposterous, as details of the government's massive shake-up of advice and provision for teenagers gradually take shape.

With every fresh exposition of the emerging regime comes the stark realisation that quite fundamental changes really are being planned. Whether these will be any good is another matter.

Ministers are reported to be nervous, recognising they're potentially vulnerable to accusations of behaving with heavy-handed authoritarianism. They've sought to counter any claims of re-moulding diverse and delicately balanced youth services to their own narrow whims, by setting in motion a number of pilot schemes to prove they're treading warily. They're also at pains to point out that the views of young people have been heeded in drawing up the grand scheme that is the Connexions strategy, soon to become a service.

Connexions sounds like the name of a respectable dating agency and, to a certain extent, that's what it is - brokering access for young people to a far more comprehensive and specialist range of services.

In part, there's also a financial imperative. It costs an average of about £58 to engage a young person in youth activities each year. The price of a place in one of the country's new secure training institutions - re-branded borstals - is about £100,000 a year. So it make sense to put some fences at the top of the cliff, so to speak, rather than assemble ambulances at the bottom.

At its most ambitious is the idea that the Connexions service will be able to offer something for every teenager, including flexible curriculum provision to include more citizenship studies and work-related learning, enabling them to make wiser career and lifestyle choices. There will be a special youth card containing details of their cv and the range of available work, training and leisure options. Individual learning accounts and education maintenance allowances are also part of an initiative designed to prevent any youngster, no matter how disgruntled or disadvantaged, slipping through a net of support, ministers claim.

Just in terms of human bodies alone, this net is formidable. Thousands of "personal advisers" and mentors, to comprise a new education profession, are being appointed to work in schools and further education colleges. They will encourage pre-16 attendance, provide information on post-16 learning and work opportunities, and offer subsequent support down whatever route youngsters take on the often rocky road leading to adulthood.

Well, that's the rhythm of the beat and it will be up to the recently-created Connexions National Unit, inevitably based in the Department for Education and Employment under the conductorship of Anne Weinstock, to ensure all parts stay in tune. Bids have just been invited for a private/public partnership to get it up and running.

It's a tricky task, because apart from national leadership, the Connexions service is designed to be delivered at both regional level - via the new Learning and Skills Councils -and locally, at the level of local education authorities. And all monitored by Ofsted.

The big issue, though, is about existing youth provision. Will the envisaged Connexions service improve the voluntary sector/local education authority domain, neatly dovetailing with it and enhancing its work? Or will it merely replicate what's already being done, and little else besides? Worse, could it result in a type of service that undermines what's already available - and even contribute to its own demise?

Leading youth organisations are concerned. Graham Clarke of YMCA England, warns: "If the adviser/ young person relationship is to be positive, it will need to be very carefully handled, be young people-focussed and ensure that young people are able to make their own decisions. If those decisions are made for them, or they are made to feel hounded by authority, it could well lead to resentment and further disengagement from society."

Tom Wylie, chief executive of the National Youth Agency, worries that in the drive for a more comprehensive and coherent system of youth support, there could be a serious erosion of key values. "The Connexions service and the work personal advisers will be expected to do puts too much stress on guidance for individuals and not enough on the range of activities which are needed, not least by disadvantaged young people," he says.

"There is no guarantee there will be sufficient and coherent local youth provision in place to which the Connexions support service can turn reliably for specialist help."

Wylie is also concerned that an essential characteristic of the youth service could be diluted. "Responding effectively to young people requires services to take risks, to innovate and to learn from innovation elsewhere. It can be too easy to focus on the different settings for work with young people - the club, the college, the streets - and on the content or curriculum of what's on offer," he says.

"Clarity of purpose and relevant content are important. But what will make this work are the values and skills of those engaged with young people, regardless of the setting or service in which they're operating."

If the Connexions service is to get beyond cerebral concept and really make a difference, then it has to be designed to meet young peoples' needs, rather than what politicians or even education professionals imagine they need, Wylie adds.

Even then it may not go far enough. After all, you could talk to Kevin three times a week for three years. But all the expert advice given would be wasted if, at the end of the day, there still were no adequate services around to keep him occupied or, indeed, catering for his "holistic" development.

"There's a danger too," Wylie warns, "of the partnership process being more about the practicalities of bringing diverse parties to the table to find an accommodation, than about a radical new service."

Many government departments are involved in Connexions, yet some may not easily give up their sole control over different parts of present youth sector provision. Certainly the history of Whitehall collaboration is not a trouble-free zone.

Of course, Britain's scouting movement will continue to swear allegiance to the Queen. But it will also have to heed the commands of her education ministers determined to create a youth service that's more efficient and uniform.

They will encourage pre-16 attendance, provide information on post-16 learning and work opportunities, and offer subsequent support down whatever route youngsters take on the often rocky road leading to adulthood. Well, that's the rhythm of the beat and it will be up to the recently-created Connexions National Unit, inevitably based in the Department for Education and Employment under the conductorship of Anne Weinstock, to ensure all parts stay in tune. Bids have just been invited for a private/public partnership to get it up and running. It's a tricky task, because apart from national leadership, the Connexions service is designed to be delivered at both regional level - via the new Learning and Skills Councils -and locally, at the level of local education authorities. And all monitored by Ofsted. The big issue, though, is about existing youth provision. Will the envisaged Connexions service improve the voluntary sector/local education authority domain, neatly dovetailing with it and enhancing its work? Or will it merely replicate what's already being done, and little else besides? Worse, could it result in a type of service that undermines what's already available - and even contribute to its own demise? Leading youth organisations are concerned. Graham Clarke of YMCA England, warns: "If the adviser/ young person relationship is to be positive, it will need to be very carefully handled, be young people-focussed and ensure that young people are able to make their own decisions. If those decisions are made for them, or they are made to feel hounded by authority, it could well lead to resentment and further disengagement from society." Tom Wylie, chief executive of the National Youth Agency, worries that in the drive for a more comprehensive and coherent system of youth support, there could be a serious erosion of key values. "The Connexions service and the work personal advisers will be expected to do puts too much stress on guidance for individuals and not enough on the range of activities which are needed, not least by disadvantaged young people," he says. "There is no guarantee there will be sufficient and coherent local youth provision in place to which the Connexions support service can turn reliably for specialist help." Wylie is also concerned that an essential characteristic of the youth service could be diluted. "Responding effectively to young people requires services to take risks, to innovate and to learn from innovation elsewhere. It can be too easy to focus on the different settings for work with young people - the club, the college, the streets - and on the content or curriculum of what's on offer," he says. "Clarity of purpose and relevant content are important. But what will make this work are the values and skills of those engaged with young people, regardless of the setting or service in which they're operating." If the Connexions service is to get beyond cerebral concept and really make a difference, then it has to be designed to meet young peoples' needs, rather than what politicians or even education professionals imagine they need, Wylie adds. Even then it may not go far enough. After all, you could talk to Kevin three times a week for three years. But all the expert advice given would be wasted if, at the end of the day, there still were no adequate services around to keep him occupied or, indeed, catering for his "holistic" development. "There's a danger too," Wylie warns, "of the partnership process being more about the practicalities of bringing diverse parties to the table to find an accommodation, than about a radical new service." Many government departments are involved in Connexions, yet some may not easily give up their sole control over different parts of present youth sector provision. Certainly the history of Whitehall collaboration is not a trouble-free zone. Of course, Britain's scouting movement will continue to swear allegiance to the Queen. But it will also have to heed the commands of her education ministers determined to create a youth service that's more efficient and uniform.

fields.headline: Plato strikes twice
fields.standfirst: The Teaching Awards 2000 continue apace
fields.trailText: The Teaching Awards 2000 continue apace
fields.body:
When the Beauchamp College goes into battle it does so in style, led by the head in an electric blue dress and followed by a skirmishing party of sixth-formers. These surrounded the Lord Lieutenant of Nottinghamshire as the East Midlands celebrated the best of the region's teaching, in a neat reversal of the Oxbridge interview process.

All with their sights set on Cambridge, the group sussed out that Sir Andrew Buchanan had been to Trinity College and they gave him a rigorous grilling. The comprehensive's two winning teachers, Richard Heppell and Bob Mitchell, happily watched this practical proof of their classroom excellence.

They weren't the only double act to come to Nottingham's stately Council House with a young support party. Across the room, two lads from the city's nearby Woodlands comprehensive hovered like minders round their winners, Carol Rial and Eileen Burch.

"Maybe students should join the judges next year," suggested one of the Beauchamp group, after releasing the lord lieutenant. There's a thought for Lord Puttnam and the Teaching Awards Trust. And another innovation for 2001 might be real, not just metaphorical, fanfares. Nebuchadnezzar's "cornet, flute, harp, sackbut, psaltery and all kinds of music" would have sounded appropriate at the Council House and at the Cutler's Hall in Sheffield where Yorkshire celebrated. Because, significantly, both regions' secondary teachers of the year lead inspirational music departments. At St Aidan's in Harrogate, Catherine Roberts has a remarkable effect on even the tone-deaf, boys and girls alike.

And in Oakham, Leicestershire, Susan Ball runs her own local version of the Arts Council at Uppingham Community College: orchestra, several concert bands, recorder ensemble, brass group, sax trio, flute choir, assorted other choirs and a violin, viola and cello session called Stringamajigs. Oh, and evening school for fledgling rock bands plus tours to gigs at weekends.

One word recurred at both ceremonies: enthusiasm. Natural in the young winners; undimmed in veterans like David Fox, long-serving head of geography at Giggleswick independent school in the Yorkshire Dales. And enthusiasm in adversity, as shown by Mike Smith of Victoria Dock primary in Hull, who switched from business to teaching at 37 after his wife died from cancer, leaving him with their four-year-old daughter Emma. He went up to collect his Plato for Yorkshire's best new primary teacher just after Tanya Taylor, who took the classroom assistant prize for Ripon College, the comprehensive that is shrugging off, at last, its inferiority complex about the city's grammar school.

Another extra-enthusiast was Sarah Groves-Allen, Yorkshire's primary teacher of the year; not content with leading the buzz at Belton CE school in Doncaster, she stepped in to cover at the next-door primary when a teacher fell ill three days before an Ofsted inspection.

Good fortune plays its part, too; judges at both ceremonies were keen to emphasise how close the results had been. And there's always a place for cunning; Sir Bob Salisbury, chairman of East Midlands judges, recalled at Nottingham how his old comprehensive got a free languages teacher every year from the Italian embassy on account of its name - the Garibaldi School.

Teachers face particular problems in Northern Ireland, writes John Mullin . Even as they were meeting at the Waterfront Hall in Belfast for the awards ceremony, arsonists were targeting two Catholic primary schools a few miles apart in County Antrim.

Heather Main, a maths teacher at Slemish College in Ballymena, close to one of the attacks, won the Guardian award for secondary teacher of the year. The integrated school has Catholic and Protestant pupils and no selection procedure. Main, head of year 10, runs two after-school maths clubs, and two students have gained gold medals in the UK Mathematical Challenge.

Winner of the Guardian award for primary teacher of the year was Geraldine Fitzpatrick, for 16 years a member of staff at St Malachy's in Newry, Co Down. The school is in a working-class area, and she is dedicated to ensuring pupils enjoy drama, believing it key in helping them to "glow and grow", as her principal said.

 Five of last year's national awards winners received OBEs in Saturday's birthday honours list: Barbara "Paddy" Beels of Wingate Nursery School, County Durham; Elizabeth Seddon of Elmtree First School, Chesham, Bucks; Jean Heslop of Cliffe Hill School, Halifax; Keith Parry, of Hyde Technology School, Cheshire and Wendy Crockett of Alderman Blaxill School, Colchester.

fields.headline: Still in the balance
fields.standfirst: MA students are urgently in need of an effective complaints procedure, reports Lee Elliot Major
fields.trailText: MA students are urgently in need of an effective complaints procedure, reports Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
Postgraduate representatives are calling on universities to improve their outdated student complaints procedures for masters courses, before institutions are forced to reform when new human rights laws are passed later this year.

The number of complaints from postgraduates has been increasing in recent years, following the boom in masters courses run by universities. The unchecked expansion of one-year postgraduate degrees has created a diverse and complex market in courses. Often degree courses with different aims and academic standards share the same titles. And students are increasingly paying thousands of pounds in fees for degrees which promise to be the first crucial stepping stones to future careers. But academic institutions have been slow to reform ineffective and antiquated student complaints procedures. In 1997 the Dearing review of higher education called on universities to put in place independent external reviews of complaints within two years.

Old universities are still guided by the archaic visitorial system, where the institution appoints an official visitor, either the Queen's representative in the form of someone from the Lord Chancellor's office, or a high-standing bishop, to adjudicate over any grievances brought forward by students. Student complaints in new universities, meanwhile, are handled by someone from the institution's own board of governors.

Both arrangements are likely to fall foul of the new human rights legislation being passed through parliament later this year, which will give students the right to external independent reviews.

University heads are now being consulted on whether independent review panels can be established to hear student and staff complaints when all internal procedures have been exhausted. But for many this is too little too late. "There are fundamental flaws in the current system," says Jeremy Hoad, general secretary of the National Postgraduate Committee. "The complaints procedures for both old and new universities need radical reform."

Hoad says complaints procedures should adhere to a set of simple principles: clear information, transparent mechanisms and an understanding of the needs of students. "Justice must not only be done, but be seen to be done," he says. It is also time, Hoad says, for the government to take the bull by the horns and help push through the much-needed reforms. Recent plans by the university quality watchdog, the Quality Assurance Agency, to publish new guidelines for independent review panels for the higher education sector were thwarted because of the legal complexities of such a move for universities.

A working group on student complaints set up by universities is canvassing vice chancellors' views before issuing its own recommendations in September. "The essential characteristics of an independent review panel are that it should provide a swift, objective and fair forum for the resolution of the issues in contention," says a paper by the group. The panel chair, it says, should be a qualified lawyer, or legal advice should be made available on a commercial basis. "The independent review should be one of last resort," says the paper.

It argues there is no compelling case for a uniform system across the sector. "Higher education institutions must be free to opt for whatever arrangements are in harmony with their existing structures and particular needs." The paper also considers the idea of an official ombudsman, but says this may be an unacceptably expensive option, and would require new legislation.

To make matters worse for current students, cases against universities can only be taken to English and Welsh courts if all existing complaints procedures have been exhausted.

"Students are caught between a rock and a hard place," says Hoad.

webTitle: Great Bear's mantle passes to Woods

fields.headline: Great Bear's mantle passes to Woods
fields.standfirst: The US Open saw a defining moment in the game's history, writes David Davies
fields.trailText: The symbolism is both apparent and amazing. At the last US Open in which Jack Nicklaus, the greatest golfer the world has known, chooses to play, the man who may succeed, and exceed, him wins it for the first time. The Bear has ceased to growl; the Tiger's roar grows ever louder.
fields.body:
The symbolism is both apparent and amazing. At the last US Open in which Jack Nicklaus, the greatest golfer the world has known, chooses to play, the man who may succeed, and exceed, him wins it for the first time. The Bear has ceased to growl; the Tiger's roar grows ever louder.

Tiger Woods won the 100th US Open by a margin, 15 shots, never before contemplated, let alone accomplished. On a Pebble Beach course that allowed no one else to come within three shots of breaking par, Woods was 12 under and only Old Tom Morris, in winning the Open of 1862 by 13 shots, has been close to that record.

Woods has now won three majors - the 1997 US Masters by 12; the 1999 US PGA by one - and now this. Three major championships won by a total of 28 shots belongs in the realms of fantasy, not golf as we know it.

But then Woods, who could complete a career grand slam in the Open at St Andrews next month, plays a game "with which we are not familiar". Those last words were spoken of Nicklaus by Bobby Jones when the former won his first green jacket at the 1963 Masters. They were Jones' way of saying the torch had been passed.

Thirty-four years later, after Woods won his first Masters, Nicklaus bestowed his benediction on him. He said then: "It's a shame Bobby Jones isn't here. He could have saved the words for me in 1963 for this young man because he's play ing a game we're certainly not familiar with."

Never was that truer than this last week. Woods laid out his credentials on the first day with an impeccable 65, added rounds of 69 and 71 in a gale and, finally, a consummate 67 that never gave his pursuers a ghost of a chance. If it had not been such a wonderful exhibition of golf in all its glory, it would have been frightening.

Afterwards Hale Irwin, three times a US Open champion, pondered aloud the imponderable: would Nicklaus in the early 60s, with the same equipment, have dominated the game to the same extent? Nicklaus was dominant all right in terms of victories and the way he imposed his will on the rest of the players of the time but still did not win by 12 or 15 strokes, and the answer to the question is probably not.

The two players are almost identically armed when it comes to hitting the ball, with Nicklaus as far past his contemporaries then as Woods is today. They both came complete with an intense desire to win and, in Nicklaus's case, to surpass the 13 major championships won by Jones; in Woods' case to beat the mark of 18 established by Nicklaus.

The difference between them lies in one word: aggression. Nicklaus was content to win by stealth, to play the first three rounds purely as a positioning exercise and then, if necessary, bring the big guns to bear in the last. It usually worked, hence the 18 championships. But occasionally it did not, as when in 1972 he arrived at Muirfield needing to win the Open to hold all four major titles at the same time.

He played his usual waiting game and, incredibly, did not take the driver from his bag for the first three rounds. When it became necessary in the final round to produce a 64 to win he could manage only a 66 and came second to Lee Trevino.

Woods, as we saw last week and also in the 1997 Masters, where after three rounds he led by 10, is prepared to attack from the bell, bringing a whole new philosophy to the game. Good players like Lee Westwood, who has adopted the Nicklaus approach in many ways, will need to consider if it is good enough to keep up, or even hang on to the great man's coat-tails.

If Woods stays healthy it beggars belief how far he could go in golf, for no test has yet been imposed that he has not overcome. He won three US boys championships in succession, followed that with three US amateur championships in a row and, when he turned professional, his first stroke was a 336-yards drive that split the middle of the fairway: here I am, it said.

Since then he has worked interminable hours with Butch Harmon, his coach, making the swing more compact, tighter, with fewer moving parts. He still whiplashes through the ball like a bowstring in a fashion that would put most of us in traction but he now knows where the ball is going nearly all the time.

It was all too much, far too much, for the field at Pebble Beach. Ernie Els, joint-second with Miguel Angel Jimenez and twice a winner of the US Open while in his 20s, said afterwards: "I'm in awe. It was just a dominating performance. I played with him today and he played better in the final round than the rest of us by three or four shots. Whatever I say is going to be an understatement, so make up your own words, you're the journalists."

That, I fear, is going to be a problem for some time to come.
