JS: I am sorry that I'm not immediately familiar with the pay structure of the armed forces - but I will pass on your concerns to Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary and ask him to send you a reply. However, I applaud people who serve in the armed forces and can tell you that as a government we are committed to the proper defence of this country. MaxSurvise: If the home secretary realises that there is such furore over Pinochet's extradition, and countries as far as Belgium are vehemently protesting over him being sent home, why does he not feel compelled to review the case? The landmark indictment of the Chadian dictator on Friday was inspired by the Pinochet case. Perhaps Mr Straw could take note and also make history? JS: Of course I understand the strong feelings which people have about this case. However, my duty in this extradition case, as in any other, is to apply the law in the fairest way I can. JS: I'm sorry that I have to go. I've greatly enjoyed this conversation. I'll do my best to reply separately to some of the specific questions asked, but for which I have not had time to answer now. Best wishes, Jack Straw.

webTitle: Ulster Freedom Fighters - the thugs in hoods

fields.headline: Ulster Freedom Fighters - the thugs in hoods
fields.standfirst: The UFF's history of terrorism shows its latest threat to resume violence must be taken seriously, argues Derek Brown
fields.trailText: The UFF's history of terrorism shows its latest threat to resume violence must be taken seriously, argues Derek Brown.
fields.body:
The Ulster Freedom Fighters can trace their origins back to the early 1970s, when Northern Ireland was tumbling into the abyss of tribal warfare.

In one sense, the UFF has never truly existed as a separate organisation. Rather, it is the name used by members of the Ulster Defence Association to claim responsibility for sectarian killings, punishment shootings, and other violent acts.

The UDA was founded in September 1971, as an amalgam of local Protestant vigilante groups, many of which called themselves "defence associations". There were alarmist reports at the time of a new loyalist underground army, training to seize power. The truth was a good deal more prosaic - and ugly.

From the start, the new organisation was determinedly working class. Its supporters were sickened by the inability of the Unionist establishment to maintain order, and resentful of the meddling of the British government. There is a strong whiff of Northern Ireland independence about many of the loyalist paramilitary gangs, and the UDA/UFF is no exception.

The group was formed to protect Protestant districts against republican attack. It was also the product of frustration with the decayed state of the Ulster Volunteer Force, which had claimed to be doing the same job since before the first world war.

Just as the Provisional IRA was founded from the debris of the Official IRA, so the UDA/UFF drew its inspiration, and many of its recruits, from the UVF. But there the similarities ended. From the outset, the Provisionals saw the security forces as their main enemy. The loyalist paramilitaries, lacking such a defined and visible target, chose most of their victims at random from the Catholic population.

The UDA started as a genuinely popular movement, able to parade thousands of men in Belfast and, especially in the early days, Londonderry. It threw its considerable muscle into the protests which followed the imposition of direct rule by Westminster in 1972, and in 1974 was one of the major components in the Ulster Workers' Council strike which brought down the first power-sharing government.

By that time the initials UFF had started to appear on the graffiti-laden walls of Belfast, and in the bombastic communiques admitting killing and maiming Catholics. From 1993, the group has carried out scores of random shootings and executions. Some of its victims have been its own members who turned Queen's evidence or "deserted" to a rival group.

The UFF was proscribed in the late 1970s, though the UDA remained a legal organisation until as late as 1992. That to some extent reflected the profound split in the movement between the politically-inclined leadership and the militants who wanted to carry their war to the republicans - and carve themselves out some lucrative rackets at the same time.

The movement was always wracked by feuding. In the 1970s there was a protracted dispute between the hard men of west Belfast, led by Andy Tyrie, and a wild bunch of killers in east Belfast, led by Tommy Herron. It ended only when Herron's bullet-riddled body was found in the trunk of his car.

Throughout the 1980s the UDA dwindled as a mass movement, but slowly evolved as a political one. The Ulster Democratic party, founded in 1989, is the product of that process.

The UFF, meanwhile, remains in business in a sporadic kind of way. It was one of the loyalist groups which declared a ceasefire in 1994, following a similar declaration by the IRA. But over the winter of 1997-98, following a series of republican outrages, the UFF broke the truce. Its resumption of the ceasefire, in January 1998, was accompanied by a warning that it would remain ready to respond to further republican violence.

That threat, just like the one delivered today, is not an idle one. The group is much smaller than the IRA, and has been weakened in recent years by its feuds with other loyalist gangs. But it is thought still to have a formidable arsenal of around 200 automatic weapons, and a cache of commercial plastic explosives.

fields.headline: UFF threatens to abandon ceasefire
fields.trailText: The Ulster Freedom Fighters today threatened to shoot nationalist attackers from midnight tonight if raids on Belfast protestants' homes did not stop, in the biggest threat to the loyalist ceasefire since it began in October 1994.
fields.body:
The Ulster Freedom Fighters today threatened to shoot nationalist attackers from midnight tonight if raids on Belfast protestants' homes did not stop, in the biggest threat to the loyalist ceasefire since it began in October 1994.

Hooded and armed UFF men delivered a statement saying the group could not stand by and watch while intimidation drove protestants out of their homes in the north and west of the city.

At a secret location in the staunchly loyalist Shankill Road area of west Belfast, the UFF claimed that since loyalist groups called a ceasefire various areas of the city had endured "a systematic or orchestrated campaign of intimidation from nationalists".

Its statement added: "This ethnic cleansing of north and west Belfast cannot and will not be allowed to happen.

"From 12.00 tonight, 20th June 2000, the UFF reserves the right to shoot any person seen to be attacking protestant homes. This will be in direct contradiction to our ceasefire, which we have steadfastly adhered to despite intense provocation, but enough is enough."

"We cannot stand idly by and watch while protestants are intimidated out of their homes."

Its statement concluded by calling on nationalists in Belfast, including Sinn Fein, SDLP and community leaders, to "put a stop to this ethnic cleansing campaign before our hand is forced".

John White, of the Unionist Democratic party which is aligned with the UFF and its associated Ulster Defence Association, commented: "I think it can have very serious implications.

"The UFF have signed up to a no first strike policy and this action here seems to contradict that."

Mr White also appealed to nationalist leaders to act to stop the intimidation, which he said was an orchestrated nationalist action to put protestants out of their homes. He said: "If we can come together there will be no need for guns to be brought out."

The SDLP West Belfast assembly member Alex Atwood condemned the UFF statement and said it was a cynical attempt to raise tensions in the marching season.

Mr Atwood said: "There is no justification whatsoever for any organisation breaking any ceasefire on any pretext and that is the wish of the people of the North and of north and west Belfast."

He said the UFF were "looking for a pretext to justify being more active in the marching season" and it was nothing more than a cynical ploy. He predicted republicans and the wider community would not be provoked by the actions of those who "can't accept the new political order".

The full statement

"The Ulster Freedom Fighters Second Battalion West Belfast Brigade are coming under increasing pressure from within our community to protect the beleaguered protestants on interface areas in north and west Belfast.

"Since the ceasefires areas such as the Oldpark, Rosapenna Street, White City, Alliance, Limestone Road and Lanark Way have had to endure a systematic orchestrated campaign of intimidation from nationalists.

"Pensioners in these areas are suffering the most. This ethnic cleansing of north and west Belfast cannot and will not be allowed to happen.

"From 12 o'clock tonight June 20th 2000 the UFF reserves the right to shoot any person seen to be attacking protestant homes. This will be in direct contradiction to our ceasefire, which we have steadfastly adhered to despite intense provocation, but enough is enough.

"We cannot stand idly by and watch while protestants are intimidated out of their homes. We are calling on nationalists from these interface areas, be they Sinn Fein, SDLP or community leaders to put a stop to this ethnic cleansing campaign before our hand is forced."

webTitle: Brit actors line up for Harry Potter

fields.headline: Brit actors line up for Harry Potter
fields.trailText: Following last week's news that Dame Maggie Smith could be taking a key role in the Harry Potter movie, today we hear that two more big-name British actors, Robbie Coltrane and Tim Roth are also up for parts
fields.body:
The excitement around the casting of the Harry Potter movie continues, and following last week's news that Dame Maggie Smith could be taking a key role, today we hear that two more big-name British actors, Robbie Coltrane and Tim Roth are also up for parts.

The 49-year-old Coltrane has become a firm favourite of cinema audiences for his role of the Russian black marketeer Valentin Dmitrovich Zukovsky in two James Bond adventures.

He is now in negotiations for £250,000 to play the large friendly giant Hagrid, the game-keeper at Harry Potter's school Hogwarts, who gets kicked out under mysterious circumstances.

Tim Roth is in talks to play the Harry Potter-hating Professor Snape. Snape is the mysterious potions teacher who has it in for Harry as soon as the young wizard-in-training arrives at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry.

Roth is due to start work soon on his second directorial effort, a Harold Pinter adaptation of King Lear.

The search meanwhile continues for the child to play Harry Potter. The families of 2,000 boys have written to the film's makers, who say they will be seeing up to 5,000 hopefuls before making a final decision.

fields.headline: Labour stalls on Lords timetable
fields.standfirst:
Beckett signals no reform before election
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The government served notice yesterday that it has no  intention of stepping up the pace of House of Lords  reform, prompting accusations that the issue has been  "kicked into the long grass".
fields.body:
The government served notice yesterday that it has no intention of stepping up the pace of House of Lords reform, prompting accusations that the issue has been "kicked into the long grass".

In the first Commons debate of the year on the future of the Lords, opposition MPs rounded on the government after ministers failed to indicate when they will set up a joint committee of MPs and peers to oversee reform.

Margaret Beckett, leader of the Commons, said that the committee - a Labour manifesto pledge - would be set up "in due course". Asked whether this could be before the general election, she said: "I would anticipate that. But there is a considerable period of time before that."

Her remarks, in the first Commons debate since publication in January of the royal commission report on Lords reform, indicated that ministers are unlikely to embrace further changes to the upper chamber until well after the next election.

Mrs Beckett said that the cross-party royal commission, which was chaired by the former Tory cabinet minister Lord Wakeham, "may" form the basis of further lords reform.

Sir George Young, the shadow leader of the house, said Mrs Beckett's remarks showed that the government has no idea of how to press ahead with reform, even though ministers gave themselves five months to respond to the Wakeham report. "We can see the long grass opening up to embrace this report," Sir George said.

The royal commission was set up by ministers to consider proposals for the "second stage" of Lords reform after the majority of hereditary peers were removed last year.

The 12-member commission called for members of the up per house to be largely nominated by an independent appointments commission, stripping the prime minister of one of his most important powers of patronage. There would be a balance of political opinion to reflect the results of the latest general election, although no party would have an overall majority. The commission said that a minority of members should be elected, but refused to say how many.

Mrs Beckett told MPs yesterday that ministers were "minded to accept the broad outlines" of the Wakeham proposals. But she said the government first wanted to listen to the views of MPs from both sides of the house.

Watched by Lord Wakeham, sitting in the peers' gallery, Mrs Beckett indicated that ministers would opt for Wakeham's lowest recommendation of the number of elected members because the government was determined to prevent the new chamber from challenging the Commons.

webTitle: Banning England would be doing everyone a favour

fields.headline: Banning England would be doing everyone a favour
fields.standfirst:
We have run out of alibis and the best course is a retreat from battle
Football violence: special report
Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: We have run out of alibis and the best course is a retreat from battle.
fields.body:
The man from the Football Association had this to say: "We have done everything in our power to eradicate the problem." David Davies was huffing and bleating, sounding like a victim. Quite apart from his odious whinnying, what he said wasn't, in the end, true.

There is one other thing the FA could do, which is to wind up its own function at the helm of English football's international relations. Such a dramatic heresy is beyond the range of Mr Davies' imagination. But these relations should cease to be. English football has become a threat to England, a curse on football, a menace to the citizens of every country where it's played: and in Belgium, June 2000, it has run out of alibis.

The alibis have been prolific. The yobs are only a minority, it was said. Other countries' fans are as bad as some of ours. We are not unique. Society in general may be at fault, football in general may be at fault, but English football and English society are not at fault. The showdowns in Brussels and Charleroi should bury these comforting myths. It's the only positive outcome of a shaming weekend. We are the experts in drunken violence, racist aggression, head-banging nationalism, copycat provocation, serial thuggery, and the snivelling whine about other people's policemen. History, culture and politics all make their contribution to this uniqueness.

History shows the English to be military people, always ready for a fight. Also a belligerent people, defending what they conceive to be their national pride. They may be lots of other things too. The cliches attribute fairness, toleration, stoicism and a love of animals to the British, and even the English. These qualities exist, but are irrelevant to the present case. They no longer efface the other things the English are known for: much more intrusive things, more aggressive, more defiantly uncivil, all drawn together by football with an inevitability that now makes it possible to generalise without fear of plausible contradiction.

Not many of the football sots and oafs may read much history. It doesn't take prime place in the national curriculum. But they get the crucial bits from the tabloids they read, modern annals that are prime accessories in football's degradation of England. Derision of foreigners and hatred of their projects is a tabloid stock in trade. Smarming piously about morons and cretinous yobbos, the Sun yesterday extended Britain's apologies to "the Belgians and the Germans, to the Dutch and the Portuguese", expecting the world to forget the years of bile and gallons of ink about the Huns and the Frogs it has poured into the unresisting minds of the same simpletons and cretins brought up to suppose that Brits can do no wrong.

In a national culture that had some respect for refinement, or any capacity for perspective, these triumphalist incitements of history might be tamed. Instead they are amplified. The English have put lottery money to the service of high culture, and 25,000 people a day are going to Tate Modern. But high art remains minority stuff. Mass culture stretches from football to sex, via rock music. Humoured by the chattering classes, footie is legitimised as a great populist art form, sentimentalised as the gratification of classless allegiance, exalted as a stage for Eric Cantona, football's answer to Charles Baudelaire.

B ut, actually, football in England is not just exploited but dominated by practitioners of yob culture. Pitiable though the discovery may be for others, lovers of violence threaten every football occasion. Violence, latent if not open, is the leitmotif. Not true of rugby, under either code, nor of all-day lager-swilling cricket. Football, by contrast, offers violence against foreigners as its custom, racial groups a speciality. Such vileness reaches deep into the sport, as we saw when hundreds of new fans, hitherto unknown to police intelligence, were this week drawn effortlessly into street battles they seemed to feel it their cultural duty to conduct. The reasons for this may be hard to fathom. Treatises on the point will continue to abound. But the mystery can no longer be a reason to deny, still less explain away, the unarguable facts witnessed in Brussels' Grande Place.

Before these facts, the politicians quail. They too, after all, have played a constructive part. Margaret Thatcher, the mother of materialistic individualism, legitimised macho yobbery. Excessive liberalism made its contribution to the breakdown of social respect and the collapse of the principle of duty. Now the apostles of Blairism claim their respect for civil liberties is all that stopped them from containing the thugs by removal of far more passports, as Uefa as well as the governments of Belgium and the Netherlands long ago requested.

This is an unbelievable explanation. Ministers who want to legislate against the right to hunt foxes shrink from a law that would give them a better chance of pre-empting football violence? On grounds of civil rights? These ministers, we should recall, also summoned parliament for a one-day emergency sitting in September 1998 to pass a law, the terrorism and conspiracy bill, handing over the civil rights of suspect terrorists to the mere opinions of policemen and politicians about their guilt or innocence. A grotesque corruption of legal order. Whatever else prevented the Home Office from establishing a legal regime whereby people reasonably suspected of an intent to commit violence at Euro 2000 could be stopped from travelling, it had nothing to do with the rights of man.

More likely it was administrative incompetence, combined with excessive reverence for the god of English football, a key New Labour icon. The Germans have listed 7,000 suspects, and stopped many of them. For the Brits to do likewise would have violated the pledge that our police intelligence is wonderful, and compromised the myth that we are fit to put on the World Cup. A law creating police powers to stop potential hooligans travelling for a fortnight would not have been an unacceptably draconian answer to the indiscriminate mayhem of which Belgians must now live in nightly fear. It would have produced some rough justice, but there is rougher justice to be seen in every court every day.

As it is we now scramble to impress Uefa with promises of life bans after the horses have bolted. Jack Straw joins David Davies in a desperate effort to ward off the unthinkable, the elimination of English football and the culture it breeds and gratifies from the scene where its cancerous nature has now become incontrovertibly apparent.

Such a removal would be humiliating for the politicians, and a day of doom for the FA. But Uefa could do the English a favour, if they won't decide to do it themselves. We need to recognise that we are very special: incapable of marrying our national sport and national culture without doing intolerable damage to the civic order of more civilised nations. The better course is retreat from battle, before we become famous for nothing else.

In a national culture that had some respect for refinement, or any capacity for perspective, these triumphalist incitements of history might be tamed. Instead they are amplified. The English have put lottery money to the service of high culture, and 25,000 people a day are going to Tate Modern. But high art remains minority stuff. Mass culture stretches from football to sex, via rock music. Humoured by the chattering classes, footie is legitimised as a great populist art form, sentimentalised as the gratification of classless allegiance, exalted as a stage for Eric Cantona, football's answer to Charles Baudelaire. B ut, actually, football in England is not just exploited but dominated by practitioners of yob culture. Pitiable though the discovery may be for others, lovers of violence threaten every football occasion. Violence, latent if not open, is the leitmotif. Not true of rugby, under either code, nor of all-day lager-swilling cricket. Football, by contrast, offers violence against foreigners as its custom, racial groups a speciality. Such vileness reaches deep into the sport, as we saw when hundreds of new fans, hitherto unknown to police intelligence, were this week drawn effortlessly into street battles they seemed to feel it their cultural duty to conduct. The reasons for this may be hard to fathom. Treatises on the point will continue to abound. But the mystery can no longer be a reason to deny, still less explain away, the unarguable facts witnessed in Brussels' Grande Place. Before these facts, the politicians quail. They too, after all, have played a constructive part. Margaret Thatcher, the mother of materialistic individualism, legitimised macho yobbery. Excessive liberalism made its contribution to the breakdown of social respect and the collapse of the principle of duty. Now the apostles of Blairism claim their respect for civil liberties is all that stopped them from containing the thugs by removal of far more passports, as Uefa as well as the governments of Belgium and the Netherlands long ago requested. This is an unbelievable explanation. Ministers who want to legislate against the right to hunt foxes shrink from a law that would give them a better chance of pre-empting football violence? On grounds of civil rights? These ministers, we should recall, also summoned parliament for a one-day emergency sitting in September 1998 to pass a law, the terrorism and conspiracy bill, handing over the civil rights of suspect terrorists to the mere opinions of policemen and politicians about their guilt or innocence. A grotesque corruption of legal order. Whatever else prevented the Home Office from establishing a legal regime whereby people reasonably suspected of an intent to commit violence at Euro 2000 could be stopped from travelling, it had nothing to do with the rights of man. More likely it was administrative incompetence, combined with excessive reverence for the god of English football, a key New Labour icon. The Germans have listed 7,000 suspects, and stopped many of them. For the Brits to do likewise would have violated the pledge that our police intelligence is wonderful, and compromised the myth that we are fit to put on the World Cup. A law creating police powers to stop potential hooligans travelling for a fortnight would not have been an unacceptably draconian answer to the indiscriminate mayhem of which Belgians must now live in nightly fear. It would have produced some rough justice, but there is rougher justice to be seen in every court every day. As it is we now scramble to impress Uefa with promises of life bans after the horses have bolted. Jack Straw joins David Davies in a desperate effort to ward off the unthinkable, the elimination of English football and the culture it breeds and gratifies from the scene where its cancerous nature has now become incontrovertibly apparent. Such a removal would be humiliating for the politicians, and a day of doom for the FA. But Uefa could do the English a favour, if they won't decide to do it themselves. We need to recognise that we are very special: incapable of marrying our national sport and national culture without doing intolerable damage to the civic order of more civilised nations. The better course is retreat from battle, before we become famous for nothing else. hugoyoung@compuserve.com Useful links Euro 2000 Official site Football Association National Criminal Intelligence Service

fields.headline: Austria's isolation in Europe
fields.standfirst:
At this week's summit in Portugal, European Union states have rebuffed Austria's attempts to end its political isolation. Derek Brown explains why
Special report
fields.trailText: At this week's summit in Portugal, European Union states have rebuffed Austria's attempts to end its political isolation. We explain why.
fields.body:
Why are the other Europeans upset with Austria?
They are queasy about the inclusion of the far-right Freedom party in the coalition government led by Chancellor Wolfgang Schussel. The party surged into second place behind the Social Democrats in last autumn's elections, with 27% of the vote.

Most of the unease centres on the Freedom party's former leader - and potential candidate for the chancellorship - Jörg Haider.

Why is Haider disliked?
He has a reputation as an apologist for the Nazis. Though he is on record as branding Hitler's third reich as a criminal regime, he has praised the SS. Most controversially, he has described concentration camps as "penal camps".

In a TV debate last year he compared the deportation of Jews to the Nazi death camps with the expulsion of Sudetan Germans from Czechoslovakia after the second world war.

What is Haider's background?
Born in the upper Austrian town of Bad Goisern in 1950, he studied law in Vienna. He became leader of the Freedom party in 1986, when the party could barely scrape together 5% of the vote in parliamentary elections. He became provincial governor of Carinthia in 1989, but was forced to resign two years later, after publicly praising the employment policies of Nazi Germany.

What does the Freedom Party stand for?
In last year's elections, the charismatic Haider campaigned vigorously for an end to immigration - in a country that has virtually none. He is also tough on crime, though Austria has an enviably low crime rate.

He wants a referendum to haul his country out of the European single currency, and is adamantly opposed to the enlargement of the European Union. Although the latter policies are anathema to most EU governments, it was his populist "Austria-for the Austrians" line which propelled his party to a share of power.

Are the EU sanctions hurting the Austrian economy?
Hardly at all, though there are fears that the tough talking on both sides could deter tourists.

Mostly, the sanctions are a blow to Austrian pride. The country which sees itself as the embodiment of central European civilisation is being cold-shouldered in ministerial meetings and barred from cultural and sports events. These symbolic snubs are bitterly resented by the coalition government, which had hoped that the European Council summit in Portugal this week would relax the measures or even drop them.

Are the Austrians hitting back?
They say they will block EU enlargement and important institutional reforms unless there is more "constructive cooperation" among the existing member states.

And in a separate dispute which has been made more rancorous by the row over sanctions, Austria has adamantly opposed a common tax on interest earned by Europeans with savings in other countries. (That tax is also fiercely opposed by Britain, on the grounds that it could severely damage the City of London as the de facto financial capital of Europe.)

webTitle: Mandy: a dirty job, but great furnishings

fields.headline: Mandy: a dirty job, but great furnishings
fields.standfirst: The Northern Ireland secretary of state's home may occasionally come under attack, but as  John O'Farrell recounts, it is not a bad place to relax
fields.trailText: The Northern Ireland secretary of state's home may occasionally come under attack, but as  John O'Farrell recounts, it is not a bad place to relax
fields.body:
"I feel safe and secure," said the secretary of state for Northern Ireland, Peter Mandelson, in Cork, 300 miles away from his residence of Hillsborough Castle. Army bomb disposal experts were combing the eight acres of Mandelson's official residence after a farmer discovered a crude home-made bomb in the grounds.

The explosive device, which had "partially exploded", is believed to have been thrown over the walls of the grounds weeks earlier, possibly by republican dissidents. If so, the device was probably intended to disrupt a planned garden party for victims of the Troubles, which was attended by the Prince of Wales last Tuesday.

It was during the visit by Prince Charles that the secretary of state came as close as he ever will to injury, or at least embarrassment, when a police dog snarled at him during a morale boosting mission to the RUC drugs squad in Ballymena, Co Antrim.

The secretary of state is very well defended. Everywhere he goes in Ulster he is flanked by three tall men. The two with earpieces and muscles are to catch any bullet or missile with Mandy's name on it. The tall skinny one, who seems have a rare condition which causes him to nod his head sagely whenever the secretary of state speaks, is Tom Kelly, the director of information at the Northern Ireland office. His job is to prevent any inquiring question reaching the ears of his master.

According to "friends" of the previous occupant of Hillsborough, Mo Mowlam, the greatest threat to the secretary of state is internal. Ms Mowlam was plagued by a series of damaging leaks while in office. Somebody in Stormont did not like her and fed the DUP with a series of embarrassing documents from her office, the best of which was Tom Kelly's masterplan on how to manipulate the media ahead of the 1998 referendum on the Belfast Agreement.

The paramilitaries have been more of an embarrassment to the secretary of state than a danger. The IRA may have come close to killing the then secretary of state Peter Brooke in 1991, but that was nothing personal, so to speak. The occasion was the IRA's mortar attack on John Major's entire cabinet as they discussed the Gulf War in Downing Street.

The most serious incident involved Roy Mason, who the Provos hated almost as much as Mason hated them. In August, the Queen's visit to the Coleraine campus of the University of Ulster could have ended in disaster, when the IRA planted a bomb in the grounds with a long-term timing device. The IRA issued a warning on the morning of the visit, which was ignored, they claim, by Mason, who gambled that it was a hoax. Luckily, the IRA's bombmakers had yet to master their new technology, and the bomb exploded at 11pm, hours after the royal party and guests had departed. The intended time of detonation was 11am, just before the visit was due to begin.

It's not as if Mason and the RUC could assume the IRA were bluffing. The entire itinerary of the Royal visit was printed on the front page of that week's Republican News.

The only other time that a secretary of state came close to injury was the occasion of a visit to Belfast City Hall, days after the signing of the Anglo-Irish Agreement in November 1985. Tom "Cat" King was chased around the car park by two DUP stalwarts, George Seawright and Jim Wells, now an Assembly member for South Down. Seawright, who was later shot dead by the INLA, tried to make his protest at the "Diktat", as unionists called the AIA, by attempting to clobber King with a large Union flag on a big stick.

The unfortunate Tom King was later the alleged victim of an IRA conspiracy in 1988, when three Irish students were arrested close to his residence, and later sentenced to long prison sentences for conspiracy to murder "persons unknown". A campaign was started to free the "Winchester Three", due to the flimsy evidence used to convict them. During the trial in Winchester, King made remarks about "abuse of the right to silence", which formed the basis of the judgment by the appeal judge, Lord Beldam. He released the two men and one woman, saying that King's remarks had prejudiced the case. In a fit of pique, the Home Office served all three with exclusion orders as they left the appeal court, and they were immediately deported to Dublin.

Being Northern Ireland secretary means living with a potential threat for ever. Roy Mason still has 24-hour protection. The job is not exactly appreciated by the unionist and nationalist politicians who will blame the Brits for everything that goes wrong.

On the bright side, however, in Westminster it is viewed as an impossible job, but the blame for that usually falls on the natives, rather than the competence of the postholder.

Plus there are the three residences: a nice flat in Whitehall, an odd 19th century neogothic pile called Stormont Castle, and the huge spread in the colour-brochure prettiness of Hillsborough village. Mandy can, and does, impress his London chums with weekend "do"s in Hillsborough - just don't ask who foots the bill. The story goes that at one such do, his puppy, Bobby, made a doggy comment on the rich food, all across the carpet. "Don't worry," Mandelson is said to have said, "just get some bleach and I'll rub out the stain." His (civil) servants had to inform him that the rug was over 200 years old, and would have to be sent to specialist cleaners, at a cost of hundreds of pounds.

Another expensive floor story concerns Mandelson's flat in Notting Hill Gate, the one bought from the profits on his Hampstead house. The taxpayer coughed up for bullet-proof windows and bomb-proof floors and ceilings, which also insulate against cold and noise, as well as potential terrorists in the downstairs flat. It is good to know, that when the job gets stressful, the secretary of state has a quiet place to go.

fields.headline: Racism fine for Brigitte Bardot
fields.trailText: Racism fine for Brigitte Bardot
fields.body:
Former sex siren and animal rights campaigner Brigitte
Bardot has been fined 30,000 francs (£3,000) after
being convicted of inciting racial hatred - for the
third time. The former movie star was found guilty in
a Paris court over remarks made about the number of
Muslim immigrants in her native France.

Her latest outburst came in a book written last year
called Le Carre de Pluton (Pluto's Square). In it, she
criticises a Muslim festival, in which sheep are
ritually slaughtered. Writes Bardot: "My country,
France, my homeland, my land is again invaded by an
overpopulation of foreigners, especially Muslims."

Bardot, 66, became an international sex symbol in 1956
after starring in the film And God Created Woman. But
it's some 30 years since her last film. She
established the Foundation for the Protection of
Distressed Animals in 1976 and has made it her life's
work. Her previous convictions for the incitement of
racial hatred came in 1997 and 1998, when she was
again fined for making comparably inflammatory
comments.
fields.bodyText: Former sex siren and animal rights campaigner Brigitte Bardot has been fined 30,000 francs (£3,000) after being convicted of inciting racial hatred - for the third time. The former movie star was found guilty in a Paris court over remarks made about the number of Muslim immigrants in her native France. Her latest outburst came in a book written last year called Le Carre de Pluton (Pluto's Square). In it, she criticises a Muslim festival, in which sheep are ritually slaughtered. Writes Bardot: "My country, France, my homeland, my land is again invaded by an overpopulation of foreigners, especially Muslims." Bardot, 66, became an international sex symbol in 1956 after starring in the film And God Created Woman. But it's some 30 years since her last film. She established the Foundation for the Protection of Distressed Animals in 1976 and has made it her life's work. Her previous convictions for the incitement of racial hatred came in 1997 and 1998, when she was again fined for making comparably inflammatory comments.

fields.headline: Phone selloff brings government £12bn surplus
fields.trailText: Britain's public finances showed an impressive  £12bn surplus last month as the first receipts from the auction of mobile phone licences poured into the government's coffers, according to official figures published today.
fields.body:
Britain's public finances showed an impressive £12bn surplus last month as the first receipts from the auction of mobile phone licences poured into the government's coffers, according to official figures published today.

The result is the biggest May surplus on record and compares with a £6.6bn surplus in April and a £1.7bn deficit in May 1999. The increase comes from the payment of £12.4bn by the first three of the winning five bidders in the £22.5bn selloff of third generation mobile phone licences.

However, the government's preferred measure of the underlying state of the public finances - public sector net borrowing - showed a deficit of £2.2bn for May.

Today's figures are likely to fuel debate over the government's decision to use the surplus to pay off part of Britain's £321.8bn national debt. In his Mansion House speech last week chancellor Gordon Brown reaffirmed his commitment to what he called his "golden rule" - that the current budget, which sets revenues against expenditure, should be balanced over the economic cycle.

This means that the government must manage spending in a way which reduces the £2.2bn deficit without taking into account the income from the sale of the mobile licences.

The Treasury has announced that although it will receive payments for the mobile licences up front, it will treat the income as rent and account for it over 21 years.

webTitle: US seeks war crime amnesty for Serb leader

fields.headline: US seeks war crime amnesty for Serb leader
fields.standfirst:
China is seen as haven if Milosevic gives up power

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: It bombed his home, put a bounty on his head and branded him a monster who could never be forgiven, but the United States is quietly seeking a way out for Slobodan Milosevic that would leave his bank account intact.
fields.byline: Rory Carroll, Julian Borger in Washington and Helena Smith in Athens
fields.body:
It bombed his home, put a bounty on his head and branded him a monster who could never be forgiven, but the United States is quietly seeking a way out for Slobodan Milosevic that would leave his bank account intact.

Despite denials, US officials are considering ways to allow the Yugoslav president to leave office without a war crimes trial at the Hague. In what may turn out to be the Balkan endgame, the US is signalling the possibility of a secure retirement for the man blamed for setting Yugoslavia aflame.

Amid reports that Mr Milosevic is transferring his family fortune to China, officials leaked claims that his emissaries have approached Washington and Athens with proposals for his ceding power in exchange for an amnesty.

The war crimes tribunal in the Hague insisted yesterday that the Yugoslav leader would have nowhere to hide, but President Bill Clinton's yearning for a historic legacy is said to be opening doors to a deal.

The US is using Greece as an intermediary to discuss bolt holes, the New York Times reported yesterday.

"If we were presented with a hard and fast offer that would get Milosevic out of power, we'd have to think very hard before saying no," a senior US administration official said.

The revelation follows rumours in Belgrade that Mr Milosevic wants out, exhausted by defeat in Kosovo, indict ment by the Hague and economic meltdown.

His wife, Mira Markovic, haunted by the fate of Romania's executed first couple, Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu, fears that events are spinning out of control, according to leaks from their tight circle of friends. Mr Milosevic's political allies have been assassinated in a wave of unexplained shootings.

At the beginning of the year and with Washington's blessing, Greece dispatched envoys to Belgrade to discuss exit scenarios for him and his family. The former Greek prime minister, Constantine Mitsotakis, is willing to act as an interlocutor between the west and Mr Milosevic, his "close friend" and sailing partner.

Mr Mitsotakis, who belongs to the opposition New Democracy party, has a reputation as the only western politician the Yugoslav leader trusts.

Last week Mr Mitsotakis reportedly vowed to undertake the mission if the US guaranteed that it was serious and that he was not made an "international laughing stock".

Denying the New York Times report, the state department yesterday repeated the official position tha Washington would never contemplate offering Mr Milosevic an amnesty from war crimes.

Any international amnesty deal behind the back of the Hague tribunal would seriously undermine its authority in administering justice in the wake of the Croatian, Bosnian and Kosovo wars.

Last year the US slapped down opposition leaders in Serbia who sought to arrange an asylum deal for Mr Milosevic as a means of ensuring a peaceful transition of power.

"If there is any place where he seeks sanctuary, I would recommend the Hague," the US defence secretary, William Cohen, said at the time. Washington has offered a $5m reward for information leading to Mr Milosevic's arrest and delivery to the Hague tribunal.

One year on, however, the Serbian opposition remains as divided as ever and apparently no closer to ousting Mr Milosevic under its own steam. Disillusionment has made the people of Belgrade sceptical of suggestions that he may step down. The rumours tend to be believed only by senior opposition figures. "Wishful thinking. They've screwed it up so that's all they've left," said one Belgrade shop assistant.

But the Clinton administration is running out of time, and is deeply concerned about its final balance sheet. Greek officials at the foreign ministry said they believed Mr Milosevic was biding his time until the US presidential election - a view echoed in Belgrade - in the hope of a Republican victory.

A British diplomat said the Clinton administration's hopes were deluded. "I don't see why he would do it. It's more dangerous for him to quit than it is to stay put."

Once he cedes power Mr Milosevic will lose all his bargaining chips. Though he is beleaguered, the official opposition in Serbia is in disarray and unpopular. The police and army remain loyal. Street protests have fizzled out.

One Nato country official insisted, however, that an amnesty was on the cards, saying: "It's in the best solution for everyone, and they [Nato] could spin it as victory. There is a strong argument that democracy should be put ahead of the person."

Greece, Belarus and Iraq are believed to be among countries ready to provide a haven. Shortly after the Bosnian war the Serb monastery on the self-governing Republic of Mount Athos, in northern Greece, prepared accommodation for Radovan Karadzic and General Ratko Mladic, though both remained in Serbia.

According to the Serb opposition leader, Zoran Djindjic, Mr Milosevic has also been offered asylum in China. Of all possible bolt-holes, that is the most likely. His son, Marko, is believed to have recently flown to Beijing to negotiate transfers of family funds with officials in the government, with which his mother's Marxist party, the Yugoslav United Left, enjoys excellent relations.

Chinese money has been pouring into Belgrade since the end of the Kosovo bombing. Advertisements in China encouraging nationals to emigrate have increased the number of Chinese people living in Serbia to nearly 100,000.

However last year's indictment as a war criminal would complicate any deal. James Landale, the Hague tribunal's spokesman, said yesterday: "The mandate of the tribunal is handed down by the security council. All states are obliged to cooperate. Anyone who is indicted is indicted for life. No one can nullify or dismiss an indictment, other than the security council."

Any package deal for Mr Milosevic will have to include his unceasingly loyal wife. "My husband is a perfect man," she wrote in her regular column in a women's magazine.

The war leaders: at home, in prison - or dead

 Radovan Karadzic The Bosnian Serb wartime leader who was charged with crimes against humanity and genocide is still living in seclusion in his home in Pale. The S-For peacekeeping troops patrolling the area have been reluctant to storm his house for fear of casualties.

 Ratko Mladic The Bosnian Serbs' top general, who is living in retirement in the Yugoslav capital, is also wanted for genocide. He commanded the constant shelling of Sarajevo and the massacre of more than 7,000 Muslim men from Srebrenica. His full address is: 119 Blagoja Parovica, Banovo Brdo, Belgrade. He likes to go to horse races and football matches, and continues to draw a monthly pension from the Yugoslav government.

 Zeljko Raznjatovic, known as Arkan. The leader of the paramilitary group the Tigers was charged last year in a sealed indictment, which was thought to include his role in massacres in Croatia in 1991, Bosnia in 1992 and possibly in Kosovo last year. He was gunned down in a Belgrade hotel soon after the indictment was issued. At the time of his murder, he had been exploring his options, sounding out at least one western country for asylum.

 Momcilo Krajisnik Karadzic's right-hand man, and the most senior war crimes suspect to have been captured by Nato troops and delivered to the Hague, in April this year. He is accused of genocide and crimes against humanity for his part in implementing a policy of ethnic cleansing across Bosnia from 1991 to 1995.

 Dusan Tadic Convicted on 11 war crimes counts by the Hague tribunal in 1997 for his part in running the horrific Omarska camp in the Bosnian Serb Republic where inmates, mostly Muslims, were tortured, raped and killed. He is currently appealing against his sentence.
fields.bodyText: It bombed his home, put a bounty on his head and branded him a monster who could never be forgiven, but the United States is quietly seeking a way out for Slobodan Milosevic that would leave his bank account intact. Despite denials, US officials are considering ways to allow the Yugoslav president to leave office without a war crimes trial at the Hague. In what may turn out to be the Balkan endgame, the US is signalling the possibility of a secure retirement for the man blamed for setting Yugoslavia aflame. Amid reports that Mr Milosevic is transferring his family fortune to China, officials leaked claims that his emissaries have approached Washington and Athens with proposals for his ceding power in exchange for an amnesty. The war crimes tribunal in the Hague insisted yesterday that the Yugoslav leader would have nowhere to hide, but President Bill Clinton's yearning for a historic legacy is said to be opening doors to a deal. The US is using Greece as an intermediary to discuss bolt holes, the New York Times reported yesterday. "If we were presented with a hard and fast offer that would get Milosevic out of power, we'd have to think very hard before saying no," a senior US administration official said. The revelation follows rumours in Belgrade that Mr Milosevic wants out, exhausted by defeat in Kosovo, indict ment by the Hague and economic meltdown. His wife, Mira Markovic, haunted by the fate of Romania's executed first couple, Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu, fears that events are spinning out of control, according to leaks from their tight circle of friends. Mr Milosevic's political allies have been assassinated in a wave of unexplained shootings. At the beginning of the year and with Washington's blessing, Greece dispatched envoys to Belgrade to discuss exit scenarios for him and his family. The former Greek prime minister, Constantine Mitsotakis, is willing to act as an interlocutor between the west and Mr Milosevic, his "close friend" and sailing partner. Mr Mitsotakis, who belongs to the opposition New Democracy party, has a reputation as the only western politician the Yugoslav leader trusts. Last week Mr Mitsotakis reportedly vowed to undertake the mission if the US guaranteed that it was serious and that he was not made an "international laughing stock". Denying the New York Times report, the state department yesterday repeated the official position tha Washington would never contemplate offering Mr Milosevic an amnesty from war crimes. Any international amnesty deal behind the back of the Hague tribunal would seriously undermine its authority in administering justice in the wake of the Croatian, Bosnian and Kosovo wars. Last year the US slapped down opposition leaders in Serbia who sought to arrange an asylum deal for Mr Milosevic as a means of ensuring a peaceful transition of power. "If there is any place where he seeks sanctuary, I would recommend the Hague," the US defence secretary, William Cohen, said at the time. Washington has offered a $5m reward for information leading to Mr Milosevic's arrest and delivery to the Hague tribunal. One year on, however, the Serbian opposition remains as divided as ever and apparently no closer to ousting Mr Milosevic under its own steam. Disillusionment has made the people of Belgrade sceptical of suggestions that he may step down. The rumours tend to be believed only by senior opposition figures. "Wishful thinking. They've screwed it up so that's all they've left," said one Belgrade shop assistant. But the Clinton administration is running out of time, and is deeply concerned about its final balance sheet. Greek officials at the foreign ministry said they believed Mr Milosevic was biding his time until the US presidential election - a view echoed in Belgrade - in the hope of a Republican victory. A British diplomat said the Clinton administration's hopes were deluded. "I don't see why he would do it. It's more dangerous for him to quit than it is to stay put." Once he cedes power Mr Milosevic will lose all his bargaining chips. Though he is beleaguered, the official opposition in Serbia is in disarray and unpopular. The police and army remain loyal. Street protests have fizzled out. One Nato country official insisted, however, that an amnesty was on the cards, saying: "It's in the best solution for everyone, and they [Nato] could spin it as victory. There is a strong argument that democracy should be put ahead of the person." Greece, Belarus and Iraq are believed to be among countries ready to provide a haven. Shortly after the Bosnian war the Serb monastery on the self-governing Republic of Mount Athos, in northern Greece, prepared accommodation for Radovan Karadzic and General Ratko Mladic, though both remained in Serbia. According to the Serb opposition leader, Zoran Djindjic, Mr Milosevic has also been offered asylum in China. Of all possible bolt-holes, that is the most likely. His son, Marko, is believed to have recently flown to Beijing to negotiate transfers of family funds with officials in the government, with which his mother's Marxist party, the Yugoslav United Left, enjoys excellent relations. Chinese money has been pouring into Belgrade since the end of the Kosovo bombing. Advertisements in China encouraging nationals to emigrate have increased the number of Chinese people living in Serbia to nearly 100,000. However last year's indictment as a war criminal would complicate any deal. James Landale, the Hague tribunal's spokesman, said yesterday: "The mandate of the tribunal is handed down by the security council. All states are obliged to cooperate. Anyone who is indicted is indicted for life. No one can nullify or dismiss an indictment, other than the security council." Any package deal for Mr Milosevic will have to include his unceasingly loyal wife. "My husband is a perfect man," she wrote in her regular column in a women's magazine. The war leaders: at home, in prison - or dead  Radovan Karadzic The Bosnian Serb wartime leader who was charged with crimes against humanity and genocide is still living in seclusion in his home in Pale. The S-For peacekeeping troops patrolling the area have been reluctant to storm his house for fear of casualties.  Ratko Mladic The Bosnian Serbs' top general, who is living in retirement in the Yugoslav capital, is also wanted for genocide. He commanded the constant shelling of Sarajevo and the massacre of more than 7,000 Muslim men from Srebrenica. His full address is: 119 Blagoja Parovica, Banovo Brdo, Belgrade. He likes to go to horse races and football matches, and continues to draw a monthly pension from the Yugoslav government.  Zeljko Raznjatovic, known as Arkan. The leader of the paramilitary group the Tigers was charged last year in a sealed indictment, which was thought to include his role in massacres in Croatia in 1991, Bosnia in 1992 and possibly in Kosovo last year. fields.headline: The fortunes of war
fields.standfirst:
A Milosevic deal would undermine the law
Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The fortune tellers who have proliferated in recent years  in Serbia agree with a suspicious unanimity that the  stars will continue to smile on Slobodan Milosevic.  Polls suggest that the many Serbians who read  newspaper clairvoyants believe he will remain in power  until at least 2010.
fields.body:
The fortune tellers who have proliferated in recent years in Serbia agree with a suspicious unanimity that the stars will continue to smile on Slobodan Milosevic. Polls suggest that the many Serbians who read newspaper clairvoyants believe he will remain in power until at least 2010. Half of them, according to one recent survey, answered Yes to the question: "Do you believe that all members of Nato will soon be punished by natural catastrophes and epidemics?" But the Serbian leader may have a clearer grasp of reality. That is why some Nato governments, according to a report in the New York Times, have been exploring the question of what we should do if he suddenly showed himself ready to step down if his safety and assets were guaranteed.

In the interest of bringing about a change for the better in Serbia, should we acquiesce or even collude in some arrangement under which he and his family found refuge in, say, Russia? The dilemma of how to dig out dictators has become more difficult since the establishment of international war crimes tribunals and the detention of Pinochet. Certainly there is an unavoidable conflict between the idea of negotiating an end to authoritarian rule, which inevitably involves some immunity for members of the outgoing regime, and ending what Kofi Annan has called the "culture of impunity." In some countries and in some circumstances the need for a bargain will rightly prevail but not, surely, in the case of Milosevic, who has been formally charged with war crimes. That would be to humiliate the tribunal in The Hague, to cast down the precedents it is setting and to look the other way as governments ignored their new duties under international law. It would also encourage Serbs- who need above all to honestly examine their responsibility for the terrible events of the last 10 years - to carry on dwelling in that fantastical twilight in which, as shown by the popularity of the soothsayers, too many of them remain.

webTitle: Harrison Ford escapes harm as plane crash lands

fields.headline: Harrison Ford escapes harm as plane crash lands
fields.trailText: Harrison Ford was forced to make his second crash landing in less than a year on Sunday night.
fields.body:
Harrison Ford was forced to make his second crash landing in less than a year on Sunday night.

The taciturn actor's six-passenger plane encountered shifting winds while landing at Lincoln, Nebraska around 5:40pm. The wind tossed Ford's plane off the runway, the Federal Aviation Administration said. Ford and an unidentified passenger were not hurt in the incident, but the plane's wings were.

"He reported wind shear as he was coming in for a landing and clipped the runway," said an FAA representative. "[The plane] took a hard left, bounced across some grass and a couple of taxiways. And sustained damage to the plane, at least to the wing tips." Ford could not be reached for comment.

Last October, the Indiana Jones star had to crash-land his helicopter during a training flight about 60 miles outside Los Angeles. Ford is only the latest among several celebs with more planes than sense, who've come a cropper when the aerial going gets tough.

Earlier this month, 80s has-been Patrick Swayze had to make an emergency landing in Arizona due to what he claimed were pressurisation problems. Three local men claimed they helped Swayze remove beer and wine bottles from his aircraft, but police have stated that there is no evidence to support that charge.

webTitle: Christopher Lee will play 'spooky' Star Wars role

fields.headline: Christopher Lee will play 'spooky' Star Wars role
fields.trailText:
Even The Daily Mirror has picked up on an Ain't It Cool news
story which avers that British horror legend Christopher
Lee has been cast in the blockbusting sci-fi saga
fields.body:
As Star Wars Episode Two approaches - only a year and
a half to wait, folks - the rumours surrounding George
Lucas's Phantom Menace follow-up intensify. Now the
Daily Mirror has picked up on an Ain't It Cool news
story which avers that British horror legend Christopher
Lee has been cast in the blockbusting sci-fi saga.

According to the newspaper, "producers want to keep
his role top secret. But insiders say he will play an
ancient - and evil - Jedi Knight". The report goes on
to quote "a Star Wars insider", who says: "It will be
a real spooky role."

Lee's Star Wars role, if it comes to pass, will consolidate something of a career revival for the 78-year-old erstwhile Dracula. Lee
has recently played a small role in Tim Burton's Sleepy Hollow, and he is currently filming the part of Sarauman in New Zealand on Peter Jackson's eagerly awaited Lord of the Rings trilogy.

Further reports in SW2, meanwhile, indicate that Maori actor and star of Once Were Warriors, Temuera
Morrison is to feature in the film as the father of one of the fans' favourite Star Wars baddies, Boba Fett. The young Boba Fett will be played by teenage kiwi actor Tupoutahi Winitana.
fields.bodyText: As Star Wars Episode Two approaches - only a year and a half to wait, folks - the rumours surrounding George Lucas's Phantom Menace follow-up intensify. Now the Daily Mirror has picked up on an Ain't It Cool news story which avers that British horror legend Christopher Lee has been cast in the blockbusting sci-fi saga. According to the newspaper, "producers want to keep his role top secret. But insiders say he will play an ancient - and evil - Jedi Knight". The report goes on to quote "a Star Wars insider", who says: "It will be a real spooky role." Lee's Star Wars role, if it comes to pass, will consolidate something of a career revival for the 78-year-old erstwhile Dracula. Lee has recently played a small role in Tim Burton's Sleepy Hollow, and he is currently filming the part of Sarauman in New Zealand on Peter Jackson's eagerly awaited Lord of the Rings trilogy. Further reports in SW2, meanwhile, indicate that Maori actor and star of Once Were Warriors, Temuera Morrison is to feature in the film as the father of one of the fans' favourite Star Wars baddies, Boba Fett. The young Boba Fett will be played by teenage kiwi actor Tupoutahi Winitana.

webTitle: Baby Spice to play 'tearaway' in Ibiza movie

fields.headline: Baby Spice to play 'tearaway' in Ibiza movie
fields.trailText: Baby Spice, aka Emma Bunton, has been cast as the lead in a new movie based on the adventures of a gang of girls on a Club 18-30 holiday. The film will be shot on location in Ibiza at the end of August.
fields.body:
Baby Spice, aka Emma Bunton, has been cast as the lead in a new movie based on the adventures of a gang of girls on a Club 18-30 holiday. The film will be shot on location in Ibiza at the end of August.

Bunton, who featured recently in the top ten of The Observer's young rich list, currently presents a music show on cable TV, but beyond her music videos, the singer has done little mainstream acting (few people would count Spice World). Nor has Bunton enjoyed such a high-profile solo career as her fellow Spice Girls.

An insider told the Mirror newspaper: "It was a great to get Emma to play one of the main characters. Obviously, people know her as a singer, but she's really impressed everyone at the audition with her acting.

"Em is going to surprise a lot of people. She's going to be fantastic in this role. Her character is a bit of a tearaway - nothing like her image in the Spice Girls. I think she wanted the role because it's such a departure for her."

The comedy, currently known as 'Full Monty on the Beach' will be set in and around Ibiza's nightclubbing capital San Antonio.

The movie is being produced by advertising agency Saatchi & Saatchi, who we can thank for Club 18-30's controversial poster campaign, which was responsible for slogans like 'Beaver Espana' and 'Wake up at the crack of Dawn'.

fields.headline: Throwing a wobbly
fields.trailText:
You suggest (Leader, June 19) that women are disappointed because Labour has failed to cut class sizes and reduce waiting lists as promised. This risks becoming conventional wisdom, but it's worth pointing out that the class-size commitment is in fact about to be fulfilled this September, and the waiting list target has already been achieved. Where the post-election euphoria gave the impression that Labour was about to solve everything from the weather to the cricket team, there is now the opposite danger that the genuine achievements are overlooked.
Nick Palmer MP
NickPalmerMP@compuserve.com

fields.headline: The shadow of Heysel
fields.trailText: As an Englishman living near the Heysel stadium in Brussels, I have now had firsthand experience of the infamous UK hooligans. There is complete incomprehension and deep anger among the local people how, so close to the anniversary of the Heysel disaster, English fans can return to Brussels with exactly the same aggression and violence that led to so many deaths a decade ago.
fields.body:
As an Englishman living near the Heysel stadium in Brussels, I have now had firsthand experience of the infamous UK hooligans. There is complete incomprehension and deep anger among the local people how, so close to the anniversary of the Heysel disaster, English fans can return to Brussels with exactly the same aggression and violence that led to so many deaths a decade ago.

While I am sure Jack Straw will get his just desserts for being so lackadaisical in the run-up to Euro 2000, he can now do nothing to stop further brutalisation of Belgium and damage to England's reputation. So how about the press taking a lead? The government should release in full the personal details of all the hooligans who have been arrested - and the press should pursue a name and shame policy. Hooligans will think twice if they realise they will have to explain to their employers and family why they rounded off their football fun by destroying a couple of bars.

Our politicians' increasingly anti-EU and anti-asylum seeker statements may appear balanced in the parlours of Kensington and Surrey but, by the time they reached the streets of Belgium last weekend, they had been reinterpreted as a parliamentary blessing for racism and violence.
Julian Wilson
Brussels
julian.wilson@cec.eu.int

 Will the fact that none of the hundreds of English fans arrested had previously been convicted of any football-related violence finally stop all this tired old nonsense about how the government should stop the "hooligans" travelling because it spoils everything for the "real fans"? The image of psychopaths on mobile phones prearranging medieval battles might be comforting for us, as it implies a nasty but small and therefore controllable problem. However, the real issue is that while millions of young Englishmen may not actively go around looking for fights, nevertheless they drink too much, behave loutishly and are violently inclined.

The fundamental problem is that English social culture is drunken and aggressive. When we come out of our state of our national denial and admit this obvious but uncomfortable fact, we might actually be able to start doing something about it.
David Bolchover
London
david.bolchover@virgin.net

 Eindhoven - half-strength beer, freely available grass, peace. Charleroi - full-strength beer, no grass, war. Case proved.
Charles Harris
London

fields.headline: Putin's attack on democratic rights
fields.trailText: The release on bail of Vladimir Gusinsky, the director of Media Most and NTV, the only major network which is independent of, and critical of President Putin and the Kremlin (Putin backtracks on detention, June 16), is welcome. However, the charge of "conspiracy against the state" is a wide and imprecise charge and the arrest and imprisonment in itself is bound to have a chilling effect on any Russian newspaper, journalist or human rights activist who opposes President Putin's war against Chechen civilians and their elected leaders, or any other policy.
fields.body:
The release on bail of Vladimir Gusinsky, the director of Media Most and NTV, the only major network which is independent of, and critical of President Putin and the Kremlin (Putin backtracks on detention, June 16), is welcome. However, the charge of "conspiracy against the state" is a wide and imprecise charge and the arrest and imprisonment in itself is bound to have a chilling effect on any Russian newspaper, journalist or human rights activist who opposes President Putin's war against Chechen civilians and their elected leaders, or any other policy.

The journalist Andrei Babitsky escaped death, or living death, because of international protests led by Elena Bonner and the Sakharov Foundation and Amnesty International. However, he is silenced, because his passport has been withdrawn - illegal under Russian law - and cannot therefore do his work for Radio Liberty.

NTV has been critical of the Russian government's war on civilians in Chechnya and Vladimir Gusinsky is one of the leading members of the Jewish community in Russia. Whatever the charges might be, in respect of unpaid tax etc, these would be something for a fiscal or inland revenue body to inquire into. Instead, masked men with guns, presumed to be special ministry of interior forces, raided Media Most offices, and some days later, Gusinsky was arrested and imprisoned in Butyrsky prison, where many Soviet political prisoners suffered.

President Putin is using KGB-style operations and is clearly out to terrorise present and future opposition into silence.
Vanessa Redgrave
London

fields.headline: Pity the poor immigrant
fields.trailText: Last Thursday, I attended the funeral in London of Natasha Tatarova, one of the asylum seekers who died in the fire three weeks ago and whose obituary you published (May 30). fields.body:
Last Thursday, I attended the funeral in London of Natasha Tatarova, one of the asylum seekers who died in the fire three weeks ago and whose obituary you published (May 30). It was a distressing occasion not only because of the family's grief, but because we had to persuade her children not to return for the burial in Slovakia, which would prejudice their immigration status. Natasha's family, unusually for Slovak Roma, had won exceptional leave to remain because of the horrific attacks made upon them before they fled here in 1997.

Her body returned on Saturday accompanied only by British members of their Roma church and her brother, who was just recovering in Slovakia from a savage beating by hooded men. The case was shown on Slovak TV news, and Natasha, not long before she died, had asked me to try to get it shown on British TV.

The question now is what will happen to her three children who want to be cared for by their close-knit aunt, uncle and maternal grandparents, likely to be considered "bogus" asylum seekers if they make a claim while here, even to look after the children. Apparently the Home Office considers only proven risk of immediate death justifies asylum, not on-going, intermittent, life-threatening persecution.
Gill Casebourne
Chair, Kent Refugee Action Network

 Thank you for the excellent article (Death in the shadow of race fears, June 16) on racial tension in Newport. I was the chairperson of the Defend Asylum Seekers meeting that you featured in your photograph. This was called in response to attempts by the BNP (not the National Front) to whip up racism in Pill and many other parts of Newport and Cwmbran. Their efforts and the regular printing of anti-asylum letters in the local paper is clearly a factor in making racism respectable and there have been a number of serious racist attacks in this part of south-east Wales.

There is an attempt at the moment by nazi parties in the UK to emulate the suc cess of Haider and Le Pen in building large, violent organisations opposed to free speech, democratic rights and racial equality.
Richard Morse
Secretary, Gwent Campaign Against Racism

 The continuous reports attacking asylum seekers in the media are building up a hysterical and racist atmosphere. I live in Wanstead in east London. Recently, there was a racist attack on an Asian man at 5.30pm on a Friday evening in Wanstead High Street. Local people were disgusted and now we are having a local meeting to defend asylum seekers and build a campaign against racist scapegoating.
Fiona Prior
London

 A tragic event such as in Newport was inevitable ever since home secretary Jack Straw's hard-line policies toward asylum seekers opened the door to Tory racism and asylum-seeker bashing from sections of the press. It was for this reason that delegates to the National Union of Journalist's conference in April initiated an open letter condemning racist hysteria in the media and politicians who encouraged it. It has since been signed by several MPs, 10 trade union general secretaries and thousands of concerned people across the country and enough money has been raised to advertise the national demonstration to stop scapegoating asylum seekers on Saturday.

A Committee to Defend Asylum Seekers has also been set up to organise events aimed at challenging lies and distortions in the press and reversing government policy toward asylum seekers.
Alan Gibson
London

Alan.Gibson@rbi.co.uk

webTitle: Magistrates under fire for reluctance to issue banning orders

fields.headline: Magistrates under fire for reluctance to issue banning orders
fields.standfirst:
Football violence: special report
Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: Magistrates were yesterday under fire for failing to use newly strengthened powers to impose orders banning convicted football hooligans from travelling abroad to games.
fields.body:
Magistrates were yesterday under fire for failing to use newly strengthened powers to impose orders banning convicted football hooligans from travelling abroad to games.

Police and Home Office sources argued that, despite being given the "tools for the job", magistrates were still reluctant to issue the bans, which can apply for up to 10 years.

Only 23 international banning orders have been imposed since their introduction in October, compared with 203 domestic banning orders, which apply to home games.

Amid yesterday's search for blame over the rioting in Belgium, magistrates, the govern ment, police and the crown prosecution service all sought to shrug off responsibility.

Only one of the 584 Britons detained at the weekend had a order against him, prompting the government to claim at first that the system had worked.

But the home secretary, Jack Straw, later underlined the widely shared conclusion that magistrates' powers are not being sufficiently used. He issued proposals to combine domestic and international bans under a single order. Courts would also be reminded to implement the orders, he told the Commons.

Magistrates were granted wider powers to deal with hooligans, together with a greater obligation to act to prevent violence, under legislation which came into force in September. The Football (Offences and Disorder) Act imposes a duty on courts to impose banning orders if magistrates are satisfied "there are reasonable grounds to believe" doing so will reduce disorder at matches.

One problem with the system is that, while the number of orders issued is known, the cases where courts have cho sen not to impose a ban is not centrally recorded, so no conclusions can be drawn over how often magistrates are shying away from issuing bans.

One police source said: "Magistrates courts are just not using the tools they now have to do the job. They should have been reminded of their legal responsibilities as they were before the last world cup."

The source suggested that magistrates believed themselves to be concerned primarily with local law enforcement. "Often magistrates will have people in front of them who is a local thug fighting at a local game and they don't regard him as a threat to international competition. They ban him from Cardiff City but don't prevent him getting to Charleroi."

The Magistrates Association yesterday could offer no explanation over why courts had imposed so few international bans. Magistrates' clerks in the main footballing cities pointed out that the number of football-related offences coming before courts was now far lower than in the 70s and 80s, giving courts fewer opportunities to impose the orders.
