webTitle: English clubs to ban thugs for life as Straw fights Euro 2000 fallout

fields.headline: English clubs to ban thugs for life as Straw fights Euro 2000 fallout
fields.standfirst: Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: Football hooligans will be banned by their clubs for life,  Jack Straw revealed yesterday as he fought off  mounting European claims that he had failed to deliver  on promises to keep English thugs away from Euro  2000.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour and Vivek Chaudhary in Brussels
fields.body:
Football hooligans will be banned by their clubs for life, Jack Straw revealed yesterday as he fought off mounting European claims that he had failed to deliver on promises to keep English thugs away from Euro 2000.

In an effort to stave off the politically disastrous expulsion of the English team from the championship by Uefa, the home secretary promised to step up numbers of police spotters on trains and exit points, urged ferry and plane companies to bar potential hooligans, and said that all 800 football fans so far deported from Belgium would be prevented from returning to the championship.

Tony Blair met his Belgian counterpart at the European Union summit in Portugal and urged Belgium to impose drink bans and mark the passports of all deported hooligans. The prime minister expressed his shame, but said it would be a tragedy if the England team were penalised.

Kevin Keegan, the England coach, last night called on genuine supporters to get behind the team and alienate those who had been causing violence.

"We have got a fantastic opportunity to go forward. We can do it if we can solve these other problems," he said.

The England squad was yesterday addressed by the FA chief executive, Adam Crozier, on the threat to expel the team in the event of further trouble.

Police in Belgium said they would continue their zero tolerance policy for tonight's match against Romania in Charleroi. Around 3,000 officers will be on duty. All plastic chairs and tables have been removed from the city's main square, scene of most of the violence on Saturday afternoon.

The home secretary also told MPs that he intended to require the courts to impose international travel bans automatically on any hooligan convicted of a football-related offence in Britain. Magistrates have rarely used their discretionary power to impose bans, despite tightening of the law last September.

Mr Straw added that the government's aim had always been to give the courts powers to impose travel bans on unconvicted fans, if police gave evidence that they were likely to commit violence.

Ann Widdecombe, for the Tories, said she was willing to back emergency legislation to push through the crackdown, and accused Mr Straw of wasting a year before considering the measure.

The plan was denounced by by the civil rights group Liberty since it breached the principle that everyone is innocent until proven guilty.

However, senior football figures are exasperated with Mr Straw for failing to give the courts the extra powers already widely used in Germany.

They also say that the level of policing at British ports and airports was minimal, one of the biggest causes of anger within Uefa.

In another sign of tension between the Home Office and some British clubs, the clubs said the initiative to impose a life ban on convicted supporters came from them and not the Home Office.

The Home Office yesterday revealed that a third of the 584 British citizens arrested in Belgium, and on which the police had any information, had criminal records. However, of nearly 400 deported, only 15 had previously been identified as football hooligans and one had been banned by the courts from attending games in Britain.

Mr Straw said this showed the authorities could not have done more to prevent the troublemakers travelling, and the police had succeeded in debarring the known hooligans.

One government member present in Brussels at the weekend said: "The difficulty is that it is not a small, mindless minority, but quite a big one, and it keeps recreating itself from generation to generation."

Only four England fans remain in custody in Belgium, and they will appear in court this week. The failure to press charges against more of them makes it more difficult for further punishments to be imposed by the British courts or football clubs.

Government sources discounted suggestions by the Labour MP Joe Ashton that the threatened expulsion was to do with the internal battle within Uefa over England's World Cup 2006 bid. Fifa, the world authority, is due to vote on July 6, and many senior Uefa figures back Germany rather than England.

However, the theory of a German plot is also supported by senior figures in the FA, who are furious that they were not given prior notice of the threatened expulsion.

fields.headline: Uefa's logic
fields.standfirst:
No England, no trashed bars
Football violence: special report
Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: Uefa's logic is hard to fault. Without England, there  would be no beatings, no trashed bars. If bad behaviour  continues and the team is excluded, sighs of relief will  be heard across the Low Countries.
fields.body:
Uefa's logic is hard to fault. Without England, there would be no beatings, no trashed bars. If bad behaviour continues and the team is excluded, sighs of relief will be heard across the Low Countries. England's absence from tournaments readily accessible from these shores would mean the riot police could be stood down and unsuspecting citizens of continental cities left in peace. You can play pass the parcel with responsibility. Uefa is challenging the English Football Association, but supporters' behaviour is not something over which it has control in the short run. Yet the FA knows there are precedents for banning matches to remove the occasion of delinquency. At one time the arrival at King's Cross and Euston of Scotland's supporters spread terror through the capital. Domestic games between England and Scotland were halted and peace reigns.

It is too soon for an autopsy on England's football culture or the law and order arrangements for this competition. The government, properly, has avoided criticism of the Belgians. Their police might, some say, have played it differently, maybe taken lessons from Dutch handling of crowds in Eindhoven and elsewhere - but why should international football demand preparations as if for war? Jack Straw, usually eager to equip himself with powers, damn the civil liberties consequences, has been reticent. That is because it does seem existing law would have done little to prevent the outbreaks in Charleroi and Brussels. The 1999 Football Act extended controls on offenders - it looks like "fans" with no previous form are the problem this week. Whether or not hooligans' passports could have been seized - the subject of an amendment dropped after party squabbling - looks academic when it is faces unknown to the police who foment trouble. If those convicted of football-related offences in England are found to have travelled to Belgium, then the extension of travel bans should be considered. But we should be very careful of revamping the "sus" laws - which is what those arguing for pre-emptive banning of non-offenders seem to want. Those are tough law and order questions. In the aftermath of this tainted competition others, deeper, more troubling, will have to be pressed: about the atavism of our tabloid press, the deformations of English nationalism and the brute incapacity of young English men to drink in a civilised fashion.

fields.headline: Catastrophe at Charleroi
fields.standfirst:
We are all to blame if England is ejected from Euro 2000

Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: We are all to blame if England is ejected from Euro 2000, writes Roy Hattersley.
fields.body:
First of all, the cliches - an indispensable part of any commentary on football. The English thugs who rioted in Charleroi last Saturday cruelly damaged the reputation of more than what is sometimes called the "beautiful game". England, as a whole, has been diminished in the eyes of the world. The sceptred isle has become the home of hooligans - a country which breeds drunken louts who the government is unable or unwilling to control.

The guilt should be widely spread and I am willing to accept my share. When I heard that the team - so recently victorious over Germany - might be ejected from Euro 2000, my immediate reaction was outrage and disbelief. Like David Davies, the executive director of the Football Association, I regarded disqualification as "too awful to contemplate". A more rational reaction would have been agreement that losing our place in the quarter finals was far less important than taking a stand against violence.

No doubt the claims in mitigation are justified. Some innocent, genuine fans were penalised by the Belgium police. Many of the thugs were no more interested in the football than Zen Buddhism. None of that changes the basic facts of either the disgrace or the inadequate way in which we have responded to it. A hysterical media seems incapable of facing the awful truth that the disease is now endemic.

On Sunday night radio, the junior home office minister, Lord Bassam, was asked why he ruled out emergency legislation to prevent Saturday's mayhem recurring on Tuesday. Parliament is probably in a mood to pass a bill in a single parliamentary sitting. But it seems unlikely that the SAS could have been deployed sufficiently swiftly to snatch the miscreants off the streets before the kick off. We need a change in culture at least as much as we need a change in the law.

The disease is so widespread that it is impossible to identify the potential troublemakers. If they were all real football supporters - hooligans who watch league matches and then enjoy a little violence on the side - they would be much easier to catch, convict and prevent from travelling abroad. But half the thugs whose pictures appeared in the weekend papers could not repeat the off side rule to save their lives.

Football provides the opportunity for warp-minded chauvinists to demonstrate their brutal contempt for foreigners - a contempt which is often encouraged by politicians and journalists. The defining picture of the weekend tragedy was a bare-chested youth, cigarette in hand, giving the Nazi salute. His tattoo, proclaiming his affection for the mother country, spelt the revered name "Great Britian". Most football thugs are the sort of men who, regretting that we no longer rule the world, want us to control the penalty area - and fight them on the terraces as we were once ready to fight them on the beaches.

That pathetic tendency has been grossly encouraged by the tabloid treatment of international football - typified by Saturday morning's "witty" headline which described the German team as "krap". Yesterday's Daily Mirror included a massively indignant editorial which demanded "crack down on the mindless thugs now". Its lofty tone was in profound contrast to a column written for that day's paper by Tony Parsons: "yes, do mention the war ... they had it coming." Mr Parsons reminded his readers of "boys in their teens who died at Anzio." He called the Germans "Huns".

The Mirror editor is explicit that "at half past seven" he decided "in light of the news that the column was inappropriate". But it appears on the Daily Mirror website. And it raises a question to which we have yet to hear the answer. If Uefa had not threatened to expel Britain from the tournament and the story of "jagged black shrapnel" had been regarded as "appropriate", how much responsibility would the Mirror have taken for the next night's riots?

The tabloids are not the only culprits. Football managers who condone fouls on the field and violence off it, television pundits who excuse any sort of behaviour if the guilty player is talented and columnists who write of football as a matter of life and death (when at best it is a game and at worst part of the entertainment industry) must share the blame. Even the benign publicity for Euro 2000 has been damaging. "Thirty years of hurt"? The emotional exaggeration is ridiculous. Unfortunately it is also another provocation to the catastrophe of Charleroi.

fields.headline: Témoin
fields.standfirst: Jeanne Dumesnil describes what it was like to witness a recent bank hold-up in Paris
fields.trailText: Jeanne Dumesnil describes what it was like to witness a recent bank hold-up in Paris
fields.body:
Ce fut une courte aventure, mais une dont on se passerait bien volontiers ! Quand je suis entrée dans la banque, un individu cagoulé m'a attrapée par le poignet. Au début, je n'ai pas réalisé ce qui se passait. J'ai compris lorsque j'ai vu que le personnel était pétrifié. Là, mon sang n'a fait qu'un tour. Ensuite, on m'a placée avec le personnel et les autres clients, une dizaine en tout, en me disant : C'est un hold-up, restez calme, tout se passera bien. On m'a ensuite ordonné de mettre les mains devant moi et de garder la tête baissée.

Les deux voleurs étaient armés. Ils ont volé l'argent, calmement, puis ils sont partis.

On n'a pas vraiment le temps de réagir car tout se passe très rapidement. On perd un peu la notion du temps. Le hold-up a duré environ une demi-heure. L'un des voleurs nous gardait devant le comptoir pendant que l'autre était dans le local de la billetterie, pour voler l'argent du distributeur.

Il n'y avait aucun bruit. Je pensais : comment cela va-t-il se finir ? Je ressentais plus de stress que de peur. Les voleurs n'étaient pas agressifs. Il n'y a pas eu de violence verbale ou physique. Ils ne donnaient pas l'impression de vouloir attenter à notre vie. Ils voulaient juste l'argent.

Ils ont pris l'argent, 117 000 FF, puis nous ont fait entrer dans le local de la billetterie. Ils se sont enfuis après avoir volé la moto d'un client. C'est le chef d'agence, resté avec eux pendant toute l'action, qui nous a libérés.

Maintenant, je ne veux plus aller à la banque, je préfère y envoyer mon mari. Et quand je dois m'y rendre, je regarde à l'intérieur avant d'entrer pour voir si tout est normal. Je ne me sens pas rassurée du tout !

Glossaire/Glossary

s'enfuir to run away
un individu cagoulé a person wearing a balaclava
pétrifiée petrified
je ne suis pas rassurée I am nervous
restez calme ! stay calm
mon sang n'a fait qu'un tour my heart skipped a beat
un voleur a robber

webTitle: Mandelson still in a spin over police bill

fields.headline: Mandelson still in a spin over police bill
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson has introduced the novel concept of retaining the name of the RUC in the police's "title deeds" to recognise that the RUC is being reformed rather than disbanded (I am listening, June 16). No one outside the ranks of the "no" unionists think the RUC is being disbanded, though Patten recommended this. No "title deeds" formula was in Patten: it is the secretary of state's own addition. As drafted, he will retain the power to change the police's name, symbols and flags in ways which may be neither neutral nor bi-national.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson has introduced the novel concept of retaining the name of the RUC in the police's "title deeds" to recognise that the RUC is being reformed rather than disbanded (I am listening, June 16). No one outside the ranks of the "no" unionists think the RUC is being disbanded, though Patten recommended this. No "title deeds" formula was in Patten: it is the secretary of state's own addition. As drafted, he will retain the power to change the police's name, symbols and flags in ways which may be neither neutral nor bi-national.

The secretary of state has agreed that all officers will sign up to the new code of ethics. A welcome step, but he has not implemented Patten (para 5:17) which referred to "international human rights standards and norms" beyond those in the European convention. Moreover, the code is to be drawn up by the chief constable not by the board.

He has conceded on aggregation to enable Patten's proposed quota to work. He agreed that it "should continue as long as it takes" to "achieve the appropriate Catholic/Protestant balance". Good: but how will that stead into law, and what is the appropriate balance? Just as importantly, the implementation plan is unclear on targeting.

Mr Mandelson says he "may have been too anxious" in placing safeguards on the policing board. Will he go further and remove the weighted majority requirement before the initiation of inquiries - which de facto will create partisan political control? Will he permit the new boards to establish their own targets?

Patten envisaged that district policing partnership boards would have fund- raising powers. Fears about paramilitaries becoming beneficiaries can be handled by appropriate legal and financial safeguards. Mr Mandelson is silent on this. Will he put the commissioner's office on a statutory basis?

Finally, Patten specifically recommended that the ombudsman should have the power to investigate patterns of police behaviour and policies: is Mr Mandelson rejecting this recommendation?

If these changes to implement Patten become part of the amended police bill, I will acknowledge that Britannia's secretary has not been perfidious: spinning into the right position will be sufficient.
Prof Brendan O'Leary
London School of Economics

webTitle: The England fast bowler with the MBE

fields.headline: The England fast bowler with the MBE
fields.trailText: Clare Taylor, 35, is England's senior fast bowler. She has also won international honours on the football pitch, and on Saturday was awarded the MBE for services to cricket, football and hockey. On Monday, she spoke to wisden.com about her MBE, her mate Karen Smithies and England's prospects in the one-day series against South Africa, which started on Tuesday. She put England on the way to victory in the first match, with her economic spell of 1-14 from nine overs.
fields.body:
Clare Taylor, 35, is England's senior fast bowler. She has also won international honours on the football pitch, and on Saturday was awarded the MBE for services to cricket, football and hockey. On Monday, she spoke to wisden.com about her MBE, her mate Karen Smithies and England's prospects in the one-day series against South Africa, which started on Tuesday. She put England on the way to victory in the first match, with her economic spell of 1-14 from nine overs.

What does the MBE mean to you?
I was delighted to receive it, especially as it was for something which I enjoy doing anyway. It's nice as well because it gives a bit of recognition to women's sport in general.

Did you hear about it in advance?
I actually heard on May 12. The letter came through to the ECB and they opened it by mistake. I got a message on my phone from Keith Pont of ECB saying, I want to talk to you urgently. At first I thought that I was in trouble but I phoned back anyway. He was more excited than I was I think - initially I was just relieved that I hadn't done anything wrong. He told me in strictest confidence but once it had sunk in I had to tell someone, so I told my Mum.

What is the mood like in the England camp?
Confident. There is a really good buzz around the squad. We desperately want to improve on the Australia and New Zealand tours in the winter [England lost all nine of their one-day internationals]. The Australian leg was dismal but the New Zealand leg wasn't too bad. It looked far worse on paper than it actually was. If we could have found another 30-40 runs from somewhere we would have been challenging them.

How do you think England will fare against South Africa?
Realistically, going on past results and on current form, we should win. We need this series to build our confidence for the World Cup at the end of the year.

How does it feel to be the senior player now that Karen Smithies [the ex-captain, dropped from the squad] is no longer in the team?
Barbara Daniels is just in front of me in terms of age , which I'm very glad of. There is a lot of inexperience. Arran Thompson and Laura Harper are new and Dawn Holden and Nicki Shaw are fairly new so it is up to the older ones - me, BB [Barbara Daniels] Lucy Pearson and even Charlotte Edwards, who is still young but very experienced - to inspire them. But the new players are very enthusiastic and confidence won't be a problem.

Have you played against the South Africans before?
We played against them in 1997 and beat them 2-1, and then beat them in a 20-over thrash in our first game of the last World Cup. Three-quarters of their side are the same.

Which of their players poses the biggest threat?
Possibly they are a stronger batting side than bowling. Helen Davies, Kim Price, the captain, and Linda Olivier are the most experienced batswomen. And Cindy Eksteen, their vice-captain, is their fastest bowler. She is probably on a par with me, speed-wise.

Is there any one ground you are particularly looking forward to playing at?
I haven't got very fond memories of Taunton. They beat us there last time. We got 253 on the board and then they beat us off the final ball. It was a televised match and really put the cat among the pigeons. I've never played at Chelmsford before, and Worcester is a lovely ground, but I don't think the venue makes that much difference.

Have you any goals in this series?
I aim to play in all the games and to do well, and for the team to do well. I think that I am bowling better now than at any time in my career. Probably because I'm now looking over my shoulder - there is real competition for places, which is a good thing.

Has Graham Dilley [England's bowling coach] helped you much?
Yes, he is a very quiet bloke but what he says is worth listening to. I am now concentrating more on using the front arm, not just waving it about.

What about your batting?
Yes, well, I don't really talk about that. I'm definitely a member of the 10 and 11 union. I give it my best shot but it is usually tip-and-run with me.

Will you miss Karen Smithies?
Yes, on the personal level. She is quite a close friend and it is always sad when something like that happens. You always want to name the day when you retire. And it is hard to know what to say. But that is sport I suppose, and you end up being a bit selfish and, though you care about your teammates, concentrating on yourself. But hopefully she is going to come down for a few of the games so I can get to see her.

Will you be able to watch the England v Romania match?
All being well, we'll get South Africa in and get them out early. Then we can have a shower and see the match. We've been training for a week up at Lilleshall and we watched the other two England games in the bar there.

Did you manage to catch any of the Edgbaston Test?
Well we were looking forward to spending our rest day on Sunday watching it but ...

When do you plan to retire?
I hope to play in the World Cup in December and then see how that goes. I am still enjoying my cricket, and in the bleep test I register between 11 and 11.5, so I can still see off some of the youngsters.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. Click here for England's fixtures against South Africa this summer. And click here for the previous Women's Page, on Isabelle Duncan, Wisden's very own cover girl

fields.headline: Bomb found at Mandelson's home
fields.trailText: An explosive device has been discovered and made safe in a field at the official Ulster residence of the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, police said today.
fields.body:
An explosive device has been discovered and made safe in a field at the official Ulster residence of the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, police said today.

The device was found in a field close to Hillsborough Castle, County Down - where the Prince of Wales last week attended a garden party with 2,000 victims of violence in the province.

Army bomb disposal experts made safe the device last night and also took away a number of items for examination, said a Royal Ulster Constabulary spokesman.

The device was found inside the perimeter wall of the castle grounds, close to the Moira Road. There were no immediate details of how large the device was, whether it was primed or how long it was thought to have been in place.

Mr Mandelson was not at Hillsborough last night. The Northern Ireland Office said he was at home in London, as was his ministerial team.

The device is believed to have been found in a bag which is thought to have been thrown over the high wall surrounding the castle grounds. The grounds were expected to be combed in a follow-up search later today.

The discovery comes at a sensitive time in the peace process, which has seen Britain cut back troop numbers to their lowest levels in 30 years. But security officials fear republican splinter groups opposed to the peace process are plotting a campaign of violence.

fields.headline: Royal Ascot
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the race meeting noted for prats in hats on the web.
fields.trailText: All you need to know about the race meeting noted for prats in hats on the web
fields.body:
1. Today is the opening day of Royal Ascot, of which Julie Andrews trilled "Everybody who is hyaa, is hyaa" in the musical My Fair Lady.

2. A large proportion of the nation's elite will indeed be thyaa - sorry, there: telly celebs, City hucksters, the odd aristo. Oh, and a large proportion of the royal family, who live in Royal Windsor, a short coach ride away.

3. The chief activity at Royal Ascot is eating and being seen. Over the next four days, the better-heeled racegoers will put away around 4,500 lobsters and slosh down 5,000 bottles of champagne. This is the serious meeting for toffs who scoff.

4. In and around the grandstand it is obligatory for men to wear top hats, and de rigeur for women to wear silly ones. The Queen is excused from this custom.

5. Private boxes are available for up to £5,400 a day (catering extra). Other hospitality options are available for a few hundred quid a nob. The riffraff can also get into Royal Ascot quite cheaply, though they are not allowed to mix with the quality, and are very much better off for being on their own side of the track.

6. Other things to do at Royal Ascot include buying upmarket knick-knacks, very tastefully designed and priced.

7. Oh, and there's horseracing too, of a quality high enough to attract the thick end of quarter of a million people, not all in hats.

8. For those who can't be bothered with fancy dress, here is a handy form guide and some tips.

9. Those who understand that kind of thing can get regularly updated news of the going.

10. Horses have raced at Ascot for nearly 300 years, ever since Queen Anne spotted the potential of a piece of wasteland near her home.
fields.bodyText: 1. Today is the opening day of Royal Ascot, of which Julie Andrews trilled "Everybody who is hyaa, is hyaa" in the musical My Fair Lady. 2. A large proportion of the nation's elite will indeed be thyaa - sorry, there: telly celebs, City hucksters, the odd aristo. Oh, and a large proportion of the royal family, who live in Royal Windsor, a short coach ride away. 3. The chief activity at Royal Ascot is eating and being seen. Over the next four days, the better-heeled racegoers will put away around 4,500 lobsters and slosh down 5,000 bottles of champagne. This is the serious meeting for toffs who scoff. 4. In and around the grandstand it is obligatory for men to wear top hats, and de rigeur for women to wear silly ones. The Queen is excused from this custom. 5. Private boxes are available for up to £5,400 a day (catering extra). Other hospitality options are available for a few hundred quid a nob. The riffraff can also get into Royal Ascot quite cheaply, though they are not allowed to mix with the quality, and are very much better off for being on their own side of the track. 6. Other things to do at Royal Ascot include buying upmarket knick-knacks, very tastefully designed and priced. 7. Oh, and there's horseracing too, of a quality high enough to attract the thick end of quarter of a million people, not all in hats. 8. For those who can't be bothered with fancy dress, here is a handy form guide and some tips. 9. Those who understand that kind of thing can get regularly updated news of the going. 10. webTitle: Naked ambition and the Naked Chef

fields.headline: Naked ambition and the Naked Chef
fields.trailText: Read why England are like an American football team! Listen to Piers Morgan grunt! Avoid Jamie Oliver!
fields.body:
* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ADVERTISEMENT

Play football, see football, talk football, breathe football. The Euro is brought to you in association with www.breathe.com It's amazing what happens when you breathe.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EUROTALK

"They were inhuman beings, using that violence. I think we were too soft on them. Our people are ready. Our officers have proved they are well trained, they can react quickly and efficiently. I think your hooligans should be worried" - Ominous words from Christian de Coninck, assistant commissioner of police in Brussels.

THE EURO-TORIAL

England have made their usual stuttering start to a major tournament: 18 minutes of brilliance against Portugal, 90 minutes of heart against Germany - and a not great deal else. Tonight they must produce the fast-paced, fluid, inclusive football Kevin Keegan has often promised, but rarely delivered, if they wish to be considered big players in Euro 2000.

Whether they will or not is another matter. Because Keegan is expected to field the same side that started against Germany - which will no doubt see England playing in the same one-dimensional way, relying on specialist players performing specialist tasks: launch long balls up to Shearer and play off him; rely on Beckham to howitzer crosses in from the right; hope the waspish Scholes will float dangerously around the box picking up what's on offer. Meanwhile the rest of the team concentrate solely on attack or, more often than not, defence. In other words, they're like an American football team but with nicer shirts.

But - oh for a change! - what if England became more than a just disparate collection of big name players? What if they became a cohesive whole? Surely it's not beyond them. It just needs Gary Neville to make overlapping runs like he does for Manchester United. It just needs players like Paul Ince to risk coming forward, knowing that Dennis Wise - or somebody else - will fill in. And it just needs England to rediscover the benefits of playing at a brisk tempo and show - like they did in their third game against Holland in 1996 - that they really do mean business.

KEEPING TABS ON THE TABS

"Grunt! Grunt! Grunt! - That's Neanderthal for: Just behave you mindless, pathetic excuses for Englishmen" - The Mirror tells it like it is on its front page.

"Give it to South Africa. Give it to Germany. Give it to Sierra Leone. Just don't give it to us" - Martin Samuel on our World Cup bid in the Express.

"Kevin Keegan and his players should come back home back this morning, and give up the game against Romania and their chance for a place in Euro 2000 quarter-final" - Jeff Powell suggests we should pull out of Euro 2000 in the Daily Mail.

"Unjust. Unfair. Wrong. Uefa threat to ban England is outrageous" - The Star's front page has a slightly different view of things.

"Bruno to Divorce" - As does the Sun's.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A MESSAGE FROM BREATHE.COM

Euro 2000. Big screen sport action. In a pub. With your mates. Win a £200 tab behind the bar at Yates's Pubs all around the country... go to www.breathe.com, click on the Euro 2000 link and enter the draw.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EURONEWS

A huge security operation is being implemented ahead of England's game against Romania. Home Secretary Jack Straw has said that immigration and police checks at ports had been stepped up to spot hooligans travelling to tonight's game. Officials have been given lists of nearly 400 people deported over the weekend so they could be refused return transport. England face expulsion from Euro 2000 if there are any fresh outbreaks of violence.

EURORUMOUR with KAREL POBORSKY

Awight geezah! It's only me, innit, the Naked Chef. Ere listen, I've got loads of well-pukka celebrity cronies, innit, but I don't know no Eastern European footballers what can come rahnd my gaff while me and me mates slum it.

So I thought: "Old Karel's me man, e's a diamond geezer, I'll nip rahnd 'is house on me scooter and knock 'im up a lahvly cauliflower and ricotta salad!" Sorted. But I'm a bit put aht, cos e's not 'ere! I s'pose I could read aht all these rumours while I'm waitin', innit, though? Yeeeeah! Diamond idea! Pukka!

Ole Gunnar Solskjaer will reject the £12m advances of Tottenham and stay at Old Trafford.

Newcastle will offer Anderlecht £6m for Jan Koller. The arrival of the 6ft 7in Czech Republic striker would signal the departure of Duncan Ferguson - Bobby Robson is prepared to listen to offers of £3m for the ex-Everton, Rangers and Dundee United player.

The two Milan clubs are planning a raid on Manchester United's England stars, according to Planet Football. Milan have targeted David Beckham, while Internazionale are said to have already tabled a £16m offer for Paul Scholes.

Derby, Southampton and Manchester City have missed out on Bjorn Otto Bragstad. The Norwegian international defender is set to sign join his compatriot Bjorn Tore Kvarme at Saint Etienne, according to French TV.

Karel STOP this is a warning STOP that ridiculous chef bloke from the telly is on his way round STOP take my advice and make yourself scarce STOP

Leicester will offer their Turkish midfielder Muzzy Izzet a three-year £20,000-a-week deal when he returns from Euro 2000.

Real Madrid are interested in signing Monaco's Portuguese midfielder Costinha, who scored Portugal's last-minute winner against Romania on Saturday.

Anyhow, I can't stand around 'ere largin' it all day. I've got to be filmed prancing around in front of a fruit-and-veg stall like an arse in order to promote mobile phones, innit. Well pukka!

TV AND RADI(EUR)O

BBC1: Match of the Day - Live (7pm, 1.05am)
England v Romania. Presumably another channel is dealing with the big match, then.

ITV: Euro 2000 Today (11.30pm)
England v Romania. Hmm, this one isn't.

Euro 2000 - The Big Match (1.30am)
England v Romania. And it's not here either.

British Eurosport: (7pm)
England v Romania. Well, surely we can follow it on the radio...

Radio 5 Live: Euro 2000 - Live (7pm)
England v Romania. Sweet Jesus! Does nobody care what happens to the Germans?!?

webTitle: Ministers block airlines' bid for Nats

fields.headline: Ministers block airlines' bid for Nats
fields.trailText:
A bid by British airlines to take over the running of
the national air traffic service (Nats) on a
non-profit making basis has been ruled out by the
government, Whitehall sources confirmed last
night.
fields.body:
A bid by British airlines to take over the running of the national air traffic service (Nats) on a non-profit making basis has been ruled out by the government, Whitehall sources confirmed last night.

The airlines, including British Airways, Virgin and British Midland, have combined in the attempt but ministers have said that it cannot be approved for political reasons.

They acknowledge that the government's move to privatise the service for £500m has already aroused so much controversy among MPs and staff, that to hand over the management of the business to the airlines themselves would produce a public outcry.

One senior Whitehall source said: "The idea has some logic, but the public is very concerned about the issue of safety in transport, and it has been ruled out." This effectively means that any bid by a foreign airline or combination of airlines would receive the same treatment.

The government stressed yesterday that it was determined to go ahead with the partial privatisation of the service, despite the weekend computer failure at Heathrow. It left thousands of passengers stranded at UK airports.

Nick Raynsford, the junior transport minister, told the Commons that the problem had "not yet been fully identified". It reinforced the government's belief that part privatisation was necessary to bring in new investment.

Bids to run the new service have to be in by the autumn in time for the company to be operating by the middle of next year. But the transport bill, setting up the company, has still to pass through parliament. It has been delayed by the volume of opposition, and still has to get through the Lords.

The government is powerless to prevent the bid going to a competitor from Europe or the US although efforts are being made to ensure that the majority partner is British.

fields.headline: Canteen concert
fields.standfirst:
Steve Roden/Val Bertoia Hayward
Gallery Cafe, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText: Californian artist Steve Roden uses art and design objects to make music under the moniker of "in between noise". In his recent series of three-inch CDs he evokes an abstract, Miles-ish mood from a Charles Eames leg splint, or rubs a George Nelson lamp to produce a genie that is closer to Boulez than Robin Williams. Roden's latest mini-CD squeezes 20 minutes of electronica from a Knoll "Diamond" chair, the 50s design classic by Harry Bertoia.
fields.body:
Californian artist Steve Roden uses art and design objects to make music under the moniker of "in between noise". In his recent series of three-inch CDs he evokes an abstract, Miles-ish mood from a Charles Eames leg splint, or rubs a George Nelson lamp to produce a genie that is closer to Boulez than Robin Williams. Roden's latest mini-CD squeezes 20 minutes of electronica from a Knoll "Diamond" chair, the 50s design classic by Harry Bertoia.

Friday evening's event, the last in a series for the Hayward's Sonic Boom exhibition, focused on Bertoia's "sound sculpture" and closed with an eccentric talk and slide show by Val, the sculptor's son. Bertoia Jr noted that all metal sculptures have sound, but that what his father found interesting was "the development of harmonious sound". Many of Bertoia's works can be played as percussion instruments, though they also make pleasing noises when the wind blows, or when a studio cat picks its way across their coral-like mass.

For the first half Roden "performed" with the sounds of a small Bertoia sculpture, a metal maquette with rods and knobs like a 50s hat rack. Two television monitors displayed continuous video loops of the metal object: one showed his hands striking the sculpture's prongs while the other showed him bowing the rods with horsehair. He processed and mixed the sounds of these loops through a slowly evolving soundscape in which echo and pitch shift pedals changed the speed, density and timbre of the quiet metallic noises.

The unspoken thesis, unproved by either event or show, is that an aesthetically pleasing visual object should produce a correspondingly beautiful sound. "What's it like?" asked a gallery attendee outside the door. "Electronic pigeon noises," replied his departing friend. In the context of Sonic Boom, where you can flit from sound to sound like scanning pictures at an exhibition, the polite conventions of avant-garde performance were difficult to observe. Roden's sound levels were sometimes outgunned by the refrigeration unit in the cafe chill counter. The constant coming and going, doors swinging open to admit a blast of MOR balladry from Philip Jeck's distressed Dansette installation, made the event seem more like a pub gig than a cool soirée. Despite the Knoll connection, this wasn't furniture music, but Roden's modest half-hour piece, with its coherent sound palette and structure, survived.

webTitle: Grim find of 58 bodies in  lorry exposes smugglers' evil trade

fields.headline: Grim find of 58 bodies in  lorry exposes smugglers' evil trade
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Although he could not see right inside, the customs  officer knew something was terribly wrong the moment  he opened the heavy swing doors.
fields.byline: Nick Hopkins, Jeevan Vasagar, Paul Kelso and Andrew Osborn
fields.body:
Although he could not see right inside, the customs officer knew something was terribly wrong the moment he opened the heavy swing doors.

The container on the white Mercedes lorry was a refrigeration unit, yet the air that belched out was warm and smelled putrid.

In the half light, he saw two Chinese men sprawled in front of him, gasping for breath. Behind them in the gloom, the officer saw what a colleague described as a scene "out of a nightmare." Fifty-eight bodies lay haphazardly on the metal floor in between seven crates of tomatoes.

Police suspect the 54 men and four women found dead during the routine inspection at Dover just before midnight on Sunday were illegal entrants from the Fujian province of China, who paid a criminal gang, called snakeheads, thousands of pounds for the chance to start a new life in the UK.

Last night it emerged that a driver called Perry Whacker, probably a false name, had picked up the load of tomatoes in Rotterdam on Sunday. The company name on the lorry was Van Der Spek Transportation.

The firm has only been in business for four days and is registered in the name of Arie Van Der Spek, a 25-year-old electrical engineer.

Its address is a nondescript flat above a bicycle repair shop in the suburbs of Rotterdam. Last night Dutch police were searching the flat.

Earlier, as the police started their cross-border inquiry and continued to question the lorry driver, the home secretary, Jack Straw, led a chorus condemning the trafficking that had caused "a most terrible human tragedy." Those who perished "must have died a terrible death," he said during a statement to the Commons.

"Let no-one be in any doubt that this is a profoundly evil trade whose perpetrators have no regard for human life."

The prime minister, Tony Blair, who is at an EU summit in Portugal, called it a"dreadful incident."

As detectives moved the two men who survived from hospital to a police station ready for questioning, there were urgent calls for a reassessment of the goverment's policy towards illegal entrants.

According to recent figures, the Chinese are the second second largest group applying to stay in the UK. Many of them arrive without documents and China refuses to take them back.

Last year's Immigration Asylum Act, which introduced £2,000 fines for drivers caught carrying illegal entrants, led to a 26% fall in the number of people being caught at the docks.

However, Nick Hardwick, chief executive of the Refugee Council, said: "It is virtually impossible for people fleeing persecution to enter Britain legally and they are therefore forced to resort to such desperate measures in their search for sanctuary."

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, added: "What must now happen is for far greater co-operation between European governments to ensure that the same priority is given to the illegal asylum trade as to the illegal trade in drugs.

"People do very desperate things in these situations, and that is what seems to have happened here."

Kent police said it could be another 48 hours before post-mortems have been completed, but it is suspected the 58 people died from asphyxiaton.

The inquiry team, led by Det Supt Dennis McGookin, was last night trying to establish where the Chinese boarded the container, and how long they had been locked inside.

When the lorry started its journey in Rotterdam, it was loaded with a single container. From there, it was driven to the Belgium port at Zeebrugge.

Customs sources said yesterday that they thought the lorry had stayed near the dock all day in temperatures of up to 32C (90F), and that its refrigeration unit was turned off.

Some reports yesterday described how the Chinese, who were locked in from the outside, were already suffering in extreme conditions and tried to raise the alarm by banging on the doors and walls, screaming for help. It would have been difficult for anyone to hear their cries; the container is like a giant, airtight fridge.

One of the survivors apparently told an interpreter that he climbed over bodies and clawed at the door to try to get out.

Port officials said the lorry was one of the last to board the 7.30pm freight-only P&O Stena vessel, European Pathway, for the four and a half hour crossing to Dover.

Although late, the driver's papers were in order, there was no search of the vehicle or the cargo, which was documented as tomatoes.

The driver paid the £412.50, plus Vat, fare in cash. During the voyage, P&O faxed the details of every vehicle on the ferry to customs and immigration officials at Dover.

The Van Der Spek lorry immediately grabbed the attention of the five customs officers working the night shift. None of them had heard of the company, and the cash payment was considered strange.

"The lorry was considered a high risk," said a customs spokesman. It fitted the profile of one that could be used to smuggle cigarettes, drugs or contraband. We didn't have any prior intelligence about the vehicle. It was a hunch."

Oddly, immigration officers looking for illegal entrants had not earmarked it for inspection.

After the ferry docked in berth seven, the lorry drove down the ramps from the ship's upper decks, and was stopped at the customs checkpoint. As one of the team spoke to the driver, another walked to the back and began to unlock the doors.

The officer who saw the scenes first was "completely traumatised." Another said: "I will never forget the sight that greeted us when we opened the back doors. There were just piles and piles of bodies. It was absolutely sickening. We were also overcome by the most revolting smell." All of them received counselling and will be off work for several days.

The lorry was driven to bay nine of a rundown port warehouse, and then to a another shed 100 yards away where the police began the grim task of unloading the bodies and setting up a temporary morgue.

For the two survivors, who were taken to hospital suffering from dehydration and shock, another ordeal begins today.

As one police spokesman said: "If you were behind the criminal organisation of this, wouldn't you want to get to the survivors?

"This kind of thing doesn't happen spontaneously. You need levels of organisation and finance to do this."

Customs sources said yesterday that they thought the lorry had stayed near the dock all day in temperatures of up to 32C (90F), and that its refrigeration unit was turned off. Some reports yesterday described how the Chinese, who were locked in from the outside, were already suffering in extreme conditions and tried to raise the alarm by banging on the doors and walls, screaming for help. It would have been difficult for anyone to hear their cries; the container is like a giant, airtight fridge. One of the survivors apparently told an interpreter that he climbed over bodies and clawed at the door to try to get out. Port officials said the lorry was one of the last to board the 7.30pm freight-only P&O Stena vessel, European Pathway, for the four and a half hour crossing to Dover. Although late, the driver's papers were in order, there was no search of the vehicle or the cargo, which was documented as tomatoes. The driver paid the £412.50, plus Vat, fare in cash. During the voyage, P&O faxed the details of every vehicle on the ferry to customs and immigration officials at Dover. The Van Der Spek lorry immediately grabbed the attention of the five customs officers working the night shift. None of them had heard of the company, and the cash payment was considered strange. "The lorry was considered a high risk," said a customs spokesman. It fitted the profile of one that could be used to smuggle cigarettes, drugs or contraband. We didn't have any prior intelligence about the vehicle. It was a hunch." Oddly, immigration officers looking for illegal entrants had not earmarked it for inspection. After the ferry docked in berth seven, the lorry drove down the ramps from the ship's upper decks, and was stopped at the customs checkpoint. As one of the team spoke to the driver, another walked to the back and began to unlock the doors. The officer who saw the scenes first was "completely traumatised." Another said: "I will never forget the sight that greeted us when we opened the back doors. There were just piles and piles of bodies. It was absolutely sickening. We were also overcome by the most revolting smell." All of them received counselling and will be off work for several days. For the two survivors, who were taken to hospital suffering from dehydration and shock, another ordeal begins today. As one police spokesman said: "If you were behind the criminal organisation of this, wouldn't you want to get to the survivors? "This kind of thing doesn't happen spontaneously. You need levels of organisation and finance to do this."

fields.headline: Police begin to piece together horrific details
fields.standfirst:
Chinese pair questioned as they recover in hospital from their ordeal.

Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Chinese pair questioned as  they recover in hospital from their ordeal.
fields.byline: Jeevan Vasagar, Paul Kelso, Vikram Dodd and Andrew Osborn in Zeebrugge
fields.body:
Police were last night pinning their hopes on two survivors as they tried to piece together a complete picture of how 58 people died in the back of a lorry in Dover.

The pair, believed to be Chinese, were being questioned by police yesterday evening.

They were taken to Kent and Canterbury hospital for treatment for the effects of being trapped in the lorry, which had its refrigeration unit switched off as temperatures outside touched 90 degrees fahrenheit.

They were understood to have been severely dehydrated and barely able to speak a word when discovered. A nurse at the hospital said: "They needed psychological counselling rather than treatment."

Yesterday afternoon they were moved to a police station where, through interpreters, detectives began trying to gain first-hand accounts of the nightmare ordeal.

Police are aware that the lives of the survivors could be in danger from whoever was behind the smuggling racket, and provided a guard of 10 officers throughout the day.

Mark Pugash of Kent police said: "If you were behind the organisation of this, wouldn't you want to get to the survivors? This kind of thing doesn't happen spontaneously on this scale. You need levels of organisation and finance to do this."

The appalling conditions in the steel box in the summer heat attached to the lorry probably meant the people suffocated to death, a haulage expert said.

Geoff Dossitter, of the Freight Transport Association, said those who died would have suffocated "one by one" as the oxygen in the sealed container ran out.

Mr Dossitter, who is giving evidence to the Commons home affairs select committee inquiry into immigration today, said: "These must have been the most horrendous deaths. You have got 60 people in the back of a vehicle and they are packed into a sealed container. The oxygen must have run out.

"It is sealed like a massive household fridge so there is no way air could have got out. I have heard of cases of this sort in the past but not this many people in a sealed container."

The Dutch lorry driver was being questioned by detectives investigating the tragedy.

The senior investigating officer is Det Supt Dennis McGookin, who led the Kenneth Noye murder inquiry.

He said: "This is a dreadful tragedy. My role is to establish if there is anyone who should be held criminally responsible."

While a forensic examination of the lorry was carried out by police scientists dressed in protective white suits, the bodies were left where they were found.

They were eventually moved to a makeshift mortuary in the docks area before being transferred to different hospitals to undergo post-mortem examinations by Home Office pathologists. Last night the bodies of the 54 men and four women were in two hospital mortuaries.

Dover's Labour MP, Gwyn Prosser, praised the authorities for their professional handling of an "appalling" situation and said he hoped the incident would remind local people of the desperation among some asylum seekers.

"If anything comes out of this horrific night I hope it will be to remind people of the kind of desperation and fear of persecution that leads people to travel across half the world to escape. It is a horrifying human tragedy that we have witnessed here today. For the police and customs officials here it must have been hell.

"People have been imported to the country with promises of jobs. They are then exploited for months and years. It is almost a form of slavery."

The investigation into the 58 deaths will spread to Belgium, where the lorry came from, and the Netherlands where it is believed to be registered.

Rose van Hoorickx of P&O North Sea Ferries, who handle loading and unloading at Zeebrugge, said measures were in place to stop people getting on board lorries once they were in the port.

She said there were fences, guard patrols and cameras to ensure people did not get into the terminal.

"We do everything possible not to have illegals on our terrain. They must have already been in the trailer.

"They pay a lot of money to get here. They are desperate, they want to get to England. It's the first time we have had so many though."

She added that usually the containers were sealed and if that was the case you needed permission from the transport company to open them.

At Zeebrugge lorries were yesterday passing through customs without being checked.

Luc Missine, spokesman for P&O's Stena Line at the port, said there was an agreement with local police to carry out spot checks and sometimes they received tip-offs about lorries containing human cargo.

"There are hardly any checks in Europe. Spot checks would affect the timing and costs. It's a problem we face every day. It's been going on for many years. However, this changes the whole picture. In future we will need to find a solution to this problem. We will have to look into it and sort out the problem of illegals in general," he said.

"For P&O staff it is a great shock to hear that these people were on their ferry. It has happened before but fortunately not very often, three or four people at most. Individuals have died because of a lack of food and drink. We can't avoid them jumping on somewhere else. It's not certain that the lorry driver was aware that he was carrying illegals."

fields.headline: Austria threatens sanctions retaliation
fields.standfirst:
Austria could block plans to enlarge the European Union and reform its creaking institutions if the quarantine imposed on its rightwing coalition government is not lifted, it hinted yesterday.

The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Hopes for movement during the Feira summit  appeared to have been dashed as plans for  easing the punitive measures were at a virtual  standstill. Wolfgang Schussel, the Austrian  chancellor, admitted last night that the situation  was bleak, after failing to persuade fellow leaders  to change tack during a tense discussion over  lunch. "I am not very hopeful."
fields.body:
Hopes for movement during the Feira summit appeared to have been dashed as plans for easing the punitive measures were at a virtual standstill. Wolfgang Schussel, the Austrian chancellor, admitted last night that the situation was bleak, after failing to persuade fellow leaders to change tack during a tense discussion over lunch. "I am not very hopeful."

The unprecedented bilateral sanctions were imposed by all other 14 EU member states in February after the far right Freedom party, then led by the controversial Jörg Haider, joined Chancelor Schussel's coalition. Portugal had proposed that Austria's behaviour could be monitored by forthcoming EU presidencies to ensure that it lived up to "European values", although not before Sweden's turn next January.

France, assuming the rotating presidency on July 1, is a hardline opponent of any concessions to Vienna, largely because of the wish to send a strong message to its own far right.

Diplomats said Mr Schussel might have been prepared to accept monitoring by the more neutral European Commission, but only if the sanctions were suspended immediately.

Britain had been quietly lobbying to "open a door" to Austria to allow this deeply divisive issue to fade away with a minimum loss of face.

But the possible price of its enforced isolation was underlined by Mr Schussel's finance minister, Karl-Heinz Grasser, who said: "Enlargement cannot be debated when inside the EU there is no constructive cooperation."

webTitle: Deaths highlight contradiction at heart of Geneva convention

fields.headline: Deaths highlight contradiction at heart of Geneva convention
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: When Jack Straw floated his plan last week to rewrite  the 1951 Geneva convention on refugees it was greeted  by British asylum groups with suspicion over his true  motives and objections about how it might work in  practice.
fields.body:
When Jack Straw floated his plan last week to rewrite the 1951 Geneva convention on refugees it was greeted by British asylum groups with suspicion over his true motives and objections about how it might work in practice.

But the horrific discovery yesterday of the bodies of 58 desperate people who tried to enter Britain clandestinely underlined why his proposal was received with great interest by EU ministers of the interior when he outlined it to them in Lisbon last Friday.

Nick Hardwick, the chief executive of the Refugee Council, said yesterday: "The real crux of the problem is that it is virtually impossible for people fleeing persecution to enter Britain legally and they are therefore forced to resort to such desperate measures in their search for sanctuary."

The home secretary identified the "essential contradiction" at the heart of the 1951 convention as being that, while it confers on the individual the right to claim asylum, it does not place a similar obligation upon any particular country to admit them to enable them to make that claim. The result is that even genuine asylum seekers have to enter Britain illegally in order to claim asylum, often at the mercy of criminal traffickers.

Mr Straw's proposal involves allowing people who want to claim asylum to lodge that claim outside the country, so removing the need for them to smuggle themselves into the country on false documents or in the back of a lorry. Those fleeing countries where it is internationally recognised that there are severe human rights abuses would be given temporary protection under an international system of quotas. One benefit for the host country would be that it would no longer have to shoulder the cost of accommodating and supporting asylum seekers while their claim was decided.

The quid pro quo would be that those who came from countries, including EU countries, internationally regarded as "safe" and from which an asylum application was likely to prove unfounded would generally not have their asylum claims entertained. The basic international right to asylum would be maintained for individuals who could demonstrate a clear case of political persecution.

Mr Straw said he regarded this issue as the "most acutely difficult ethical issue I have had to deal with in government".

Reaction from British refugee groups was sceptical. Asylum Aid, which works with refugees, said it only took moments to spot the flaws in his plan. "Who will guarantee the safety of a fugitive from a repressive regime pending a decision on their application?" asked its director, Alasdair Mackenzie. "It is hardly to be imagined that the British embassy will put them up while they wait."

A Labour MEP and immigration expert, Claude Moraes, agreed with Mr Straw that there was an undoubted need to revise the Geneva convention to meet the needs of those fleeing deep poverty as well as torture and persecution. But any such revision should not be "a backdoor method of excluding genuine asylum seekers who in their desperation will break the immigration laws in fleeing persecution. They will often have the most difficult cases to prove, having destroyed their documentation or suffering severe trauma."

The United Nations high commissioner for refugees was also alarmed by Mr Straw's plan and restated its belief that the 1951 convention remains a resilient instrument to provide protection from persecution and violence to millions of refugees. Schemes for temporary protection were no substitutes for the convention itself, it said.

webTitle: World Online deal with Brink still on ice

fields.headline: World Online deal with Brink still on ice
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
www.worldonline.com
fields.trailText: World Online has yet to conclude the expected consultancy agreement with founder Nina Brink who resigned as chairman in controversial circumstances in April.
fields.body:
World Online has yet to conclude the expected consultancy agreement with founder Nina Brink who resigned as chairman in controversial circumstances in April.

James Kinsella, who was formally elected chairman of the Dutch-based internet service provider at the annual meeting yesterday, is expected to hold talks with Ms Brink soon.

When she resigned, the World Online supervisory board indicated that she would be offered a consultancy agreement but that has not yet been concluded.

A company spokeswoman said that Mr Kinsella, who will receive a $1m salary plus stock options, had been busy meeting staff, investors and customers since he had joined the group had not yet begun negotiations over an agreement with Ms Brink.

Ms Brink resigned as chairman in April after it emerged that she had sold the bulk of her stake in the group ahead of its stock market flotation at a level below the 43 (£27) price at which World Online shares were offered to investors. The share price subsequently fell as low as 10 in late May but has since recovered to just below 15.

At the annual meeting yesterday Mr Kinsella - a former Microsoft vice-president and president and chief executive of Microsoft's joint venture with NBC - said the company had great prospects.

He said: "We recently reported results for the first quarter which showed strong subscriber growth."

At a bad-tempered meeting executives sought to reassure shareholders that the volatility which had swept through high-technology stock markets just after World Online had made its market debut had had a significant bearing on the performance of the shares.

However, a scheme to help staff who bought shares as part offer to sell them back at the purchase price came under heavy fire.

webTitle: Fast moving world of a web designer

fields.headline: Fast moving world of a web designer
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
First-e
fields.trailText: David Bermingham could be forgiven for wondering whether he is coming or going. The 27-year-old computer programmer for internet bank First-e has moved offices four times in the past four months.
fields.body:
David Bermingham could be forgiven for wondering whether he is coming or going. The 27-year-old computer programmer for internet bank First-e has moved offices four times in the past four months.

Now he is packing up the contents of his desk once again as his employees move offices once again in an attempt to keep most of its fast growing workforce together in one place. "God knows where we'll be off to next," he said.

Mr Bermingham joined First-e last summer after three years with Visio, a local software company. He is now one of the senior web designers but four years ago when he originally graduated from Trinity College in Dublin with a business studies degree he had barely considered working for an internet company.

Unsure what it was he wanted to do, he plumped to stay on at college for a further year and take a postgraduate qualification in information technology.

His timing was perfect. "By the time I was leaving college the internet was starting to happen and all of a sudden a career in IT was looking unusually appealing. Start-ups were springing up offering young people the opportunity to take responsibility in explosive growth companies."

When he joined First-e it employed 70 people. Today there are 300 staff and a new owner, Uno-E of Spain following a £1.5bn merger in March. Mr Bermingham has no regrets about not following a more traditional career path. "The working environment is relaxed, it's less hierarchical and you don't have to wait three years for a promotion.You expect to move up in 12 months if you do well."

He says his generation's success is conspicuous. "A lot of people my age are going skiing at Easter, to Thailand in the summer then having another holiday before the year is over."

But their money cannot buy everything. "House prices make it almost impossible for people between 25-35 to buy. Most people under 30 are throwing away dead money on rent because even if you earn £20,000-£30,000 you can't afford to buy."

Bars in town charge almost £3 for a pint of beer, while coffee shops line both sides of streets like the historic Baggot Street. "The wealth is conspicuous. You'd expect scenes like this in the US not Dublin. There's a real feeling in the city that good times have arrived," Mr Bermingham said.

fields.headline: New direction  for InterX
fields.trailText: Computer group InterX has turned to high-profile software executive Philip Crawford to oversee an ambitious strategic shift that aims to turn the British hardware distributor into a global software business.
fields.body:
Computer group InterX has turned to high-profile software executive Philip Crawford to oversee an ambitious strategic shift that aims to turn the British hardware distributor into a global software business.

Mr Crawford is likely to become chief executive of InterX in August once the sale of its Ideal hardware distribution firm to Bell Microproducts of the US has been completed for about £20m.

He is at present chairman of Cromwell Media - a web platform developer bought by InterX in February for £226m and the planned cornerstone of the new business; before that he held senior positions with Oracle and computer services group EDS.

James Wickes, the chief executive and Ideal's founder, is to become group marketing director. "I've been trying to persuade Philip to take over for some time," Mr Wickes said. "He is one of Europe's pre-eminent software specialists and it would be illogical for me not to allow him to take the business forward."

The market reacted positively, marking InterX shares up 12% at £14.50.

fields.body:
Petrol prices are soaring to unprecedented levels in parts of the US, causing outrage among car drivers pinning their hopes for some respite on tomorrow's meeting of the oil producing nations.

In parts of the mid-west, where gas-guzzling "off-roaders" are a common sight, prices at the pump tipped over the $2 a gallon this weekend, double the level of a year ago and higher than their recent peak in the early 1990s during the Gulf war.

Prices are rising so quickly that the rate of increase is at its fastest in some parts of the US since the oil crisis of 1973. Prices at the pumps started rising in mid-May and started to accelerate last week. The Wall Street Journal quoted Lionel Robin, a textile saleman filing his 1992 Jaguar in Chicago as saying: "How many four letter words can I use? You eat through $10 bills like it's nothing"

While the price - equivalent to 35p a litre - is still low by comparison with Britain, Americans have traditionally enjoyed cheap petrol prices. Such is the degree of concern about fuel prices in the mid-west American heartland that President Bill Clinton last week asked the federal trade commission to investigate the prices being charged at the pumps - some of which are reported to have run dry in Detriot at the weekend.

Figures from the American Automobile Association - compiled daily by collecting prices at 60,000 filling stations around the country - show that motorists in Illinois can expect to pay an average of $2.20 for gallon of premium petrol while those in Georgia can pay $1.62.

With the Opec meeting tomorrow pressure is now building for the oil producing nations to increase production to help reduce prices.

Speaking yesterday, Ali Rodriguez, Opec's president, appeared to suggest that the nations were prepared to increase output for the second time since March, when it was raised by 7%.

Mr Rodriguez, while insisting that there was not a supply problem, was quoted as saying: "There is an intense problem of speculation, especially in the US because of the gasoline problem.

"If necessary, production will be raised - but that is what we have to analyse, whether an increase is necessary because there is no supply problem."

His comments were cited as a reason for slight easing of oil prices yesterday on the major exchanges but the key indicator, crude oil, remained above the $30-a-barrel mark which even the producers themselves are thought to regard as being too high.

Bruce Steinberg, the chief economist at investment bank Merrill Lynch, pointed out that local issues such as special formulations of petrol being introduced to reduce summer smog but which are more difficult to produce were causing supply problems.

fields.headline: 3,000 go as PO loses £264m
fields.trailText: The Post Office yesterday said it would shed 3,000 jobs in the next year after huge spending to computerise the network resulted in a £264m loss after tax.
fields.body:
The Post Office yesterday said it would shed 3,000 jobs in the next year after huge spending to computerise the network resulted in a £264m loss after tax.

A £571m writedown on the computer system was forced after the government announced earlier this year that pensions and benefits would be paid directly into claimants' bank accounts from 2003 instead of being handled by the Post Office.

Those payments account for over a third of the income for branch post offices.

The Post Office had earmarked £1bn to be spent on introducing a computer sys tem across its 18,500-strong network which would have dealt with pension and benefit payments and other services. The switch to a banking system resulted in much of the technology, developed by computer services firm ICL, becoming redundant.

Almost 8,000 post offices have already been automated and 300 more are being equipped each week.

"Despite the very difficult competitive circumstances in the year our sales did grow 7% and our volume growth was very credible," Neville Bain, the Post Office chairman, said. "We are very confident we will be in full profit in the current year."

The after-tax loss compared with a £496m profit in 1999. On a pre-tax basis the Post Office reported a loss of £171m compared with a profit in the previous year of £608m.

The fall in earnings also resulted from and increased competition and the Post Office's decision to freeze or cut postal prices during the year.

Post Office executives still received part of their bonus packages despite failing to reach the profit target set by the government. The Post Office defended the payments saying that executives performance targets varied as part of their remuneration scheme.

In 2001 the government requires the Post Office to achieve a pre-tax profit of £392m.

Domestic letters carried by Royal Mail increased by 4.6% to 80m in the year.

However, the explosion of text messaging on mobile phones and email has shaved 1.7% off the growth in Royal Mail volumes.

Last year 382 post offices closed despite the development of other services such as banking which is expected to prop up the income base and replace lost revenues when the payment service for pensions and benefits transfers to the banks.

Post Office chief executive John Roberts said that the effect of the losses meant that the Post Office would have to continue to seek cost savings.

webTitle: Staff outrage as 1st Line pulls the plug

fields.headline: Staff outrage as 1st Line pulls the plug
fields.standfirst: Call centres thrive despite collapse of  firm which made dunces of its workers
fields.trailText: The mobile phone revolution hit Wales last week and crashed, leaving 2,000 mainly young entrants to the new economy redundant at a stroke. Angry ex-employees of 1st Line Mobile Communications, many of them unable to meet their bills, gathered outside the company's two call centres in Swansea and Cardiff to demand an explanation - and their weekly wages, which went unpaid.
fields.body:
The mobile phone revolution hit Wales last week and crashed, leaving 2,000 mainly young entrants to the new economy redundant at a stroke. Angry ex-employees of 1st Line Mobile Communications, many of them unable to meet their bills, gathered outside the company's two call centres in Swansea and Cardiff to demand an explanation - and their weekly wages, which went unpaid.

In Swansea the anger was so intense that windows were smashed, but the directors of a company that had promised to be part of a paradigm shift in the Welsh economy from traditional manufacturing to services were nowhere to be found.

1st Line had abruptly ceased trading, blaming the withdrawal of support from "a major creditor" - and owing, it is understood, millions of pounds. Only now, as former staff, some of whom had worked for the company for a matter of days, learn they may get some of their money and/or redundancy payments, is that understandable ire beginning to abate.

On June 27 the few remaining directors, shareholders and creditors will be asked to approve insolvency experts Grant Thornton, or another firm of accountants, as liquidator.

This sorry demise of a company born less than two years ago has brought a fair share of anger, too, to hapless members of the new national assembly, including first secretary Rhodri Morgan, unable to intervene because no government aid is involved, and to frustrated union officials, denied negotiating rights and told just four days before the company went under that an initial swath of 450 job losses would rescue it.

There are signs a week after 1st Line's collapse that the company is being treated, as Max Munday of the Welsh economy research unit at Cardiff business school puts it, as "an aberration" and one that poses no serious risk to the present and future role of call centres in propelling Wales towards a high-quality, hi-tech service economy.

Certainly, the company engaged in some unusual business and employment practices, which one MP has likened to those of the 19th century.

Consumer programmes such as the BBC television's Watchdog (and our own consumer pages) reported a spate of complaints from customers, many of them elderly, about hard-sell cold-calling and activating bank direct debits before the promised 30-day trial period was over.

Too much, too soon

But 1st Line grew to the extent it could claim to be Britain's biggest retailer of post-pay mobile phones, with 250,000 customers and staff, often teenagers, earning up to £1,000 a week in pay and commission. But the staff was undergoing about the same rate of "churn" as the customers, many of them leaving in disgust at practices such as waving fistfuls of tenners to encourage them to sell, forcing slow learners to stand in corners with a dunce's hat on and dressing down in public those unable to make a quick sale.

This year the business ran into financial difficulties as daily sales fell from 500 to just five at the end of May. A television relaunch featuring Melinda Messenger, and extensive retraining of staff failed to staunch the losses. 1st Line was, essentially, a telesales unit with no assets and, as churn grew, four directors quit the board.

One, Philip Ruddall, has said he was told that the company had no chance of succeeding. Its marketing agency, it is understood, presented a winding-up order to it, and Cellular Ops, which handled billing and supplied the Ericsson mobile phone handsets, pulled the plug.

But the company was just one of 80 call centres in Wales where, after its demise, more than 12,000 still work in the sector. Mr Munday says Wales has been successful in attracting relatively low-skilled jobs such as back-office functions within the financial services sector as a whole - rather than the high-quality call centres deliberately sought and won by cities such as Dublin and Glasgow.

He is worried that Wales will lose out as business and its clients switch to web-based technology which does not rely on human contact. But Sandra Busby, head of the Cardiff and Newport call centre initiative, a body backed by the WDA and local authorities, disputes this.

Future on the web

Her remit is to attract new web-enabled, multi-channel call centres to south-east Wales, and so far, out of the 53 set up in the area, around a dozen have this greater technological facility. These include ones established by the Royal College of Nursing, the health and safety executive, Yes TV and the inland revenue, which tend to employ graduates and offer advice and consultancy on an interactive basis.

"Call centres are all about delivering customer services and the key to that is the skill and ability of the people working in them and any company which does not embrace that won't survive," she said. "And these centres offer proper training and higher salaries. We are new compared to Dublin and Glasgow, and Wales employs just 1.1% of the labour force in call centres compared with a UK average of 1.9%.

"We are in a prime position to capture the new, multi-channel centres and many of the existing ones are upgrading to that status."

Wales, which traditionally suffers from poor education and training, has pioneered a range of national vocational qualifications courses up to Level 4 which are geared towards call centre work and about to be launched and then rolled out across Britain.

fields.headline: Tourist limbers up for space
fields.trailText: A 59-year-old American businessman announced yesterday that he is to become the world's first space tourist - provided he passes a rigorous Russian cosmonaut training programme.
fields.body:
A 59-year-old American businessman announced yesterday that he is to become the world's first space tourist - provided he passes a rigorous Russian cosmonaut training programme.

Denis Tito's desire to travel to Russia's Mir space station - promoted by its new leaseholders, MirCorp, as a potential holiday destination - is so strong that the danger and the ticket price, which runs, he says, into tens of millions of dollars, have not dissuaded him from his goal.

"There are always some risks involved in going into space and there have of course been some fatalities," he said.

"It's not as if I'm taking a motorcycle and jumping over fountains in Las Vegas or going bungee jumping or sky diving. I'm going to be doing something very serious."

Before he is permitted to make the trip, a date for which has yet to be set, Mr Tito will have to undergo between two and four months of training in Star City, the centre of Russia's space programme.
