fields.headline: Arnault postpones Europ@web fund float
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Groupe Arnault yesterday postponed the stock market flotation of its Europ@web internet investment fund.
fields.body:
Groupe Arnault yesterday postponed the stock market flotation of its Europ@web internet investment fund.

The announcement came less than 24 hours before the group was due to give details of a planned market listing for Europ@web, which had been expected to take place early next month.

Groupe Arnault - the holding company of Bernard Arnault, the head of luxury goods group LVMH - said the decision followed "recent discussions regarding strategic alternatives".

Industry watchers believe that one possibility could be that the group may have been concerned that market conditions might have affected the value it would realise from a listing.

Europ@web's biggest investment is holding around one third of internet services provider Liberty Surf.

The company's portfolio includes shareholdings in companies such as the British auction site, i-Collector, artprice.com and e-Luxury.

Groupe Arnault said yesterday that it would continue to discuss its strategy options before going ahead with any listing for Europ@web.

The group did not commit itself to a listing timetable - saying only that it had told the French stock market authorities that "it will not be proceeding with the initial public offering of Europe@web before the summer".

webTitle: Data miners play leading role in frontier drama

fields.headline: Data miners play leading role in frontier drama
fields.standfirst:
Even by the standards of Ireland's fast growing e-economy, the sudden emergence of Dublin's Norkom Technologies has surprised most people

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Even by the standards of Ireland's fast growing  e-economy, the sudden emergence of Dublin's Norkom  Technologies has surprised most people
fields.body:
Last month it won e-challenge 2000 to be named Best Internet & Wireless Company in Europe, beating over 1,000 companies from 19 countries. The judges' attention was drawn to Norkom's software - Alchemist - which uses sophisticated data mining techniques to help firms understand customers needs, how to retain them and how to extract maximum value from them.

For example a high-street bank could use Alchemist to determine how much its account holders are likely to net the bank, how likely they are to move on and what supplementary financial products they are most likely to buy. Norkom says the reduction in customer churn and customer acquisition costs can be dramatic.

Norkom was set up in March 1998. It employs 210 people in Dublin, London, Ghent and Boston and is forecast to generate annual revenues of ?20m by the end of its third year.

The local business establishment, never keen to miss an opportunity, has already started to climb aboard the bandwagon. Celebrated local tech entrepreneur Denis O'Brien, chairman of Esat Telecom, and Gavin O'Reilly, son of Heinz boss Tony O'Reilly and managing director of Independent Newspapers, recently became non-executive directors and will provide strategic advice.

They also invested as part of a fundraising round that valued Norkom at £66m. Advisers at Lehman Brothers in London are keen to take the company public later this year.

At Norkom's helm is chief executive Paul Kerley, a 36-year-old Dubliner, who has spent the past 18 years working in software and consulting roles. He and four founding members own around 58% of Norkom. He believes that, in five years, Norkom can become the global leader in a field estimated to be worth £4.5bn.

Although committed to his home city and impressed by its transformation over the past few years, he realises that Norkom's location could be a key challenge to growth.

Recruitment and office space are two of the biggest issues. Norkom has already recruited in China and India but Mr Kerley hopes more Irish people can be taken on now that many are coming home from overseas. "Speed to market is everything in this business. We cannot lose velocity, but I'm confident we won't get left behind. The Irish are like salmon. Come spawning time they move back upstream."

Norkom uses three offices to house its 120 Dublin-based staff but it is looking for 60,000sq ft of floor space to bring them all together.

"Space is at a premium and finding the right location is very difficult. Many of our staff are young and don't particularly want to work at a technology park somewhere outside town. It could affect our ability to retain staff if we were forced to move outside Dublin."

Mr Kerley has sympathy with the locals who are not riding the technology boom. "It's causing a lot of upset. Teachers, police and medical staff have lived the past 100 years in parity, working in nice safe jobs. Now they find they can earn four times as much working for a technology company."

However, he believes that the social consensus that has emerged between employers and unions is likely to remain as long as the economy stays buoyant. "Some very enlightened decisions have been made in terms of education, telecoms and infrastructure."

However he cannot see an easy solution to Dublin's road and public transport problem. "There's going to be another 10 years of hell but it will be sorted. The government and EU have invested heavily in things like telecoms and education. So we still have Mediterranean roads, but if that's our problem I'll take it."

fields.headline: Carphone Warehouse controls float plans
fields.trailText: Carphone Warehouse yesterday announced a scheme to limit any potentially damaging volatility in the company's shares in the weeks after its planned stock market flotation.
fields.body:
Carphone Warehouse yesterday announced a scheme to limit any potentially damaging volatility in the company's shares in the weeks after its planned stock market flotation.

The mobile phone retailer intends to give priority to private investors who agree to hang on to their shares for at least three months. In the likely event that the offer is oversubscribed, retail investors signing up to the lock- in will jump to the head of the queue when the shares are allocated.

The scheme may go some way to warding off fears over the jittery state of the markets, which has caused a number of planned flotations to cancel at the last minute.

Up to 25% of the shares have been earmarked for private investors, although a final figure has yet to be decided.

The minimum retail application for shares in the business will be £1,000 and the maximum limit has been set at £50,000. Application forms will be available from the group's chain of 800 stores.

Charles Dunstone, founder and chief executive of Carphone Warehouse, said the structure of the offer had been created to encourage long-term holders of the stock.

"We have seen the problems in some other share offers of having to scale down applications to low levels," he said. "We have also seen there has been no ability to distinguish in allocation between short term and longer term in vestors. We wanted to create a structure which does enable that differentiation and which allows us to allocate sensible numbers of shares to retail applicants who wish to hold shares for the longer term."

The prospectus for the offer will be published later this month.

Carphone Warehouse is offering 20% of its enlarged share capital for sale, although that could rise to 25% dependent on demand. The flotation is likely to value the business at between £1.6bn-£2bn.

The scheme may go some way to warding off fears over the jittery state of the markets, which has caused a number of planned flotations to cancel at the last minute. Up to 25% of the shares have been earmarked for private investors, although a final figure has yet to be decided. The minimum retail application for shares in the business will be £1,000 and the maximum limit has been set at £50,000. Application forms will be available from the group's chain of 800 stores. Charles Dunstone, founder and chief executive of Carphone Warehouse, said the structure of the offer had been created to encourage long-term holders of the stock. "We have seen the problems in some other share offers of having to scale down applications to low levels," he said. "We have also seen there has been no ability to distinguish in allocation between short term and longer term in vestors. We wanted to create a structure which does enable that differentiation and which allows us to allocate sensible numbers of shares to retail applicants who wish to hold shares for the longer term." The prospectus for the offer will be published later this month. Carphone Warehouse is offering 20% of its enlarged share capital for sale, although that could rise to 25% dependent on demand. The flotation is likely to value the business at between £1.6bn-£2bn.

fields.headline: Anger at Gent's £10m bonus
fields.trailText: Vodafone AirTouch yesterday provoked the wrath of the investment community after it revealed plans to pay at least £20m in bonuses to executives for the successful takeover of German telecommunications group Mannesmann.
fields.body:
Vodafone AirTouch yesterday provoked the wrath of the investment community after it revealed plans to pay at least £20m in bonuses to executives for the successful takeover of German telecommunications group Mannesmann.

Vodafone, Britain's largest company, said its chief executive, Chris Gent, would receive £5m in cash and £5m in shares as a bonus for the completion of the deal.

The payments will be in addition to Mr Gent's salary package of £1.36m, the £2m in shares he holds and options on 2.58m shares exercisable at an average price of 111.1p, the company said.

Ken Hydon, group financial director, and Julian Horn Smith, chief executive of Vodafone's Europe, Middle East and African operations, also each receive £2m in cash and £2m in shares as bonuses for the Mannesman deal. Two other executive directors will also receive a cash bonus of £1m each.

The part payment of the bonus in shares will not be made until 2002 and is conditional on certain profit growth targets being achieved.

Vodafone further announced it had changed its global remuneration plan so that base salary and short incentives only accounted for 25% of the target remuneration. The remaining 75% would be paid by share option schemes with attached performance targets.

Vodafone said historically it had not approved the payment of special bonuses and it was not policy to do so.

The company qualified these bonus payments in its annual report by saying its size had quadrupled in the past 18 months and that remuneration of its executives was not set at internationally competitive levels. "The executive talent needed to maximise returns for shareholders in the international business of telecommunications is very scarce and the future performance of the company will depend on its ability to incentivise its employees and to offer remuneration packages which are competitive," the report said.

Alan MacDougall, managing director of Pirc, the corporate governance research group, said the bonuses were not justified.

"There was no discussion of these bonuses in the takeover documentation. We simply don't believe that by quadrupling the assets of the business through takeover that these bonuses are justified."

He said the success of the Mannesmann takeover would still not be known for several years.

"When I have spoken to other fund managers it's certainly a concept that isn't at all popular. I think managers do want companies to know this [bonus payment] is not a model to copy."

Vodafone bought Mannesman for £107bn, completing the deal earlier this year.

Mr MacDougall said: "The evidence seems to suggest that hostile takeovers are usually unsuccessful in creating shareholder value."

Michael McKlerzy, manager of investment affairs, at the Association of British Insurers, said: "Shareholders will wish to satisfy themselves that this is a one-off. We would not want to make this a precedent. It appears to a be a significant amount of money."

Vodafone's shares fell 13.75p to 311.25p yesterday.

There was some support among Vodafone AirTouch's bigger shareholders. One fund manager said: "I don't have any problem with it. It was one of the biggest corporate deals ever."

Vodafone AirTouch said it had consulted with at least 20 of its institutional shareholders before introducing the package and had also used the remuneration consultant, William M Mercer.

webTitle: District nurses seek end to parking fines

fields.headline: District nurses seek end to parking fines
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: District nurses warned yesterday that their job at the forefront of the government's health reforms is being frustrated by local parking restrictions which deny them easy access to their patients.
fields.body:
District nurses warned yesterday that their job at the forefront of the government's health reforms is being frustrated by local parking restrictions which deny them easy access to their patients.

The Community and District Nursing Association said its members' cars were regularly ticketed and clamped during urgent house calls.

Parking on a yellow line might be unavoidable if they were to get through their patient caseload, but health authorities invariably refused to pay the fines.

Ann Keen, Labour MP for Brentford and Isleworth and a former district nurse, said the government wanted local authorities to exempt key health workers from parking restrictions. It recommended they should provide a windscreen sticker, recognised by traffic wardens and police, for those making home visits.

But, although such a scheme operates in London, government advice is being ignored in most parts of the country.

Ms Keen said a district nurse in Torbay was made to hand over her wedding ring as security before a clamp could be removed from her car to allow her to attend other patients.

Sandie Eckersall, a district nursing sister in Stockport, said she recently got a parking ticket during a 15 minute house call. Parking legitimately was often impractical because nurses had to go back and forth to their cars for equipment. But her health authority would not pay the fine.

She said Stockport council was keen to introduce an exemption scheme for health workers, but the chief constable wanted it to cover all of Greater Manchester and other boroughs were dragging their feet.

The association said more than 35,000 hospital patients could be treated at home if community health and social services were set up to operate 24 hours a day.

"This could reduce winter beds pressures, bring much needed dignity to the care of older people, and be a more efficient way of running a modern NHS," said Anne Duffy, association chairwoman.

"Delays caused by parking problems often result in increased stress to the district nurse, the patient and family who must wait for treatment. Intensive care does take place in the home. We would not expect a hospital based intensive care nurse to endure the same problems," she said.

fields.headline: Man Utd signs an adviser
fields.trailText: Manchester United yesterday effectively ruled out signing away its media agency rights to a major broadcaster by appointing independent consultants Media Content to advise on all future rights negotiations.
fields.body:
Manchester United yesterday effectively ruled out signing away its media agency rights to a major broadcaster by appointing independent consultants Media Content to advise on all future rights negotiations.

Peter Kenyon, deputy chief executive of United, said Aim-listed Media Content had been contracted to advise on all online and off-line media issues until June 2002. Shares in Media Content rose 65% to 9.5p.

United is bucking a trend set by several rivals, including Chelsea and Aston Villa, who have taken on broadcasters BSkyB and NTL to advise on media negotiations in exchange for an investment in new shares. United believes there is more value in remaining independent, particularly in light of the recent £1.6bn sale of Premier League broadcasting rights.

Analysts said the move was ironic given that 18 months ago the United board voted to sell the club in its entirety to BSkyB for £623m.

They expect Media Content, whose clients include the World Wide Wrestling Federation and New Zealand Rugby Football Union, to make the development of Manutd.com and overseas expansion of television channel MUTV top priorities.

webTitle: Ex-minister hit woman after night out, court told

fields.headline: Ex-minister hit woman after night out, court told
fields.trailText: A former Conservative minister caused a 23-year-old woman to "fear for her life" as he punched her in the face and flung her into a parked car, breaking her elbow, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A former Conservative minister caused a 23-year-old woman to "fear for her life" as he punched her in the face and flung her into a parked car, breaking her elbow, a court heard yesterday.

Rod Richards, the former Tory leader in the Welsh assembly, assaulted Cassandra Melvin just hours after taking her and her sister, Tiffany, for a meal, it was alleged.

Mr Richards, of Radyr, Cardiff, has pleaded not guilty to causing grievous bodily harm.

Minutes before the assault he had been smoking cannabis, Kingston crown court heard, but the evening turned sour when Miss Melvin struggled to shut him out of the sisters' flat where he had invited himself back for coffee.

"He was on one side of the door, pushing and shouting, being really aggressive, and I was on the other side, fearing for my life," the former coffee shop manager said.

The court heard that the couple had never met before the evening of the alleged assault, July 27 last year, when Mr Richards, a junior Welsh minister in John Major's government, approached the sisters in the Victoria Inn in Richmond, Surrey.

The married father of three suggested the trio went on for a pizza and then "out on the razzle", Miss Melvin said.

She had agreed and they had gone to Pizza Express for a meal and two bottles of wine - for which the Clwyd West AM had paid.

At the end of the meal, Miss Melvin had ordered two cabs, but had been surprised when Mr Richards had joined the sisters in theirs. "He said he wanted to see us home and that he would drop us en route," she told the court. But she thought this "very odd" since his Richmond flat was in the opposite direction to theirs.

She said when the cab arrived at the sisters' flat some time after 11pm, Mr Richards "said something about coming in for a coffee".

"I said it would have to be quick as I was extremely tired," she said.

But once inside the flat, Miss Melvin told the court, the 53-year-old declined the offer of a drink and smoked some cannabis with her sister.

Tiffany Melvin quickly phoned for a minicab, however, later explaining to her sister he had been rude and she had wanted him to leave immediately, it was alleged.

Cassandra Melvin, who said she had no idea of her unwanted guest's profession, told the court that, at the sound of a car, she showed the politician to the door and tried to shut it on him when she realised it wasn't his cab. A scuffle then ensued, she said.

"He said something like: 'It's not the cab, you fucking bitch.' He started pushing on one side. I was pushing on the other to try and close it. I was calling to Tiffany to help. She looked extremely distraught."

As her sister phoned the police, Miss Melvin managed to push shut the door. But she opened it 20 seconds later to check if Mr Richards had gone.

"I took two steps forward and he jumped out, started swearing, and punching me straight in my face, on my nose.

"He then went to turn around and I grabbed his jacket. I said: 'you can't do this to me, you've no right to do this to me.' There was a bit of a scuffle... He grabbed my arm and literally threw me into a parked car.

"The pain was so severe I must have been knocked out. The last thing I remember was him being very close on top of me, lots of swearing and feeling petrified."

She came to on the ground moments later to see Mr Richards running off, she said.

The sisters then took a cab to Kingston hospital where Cassandra Melvin was treated for a broken left elbow, scraped knee and bruises to her nose.

She still requires physiotherapy and has suffered depression and a breakdown in her relationship with her sister, whom she partly blames for the incident, the court heard.

Under cross examination by Lady Mallalieu QC, Miss Melvin denied she had broken her arm falling in the street or that she had been the aggressor.

Mr Richards, had behaved "like a gentleman" during the evening, said Lady Mallalieu.

"Here's a man who was trying to run away. It was you who were attacking him," she said. Miss Melvin replied that this was not true.

The case continues today.

webTitle: Hooligans meet a new and furious foe

fields.headline: Hooligans meet a new and furious foe
fields.standfirst:
Turkish and Moroccan youths unite against English who taunt them

Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: Turkish and Moroccan youths unite against English who taunt them.
fields.body:
They gather in squares and on street corners in central Brussels, discussing the English before setting out to look for them in a depressing ritual that has become all too familiar over the past few days. Last night was no different as Turkey prepared to play Belgium and once again the fighting and not the football seemed to bring out mobs of young men from inner city Brussels.

There might not have been many England fans around but their arrival today, ahead of tonight's match in Charleroi, is being eagerly anticipated. "The English, they think they are hard and they started all these problems but we are ready for them," said Hamid, an 18-year-old Moroccan youth from the Molembeek area of the city. "We have already given them a good fight over the weekend. I think they now know what the Moroccan are about."

While focus has been concentrated on trouble around the main square, mostly between England fans and the police, possibly more worrying violence has been brewing elsewhere. Scores of Moroccan and Turkish youths have been roaming the streets of central Brussels more than willing to fight the English. Although Turks and Moroccans living in Brussels have had problems with each other in the past and clashed on occasions, a new found unity has been brought about by the common enemy trying to wreak havoc on their streets.

As an England fan was severely attacked by a mob over the weekend, a taxi driver explained what was going on. Asked if the mob was made up of Turks or Moroccans he crossed his fingers to symbolise that it was both. "Brothers united," he said. "They will defeat the English. These hooligans don't realise what they have started." When the organisers of Euro 2000 invented the slogan "football without frontiers" for their tournament, this is not what they had in mind.

On the streets of Molembeek, Laekan and St Josse yesterday, some of the inner city areas of Brussels which are dominated by Moroccans and Turks, locals will tell you that the violence was started on Friday afternoon by the English after they spat and abused a woman walking past a bar wearing traditional clothing.

Fayfal Ananou, a 30-year-old driver who was in the centre of Brussels when the violence started, said: "I think the English thought she was Turkish because they were singing anti-Turkish songs. These hooligans can't tell the difference and the attack was seen by a group of Moroccan men who followed the English into a shop and started fighting with them."

The irony is that after almost two decades of creating mayhem abroad, the English fans have at last come across a formidable foe fuelled on something more potent that lager and a cheap sense of nationalism.

Political and economic alienation combined with a macho culture can be a powerful cocktail, as some English fans have seen over the past few days.

Knives

Wayne Hodgkinson, an England fan from Nottinghamshire, who said that he was punched and kicked by a group of "Turks", said: "The scary thing is that these guys aren't even pissed. They play by a totally different set of rules. It's not about having a row, running a mob and breaking a few windows. These blokes are tooled up, they've got knives. Quite often they start the trouble. But it's the English who get the blame."

Few in Molembeek have sympathy for the English as the area's young men prepare for another possible round of confrontations with them. There is already talk of taking them on over the weekend should England qualify for the quarter-finals, when they will play in Brussels.

Qassim, 21, said: "The hooligans think they are strong, that they're the toughest but they don't know what we Moroccans are like. The Turks are the same as us. We are tranquil people, we are Muslims, but if you mess about with us then there are going to be big problems. It's going to be dangerous. We never wanted any trouble, it is the English who provoked us."

Over the weekend English fans could be seen goading young men of Turkish or north African appearance or indeed anyone who had a brown face, giving zeig heil salutes and chanting "I'd rather be a Paki than a Turk". Mr Ananou, who has been trying to pacify the local youngsters said: "You have to remember that we have grown up in very tough circumstances. There is a lot of discrimination in Belgium but we are also a very proud people. We will not let the English abuse us."

The majority of Moroccans and Turks arrived in Belgium in the 1970s, heading mainly to the south to work in mines and factories. Once these closed they moved to Brussels and now make up 40% of the city's population of just over 950,000. Confined to poor inner city areas they face daily discrimination which has made them tough. The average unemployment rate in Belgium is about 10%; in Brussels, among Turks and Moroccans it is 29%.

Many will tell you they are turned down for jobs because of their race. Most work as taxi drivers, waiters or in catering. Belgium's far rightwing, the Vlaams Blok party, is strong in the Antwerp area, and many non-white Belgians claim there is much racism outside the capital.

Turkish fans outside the stadium for last night's match expressed little sympathy for the English. Mehmet, from the St Josse area, said: "We have already beaten the English twice. Everywhere they go they start problems, but we are more than ready for them."

His friend Mustafa said: "Everyone has come together to fight the English. They have abused our culture, our women, our religion. Nobody wants violence but the English always start it. They are all bad."

There is already talk of taking them on over the weekend should England qualify for the quarter-finals, when they will play in Brussels. Qassim, 21, said: "The hooligans think they are strong, that they're the toughest but they don't know what we Moroccans are like. The Turks are the same as us. We are tranquil people, we are Muslims, but if you mess about with us then there are going to be big problems. It's going to be dangerous. We never wanted any trouble, it is the English who provoked us." Over the weekend English fans could be seen goading young men of Turkish or north African appearance or indeed anyone who had a brown face, giving zeig heil salutes and chanting "I'd rather be a Paki than a Turk". Mr Ananou, who has been trying to pacify the local youngsters said: "You have to remember that we have grown up in very tough circumstances. There is a lot of discrimination in Belgium but we are also a very proud people. We will not let the English abuse us." The majority of Moroccans and Turks arrived in Belgium in the 1970s, heading mainly to the south to work in mines and factories. Once these closed they moved to Brussels and now make up 40% of the city's population of just over 950,000. Confined to poor inner city areas they face daily discrimination which has made them tough. The average unemployment rate in Belgium is about 10%; in Brussels, among Turks and Moroccans it is 29%. Many will tell you they are turned down for jobs because of their race. Most work as taxi drivers, waiters or in catering. Belgium's far rightwing, the Vlaams Blok party, is strong in the Antwerp area, and many non-white Belgians claim there is much racism outside the capital. Turkish fans outside the stadium for last night's match expressed little sympathy for the English. Mehmet, from the St Josse area, said: "We have already beaten the English twice. Everywhere they go they start problems, but we are more than ready for them." His friend Mustafa said: "Everyone has come together to fight the English. They have abused our culture, our women, our religion. Nobody wants violence but the English always start it. They are all bad." fields.headline: Hushang Golshiri
fields.standfirst:
Brave Iranian writer who stood against tyranny
Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Across more than three decades, Hushang Golshiri,  who has died aged 63, produced some of the finest  novels and short stories in recent Iranian history. In  turbulent times, he was also pulled, unwillingly, into  politics, organising writers against the Shah's  censorship - and that of the current Islamic  government. As a result, he was persecuted by both  regimes.
fields.body:
Across more than three decades, Hushang Golshiri, who has died aged 63, produced some of the finest novels and short stories in recent Iranian history. In turbulent times, he was also pulled, unwillingly, into politics, organising writers against the Shah's censorship - and that of the current Islamic government. As a result, he was persecuted by both regimes.

Golshiri was born into a working-class family in the historical and industrial city of Isfahan. Two events in his early 20s channelled his interests into literature. He met a group of young people in Isfahan who were fascinated by the postwar new wave in French literature, and he had a love affair with a British woman in the city, a teacher of English language and literature. His other major influence was to be his wife, the literary critic and translator Farzaneh Taheri.

Golshiri wrote his first collection of short stories, Like Always - about the dull, repetitive life of small-town office workers - in the late 1960s. His most famous novel, Prince Ehtejab (1968), later became an internationally acclaimed film. He became one of the first Iranian writers to apply modern literary techniques in his books and to depict the demise of the Iranian aristocracy. His style, storytelling ability and command of Persian language and classical literature attracted general readers, as well as the literary elite.

In 1975, political prisoners provided the theme of his short story collection, My Little Prayer Room, which showed how despotism alienates both the oppressed and the oppressor. In other works, he questioned the integrity of intellectuals who had put themselves at the service of the Shah's regime. Critics suggest that, a year before the 1979 Islamic revolution, Golshiri's novel, The Shepherd And The Lost Sheep, anticipated the advent of fundamentalism in his country.

The new religious rulers were deeply hostile to independent literature, and Ayatollah Khomeini declared that pens which did not write for Islamic values must be broken. Most of Golshiri's fiction was banned and, until a few years ago, he was not allowed to publish new works. A social and gender censorship was added to the Shah's draconian measures; writers were even banned from writing about ordinary relationships between men and women.

Golshiri temporarily abandoned fiction, and focused on campaigning for freedom of expression. He also set up private classes to nurture a new generation of writers. Harassed by the authorities, he was interrogated about his efforts to found an independent writers organisation, and accused on tele- vision of being in the pay of foreign powers, while newspapers probed his private life and charged him with links to foreign embassies.

Life under such conditions took an appalling toll on Golshiri's health and literary output. Writing under constant threat of death became a struggle on its own. He left Iran several times to finish his last great work, The Book Of Genies, which was published abroad. In 1990, he smuggled his novel, King Of The Benighted, to the United States to be published in English under a pen-name - his authorship of it was only confirmed after his death. In his last works, Golshiri depicted the lives of fict- ional religious fanatics, who wanted to return to the middle ages.

Two years ago, Iran's secular writers paid the price for defending freedom and human rights; two dissident authors were murdered by security agents. Golshiri's eloquent and moving speech at their graveside is regarded as one of the most defiant statements by an Iranian writer in recent years.

Yet Golshiri never allowed anger to turn his literary work into sloganeering. He had a strong sense of humour, and kept his spirits up. He was awarded Germany's Erich Maria Remarque prize last year for his efforts to fight oppression and promote democracy and human rights.

He leaves his wife Farzaneh, a son and a daughter.

fields.headline: Lord Mostyn
fields.standfirst: Welsh aristocrat compelled to sell off the family silver
fields.trailText:
The family of the 5th Baron Mostyn, who has died
aged 80, were long the largest landowners in north
Wales. In 35 years, Lord Mostyn never said a word in
the House of Lords in defence of his vast, but
shrinking, domain; indeed, he died without having
made his maiden speech in the chamber.
fields.body:
The family of the 5th Baron Mostyn, who has died aged 80, were long the largest landowners in north Wales. In 35 years, Lord Mostyn never said a word in the House of Lords in defence of his vast, but shrinking, domain; indeed, he died without having made his maiden speech in the chamber.

By 1997, his farming company, Mostyn Estates, was worth £25m, making him the 859th wealthiest Briton. Increasingly, the family concentrated on urban land, particularly around Llandudno, which had become "the queen of Welsh resorts" because his great-grandfather, the local MP, EML Mostyn, put through an act of parliament controlling its development, and because the family controlled virtually all the town's freeholds. The well-planned Victorian community has thus been been protected from the vulgarity disfiguring nearby Rhyl.

Born in Mostyn Hall, Flintshire, Mostyn went from Eton to the Royal Military Academy at Sandhurst; aged 19 when the war broke out, he joined the 9th Queen's Royal Hussars, a tank regiment. He saw action in France, North Africa and Italy. Wounded twice, he was mentioned in dispatches, and was awarded the military cross in 1943, the year he married his first wife, Yvonne Stuart Johnson.

After the war, the couple settled in Ireland, where they established a stud - which turned out several successful racehorses - and Mostyn be came a "relentless point- to-point rider". Their son, Llewellyn, and daughter, Virginia, were born there. The marriage ended in 1957, when he married Sheila Edmondson Shaw.

It was only when Mostyn's father died in 1965 that they returned to Mostyn Hall, to take over the family estate, particularly the 250-acre farm. "We entertain a lot during grand national week," his second wife disclosed. "We have about 15 to 20 people staying here."

Mostyn also played the role of lord of the manor. In 1966, he donned period costume to emulate an ancestor, who, 400 years earlier, had ridden into Caerwys to convey the Queen's blessing on the first eisteddfod. He continued his interest in horseracing, at least until 1968, when he took a bad fall at Worcester.

Because of what his father had described as "crippling taxation", assets accumulated since the time of the first baronet in 1778 were liquidated. By 1974, the last of the magnificent Mostyn library was sold, in five separate Christie's auctions. In 1982, the British Museum paid him £500,000 for a 17th-century spring clock, made for William III by Thomas Tompion, Britain's greatest horologist. In 1991, Plas Mawr, in Conway - the country's finest surviving Elizabethan town house - was given to the nation, partly because it required expensive repairs.

Mostyn's son becomes the 6th baron, no longer faced by the problem of speaking or voting in the Lords. His daughter and second wife also survive him.

Roger Edward Lloyd Lloyd-Mostyn, 5th Baron Mostyn, landowner, born April 17 1920; died June 5 2000

webTitle: More checks on healthy food ads claims

fields.headline: More checks on healthy food ads claims
fields.trailText: Food manufacturers face more checks on the health claims of their products and new rules about the way they label them.
fields.body:
Food manufacturers face more checks on the health claims of their products and new rules about the way they label them.

A body to police a voluntary code will be announced within the next few weeks, which the industry said would make it easier for trading standards officials to prosecute wrongdoers; the Consumers' Association, however, said yesterday it would not go far enough.

It demanded EU laws requiring companies to satisfy regulators about the accuracy of claims such as "maintains strong bones" or "helps to lower cholesterol" before they could use them.

The association said there was a danger that the public were being misled by the rapidly growing market of "functional foods" worth already about £650m a year in Britain. The government's food standards agency is conducting a review of all labelling rules to see whether they are strong enough.

The row covers food and drinks which do not make specific medicinal claims to treat, prevent or cure a disease but imply they are beneficial to long-term health. The association's Sheila McKechnie said the jury was out on whether such products, even where there were provable benefits, did enough to justify their higher prices.

The latest issue of the association's Health Which? magazine assessed three products. Aviva orange juice, it said, might be beneficial for people who did not get enough calcium from dairy products and vitamin D from sunlight, but "it may be better to take a supplement and avoid the added sugar in the juice drink".

Yakult fermented milk drink introduced "friendly" bacteria into the digestive system but experts could not agree on whether this would have real health benefits . The company, which is helping to fund the new voluntary scheme on health claims, said: "We are keen to give consumers good information."

The voluntary code, agreed by the industry, trading standards officials and consumer groups, was used in evidence last month by Shropshire trading standards department which successfully prosecuted Nestlé, half the partnership in Cereal Partners, for the way it had labelled and advertised Shredded Wheat last year. The company was fined £7,500 and ordered to pay £13,600 costs for "inviting the irresistible inference that eating Shredded Wheat will reduce the risk of coronary heart disease".

fields.headline: Mary Cannell
fields.standfirst:
Her biography championed the achievements of a great
19th-century scientist
fields.trailText:
The lasting reputation of the educator Mary Cannell,
who has died aged 86, was secured in 1993 with the
publication of George Green: Mathematician And
Physicist 1793-1841, her acclaimed biography of the
Nottingham miller-mathematician who was one of the
19th century's most original scientists.
fields.body:
The lasting reputation of the educator Mary Cannell, who has died aged 86, was secured in 1993 with the publication of George Green: Mathematician And Physicist 1793-1841, her acclaimed biography of the Nottingham miller-mathematician who was one of the 19th century's most original scientists.

It was only after her retirement that Cannell became a remarkable historian of mathematics. She charmed audiences on several continents, promoting interest in Green and early 19th-century mathematical physics, in the clear tones and pure vowels of prewar English, somewhere between Miss Marple and Dame Peggy Ashcroft.

Most mathematicians learn of Green's theorem and Green's functions, but widespread knowledge of Green himself dates only from the 1970s, when Cannell and other Nottingham colleagues worked to restore his windmill and his memory. It is now argued that the great 19th-century Cambridge school of applied mathematics, which included such luminaries as Lord Kelvin, James Clerk Maxwell and JJ Thomson, was fathered essentially by the self- educated Green in his 1828 Essay On The Application Of Mathematical Analysis To The Theories Of Electricity And Magnetism.

By the time of the bicentenary of Green's birth in 1993, the mill at Sneinton, now a Nottingham suburb, was working again, a stained-glass window to Green was unveiled in his Cambridge college, and a memorial plaque was placed in the floor of Westminster Abbey, a few feet from Isaac Newton's tomb.

In all of this, Cannell played a central role, not least through her biography, which outlines Green's influence on mathematical physicists - from Kelvin in the 1840s, to Nobel laureate Julian Schwinger, the first to introduce Green's functions to quantum mechanics, Richard Feynman, and Freeman Dyson, who demonstrated the equivalence of the ap proaches used by Feynmann and Schwinger. Cannell's book placed Green studies, and the history of mathematical physics in the 19th century, in a new light. She located the scientist in his social and educational context.

Brought up and educated in Liverpool, of Manx stock, Mary Cannell won a scholarship to Merchant Taylors' school for girls, and read French, with subsidiary history, at Liverpool University. After a postgraduate diploma in education, she taught French in English schools, and English at a school in France. After the war, the experience of lecturing to the troops led her to spend the rest of her career in higher education, specifically in teacher training.

In 1960, she was appointed deputy principal of the new Nottingham college of education, where, as acting principal 14 years later, she super- vised the amalgamation of the college with Trent Polytechnic, later to become Nottingham Trent University.

Her researches on Green were tireless, widespread and thorough. She talked to his descendants and even introduced two branches of the family who did not know of each other's existence. She made frequent visits to Cambridge, particularly to Gonville and Caius College, where Green became an undergraduate at the age of 40, and then a fellow, and to Queens' College to learn more about the Rev John Toplis, the Nottingham headmaster and Cambridge wran gler whom she identified as the person most likely to have guided Green, given his only 18 months of schooling.

Mary's prewar studies into French culture lent insight into the mathematical sources used by Green, and her interest in English social history enabled her to appreciate the unrewarding and frustrating position in which he lived - that of a working miller and mathematical genius, struggling to find a voice in a period of social privilege and rigid class structure.

Mary Cannell was working on projects of one sort or another - the Green website, the revised edition of the biography, research papers, the catalogue of papers in the University of Nottingham library - right to the end, in days filled with her characteristic energy and enthusiasm.

She is survived by her nephews, David and Peter.

Doris Mary Cannell, educator and historian, born July 19 1913; died April 18 2000

webTitle: Clenched fist may endow Old Spice with stronger modern image

fields.headline: Clenched fist may endow Old Spice with stronger modern image
fields.trailText: Once it was a proud symbol of the unreconstructed male. But now Old Spice, the aftershave that has been "the mark of a man" for half a century, has turned to a comedian for salvation.
fields.body:
Once it was a proud symbol of the unreconstructed male. But now Old Spice, the aftershave that has been "the mark of a man" for half a century, has turned to a comedian for salvation.

Johnny Vegas, the overweight "failed potter" whose wobbly one-minute jugs thrown on stage are now in the Victoria & Albert Museum, has been commissioned to redesign the famous silver-topped bottle.

Vegas has replaced it with a clenched fist as a mark of resistance against post-feminist man's weakness for effete eau de Cologne and skin balm. "The fist is also a symbol of men's struggle to be taken seriously by women," he said. "I prefer to think of it not as a stopper but as five fingers of angst and frustrated male desire."

He has also adorned his prototype with a flower to show that "though we look tough on the outside, the bottle, like men, conceals sweetness and beauty within".

It is all a long way from those macho surfers in the old TV ads splashing on the Old Spice to the strains of Orff's Carmina Burana.

Vegas claims Old Spice transformed his life. "I have always had the looks," he admitted. "But Old Spice gave me the aura to become a true romantic all-rounder, and find love with lots of ladies, as well as pushing my craft into, and beyond, hitherto unknown boundaries."

Behind all the self-conscious irony is the hard economic reality of how a once dominant brand has become naff since the halcyon days of the 70s, when only one in four British men bothered with a deodorant, preferring pungent aftershaves instead.

While Old Spice has acquired a certain retro chic since popping up in films such as The Talented Mr Ripley and The Limey, manufacturer Procter and Gamble said there was a limit to how long the nostalgic appeal of a retro object would last. Vegas's bottle is a part of a year-long rethink of the brand.

David Waters, author of Grooming Essentials for Men, and the editor of Men's Health magazine, said he hoped it would stick with the old version. "They have to do something, I suppose. The Vegas bottle is very funny and I can see it appealing to the younger market they are trying to reach. They'll laugh along with the joke but will they want to smell of it? And would you want to use it? Part of its appeal in the 60s was that it stung your face.

"Men were then very wary of using fragrances, so the fact that it hurt made it OK."

The Vegas bottle is very funny and I can see it appealing to the younger market they are trying to reach. They'll laugh along with the joke but will they want to smell of it? And would you want to use it? Part of its appeal in the 60s was that it stung your face. "Men were then very wary of using fragrances, so the fact that it hurt made it OK."

webTitle: Lower entry grades set for poor students

fields.headline: Lower entry grades set for poor students
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A radical plan to widen university intake by lowering  the A-level entry requirements for some applicants has  been set up to counter allegations of elitism.
fields.body:
A radical plan to widen university intake by lowering the A-level entry requirements for some applicants has been set up to counter allegations of elitism.

Seventy extra places have been created at Newcastle University for pupils previously thought likely to under-achieve in A-levels or from families where higher education had not been considered a realistic option. The Partners programme, involving 40 schools and six further education colleges on Tyneside, swaps lower A-level entry requirements at Newcastle for a programme of seminars, student-shadowing and a summer school on the campus in the city centre.

Pupils selected from the region's most deprived areas by postcode, and then filtered by school heads and a joint school-university study of their classroom records, must complete the year-long programme to qualify.

The university denied yesterday that the scheme represented any "dumbing down". There have also been worries among heads about the risk of a two-tier application system, decided on criteria too simplistic.

Alan Smithers, of Liverpool University's centre for education and employment research, said universities put academic standards at risk if they bowed to pressure from the government for wider access through crude measures, such as postcodes. Newcastle said postcodes were only part of the system and were used with caution.

Its vice-chancellor for teaching and learning, Madeleine Atkins, said: "None of us has any doubt that Partners is getting at people whose past results have not told the full story about their academic potential; school students, for instance, who have worked long hours to bring money into homes where no one is in work."

The programme is part of a £1.7m scheme to widen access approved by the higher education funding council for England last year, and pre-dates the Tyneside pupil Laura Spence's failure to win an Oxford place - the rejection that triggered the elitism debate.

webTitle: £20m price tag to end bias by top universities

fields.headline: £20m price tag to end bias by top universities
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Leading universities need to spend less than £20m to  end their bias against state school admissions, a  central figure in the debate about elitism in education  said last night.
fields.body:
Leading universities need to spend less than £20m to end their bias against state school admissions, a central figure in the debate about elitism in education said last night.

Peter Lampl, chairman of the Sutton Trust, told the Guardian that the sum, properly targeted, would prevent state school pupils with the right A-level grades being denied places at top universities.

A report by the trust this month illustrated the waste of state school talent, with more than 1,000 students from poorer areas not winning the places at the top 13 universities to which their marks entitled them. This is the first time Mr Lampl has put a price tag on his proposals to reverse the trend. "Given that graduates from our top universities will form the future leaders in society, this is a small price to pay to correct the imbalance," he said.

According to figures from the university funding councils, 11 of those ranked in unofficial surveys as the top 13 universities in Britain failed to reach their benchmark figures for state school places - the proportion they should have admitted based on grades and subject mix.

Mr Lampl said £20m could pay for a small group of recruitment officers at each university to visit schools to persuade bright students from working class backgrounds to apply.

It would fund an extension of summer schools at universities for sixth-form students, and for teachers from state schools to foster links between them and leading university academics. Pupils in year 10 (aged 14-15) would be able to spend a day and night at a top university to give them an idea of what to expect.

Mr Lampl, a businessman and educational philanthropist, is already paying for a series of summer schools. David Blunkett, the education secretary, has announced £4m in extra spending to recruit bright students in areas where few go to university.

York and Warwick universities exceed the state school benchmark figure and Nottingham and Birmingham are just five percentage points behind. But the remainder - Oxford, Cambridge, Bristol, St Andrews, Edinburgh, Durham and three London colleges, Imperial, University and the London School of Economics - are a dozen or more points adrift.

Oxford and Imperial are the worst offenders, both 18 points behind on the most recent figures. Oxford should fill 65% of its places with state school applicants but only takes in 47%, and Imperial should take 71% but takes in 53%.

Mr Lampl, who is giving evidence to the Commons education select committee today, ultimately advocates a complete overhaul of the university admissions system. He believes A-level results are too narrow a measure and is funding a scheme to develop US-style scholastic aptitude tests. He also proposes that university selection should take place after A-level results are published, arguing that pupils from schools with low participation rates lose out to those from schools with a record of university admission.

"Universities and schools should be able to go towards a post-qualification entry system," he said. "The whole business of conditional offers puts a lot of stress on students and I think it works against students from the types of backgrounds we are trying to encourage."

Mr Lampl is joining a steering group for a new phase of a research project, announced by the committee of vice-chancellors and principals yesterday, which will investigate schemes to widen participation.

webTitle: Waco ghosts return to haunt US

fields.headline: Waco ghosts return to haunt US
fields.standfirst:
Relatives to claim in court this week that the FBI's excessive force led to Texas inferno

Branch Davidians
FBI
fields.trailText: Relatives to claim in court this week that the FBI's excessive force led to Texas inferno.
fields.body:
The United States government finds itself in court this week facing the survivors and relatives of the more than 80 Branch Davidian sect members who were burned to death in Waco, Texas, in 1993.

At the heart of the civil action, which started yesterday and accuses the government of causing the wrongful deaths of the sect members, is the role of the FBI and whether its agents used excessive force on that ill-fated day.

"The case is going to prove that our government can be held accountable for its abuse of power," said Michael Caddell, the leading attorney acting for the families. "And that's what happened on April 19 [1993]. It was an abuse of power."

Mr Caddell said he thought the government was in a state of panic about the case.

The US government will argue that the deaths were the sole responsibility of David Koresh, the former leader of the Branch Davidians who died at the compound.

Federal lawyers will claim that Koresh's messianic belief that that the end of the world would come about as the result of a fight with the government was the real cause of the conflagration. Part of their evidence will be photographs of the sect's massive stockpile of weapons.

The government will also argue that it was not negligent in failing to tackle the fire that engulfed the compound that day, as there were genuine fears that firefighters would be shot if they had attempted to tackle the blaze.

What will also be examined during the trial, which is likely to last between one and two months, is why it took until last year for the FBI to admit that it had fired pyrotechnic munitions at a bunker near the main compound just before the main blaze started. The FBI's alleged cover-up of this action is the subject of an ongoing inquiry under former Senator John Danforth, who has spoken of the "dark questions" that have not yet been answered.

The trial judge, Walter Smith, will ask an advisory jury to decide whether government agents used excessive force, whether FBI agents disobeyed the orders of the justice department, and whether negligence led to a failure to have firetrucks at the ready. The jury's decision will not be binding on the judge, because of the panel's advisory nature.

Judge Smith was the judge in the 1994 trial of eight surviving Davidians who were convicted of firing at government agents. He gave them 30-year sentences for the offences, but the terms were cut to five years on appeal.

The trial will examine every aspect of the event except whether or not the FBI opened fire into the compound. Judge Smith will look into that aspect in a separate trial, which is to start in August.

Mr Caddell has said that he is not going to suggest that there was a deliberate decision to kill the sect members, but rather that the government agents behaved in a reckless and negligent way which led to their deaths.

The leader of the plaintiffs' legal team will concentrate on the women and children who died in the blaze rather than the men who had fired on the agents and he has said that he will not seek to defend Koresh.

He will argue that the teargas canisters started the blaze that led to the deaths, while the government lawyers, led by Michael Bradford, will claim that those inside perished as the result of a suicide pact initiated by Koresh.

As yet, Mr Caddell has not named a figure that he and his team are seeking for the 15 survivors and 85 relatives of the dead.

One key witness is likely to be David Thibodeau, a former rock musician from Los Angeles and one of only four survivors who were not convicted for their roles in the events.

"I know there's going to be a lot of dirt slung both ways at the trial," said Mr Thibodeau in an interview with the Los Angeles Times. "But my whole stance is that, whatever you think of David Koresh and his people, what the government did... was wrong and these people in the government should be put on trial. I just want the truth to come out."

Mr Thibodeau is adamant that the government's agents murdered those in the compound.

The US attorney general, Janet Reno, has already made a statement about her role in the case.

In it, she spoke of her decision to use teargas to end the siege: "This was the best time in which we would have the best opportunity to... try and protect lives."

Waco, a town of 100,000, now finds itself having to endure a different kind of siege as hundreds of media personnel descend upon it for the duration of the case.

webTitle: Style victim blames it all on Saudis

fields.headline: Style victim blames it all on Saudis
fields.trailText: A Paris appeal court will decide today whether to ban the shop-and-tell memoirs of a long-suffering multimillionaire - the Lebanon-born former cocktail waitress who became perhaps the world's greatest collector of expensive frocks.
fields.body:
A Paris appeal court will decide today whether to ban the shop-and-tell memoirs of a long-suffering multimillionaire - the Lebanon-born former cocktail waitress who became perhaps the world's greatest collector of expensive frocks.

Mouna Ayoub remains a legend in couture salons, where staff have always greeted her and her chequebook with open arms.

She once ordered her maternity smocks from Christian Dior and admits to spending $1m (£660,000) a year on designer dresses, says she wrote La Vérité, or The Truth, to explain to her five children the horrors of her 20-year, on-off marriage to Nasser al-Rashid, a Saudi businessman.

"It's the testimony of a woman subjected to the laws of a macho, fundamentalist and retrograde society," she said. "People don't understand. They say I was showered with gold and diamonds and dresses and cars. That's true. But when you are rejected by an entire society, all the wealth in the world isn't enough."

Ms Ayoub, 43, divorced Mr Rashid - referred to in the book as Amir al-Tharik - for the third and final time in 1996, by fax. Since then she has been subjected to torrents of abuse from the Saudi press, which says she married for money and separated solely to spend her husband's billions more effectively.

Mr Rashid and the couple's oldest son are suing her publishers, Michel Lafont, arguing that Ms Ayoub's revelations are in breach of France's strict privacy laws. Their case was rejected by a lower court last month on the grounds that the book was already on sale, but subsequently went to appeal.

Ms Ayoub makes no bones about her flamboyant lifestyle. At one stage, she says, she owned four Aston Martins and kept more than 1,000 outfits by Chanel, Givenchy, Versace, and St Laurent in a 5,500 sq ft air-conditioned room. But her days as a Saudi Arabian wife, she insists, were pure hell.

She met her husband in Paris when he was 38 and she just 18 and married him a year later after converting to Islam. In 1978 the couple moved to Riyadh, where Ms Ayoub says she rapidly discovered that, despite having the run of a specially built marble palace, she was the prisoner of a patriarchal society and of her husband's every whim.

She was forbidden to go to the cinema, forced to wear a veil, and rapped over the knuckles with a stick by the religious police for exposing her hand in public during Ramadan, she says - but was also expected to skip willingly to her master's bedroom when commanded.

"I was in a cage, a gilded cage where I felt myself to be unjustly treated and powerless," she writes. "I was given the most sumptuous dresses and amassed a huge collection of jewels, yet I could only wear my black Arab robe and a veil. I was forbidden to speak to men, forbidden to see female friends not approved by my husband, forbidden to play sport, forbidden to laugh, or speak loudly in public."

Ms Ayoub writes that she attempted suicide, and became addicted to Prozac. She survived, she says, by concentrating on building up her own fortune: "No one came to Saudi Arabia to do anything but make money. So I thought it was a pity to be there and not make some of my own."

Thus began an unusual series of Friday afternoon clearance sales in the garage of her Riyadh palace, at which the enterprising Ms Ayoub flogged off the very expensive but unwanted designer jewellery, luggage, ceramics, clothing, shoes, furniture and electronic goods her husband brought back from his frequent business trips.

Using the proceeds, she invested in the property and stock markets in Lebanon and the United States, and she claims now to be spending most of her time managing a personal fortune of around £300m. Needless to say, she is not particularly happy.

"Nothing can liberate me from a terrible pain: that of a love spoilt, and of children lost," she laments in La Vérité. "Only my daughter keeps in contact with me. What also makes me despair is all this hatred unleashed against me, both in my husband's country and in the Lebanon of my childhood. But I have time to discover other riches. At 43 years of age, I'd like to start living."

fields.headline: The running mate
fields.standfirst:
He used to run in front of thousands of fans. Now Seb Coe runs behind William Hague, holding the boss's bag. But the Olympic star once dismissed as an ineffectual politician is rapidly emerging as the Tory leader's closest confidant. Michael White reports on a friendship forged over the judo mat

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: He used to run in front of thousands of fans. Now Seb Coe runs behind William Hague, holding the boss's bag. But the Olympic star once dismissed as an ineffectual politician is rapidly emerging as the Tory leader's closest confidant.  Michael White  reports on a friendship forged over the judo mat
fields.body:
Sharp-eyed TV viewers sometimes spot him in the background of William Hague's campaign walkabouts, the man in the dark suit on the mobile phone or carrying the boss's bag. He is rarely far away.

To many, the face in the background may be vaguely familiar, but somehow set in the wrong context. Only to west Cornish voters, middle-aged athletic fans and political anoraks will he be instantly recognsible as Sebastian Newbold Coe, CBE, MBE. A former Olympic gold medallist, ex-MP for Falmouth and Camborne, since last month he is also Lord Coe, peer of the realm.

Much more important than any such trimmings, now that William Hague is finally starting to make an impact as leader of Her Majesty's Opposition, is that Seb Coe's main job these days is to run Hague's private office. More important still is that he is the opposition leader's most important political confidant.

This is puzzling to many Tory MPs, not all of them on the disaffected left. Ask them about the management of Hague's office and some say it's a shambles or tell you about the time that the former Tory cabinet minister, Lord Peter Walker, rang in to offer help. The grandee was asked to write a letter instead ("William's very busy") and gave up after the private office admitted it had lost it.

That incident may have been a while back. But politics is a bitchy business in which it is often politic to blame the advisers, not the leader. You see the process at work in Downing Street where the chief of staff, Jonathan Powell, or press secretary, Alastair Campbell, take the flak for Tony Blair's failings.

Coe is in poll position for the same treatment. He's a sportsman, the argument goes, so he must be thick. He was only an MP for one parliament (1992-97) and not a very distinguished one either. He did not speak well and rose to the dizzy heights of junior whip in the dying days of Majorism.

And here he is now, the man who spends more time in William's company than any soul alive except Ffion, and possibly more than she does, even counting weekends. Dammit, the two of them work out at the gym and do judo together.

"It's extraordinary," say the whisperers. "What's Coe got?" Hague is said to be defensive on this point, inclined to clam up or change the subject. So genial Cecil Parkinson, twice party chairman in both Thatcher and Major eras, once put it to him, man to man.

"Hague replied: 'He's my mate,'" Lord Parkinson confirms. The former Tory pin-up explains that what the leader meant was that "Seb is the chap he can sit down with, kick off his shoes and have a whisky late at night to bounce ideas off. He trusts him and knows he can speak in complete confidence."

Confidence is important. So is being no kind of threat. Ian Gow MP famously enjoyed the boss's late-night confidences as Thatcher's loyal parliamentary private secretary. It was one reason that the IRA killed him. Robert Atkins was a mate of John Major's, a fellow-MP and sports buff, they went to cricket together and are still friends. But Atkins was thought to talk a bit and lost his role as Best Mate.

It is not an office recognised in the British constitution, but there is usually a Best Mate in the system, and Coe's credentials are more impressive than Commons gossip allows. For one thing, the middle-distance man who won the 1,500 metres at the 1980 Moscow Olympics and did it again at Los Angeles in 1984 - the breaker of 13 world records - is much more of a Hague prototype than most profile writers have spotted.

He was born in Chiswick, west London, in September 1956, which makes him four-and-a-half years older than Hague, who was born in March 1961. But he moved to Sheffield when very young and grew up within six miles of the Rotherham soft drinks family. Both boys went to state schools (Coe's was actually a secondary modern because he failed the 11-plus), both became instinctive Conservatives - "Tory boy", Hague's big sisters called him during their teens.

It was a reaction to living in what both would later call "the People's Republic of South Yorkshire", a world in which they saw too many people working close to subsistence in clapped-out nationalised industries, and living in municipal housing without much hope or aspiration.

Coe joined the Young Conservatives in 1976, about the same time as the precocious Hague who took the Tory conference by storm only a year later with that speech. Young William went on to an Oxford first and presidency of the union. But Coe was already ferociously competive in his chosen field too.

They knew each other slightly in those days, Coe recalls. But he was already at Loughborough University, reading economics and training hard under his father, Peter. They would both be famous young - and Coe still gets his share of attention from the autograph hunters.

"I started competitive running at 12 and did not make the Olympics until I was 23 and then 27," he would say later, making a direct comparison with the long-term goals which he and Hague have set themselves. "Most athletes spend many years in apprenticeship and their biggest sponsors are their families."

There is a direct link between what Coe sometimes calls "my former profession" and his present role as private secretary to Hague, a title he has preferred to "chief of staff" since stepping in, in February 1998. fields.headline: Open the door
fields.standfirst:
A more flexible immigration policy would boost our economy and stop people dying in the backs of lorries

Refugees in Britain: special report
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: The tragic discovery in Dover yesterday morning of 58 bodies in an airtight container lorry underlines the urgency of tackling the root causes of this murderous trade in asylum seekers.
fields.body:
The tragic discovery in Dover yesterday morning of 58 bodies in an airtight container lorry underlines the urgency of tackling the root causes of this murderous trade in asylum seekers. It is now virtually impossible for anybody, whether a genuine asylum seeker or an abusive economic migrant, to enter Britain legally.

The Geneva convention on refugees was never designed to regulate the mass migration of people across the planet fleeing from poverty. Instead it is time to consider reform of Britain's and Europe's immigration policy. Asylum problems must be managed with asylum tools and migration problems with migration tools.

Britain's 1971 Immigration Act was framed at a time when London was keen to honour its obligations to Commonwealth countries by ensuring that those who had already come had rights to bring the rest of their families. Beyond that, the door was firmly shut on any further primary immigration.

It is no wonder that economic migrants from the developing world, especially after the fall of the Berlin Wall, started to batter on the asylum door instead. The growth of low-paid, "black-economy" service-sector jobs across Europe made it possible to live as an illegal, undocumented, person in a way that would have been impossible 20 years before.

But the tragedies of mass deaths in the backs of lorries or of those who cling to the undercarriage of a plane leaving an African airport will continue until a better way of handling these migration flows is found.

Politically it is difficult. Im migration has to be reinvented as a positive force and a way of reinvigorating our economy, culture and traditions in each generation, as it is in America, Australia and Canada.

It is already recognised that the British Asian and Chinese millionaires play a crucial role in penetrating Britain's markets in Asia. Even the Daily Telegraph yesterday ran an editorial entitled Immigration Does Work and recognising that successive waves of migrants had saved the corner store and were significant generators of national prosperity today.

The demographers and economists forecast that western Europe, Britain included, is heading for rising numbers of elderly people and a shrinking younger generation. The OECD believes that high volumes of migration will be needed to change the trend to ageing populations in Europe's prosperous countries.

So what would an new comprehensive immigration policy for the era of globalisation in the 21st century look like? A policy of no immigration controls would soon see any government in power turned out of office. But a policy of opening the door could undermine the clandestine trade and be in Britain's economic interests.

Already the Department for Education and Employment's overseas labour division has begun to acknowledge that Britain needs once again to open the door to an immigration policy based on its economic needs rather than its foreign policy objectives or asylum sympathies. It has just started advertising a fast-track entry to Britain for those with information technology and other skills in short supply.

The Australians learned this lesson in the mid-1980s. They realised that their "keep Australia white" immigration policy was damaging their economy. It was politically difficult, but Australia's leading politicians maintained a consensus that they would not play the race card as their country opened up to Asian immigration. The net result was a far more flexible immigration policy, with all the economic and cultural benefits that have followed.

America has long faced this problem and has a well-established system of greencard quotas for specific jobs. It meets the problem of weighing up the claims of economic migrants by simply putting the names of all those who qualify into a lottery to see who should be admitted. Canada operates a slightly more rational, but similar, points system.

Difficult problems are involved. Those who flee tend to be the most motivated and the most hungry for success. It is a kind of social Darwinism that says those who survive the worst journeys, say across the Sahara, should be rewarded with a job and legal status in their chosen country.

It is also indefensible to deprive the poorest countries of those with the most skills. It is said there are more doctors from Sierra Leone in Chicago than in the country itself.

But these "brain-drain" arguments tend to prove marginal when looked at more closely. In a way, migrant communities prove a far more potent and effective way of helping the developing world than official overseas aid policies. The IMF estimated at the beginning of the 1990s that the global value of remittances sent home by migrant workers totalled $65bn a year - some $20bn more than the official global overseas aid effort.

The tide of migrants will continue to flow. The question is whether death while in the hands of criminal traffickers should be a regarded as a normal part of life in the 21st century.

webTitle: World's largest sail ship slips anchor

fields.headline: World's largest sail ship slips anchor
fields.trailText: With masts taller than Nelson's column and 54,360 sq  m of material in its 42 sails, the Royal Clipper, the  world's biggest sailing ship, has taken to the sea for  the first time, leaving Rotterdam on Sunday for sea  trials and bound for the Thames at some time next  month.
fields.body:
With masts taller than Nelson's column and 54,360 sq m of material in its 42 sails, the Royal Clipper, the world's biggest sailing ship, has taken to the sea for the first time, leaving Rotterdam on Sunday for sea trials and bound for the Thames at some time next month.

The clipper is modelled on the legendary German five-masted Preussen, which was launched in 1902 and which sank in the English Channel eight years later after colliding with a slower steamship. It is 439ft long - 38ft longer than the former world's largest sailing ship, the Russian-owned Sedov - and will be used as a cruise ship setting sail from Cannes in the south of France and the Caribbean.

A spokesman for Star Clippers, the owner, said: "It is the first sailing ship in 100 years to be built with five masts and it's the world's largest sailing ship. Once the sea trials are completed it will sail from Rotterdam to Monaco via London or Dover in mid July."

The ship has been fitted with a special ballast system to help reduce list in high winds. Each of the five masts has a bench on the first crow's nest so that passengers can sit there and enjoy the view. Crew will hoist up a bottle of champagne or wine if required.

Passengers in some of the deluxe cabins will get a 24-hour butler service, and the onboard facilities include three swimming pools, a piano bar, a casino, a library, a health club, and a viewing lounge with portholes below sea level.

Depending on weather conditions, the Royal Clipper will move using the sails only or a combination of sails and the ship's two engines. It can get up to 13.5 knots with its engines, but its top speed of 17 knots can be reached using sail only - the square sails are electronically controlled and the fore and aft sails are manoeuvred by crew members from the deck.

Donald Starkey, who completed the interior design for the Royal Clipper, said: "It is the most impressive sailing ship ever. There is literally nothing else like it. He added that the plan had been to replicate the way sailing was at the end of the 19th century.

The Royal Clipper will sail out of Cannes in early June for cruises around the Mediterranean, including the Balearic islands. It will sail across the Atlantic in October for its winter season in the Caribbean.

A seven-night voyage costs between £1,000 and £3,000.

webTitle: Judge attacks waste in custody battles

fields.headline: Judge attacks waste in custody battles
fields.trailText: Vast amounts of public money are being spent on court battles between warring parents, which could be better resolved by therapy, an appeal court judge said yesterday.
fields.body:
Vast amounts of public money are being spent on court battles between warring parents, which could be better resolved by therapy, an appeal court judge said yesterday.

Lord Justice Thorpe said a great deal of the resources of the family justice system were taken up with disputes between estranged parents over contact with their children. Yet the system had a limited capacity "to produce good outcomes in disputed areas of personal relationships".

He added: "I would question whether the investment of public funds in litigation as the conventional mode of resolving contact disputes is comparatively productive. In many cases the same investment in therapeutic services might produce greater benefits."

The judge made his comments in a judgment yesterday laying down guidelines for judges in deciding whether an estranged parent who was violent or threatened violence to the other parent should be allowed to see the children. He, with the president of the high court's family division, Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, and Lord Justice Waller, dismissed appeals by four fathers who were denied direct contact with their children by circuit judges.

The four appeals involved 11 barristers, including five QCs, all paid for from the public funds.

In one of the four cases, a father had been seeing his son, now aged nine, fortnightly at a contact centre for five years with his mother present until an argument between the parents prompted the boy to refuse to see his father again. That case had cost nearly £20,000 in public money even before the appeal, Lord Justice Thorpe said.

The guidance in the judgment marks a shift in the court's attitude to domestic violence, with an admission that the effect on children of exposure to violence between parents may have been underestimated in the past.
