fields.headline: ITV to screen gay drama during peak time
fields.standfirst: Network hires Queer as Folk team to beef up  mid-evening schedule
fields.trailText: Tuesday June 20, 2000 18:12 ITV is to push at the boundaries of mainstream television by commissioning the team behind the controversial Channel 4 drama Queer as Folk to make a new series for the main commercial network.
fields.body:
Tuesday June 20, 2000 18:12 ITV is to push at the boundaries of mainstream television by commissioning the team behind the controversial Channel 4 drama Queer as Folk to make a new series for the main commercial network.

In a move that will raise the hackles of traditionalists, but is part of a strategy by ITV to woo lucrative young viewers, the writer and producer of the first gay drama are making a series about the life of a gay man who falls in love with a woman. It is thought to be the first time that ITV has commissioned a prime-time drama series in which the principal character is gay.

The show, written by Russell T Davies and produced by Nicola Shindler, will not be nearly as explicit as its predecessor. Its plot has echoes of the latest Madonna movie, Next Best Thing, which also stars the singer's real life gay friend Rupert Everett, but Ms Shindler insisted that the idea has been around for some time.

The series, called Bob and Rose, will be broadcast in six hour-long parts. It will contain some gay sex scenes, said Ms Shindler, to put the character of Bob in context, but the show would not be as explicit as Queer as Folk.

Work on the script is under way, but the two main characters have not yet been cast. The series will go into production early next year, and it is anticipated that it will air in a slot between 9pm and 11pm.

Ms Shindler and Mr Davies first worked together on Queer as Folk, which charted the hedonistic lifestyles of a group of young gay men in Manchester. The programme was a hit for the broadcaster, which highlighted it in its recent annual report as one of its defining shows of the year.

Mr Davies is no stranger to mainstream drama: he was a staff writer for Granada television, where he worked under the present ITV programming director, David Liddiment, who is a former managing director of the Manchester-based station.

The decision by Mr Liddiment to commission the show was part of a plan to use the slots made available by the scrapping of News at Ten for programmes that would not otherwise have been aired on ITV. Series such as Cold Feet, Wonderful You, the Grimleys and Bob Martin would not have made it to the screens were it not for the new thinking fostered by the new schedule, he said.

Some of the risks had not worked, Mr Liddiment conceded, but he was determined that, over time, a new audience could be fostered for ITV. Even though Bob Martin, a spoof comedy starring Michael Barrymore, was a ratings failure, a new series was already in production.

Lessons had been learned from the original series, and the new shows were likely to be "tighter". Another mistake was to promote the first series to the traditional Barrymore audience, whereas the show was far more likely to be popular with viewers who would never think of tuning in to Strike it Lucky or My Kind of People.

Shows aimed at youth market

How ITV is trying to draw in a young audience:

Cold Feet
Hugely successful comedy drama starring Helen Baxendale and James Nesbitt, defined a new genre and proved an unexpected hit with young audiences. Third series in production.

Mr and Mrs
A disastrous remake of the classic gameshow, with the comedian Julian Clary hosting. It was drivel and was pulled before the end of the first series.

Metropolis
From the same stable as Cold Feet. Stylish but trashy thriller drama got off to a moderately good start, with mixed reviews and acceptable viewing figures. May be recomissioned.

Bob Martin
Michael Barrymore vehicle. Disastrous ratings for first series, but ITV bosses still hope the quirky, intelligent take on celebrity can be a hit with ITV audiences.

When Celebrities Strip
"Close your eyes and think of the ratings," said one ITV producer.

webTitle: Lecturer 'killed for fear of dying alone'

fields.headline: Lecturer 'killed for fear of dying alone'
fields.standfirst:
Court told suicidal tutor used rolling pin to kill popular colleague

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A suicidal University of Westminster lecturer lured a  young colleague into a laboratory before bludgeoning  her to death with a rolling pin because he did not want  to die alone, Middlesex crown court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A suicidal University of Westminster lecturer lured a young colleague into a laboratory before bludgeoning her to death with a rolling pin because he did not want to die alone, Middlesex crown court heard yesterday.

Steven Reid, 34, of Marylebone, west London, asked Elizabeth Stacey for help with his computer but when the 24-year-old IT technician sat down at a desk he struck her over the head with the cooking utensil, said Orlando Pownall, prosecuting.

The court heard that when Miss Stacey was not immediately knocked unconscious by the blow, he attempted to tape her mouth and nose with masking tape he had bought the day before. He had previously cut it into strips and stuck it to the edge of a desk in order to suffocate her.

She was found to have suffered multiple skull and facial bone fractures, said Mr Pownall.

Her body was not found until shortly before noon the next day, Saturday, November 6.

Friends and family had grown concerned at her disappearance after she failed to meet a close friend, Chris Bishop, who had travelled from Loughborough to meet her the day she disappeared. Mr Bishop reported her missing to Marylebone police who later that evening began a search of the university premisies.

Reid denies murder, although the court heard that when interviewed by police he admitted killing her.

The crown contends that Reid's actions leading up to and surrounding the death of Miss Stacey showed that he was in control of his acts and had meticulously planned to murder his colleague.

The jury heard that on November 4 1999 Reid had gone to the John Lewis department store in London where he purchased a rolling pin, then later went to a Ryman's stationery shop and bought adhesive tape and a craft knife.

Reid told police that the knife was a "stop-gap" measure that he would use to slash his wrists if an overdose failed.

"In the days leading up to November 5 he frequently considered committing suicide in Edinburgh, his place of birth," Mr Pownall told the court.

"He decided he did not want to die alone and chose the deceased as he wanted to go with someone he liked and respected. Of all the people in the office she was the only person who 'fitted the bill', to quote his words.

"Because Miss Stacey was kind to him he decided that he would kill her before committing suicide."

The court heard that on the night before the murder Reid withdrew the maximum £250 from his bank account, and then removed the same sum the next morning.

He later told police how he had left Westminster University and made his way to the first of two hotels in St Pancras, north London. Reid said that he had taken an overdose of aspirin, but was later sick. He then tried to slash his wrists but also survived this suicide attempt. Realising that the only two options available were to either give himself up or get out of London, he chose the latter.

Police officers eventually caught up with Reid in Brighton after his photo had appeared on the BBC television programme Crimewatch on November 16. They arrested him the following day.

Reid told police and psychologists that in 1987 he tried to commit suicide by taking a combination of antibiotic pills and alcohol, but was sick and the attempt failed.

He moved to London in 1992 and worked in a jobcentre. However, he "found it difficult to make friends", said Mr Pownall.

As he was "interested in psychology" and "hoped it might help him to get on with other people" he enrolled at the University of Westminster and took a psychology degree.

Hazel Dewart, chairwoman of the department of psychology at the University of Westminster, told the court Reid "was very bright but not particularly sociable, he was certainly someone who tended to be withdrawn".

This was in contrast to Cambridge graduate Miss Stacey who graduated from Christchurch College two years ago with a BA and masters degree in physics, the court heard.

Last September, she decided that she wanted to improve her IT skills, and began working at the University of Westminster as a lab psychology technician.

"What the defendant lacked in social skills, she had in abundance," said Mr Pownall. "Those who had dealings with her described her as attractive, sweet, bright, gentle and warm. She always seemed to have time for everybody and became very popular. It may be those very attributes that caused the defendant to take her life."

The trial continues.

webTitle: Cooler days follow hottest June night for 60 years

fields.headline: Cooler days follow hottest June night for 60 years
fields.standfirst: The weather: special report
fields.trailText: Britons continued to swelter in the summer heatwave as weather forecasters revealed that Sunday night was the hottest June night since 1940 - and was followed by daytime temperatures reaching 33C (91F), hotter than Rhodes and Alicante.
fields.body:
Britons continued to swelter in the summer heatwave as weather forecasters revealed that Sunday night was the hottest June night since 1940 - and was followed by daytime temperatures reaching 33C (91F), hotter than Rhodes and Alicante.

Insomniacs spent an uncomfortable night as the lack of wind pushed night time temperatures to 21.8C (72F) in London, with similar readings across the rest of the country.

RAF Coltishall in Norfolk was the hottest recorded place in England with temperatures as high as 33C. Glasgow was the warmest place in Scotland with temperatures reaching 26C (79F). It soared to 32C (90F) in London. The south-west of England had some respite, with temperatures in Cornwall dropping to 21C (70F) thanks to sea fog and cloudy conditions.

But forecasters predicted an end to the heatwave this evening. "This is the last of the hot days. Tomorrow there will be showers in many places, though it still be fairly hot in East Anglia," said one.

In the north-west, temperatures could be as low as 14C-15C (57F-59F) and by Friday temperatures across the country are likely to be lower than average for the time of year. The spokesman said: "It's going to become breezier, cooler and more unsettled."

Michael Meacher, the environment minister, yesterday urged everyone "to do their bit" to curb pollution levels as the summer smog season began. Levels of smog and ozone pollution were high throughout the country yesterday, making breathing difficult for sensitive individuals.

In Lincolnshire, Ronald Waite, 29, drowned while swimming with friends in an isolated reservoir near the village of Metheringham as temperatures soared yesterday.

In Northumberland the body of Debbie Walker, 13, was recovered last night from the river Tweed, near Berwick, where she had been playing.

fields.headline: An avoidable tragedy
fields.standfirst:
Europe must deal with asylum collectively
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The cruellest paradox of the 58 illegal entrants found  dead in a refrigerated container truck in Dover was the  reaction yesterday. Everybody across the political  spectrum expressed sympathy for the victims. Ann  Widdecombe, the Tory shadow home secretary, was  "shocked and saddened". The equally rightwing Roger  Gale, the Thanet North Tory MP, described the deaths  as an "appalling human tragedy".
fields.body:
The cruellest paradox of the 58 illegal entrants found dead in a refrigerated container truck in Dover was the reaction yesterday. Everybody across the political spectrum expressed sympathy for the victims. Ann Widdecombe, the Tory shadow home secretary, was "shocked and saddened". The equally rightwing Roger Gale, the Thanet North Tory MP, described the deaths as an "appalling human tragedy". Home Office ministers extended their deepest sympathy to the families of the victims. Yet, had the 58 immigrants survived and been exposed in the back of the truck, there would have been nothing but condemnation for the "bogus asylum seekers" and calls from both left and right for their deportation as quickly as possible. Why does it take deaths on such a gruesome scale to evoke the correct response?

The fundamental cause of yesterday's tragedy is the contradiction that lies at the heart of the 1951 Geneva convention on refugees. The convention rightly obliges its signatories to offer sanctuary to refugees who can claim "a well-founded fear of persecution", but there is nothing within the treaty prohibiting those same states from erecting every conceivable barrier to prevent genuine refugees from reaching their safe shores. Thus the succession of asylum and immigration acts in the UK that have turned every airline serving Britain into an arm of our immigration service, through fines and other penalties imposed on them for carrying people without proper papers. People fleeing persecution do not dare ask for proper papers. As even the home secretary conceded earlier this month, refugees applying for asylum in Britain are forced to break the law in order to seek it.

Britain is not alone. Most of our neighbours in the last decade have been more liberal towards receiving refugees from our war-torn continent, but drawbridges have been raised across Fortress Europe. There is nothing coincidental about the rise of the latest Frankenstein monster - traffickers in illegal immigrants. They are a direct result of Europe's ever tighter immigration laws.

Governments genuinely interested in eliminating the evil trade, must recognise this link. There are a few rays of hope. The last heads of government gathering, in Finland, called for "a full and inclusive interpretation of the Geneva convention". There was much genuine concern in Lisbon yesterday over the latest tragedy. Fighting traffickers is one issue on which all governments should be able to unite. Ann Widdecombe was right to ask why the Dutch truck was not searched in Holland or Belgium. The European Commission is currently drafting a directive aimed at achieving a common set of minimum standards for asylum. This must end the present nonsense under which asylum seekers have to break the law to obtain its protection. They must be offered a legitimate route.

To this end Jack Straw's call for a redraft of the 1951 convention - initially set out at an Observer-sponsored seminar, but repeated in Lisbon before yesterday's summit - should not automatically be rejected. Mr Straw's proposal for an international quota system, under which European countries would share out asylum seekers from countries where there were internationally recognised abuses of human rights, would be a step forward as long as it was an added safeguard and did not replace the present obligation of the treaty. The right to protection from political persecution must remain sacrosanct - not left to politicians to redefine and reduce to the lowest common denominator.

fields.headline: Men first
fields.standfirst: Women are missing out on the New Deal programme  for the unemployed. Most spending is going to  predominantly male groups
fields.trailText: The Blair government is spending more on men than on  women in some of its key social programmes, even  though they were intended to be neutral between the  genders. Take the various New Deal programmes.  These are aimed at getting the young, the long-term  and and now the older unemployed into the market for  jobs. Through them, Labour hopes to promote  "economic and employment opportunities for all".
fields.body:
The Blair government is spending more on men than on women in some of its key social programmes, even though they were intended to be neutral between the genders. Take the various New Deal programmes. These are aimed at getting the young, the long-term and and now the older unemployed into the market for jobs. Through them, Labour hopes to promote "economic and employment opportunities for all".

At first sight, such an effort ought to affect women and men in equal number. The schemes are open to all. They are run by the Employment Service, which is proud of its equal-opportunities code. If we look closely, however, the very design of New Deal programmes results in significantly more men taking part. In addition, more ends up being spent on those new deals which cater to a predominantly male group.

An imbalance between the genders follows from the way these programmes draw participants from the unemployed (defined as those claiming benefits). Figures from the Department for Education and Employment show that of those who have taken part in the new deal for young people, 27% are female. Women make up just 16% of those on the new deal for the long-term unemployed.

These proportions accurately reflect the make-up of the population of benefit claimants. But the relatively low representation of women reflects the vagaries of the benefits system - not whether women could get jobs. The system decrees that where women have an employed partner, they are mostly not eligible for job seeker's allowance. Where both partners in a household are unemployed, the man is more likely to register as the main job seeker. As a result, many women - and particularly those living with a man who is out of work - lack the requisite periods of certified unemployment in order to take part in either of the main new deals.

Where women are registered as unemployed they tend to move off the register more quickly than men. This reflects how women often find it easy to get low-paid, part-time jobs. Once in them, however, they find it difficult to progress - the "sticky floors" effect.

Research from the Department of Social Security has shown that women are more likely to be caught in a low pay, no pay cycle with bad effects on their welfare and their children's. The cabinet office women's unit found a persistent gap between how much women and men earn over their lifetimes. So, creating economic and employment opportunity for the registered unemployed is not the same as opening the door to those lacking job opportunities.

The government has been aware of the problem. Other new deals have been established which target women. Some 95% of those in the new deal for lone parents are women. There is a new deal for partners of the unemployed and, as it rolls out, most of its participants are likely to be women. Such targeting is good practice - after all, different groups have quite distinct needs. But those new deals with high levels of male participation still command the most spending. The chart shows how the £2.6bn in windfall tax meant to pay for the new deals has been assigned to the various schemes. The bulk of the money (57%) goes to the new deal for young people, while the new deal for the long-term unemployed commands a further 23%. The remaining fifth is shared between the other schemes. The new deal for lone parents commands 8% of total expenditure while the new deal for partners of the unemployed will cost only £50m (2% of the total).

There are even differences in spending per person between men and women on these programmes. Rough estimates suggest that, compared with lone-parent new dealers, young unemployed new dealers will have double the amount spent on them on average. This clearly reflects the fact that lone parents are being offered a less complete service. Even with the extensions in training announced by Gordon Brown in the last budget, lone parents do not have access to the year's worth of training which is one very popular option available to young people.

Other pots of expenditure may be helping women to move into employment. The national childcare strategy is beginning to address the large deficit in the number of places where children can be cared for while a parent works. However, expenditure is relatively small compared with the jobs programmes.

Some £470m has been allocated for childcare over a five- year period and that is less than a fifth of the spending on the employment-focused new deals or an annual spend of about 0.01% of GDP. By comparison, Sweden spends almost 2% of GDP on childcare (and an additional 1% on maternity and parental leave); it also experiences some of the highest rates of female employment in Europe .

In order to redress the imbalance in public spending between men and women, all policies are going to have to be examined for their incidence between the sexes and corrected if there is bias. The government has a stated commitment to do exactly this - what it terms gender-impact assessment - yet it does not seem to happen often enough. For example, this year's budget statement contained little analysis of how new measures will affect women and men. There was no examination at all of who does benefit from the bulk of public expenditure.

 Katherine Rake lectures in social policy at the London School of Economics. She was seconded to the cabinet office women's unit last year

K.Rake@lse.ac.uk

The cabinet office women's unit found a persistent gap between how much women and men earn over their lifetimes. So, creating economic and employment opportunity for the registered unemployed is not the same as opening the door to those lacking job opportunities. The government has been aware of the problem. Other new deals have been established which target women. Some 95% of those in the new deal for lone parents are women. There is a new deal for partners of the unemployed and, as it rolls out, most of its participants are likely to be women. Such targeting is good practice - after all, different groups have quite distinct needs. But those new deals with high levels of male participation still command the most spending. The chart shows how the £2.6bn in windfall tax meant to pay for the new deals has been assigned to the various schemes. The bulk of the money (57%) goes to the new deal for young people, while the new deal for the long-term unemployed commands a further 23%. The remaining fifth is shared between the other schemes. The new deal for lone parents commands 8% of total expenditure while the new deal for partners of the unemployed will cost only £50m (2% of the total). There are even differences in spending per person between men and women on these programmes. Rough estimates suggest that, compared with lone-parent new dealers, young unemployed new dealers will have double the amount spent on them on average. This clearly reflects the fact that lone parents are being offered a less complete service. Even with the extensions in training announced by Gordon Brown in the last budget, lone parents do not have access to the year's worth of training which is one very popular option available to young people. Other pots of expenditure may be helping women to move into employment. The national childcare strategy is beginning to address the large deficit in the number of places where children can be cared for while a parent works. However, expenditure is relatively small compared with the jobs programmes. Some £470m has been allocated for childcare over a five- year period and that is less than a fifth of the spending on the employment-focused new deals or an annual spend of about 0.01% of GDP. By comparison, Sweden spends almost 2% of GDP on childcare (and an additional 1% on maternity and parental leave); it also experiences some of the highest rates of female employment in Europe . In order to redress the imbalance in public spending between men and women, all policies are going to have to be examined for their incidence between the sexes and corrected if there is bias. The government has a stated commitment to do exactly this - what it terms gender-impact assessment - yet it does not seem to happen often enough. For example, this year's budget statement contained little analysis of how new measures will affect women and men. There was no examination at all of who does benefit from the bulk of public expenditure.  Katherine Rake lectures in social policy at the London School of Economics. webTitle: Sex-change Iranian hates life as woman

fields.headline: Sex-change Iranian hates life as woman
fields.standfirst: More about Iran
fields.trailText: Maryam took one hard first-person look at life as a woman in Iran and made a decision: "she" wanted out.
fields.body:
Maryam took one hard first-person look at life as a woman in Iran and made a decision: "she" wanted out.

Born Mehran, the 25-year-old Iranian, then a man, had earlier swept aside strong parental objections and undergone a sex change operation last year. But in female form, Maryam soon found it impossible to cope with the constraints imposed by the Islamic republic - so impossible that she now wants to reverse the operation.

"I cannot go on living with the new identity, after years of living as a man with no restrictions," she told the daily newspaper Iran. "At first, I thought I would get used to it, but life has become painful and intolerable. So I want a new sex change."

No one ever said life as an Iranian woman would be easy. The country's social and legal codes severely limit women's choices.

Most move from the authority of their father and brothers to that of a husband, so have little or no experience of life on their own.

They also face personal restrictions and taboos that implicitly prevent them renting apartments on their own or travelling overseas without first getting the consent of a male relative.

State health officials report that between the sexes, it is the women who have the higher suicide rate, with the highest figures being registered in the holy Muslim Shi'ite city of Qom, Iran's centre of religious learning.

Although reliable figures are impossible to come by, anecdotal evidence makes it clear that women turned out overwhelmingly in the 1997 parliamentary election to vote for the social, cultural and political reforms advocated by President Mohammad Khatami.

Some of the more superficial restrictions on women's dress and conduct have been eased. The enforcement of veiling is more relaxed, particularly in the capital, Tehran. But on substantive issues involving legal and social rights, much more remains to be done.

Sex change operations are legal in socially conservative Iran, although formal permission from the coroner's office is required before the surgery can take place. Critics of the system say conservative mores prevent candidates for such radical operations from testing out their new sexual identity first, as is often the case elsewhere.

The only option for someone who changes her mind, like Maryam, is to undergo a second operation.

In the legal system, a woman's testimony is given half the weight of that of a man, while inheritance, divorce and child custody laws all favour men. For example, a boy as young as two and a girl as young as seven are automatically awarded to the father if a couple divorces, a fact that keeps some women in abusive or dangerous marriages.

Upper middle class women have taken to demanding special clauses in their marriage contracts reserving them the right to initiate divorce. Otherwise, that power resides with the man alone.

webTitle: Mindless majority who bring shame on the nation

fields.headline: Mindless majority who bring shame on the nation
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Once again, the House of Commons has had to  witness a display of brutal thuggery, of an  all-too-familiar type that has brought shame upon our  nation around the world.
fields.body:
Once again, the House of Commons has had to witness a display of brutal thuggery, of an all-too-familiar type that has brought shame upon our nation around the world.

And again the blame can be firmly pinned on a tiny, unrepresentative majority of mindless MPs who spoiled the pleasure for the overwhelming minority who had made the trip, hoping to enjoy an exciting debate in peace and safety.

The day started well, though the authorities were clearly taking no chances. They had stationed a heavily armed man in a black uniform - the Serjeant at Arms - in the main chamber where in previous years rival gangs have gathered to taunt each other.

There was a good-natured atmosphere at first, and Jack Straw, the home secretary, even won agreement as he spoke about his "outrage and shame" when he saw "our fellow citizens engaged in appalling drunken violence on the streets of Belgium. These people have disgraced the nation and our national game."

"Like John Bercow," yelled a Labour MP. Mr Bercow, one of the Tories' most notorious hooligans, was not present. Presumably William Hague has had him subjected to a banning order. But the Labour taunt was the equivalent of the first bottle that starts a riot, and given the centuries-old track record of enmity between these two sides, what followed had a horrific inevitability.

The violence got under way when Mr Straw had almost finished his speech. He said he hoped last year's Football (Offences and Disorder) Act should have contained a clause that allowed the courts to stop anyone suspected of hooliganism - they did not need to be convicted - from travelling abroad. "But, as the house knows, this proposal encountered vociferous opposition from certain hon members."

(To abandon the metaphor for a moment: the government's view is that the proposal would not have done any good, since the latest batch of hooligans were hitherto unknown. On the other hand, the fact that it was Tory MPs who threatened to smash up the bill was the equivalent of a tempting barstool being thrust into Mr Straw's hands. If you've got it, you might as well throw it.)

A loud, rumbling, grumbling shout of anger rose up from the Tory yobboes. They had, as they would no doubt have said, been thoroughly dissed by Mr Straw. This provocation could not go unanswered, and within moments Ann Widdecombe was on her feet, if only just.

She hurled herself across the dispatch box. Thank heavens it is reinforced and stood up to the assault. "Woefully complacent and inadequate," she yelled. Any bar owner in Charleroi would have been terrified to see that figure hurtling towards his plate glass window.

Crash! Smash! "One of the most pathetic exhibitions over the past few days has been that of the home secretary, who has been in office for three years, trying to blame the opposition for his own inadequacies.

"He said that we need to find a way of dealing with these people. That was in May 1999, it's now June 2000, and he has done absolutely nothing to fulfil his promise!"

What can we do to prevent a repeat of these terrible scenes? An urgent action plan is needed. It could include closing down the tea-rooms, where much of the plotting for the mayhem takes place, a better intelligence service for Madam Speaker so she can ban the hooligans from stirring up trouble in the chamber, and for the Serjeant at Arms to run repeat offenders through with his sword.

It's the only language most of these MPs understand.

webTitle: Mexico's machine squeezes poor for votes

fields.headline: Mexico's machine squeezes poor for votes
fields.standfirst: Ruling PRI goes for coercion with a 90s gloss
fields.trailText: The young woman leaning on the flimsy sheet metal door of her ramshackle home looked at the ground as she told the story of how she became a campaign worker for Mexico's ruling Institutional Revolutionary party as it seeks another six years in government, to add to its total of 71.
fields.byline: Jo Tuckman in Valle de Chalco southern Mexico
fields.body:
The young woman leaning on the flimsy sheet metal door of her ramshackle home looked at the ground as she told the story of how she became a campaign worker for Mexico's ruling Institutional Revolutionary party as it seeks another six years in government, to add to its total of 71.

At the urging of officials who control a modest school grant for her 10-year-old sister, Maria Gonzalez set aside her pride and independence of mind and appealed to neighbours to write down their names and voter ID numbers on a form emblazoned with the PRI logo.

With the campaign proving one of the tightest in recent times, the result may hang on what goes through the minds of voters like Mrs Gonzalez on polling day, people whose dependence on welfare benefits makes them vulnerable in the run-up when the ruling group presses for them to declare their allegiance - but who may feel different when alone in the election booth.

'Is the vote secret?'

Mrs Gonzalez believes that the friends "who did me this favour" of signing the PRI pledge are committed to voting for the ruling group on July 2, when the congress, the senate and the president are all up for election - but she is not sure how binding that commitment is.

"Is the vote really secret? What if they find out you did not vote for them?" she asked, suspicious of the assurances of confidentiality from election authorities. "If it is secret, what do they want the credential numbers for?" She categorically refused to give her real name.

Such stories of pressure, as well as vote-buying and threats to the job security of those who have public-sector jobs, are becoming increasingly common as the PRI's vast electoral machine cranks into action to deal with the challenge posed to it and its presidential candidate, Francisco Labastida, by the National Action party's challenger, Vicente Fox.

A former Coca-Cola executive in cowboy boots, Mr Fox has used the mass media astutely, reaching beyond the PAN's traditionally conservative constituency to create a broader movement with one goal in mind - voting out the PRI.

The ruling group has long been vilified for corruption and economic mismanagement, but a divided opposition has helped prolongue its reign.

Opinion polls since the end of April have been showing the two frontrunners roughly tied at about 40%, though the Fox bandwagon appears to have stalled. This is due in part to a tactical rethink in which the PRI decided not to rely on its carefully constructed reformist image alone, and cranked up the tried and tested electoral apparatus.

"What gives the party its strength is the enormous number of activists, in every town and neighbourhood," Mr Labastida said in a recent interview. "When all these activists start campaigning they have an unrivalled capacity to reach out to people."

"In every country in the world, the party in power has an advantage," said Meyer Brownstone, a Canadian political scientist who belongs to a delegation evaluating the pre-poll environment. "The difference here is the scale and the evidence of explicit pressure."

Referring specifically to allegations of coercion exerted through the Progresa programme of grants to about 2.7m poor rural women, he said: "The scale of this is staggering." A recent report by Civic Alliance, Mexico's largest observer group, detailed cases countrywide, but especially in rural areas of the deprived southern states and slum sprawls like Valle de Chalco where Mrs Gonzalez lives, an hour's drive from the capital.

Organising and monitoring the ballot next month is the Federal Electoral Institute. Despite unprecedented independence from the government, the directors of the institute say that there is little they can do about the coercion - victims are rarely willing to go public, let alone file lawsuits.

Thuggery declining

"We can guarantee, and we will guarantee, that the part of the electoral process within our competence is legal, but on our own we cannot guarantee the context to ensure that it is also fair, legitimate and transparent," said Emilio Zebadua. He insisted, however, that the institute has made enormous strides towards eliminating the blatant fraud of the past such as the computer crash on polling night 1988 that many believe cheated the leftwing candidate, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, of victory.

Being unable to rig the vote seems, however, to had led the perpetrators to find other methods to manipulate the balloting, such as the list of names and ID numbers Mrs Gonzalez felt obliged to collect.

"Given the kind of safeguards in the system now, they [the PRI] cannot be as crass as they used to be," said a political analyst, Federico Estevez, recalling past elections when groups of party thugs roamed the streets and voters marked their ballots in full view of party watchdogs.

"They've innovated a bit and got more sophisticated - but at the same time it gets more tenuous. In all probability today's methods are much less effective than in the good old days."

fields.headline: Tory visit winds up Toxteth
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Conservative attempts to attack Labour's record on  urban regeneration backfired yesterday when the  shadow environment secretary told how he "wound up  all the windows" while driving through the Toxteth  district of Liverpool.
fields.body:
Conservative attempts to attack Labour's record on urban regeneration backfired yesterday when the shadow environment secretary told how he "wound up all the windows" while driving through the Toxteth district of Liverpool.

Archie Norman was accused of "negative stereotyping" over the remark, made following a visit to the area which was the scene of riots in 1981. Gideon Ben Tovim, leader of the city's Labour group, whose Granby ward lies in Toxteth, said: "It is just another example of negative stereotyping which ignores the gradual but significant improvements which are being made in the area."

Mr Norman, who was speaking to MEPs, councillors and representatives of the region's business communities, said there "wasn't a policeman in sight" during his tour.

A Conservative spokesman said: "Archie's remarks were taken out of context. He had spent the whole day on foot in Toxteth before driving through the area and one of the issues people constantly raised with him was street crime. He was reflecting their concerns."

webTitle: Drought hitting 13m in Horn of Africa

fields.headline: Drought hitting 13m in Horn of Africa
fields.standfirst: Ethiopia: special report
fields.trailText: Three months after the world learned of the serious drought on the Horn of Africa, the head of Unicef warned yesterday that the lives of millions of people remain under threat.
fields.byline: Craig Nelson in Nairobi and agencies
fields.body:
Three months after the world learned of the serious drought on the Horn of Africa, the head of Unicef warned yesterday that the lives of millions of people remain under threat.

"This drought is still here, it's very serious and the women and children of the Horn of Africa need our total commitment to help them survive," Carol Bellamy said in neighbouring Kenya.

Ending a five-nation tour of the region, Ms Bellamy said Eritrea was in particular danger after a combination of drought and war, despite signing a partial peace accord with Ethiopia on Sunday. The fighting displaced at least a million Eritreans, endangering the planting season.

The conflict has put off some "historically very good donors", she admitted - an apparent reference to Germany and Britain, which criticised Ethiopia for demanding food aid while spending exorbitantly on arms to fight its neighbour.

The result is a "humanitarian crisis on an enormous scale", said Unicef's chief, who also predicted that drought in north-western Kenya could worsen to levels exceeding the famines of the 80s and 90s.

The UN asked donors last week for $378m (£250m) in drought relief for the region, where an estimated 13.4m people have been affected by lack of rain.

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Plea of the day
fields.body:
Plea of the day

Lord Longford, age 94, made a heartfelt plea for older people. Backing calls to raise the retirement age of ambassadors from 60 to 65 he told peers: "Some of us oldies regard men and women of 60 as hardly having begun life. They are youngsters, neophytes."

Nimby of the day

Lord Deedes. The former Daily Telegraph editor and golfing partner of Sir Denis Thatcher raised in the Lords plans to establish a detention centre for 350 asylum seekers and up to 200 staff in his home village of Aldington, Kent. "What sort of traffic problem is going to arise?" he asked.

Today

Foreign questions. Opposition debates on US/UK air negotiations and planning, house building, development of greenfields and the decline of the cities. Census (Amendment) Bill (Lords), second reading. Lords: Terrorism Bill, report.

webTitle: Jurors in Martin farm murder case to be questioned on 'intimidation'

fields.headline: Jurors in Martin farm murder case to be questioned on 'intimidation'
fields.trailText: Jurors in the case of Tony Martin, the farmer jailed for  life for the murder of a teenage burglar, will be  questioned in writing about whether they were  intimidated, the court of appeal decided yesterday.
fields.body:
Jurors in the case of Tony Martin, the farmer jailed for life for the murder of a teenage burglar, will be questioned in writing about whether they were intimidated, the court of appeal decided yesterday.

If their answers confirm that they were menaced, a judge could take the rare step of ordering them to be questioned orally in the appeal court.

Lord Justice Rose, Mr Justice Harrison and Mr Justice Tomlinson gave the go-ahead for the registrar of criminal appeals to write to the jury and ask them to answer certain questions "as soon as possible".

The judges, sitting in London, ordered that the terms of the questions addressed to the jury should not be disclosed by the press.

Martin's application for leave to appeal is expected to be heard next month, with the full appeal hearing later this year.

His solicitor, Nick Makin, said his client would be "very pleased that the allegations are being taken seriously and something is being done". He said there were eight grounds of appeal, of which the most important were misdirection by the trial judge, the judge's allowing the jury to hear inadmissible evidence and an atmosphere of intimidation of the jury and witnesses.

It had been thought that this would break new legal ground, but it emerged yesterday that there is at least one precedent. Last Monday the appeal court quashed the fraud conviction of two Italians and a Swiss after learning that the detective constable in the case had passed his business card to jurors through the jury bailiff. A single juror and the jury bailiff gave evidence at the appeal court hearing, although this was not reported at the time.

webTitle: Blair kills EU tax threat to City

fields.headline: Blair kills EU tax threat to City
fields.standfirst: Successes at summit delight Downing Street
fields.trailText: Tony Blair last night reclaimed a role for Britain at the  heart of the European Union's diplomacy after a string  of negotiating successes which finally saw off the  threat to the City of London of an EU-wide savings tax  and a produced an unexpected surge of support for his  minimalist position on a new charter of fundamental  rights.
fields.byline: Michael White, and Ian Black in Santa Maria da Fiera
fields.body:
Tony Blair last night reclaimed a role for Britain at the heart of the European Union's diplomacy after a string of negotiating successes which finally saw off the threat to the City of London of an EU-wide savings tax and a produced an unexpected surge of support for his minimalist position on a new charter of fundamental rights.

Buoyed by a crisis-free summit which did not leave his government isolated in the traditional British fashion, the prime minister portrayed the EU's mid-summer get together as a vindication of his "far more engaged and constructive" approach to Europe, despite the tensions within the cabinet and the EU over his wait-and-see stance on membership of the euro.

For Britain the crucial gain was a majority against the original version of the savings tax - leaving Luxembourg and Austria holding out against an alternative model - and routine exchanges of information between banks and tax collectors.

The savings tax had threatened thousands of City jobs and could have undermined London's status as a leading financial capital.

Though a final decision was delayed, Downing Street used the shift to praise Gordon Brown's "extraordinarily relentless negotiating skills and tenacity" - balm to the chancellor's soul after a week which saw him attacked by cabinet colleagues for trying to stifle debate in favour of Britain joining the single currency.

Mr Blair was emboldened to tell BBC Radio 4: "If I recommend to the British people that we join the euro, I will make the case for it as strongly and as powerfully as you could possibly hear." But he added that he would not repeat John Major's error in taking Britain into the exchange rate mechanism "on political grounds, ignoring the economics [which] resulted in economic disaster for this country".

Psychological pressure on Mr Blair to move on the euro grew yesterday. The summit agreed to let Greece, one of four EU members outside the currency, join on January 1 next year. Its new government has taken tough steps to qualify for membership.

A compensating boost for the Treasury's caution came from an unlikely quarter. Eurostat, the EU's statistical bureau, confirmed that the UK's annualised inflation rate between April and May was the EU's lowest, at 0.5%, with Ireland's the highest at 5.1%. The 11-country euro zone's average was 1.7% - compared with 1.1% a year ago.

Yesterday the summit was forced to defer a major debate on the proposed charter of rights after the former German president, Roman Hertzog, who was chairing the drafting committee, withdrew on the death of his wife.

But Mr Blair's call for a charter which restates existing rights, both national and those enshrined in the European convention, in terms that ordinary voters could relate to (a New Labour-style pledge card was even considered) found support from Spain, Ireland, Sweden and Denmark. Berlin may resume its campaign for a legally-enforcible charter by the Nice summit in December.

The summit's failure to resolve the dispute with Vienna over the extremist-tainted coalition left the EU leaders with a veiled threat by Austria to veto the union's promised enlargement to the south and east, and other reforms.

There is little hope of resolving that simmering problem in today's final session, held at a conference centre in central Portugal. But after a week of domestic discomfort over the euro, and the embarrassment caused by rioting England football fans at Euro 2000, the Downing Street spokesman trumpeted it as a day of solid achievement.

"The days when the story at any summit was 'Britain isolated' and 'Britain against the rest' are gone. You now have a British government actively pursuing a constructively- engaged policy. We believe that is to the benefit of Britain and the British people," Alastair Campbell said.

Today's final communique will reinforce pressure for national legislation to provide "severe sanctions" against refugee-running gangs. It was proposed during the Finnish presidency of the EU but has not been acted on.

webTitle: Major will face MPs' questions on conduct code

fields.headline: Major will face MPs' questions on conduct code
fields.trailText: John Major is expected to strongly support the role of  Parliament in tackling "sleazy" behaviour among MPs  and the need for a tough ministerial code for ministers  when he gives evidence to the Commons public  administration committee next month.
fields.body:
John Major is expected to strongly support the role of Parliament in tackling "sleazy" behaviour among MPs and the need for a tough ministerial code for ministers when he gives evidence to the Commons public administration committee next month.

The former prime minister - who announced his unusual decision to give evidence yesterday - is understood to be keen to do so because he believes that Tony Blair has downgraded the importance of Parliament since he won his landslide victory in 1997.

Mr Blair refused to give evidence to the same inquiry by the committee, sending Mo Mowlam, Chancellor of Duchy of Lancaster in his place.

MPs plan to question Mr Major over the background to the cash for questions affair which led to the resignations of former ministers Neil Hamilton and Tim Smith.

He will also face questions over his government's handling of the Jonathan Aitken affair, after the Guardian showed that the former cabinet minister's hotel bill at the Paris Ritz was paid by a Saudi Arabian arms dealer.

The committee is examining whether the present ministerial code needs to be strengthened, as recommended by Lord Neill, chairman of the committee on standards in public life. It is also looking at whether an ethics commissioner should be appointed to police the code, which was rejected by Lord Neill.

Lord Neill instead believes that the prime minister should be able to appoint an accountant or lawyer to investigate an erring minister and report to him in confidence.

Mr Major encountered considerable criticism from Tory MPs when the last government implemented proposals from Lord Nolan, then chairman of the committee on standards on public life, which forced MPs to declare their income from directorships and consultancies, in the wake of the cash for questions scandal.

Mr Major has always defended the former Cabinet secretary, Lord Butler, for his handling of the Aitken affair, although it was later proved in court that Mr Aitken had lied to both Lord Butler and Mr Major about his stay at the Ritz.

Lord Butler has always maintained that it was difficult for a Cabinet secretary to handle an investigation into a minister but he also rejected the creation of a separate ethics commissioner.

Mr Major is also expected to be questioned about the Tony Blair's huge increase in the number of special advisers, who have doubled inside the government and trebled inside Downing Street since Labour's 1997 election victory.

fields.headline: Japan's politics of brotherly hatred
fields.standfirst: Feud highlights hereditary democracy
fields.trailText: Critics say he is so disloyal that he has stabbed his brother in the back, so shiftless that he has swapped parties five times, and so unprincipled that he is running on a green ticket despite standing for a party that has spent the past few decades covering Japan in concrete.
fields.body:
Critics say he is so disloyal that he has stabbed his brother in the back, so shiftless that he has swapped parties five times, and so unprincipled that he is running on a green ticket despite standing for a party that has spent the past few decades covering Japan in concrete.

But when the country goes to the polls next Sunday, Kunio Hatoyama, a candidate for the Liberal Democratic party (LDP) in Tokyo, is confident that he will win a seat in the lower house of parliament.

Why? Because he is a Hatoyama, and in Japan's semi-feudal democracy, such a prestigious family name is often more important than ability, experience or policy.

Like more than a quarter of Japan's 500 MPs, Mr Hatoyama was born with a parliamentary seat under his bottom. His great-grandfather was speaker of the lower house long before the war, his grandfather was one of the LDP's first prime ministers and his father held the post of foreign minister in the 1970s.

But a bitter sibling rivalry within this historic family has exposed the increasingly hereditary nature of Japan's democracy, and added venom to an unusually negative election campaign.

Last month, Mr Hatoyama decided to stand for the conservative LDP, abandoning the main opposition Democratic party of Japan (DPJ) led by his elder brother Yukio.

Yukio is fuming at this treachery. The two formed the DPJ in 1996 in a move that they claimed would create a new idealistic force in Japanese politics and overthrow the LDP.

Yukio has not spoken to his brother since Kunio switched allegiance, but his silence has been met with vitriol.

Kunio, a former education minister, accuses his sibling of being a "political chameleon" who changes his views to match whichever group he is trying to form an alliance with. "I trusted my brother, but he deceived me," Kunio said.

In a personal attack that has fascinated Japan, he also joked that Yukio has upset his mother and been unfaithful to his wife. "When we were children, we used to play baseball together and catch butterflies, but now he only chases after butterflies of the night," Kunio said of his brother.

Many express frustration at such antics by hereditary MPs, whose numbers have steadily increased since the 1960s. The Hatoyamas are among more than 150 second-, third- and fourth-generation candidates running for office, mostly for the ruling party.

"The presence of hereditary MPs holds up change," said Professor Takeshi Sasaki of Tokyo University.

"Some are good, but on the whole they are the cheap and easy option. It's a unique feature of Japanese democracy, but not a good one."

Prof Sasaki in not alone in his criticism of Japan's nepotistic political system. The newspaper Asahi Shimbun said: "We need to decide who to vote for based on who the candidate is, not what family they are from."

But despite such opposition and the urge to punish the ruling party after four years of recession, analysts expect the LDP-led coalition to hang on to power and Kunio to win a seat next Sunday.

webTitle: Shopping habits to be checked for GM risks

fields.headline: Shopping habits to be checked for GM risks
fields.standfirst:
Britons' shopping habits and consumption of GM foods are to be monitored in another attempt to shore up confidence in the new technology.

GM debate: special report
fields.trailText: The new food standards agency believes it will soon be able to track the sale of products and match them to medical data for populations by area, to provide an early warning of increased rates of chronic illnesses, allergies or foetal abnormalities.
fields.body:
The new food standards agency believes it will soon be able to track the sale of products and match them to medical data for populations by area, to provide an early warning of increased rates of chronic illnesses, allergies or foetal abnormalities.

It will announce in the next few days an 18-month experiment in matching the nation's buying power to its health. The system will use data collated by market research bodies, including information from supermarkets.

If the trial works, the consumption of GM products and other foods, including, for instance, ingredients designed to lower cholesterol or replace sugar, will be monitored even after they have passed all the existing safety procedures.

The government is keen to provide what one minister has called "a comfort blanket" without giving the impression that the public are being used as guinea pigs.

The system may also help to alert health officials to trouble and allow the government to respond rapidly should unexpected effects occur.

The food agency is also planning random tests this autumn to ensure that companies are not breaking EU rules requiring them to label any GM ingredients making up 1% or more of a processed food.

fields.headline: Tomb raiders plunder Italy's past
fields.standfirst: Looters of the night get rich on worldwide trade in antiquities
fields.trailText: The looting of Italy starts at sunset when men like Antonio stride into the deserted landscape,  hunting history.
fields.body:
The looting of Italy starts at sunset when men like Antonio stride into the deserted landscape, hunting history.

Melting into the shadows to elude police, they work soundlessly. The most important tools of their trade are matches, a torch, a shovel and a spiedo, a thin iron rod which is inserted into the earth at an angle and twisted until it hits something solid.

From the texture Antonio can tell straight away if he has found another tomb. A few more insertions tell him what type of tomb and where the entrance is. Then he picks up his shovel. His fingers are scarred and thumbs mutilated but 40 years of robbing Etruscan necropolises have left Antonio with no regrets. The hills of central Italy he knows so well roll into the horizon. "They've been good to me."

They have been even kinder to his customers, for beyond Antonio there are dealers, auction houses, collectors and museums making billions of pounds from the international trade in looted antiquities that is destroying heritage.

A report last week by the Museums Association and the International Council of Museums warned that the market is getting more sophisticated and ruthless. By some estimates it is the fourth largest criminal enterprise, after drugs, arms and money laundering.

The report lambasted countries, including Britain, that refuse to sign UN and other protocols outlawing the trade. Dealers and museums mobilise lawyers and experts to maintain the flow, for they must collect to survive, but supply ultimately hinges on the graverobbers.

Italy, which has one of the highest densities of historic remains in the world, calls them tombaroli . They operate mostly in Tuscany and northern Lazio, where the Etruscans reigned for nearly 1,000 years before Rome, and in Sicily, colonised by Phoenicians, Greeks and Romans.

Antonio, a mint-sucking, chain-smoking, youthful 65, is the granddaddy of tomboroli in northern Lazio. He has decided to give this, his first and last, interview on the eve of his retirement, he says.

A decorator by profession, he started robbing in the late 1950s, learning from books and archaeologists who were digging up some of the area's tens of thousands of tombs. "I head out at around 8.30 and work until 2am. It took a few years but now I can usually guess where a tomb is by the shape of the terrain and the colour of the grass. Winter is better because the ground is softer.

"If the police are active I take someone along to act as look-out. After 2,000 years a tomb can be filled up with toxic gas, so after opening one, I light a match to test for oxygen."

Etruscans liked to remind the dead of pleasures of life so they filled their resting places with figured pottery, statues, paintings, theatre masks, urns and mirrors. A single tomb can contain more than a dozen sarcophagi. Archaeologists prize such finds because in context they tell a story. Spirited away and displayed elsewhere they retain their beauty but reveal little about the past.

Antonio, not his real name, spits in disgust. "I've heard that a thousand times. Italy's museums don't have the money or space to display all these things so all they do is stick them in warehouses and forget about them."

Twice he was almost crushed by a collapsing tomb, he risks prison and it's backbreaking work, so it's only right he is rewarded, says Antonio. He sells his finds to a dealer in the town of Viterbo, who trucks them to another in Switzerland, who sells them on the legitimate art market to private collectors and museums.

Antonio insists he is supplying demand, not creating it. Tourists looking for black market bargains have been conned by tomboroli who lead them to tombs where they placed cheap vases two months earlier. "That's just pennies. The real money we get from the dealers, the professionals."

One of his friends found a drinking cup, dating from 500 BC, which ended up in America's Getty museum, according to Maria Rizzo, of the archaeological superintendency of southern Etruria.

Antonio complains that surveillance is making his job impossible but the local police commander, who asked not to be named, sighed. "If only. To prosecute we need to catch them red-handed and for that we need to anticipate where they'll strike. I can't hide men behind every bush every night.

"If they see us coming they drop everything and say they were out for a walk. The older ones are teaching the next generation where to look." From beneath his desk the commander took out a cardboard box with two vases and a figurine wrapped in newspapers. "We got these last week. A fluke."

Lack of resources is a refrain of the culture ministry, which watches over more than 3,000 museums, 6,000 libraries, 100,000 churches, 50,000 other buildings and more than 1,000 archaeological sites.

In Sicily and southern Italy the tombaroli , reinforced by the mafia, are bolder. Bulldozers have been used in daylight. In 18th century watercolours of Pompeii frescoes can be seen which have since vanished.

The world's largest collection of allegedly stolen archaeological treasures was found last year in the Sicilian home of art collector Vincenzo Cammarata, who police say was the mafia's conduit to Switzerland. Mr Cammarata says the more than 30,000 artefacts, valued at £20m, were all registered. Five other Sicilians, including two professors, were charged with aiding and abetting him.

Italian police have scored other successes. Last November six people were caught looting 250 relics from Hadrian's villa. In May an elaborately carved Roman sarcophagus was seized from a farmhouse near Rome. Four art dealers and a university lecturer are being investigated.

Police systematically trawl the catalogue of auction houses like Sotheby's and Christie's, checking suspicious items on a database of stolen artworks. Some major pieces have been extricated from auction houses and museums.

"The trade is fuelled partly by competition among museums to acquire superstars," said the American Journal Archaeology.

Lord Renfrew, professor of archaeology at Cambridge, is scathing about Britain's role. "The government is in the pocket of the art market, which wants to keep the flow of antiquities. It's a scandal."

He has been appointed to a committee established last month by the Department of Culture to report by the autumn on how to tackle the trade. Some archaeologists have a grudging respect for the tombaroli 's skill. Not Lord Renfrew: "Thieves, looters, that is what they are."

Back in Viterbo, Antonio shakes his head. "I am not a criminal. I find history and I sell it." He prepares for another night among the tombs of his ancestors. His tools, a tube of mints and cigarettes will keep him going till 2am.

"I stick to the Etruscans now, my arms aren't so strong and their tombs are shallower. The Romans I'm leaving to future tombaroli ."

Recovered loot

 Golden phial, 450 BC
Excavated illegally near Palermo around 1984. Sold to a collector, for $1.2m. Returned to Italy in February

 Marble sarcophagus, 2nd century BC
Seized by police last month, foiling alleged plot to smuggle it to Switzerland for $1m

 £7.5 m statue of Aphrodite
Returned by the Paul Getty Museum in California after it accepted it had been stolen

 Capitoline Triade, 2nd century BC
Marble statue stolen in 1992 and sold for £2m to a Swiss dealer who was planning to sell it for £3m to a collector when it was recovered

By some estimates it is the fourth largest criminal enterprise, after drugs, arms and money laundering. The report lambasted countries, including Britain, that refuse to sign UN and other protocols outlawing the trade. Dealers and museums mobilise lawyers and experts to maintain the flow, for they must collect to survive, but supply ultimately hinges on the graverobbers. Italy, which has one of the highest densities of historic remains in the world, calls them tombaroli . They operate mostly in Tuscany and northern Lazio, where the Etruscans reigned for nearly 1,000 years before Rome, and in Sicily, colonised by Phoenicians, Greeks and Romans. Antonio, a mint-sucking, chain-smoking, youthful 65, is the granddaddy of tomboroli in northern Lazio. He has decided to give this, his first and last, interview on the eve of his retirement, he says. A decorator by profession, he started robbing in the late 1950s, learning from books and archaeologists who were digging up some of the area's tens of thousands of tombs. "I head out at around 8.30 and work until 2am. It took a few years but now I can usually guess where a tomb is by the shape of the terrain and the colour of the grass. Winter is better because the ground is softer. "If the police are active I take someone along to act as look-out. After 2,000 years a tomb can be filled up with toxic gas, so after opening one, I light a match to test for oxygen." Etruscans liked to remind the dead of pleasures of life so they filled their resting places with figured pottery, statues, paintings, theatre masks, urns and mirrors. A single tomb can contain more than a dozen sarcophagi. Archaeologists prize such finds because in context they tell a story. Spirited away and displayed elsewhere they retain their beauty but reveal little about the past. Antonio, not his real name, spits in disgust. "I've heard that a thousand times. Italy's museums don't have the money or space to display all these things so all they do is stick them in warehouses and forget about them." Twice he was almost crushed by a collapsing tomb, he risks prison and it's backbreaking work, so it's only right he is rewarded, says Antonio. He sells his finds to a dealer in the town of Viterbo, who trucks them to another in Switzerland, who sells them on the legitimate art market to private collectors and museums. Antonio insists he is supplying demand, not creating it. Tourists looking for black market bargains have been conned by tomboroli who lead them to tombs where they placed cheap vases two months earlier. "That's just pennies. The real money we get from the dealers, the professionals." One of his friends found a drinking cup, dating from 500 BC, which ended up in America's Getty museum, according to Maria Rizzo, of the archaeological superintendency of southern Etruria. Antonio complains that surveillance is making his job impossible but the local police commander, who asked not to be named, sighed. "If only. To prosecute we need to catch them red-handed and for that we need to anticipate where they'll strike. I can't hide men behind every bush every night. "If they see us coming they drop everything and say they were out for a walk. The older ones are teaching the next generation where to look." From beneath his desk the commander took out a cardboard box with two vases and a figurine wrapped in newspapers. "We got these last week. A fluke." Lack of resources is a refrain of the culture ministry, which watches over more than 3,000 museums, 6,000 libraries, 100,000 churches, 50,000 other buildings and more than 1,000 archaeological sites. In Sicily and southern Italy the tombaroli , reinforced by the mafia, are bolder. Bulldozers have been used in daylight. In 18th century watercolours of Pompeii frescoes can be seen which have since vanished. The world's largest collection of allegedly stolen archaeological treasures was found last year in the Sicilian home of art collector Vincenzo Cammarata, who police say was the mafia's conduit to Switzerland. Mr Cammarata says the more than 30,000 artefacts, valued at £20m, were all registered. Five other Sicilians, including two professors, were charged with aiding and abetting him. Italian police have scored other successes. Last November six people were caught looting 250 relics from Hadrian's villa. In May an elaborately carved Roman sarcophagus was seized from a farmhouse near Rome. Four art dealers and a university lecturer are being investigated. Police systematically trawl the catalogue of auction houses like Sotheby's and Christie's, checking suspicious items on a database of stolen artworks. Some major pieces have been extricated from auction houses and museums. "The trade is fuelled partly by competition among museums to acquire superstars," said the American Journal Archaeology. Lord Renfrew, professor of archaeology at Cambridge, is scathing about Britain's role. "The government is in the pocket of the art market, which wants to keep the flow of antiquities. It's a scandal." He has been appointed to a committee established last month by the Department of Culture to report by the autumn on how to tackle the trade. Some archaeologists have a grudging respect for the tombaroli 's skill. Not Lord Renfrew: "Thieves, looters, that is what they are." Back in Viterbo, Antonio shakes his head. "I am not a criminal. I find history and I sell it." He prepares for another night among the tombs of his ancestors. His tools, a tube of mints and cigarettes will keep him going till 2am. "I stick to the Etruscans now, my arms aren't so strong and their tombs are shallower. The Romans I'm leaving to future tombaroli ." Returned to Italy in February  Marble sarcophagus, 2nd century BC Seized by police last month, foiling alleged plot to smuggle it to Switzerland for $1m  £7.5 m statue of Aphrodite Returned by the Paul Getty Museum in California after it accepted it had been stolen  Capitoline Triade, 2nd century BC Marble statue stolen in 1992 and sold for £2m to a Swiss dealer who was planning to sell it for £3m to a collector when it was recovered

webTitle: Rise in Chinese illegal entrants alarms officials

fields.headline: Rise in Chinese illegal entrants alarms officials
fields.standfirst:
The global racket is worth $7bn a year

Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Even before yesterday's Dover tragedy, British  immigration officials were alarmed at the rising number  of Chinese asylum seekers this year.
fields.body:
Even before yesterday's Dover tragedy, British immigration officials were alarmed at the rising number of Chinese asylum seekers this year.

The £2,000-a-head fine on lorry drivers found with illegal entrants on board did nothing to prevent the number of Chinese nationals increasing from 225 last October to 500 in March and 455 in April. Chinese are second only to Sri Lankans in the league table of nationalities now applying for asylum in Britain.

Some come to join relatives in Britain's 150,000 strong Chinese community, but the Home Office believes the recent increase has less to do with political persecution and more to do with the emergence of a new organised illegal trade with links to major crime syndicates, including possibly the Triads.

The International Organisation for Migration estimates that in 1996 global immigration racketeering was already worth as much as the drugs trade, with annual profits of $7bn a year. There is little doubt that it has grown larger since then.

The Home Office estimates that at any one time about 1m people are in the process of moving to western countries as part of organised trafficking. It is also officially recognised that its causes - economic deprivation, overpopulation and social and political instability - are unlikely to be resolved in the short term.

The criminal gangs involved in the trade use similar routes and networks as they do for drug trafficking, although rarely at the same time. The trade has only really emerged in the last five years, after governments around the world imposed fines on airlines and shipping companies that allowed passengers to travel without proper documents.

But extra vigilance by airline staff and port officials only served to drive the traffic underground. Where once illegal entrants flew British Airways economy class, they now face the dangers of a journey, often lasting days, in the back of a lorry or on a clandestine boat.

Their ordeal does not end when they emerge from the back of the lorry in the car park of some motorway services area. They are often obliged to work for those who have brought them across to pay off the cost of their journey. For some it is little better than slavery. Last month a Home Office report revealed that hundreds of trafficked women had been forced into prostitution in Britain as a result of intimidation.

Immigration intelligence estimates that there are at least 50 criminal gangs involved in smuggling people, with just four or five organised syndicates from the Indian subcontinent bringing 2,000 to 3,000 people into Britain each year. Many pay up to £18,000 for the journey and some find they are locked in safe houses in Britain until their families have paid all the money.

Apart from the £2,000 a head fine, the Home Office attempted to choke off the trade by denying access to welfare benefits to illegal entrants. The thinking was that since migrants were coming to Britain to save money while their asylum applications were processed, they would no longer have any money to send back home.

A Home Office spokesman said yesterday: "Smuggling people is a very lucrative business and the immigration service and the government has put a lot of resources into combating it. There is certainly evidence that particularly the Chinese are brought in to work in very harsh conditions to repay the money that they owe for being brought in.

"They come to work in restaurants, sweat shops, and up in the Midlands people from the Indian subcontinent are being employed on huge farms, fruit picking and vegetable picking.

"Gangs extort the money from the people who are being smuggled. They are the people that are going to be paying in the long term, whether by forced labour or from threats to their relatives in their own country."

webTitle: Compromise fails to end savings row

fields.headline: Compromise fails to end savings row
fields.trailText:
European finance ministers narrowly failed last night to
end the protracted controversy over an EU-wide
savings tax after Austria refused to follow
Luxembourg's lead and accept the
Portuguese-brokered compromise.
fields.body:
European finance ministers narrowly failed last night to end the protracted controversy over an EU-wide savings tax after Austria refused to follow Luxembourg's lead and accept the Portuguese-brokered compromise.

But Britain's long rearguard action to head off what Treasury officials called an "extremely crude" device for tackling tax evasion had already prevailed, leaving the two states in a 13-2 minority until Luxembourg buckled after last minute concessions during nearly 24 hours of talks at the EU summit. The stalled Portuguese compromise would allow states to impose a with olding tax on savings if they want to - five EU states will now do so at rates of 20-25% - leaving others to trade banking details instead.

Austria's objections were partly political, a desire not to be too helpful - by changing its constitution - when its EU partners are cold-shouldering Vienna over the Freedom party's coalition status.

The Portuguese presidency was determined to find a solution, following the row between Britain and most of her partners at the Helsinki summit in December, with Tony Blair and Gordon Brown adamant in resisting a change which would have damaged the City of London's euro bond market, in the same way that a similar tax hurt the New York money markets a generation ago.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The relentless shift of Britain's freight traffic from railway to groaning road network is investigated by Alan Whitehouse for File On 4
fields.body:
The relentless shift of Britain's freight traffic from railway to groaning road network is investigated by Alan Whitehouse for File On 4 (8.0pm, Radio 4). The simple calculation is that one train can carry as many as 50 lorries. When British Rail was privatised five years ago, we were told that by now we should have had a threefold increase in the new railway companies' freight carriage. What we have actually had is government permission for ever-larger lorries to snatch the business.

It was all so much simpler in The Summer Of 1940 (9.0pm, Radio 2) when everything was subordinated to national survival. Michael Aspel's four-part survey now looks at the seven-week Blitz on Britain's major cities, which killed thousands of non-combatants. Their stoic response should have established for all time how ineffectual aerial attacks are in breaking civilian morale. But, 50 years on, military planners still believe the tactic will work.
