fields.headline: You've got to laugh
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: Where do comedians get their material from? In the case of Eddie Izzard, one of the interviewees in Stand Up with Alan Davies, it's nature documentaries, so we must hope that he was watching The Natural World (BBC2) last night.
fields.body:
Where do comedians get their material from? In the case of Eddie Izzard, one of the interviewees in Stand Up with Alan Davies, it's nature documentaries, so we must hope that he was watching The Natural World (BBC2) last night. The subject of salmon may not seem very promising, but as we followed these foolhardy fish from a languid life in the Pacific to an exhausted death at their inland breeding grounds, there was humour aplenty. The sight of salmon leaping up waterfalls is one of the great commonplaces of natural history TV, but never has it been quite so well photographed as this. The fish - still fat and glossy from years of cruising around the ocean - braced themselves for flight, then shot out of the water as if thrown. Their optimism alone was entertainment enough.

But there was more. Along the way, the salmon risked fleets of trawlers, hungry killer whales, grizzly bears and any other opportunistic carnivore that could be bothered to lumber down to the river. The sudden move from saltwater to fresh rotted their skin and broke down their muscles, but still they came, propelled by the irresistible desire to mate. Finally, as they neared their home gravel, the salmon underwent a nightmarish transformation from the sleek, fat fish of the cold buffet to weird, gaudily-dyed monsters, decked out in breeding colours of red and green. The males developed hooked jaws and huge humps, while all and sundry fell prey to fungal infections and general fin rot. Revolting as it looked to us, it was sexy to the salmon, who consummated their life's mission with a few seconds of frenetic coupling in the shallows. Fish are not known as particularly expressive creatures, and yet the look on their faces - mouths agape, eyes goggling - spoke volumes about our shared slavery to hormones. You and me baby ain't nothing but salmon, you might say.

There were generous minutes of calming footage featuring the woods and waters of Washington and Alaska, an eco-system that, we learned, is almost entirely dependent on the annual influx of salmon. All passion spent, the fish die, their corpses pile up and rot, leaching vital nutrients back into the water and, through maggots and scavengers, onto the land. Hence the gorgeousness of the flora and fauna: "The river's beauty," said the voice-over, "is based on rotting fish."

And it's this kind of observation that clearly inspires the likes of Eddie Izzard, much the funniest of the fellow comedians in Alan Davies's new three-part series. Stand Up With Alan Davies (BBC1) followed the self-styled "curly fucker" on tour round the UK, and attempted a little analysis of what prompts young men to pursue a career in comedy. Jasper Carrott admitted that money was the main draw, while Izzard, ever the artist, regarded suicide as the only alternative to performing. Davies himself was sweet and blokeish, "the perfect version of the modern man", according to one of his legion of female fans. Self-effacement was the name of the game as Davies admitted to trotting out routines he was doing back in 1992. His partner Catherine Porter assured us that he's not funny at home, and indeed he wasn't very funny off stage either. Nervous before a show, or exhausted and hungry afterwards, he was never likely to shine. He engaged in a bit of on-the-road banter with support act Ian Stone in the back of the tour van, but Spinal Tap it wasn't. Comedy, unlike rock'n'roll, isn't a particularly funny subject, except when it goes wrong.

There was some tentative theorising about the roots of comedy as Davies discovered that Izzard, like him, lost his mother when he was six years old, and that Dave Allen's father had died when the budding comedian was 12. Did a craving for unqualified love propel these young men to the stage? Davies appeared embarrassed by the seriousness of the question he had raised - to which, after all, there can never be an answer.

Ardal O'Hanlon announced that the only taboo area in his work was jokes about eating kebabs on the way back from the pub - mere moments after we'd watched Davies's spin on that very topic. Back in north London, Davies attended a cabaret workshop where a man did a mime of a fish out of water; it wasn't funny. If only he'd watched The Natural World, he might have made something out of that.

webTitle: Rebels elude Russians in the foothills

fields.headline: Rebels elude Russians in the foothills
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: The Russian army base of Khatuni, the frontline posting on the edge of Chechnya's still unconquered mountainous territory, has become one of the most perilous places in the war-torn region for the troops who serve there.
fields.byline: Amelia Gentleman in Khatuni, in the Chechen mountains
fields.body:
The Russian army base of Khatuni, the frontline posting on the edge of Chechnya's still unconquered mountainous territory, has become one of the most perilous places in the war-torn region for the troops who serve there.

Situated in the foothills of the dramatic mountain range dividing the separatist region from Dagestan to the east and Georgia to the south, the camp is highly vulnerable to nightly attacks from rebels living in the forests which surround it.

Somewhere in these densely wooded mountains, the most powerful Chechen rebel leaders, Shamil Basayev and Khattab, are thought to be hiding alongside the Chechen president, Aslan Maskhadov.

Russian generals estimate that around 3,000 guerrillas survived the eight-month onslaught on the region, and they believe most of them are roaming the hills in small bands, living in mountain camps.

Now that the Russians' sweeping bombing campaign of the region has calmed, the army has adopted a new tactic for the remaining Chechen fighters: groups of soldiers are sent to hunt down the rebels in the woods and gorges.

So far this approach has had limited success. Last week soldiers discovered a rebel camp, but it had been abandoned days earlier. After months of searching, the main guerrilla leaders remain at liberty.

During the conflict, a few journalists have tracked down the warlords in their bases in the hills - but the army has been unable to catch them.

The Russian soldiers' task has become much more difficult with the arrival of summer. The expanse they have to search is huge - mile upon mile of dense forest, ideal terrain for guerrilla warfare. With the trees in full leaf, the rebels wearing camouflage gear are invisible to the helicopters circling above.

Recently, Chechen fighters have started targeting the enemy, setting traps, attacking lone vehicles and laying landmines along the paths.

The deputy commander of the eastern division, Colonel Karol Yeritsyn, said: "It's a very tough assignment. The rebels move around in groups of no more than about a dozen men, they are living in hiding places which they have been preparing for the last 10 years and they know the terrain far better than we do."

For most of the day, troops from the elite 51st paratrooper division who are based in Khatuni battle against the boredom of inactivity. The relentless throb of pop music blasts through the hills from speakers wired up to one of the stationary tanks at the base.

From time to time the music is obliterated by the roar of rockets being launched from heavy artillery trucks pointing into the hills. The attack lasts a few seconds, then the music is audible again.

The real work begins at dusk, when most of the search operations are launched. Groups of about 40 men are dispatched into the hills, acting on reconnaissance missions by helicopters.

"It feels like a dangerous task, especially recently. The rebels shoot at us as we walk through the forests, and usually we can't see them," said Major Sergei Vershinin. "But the local people are more ready to help us now. They have also been shot at by the rebels in the hills and most are quite happy to give us information about where we can find the rebel bases"

The head of the village adminstration, Imam Masayev, agreed that the locals felt alienated from the rebel leadership whom they held responsible for the chaos of the war, but he added that there was growing weariness with the Russian troops.

The main problem was the landmines laid by the army around the base. Every day villagers' cows wandered into the minefield and were blown up.

But the problems went further, he added. "About 25% of our village was completely destroyed in the bombing at the beginning of the year and more than 30 villagers died.

"The local economy has been devastated - we used to have juice and jam making factories but they were bombed out - there is no work for the local people and despite all the promises, the Russians are still not paying any pensions.

"Our children still find it difficult to sleep at night because of the shooting."

The real work begins at dusk, when most of the search operations are launched. Groups of about 40 men are dispatched into the hills, acting on reconnaissance missions by helicopters. "It feels like a dangerous task, especially recently. The rebels shoot at us as we walk through the forests, and usually we can't see them," said Major Sergei Vershinin. "But the local people are more ready to help us now. They have also been shot at by the rebels in the hills and most are quite happy to give us information about where we can find the rebel bases" The head of the village adminstration, Imam Masayev, agreed that the locals felt alienated from the rebel leadership whom they held responsible for the chaos of the war, but he added that there was growing weariness with the Russian troops. The main problem was the landmines laid by the army around the base. Every day villagers' cows wandered into the minefield and were blown up. But the problems went further, he added. "About 25% of our village was completely destroyed in the bombing at the beginning of the year and more than 30 villagers died. "The local economy has been devastated - we used to have juice and jam making factories but they were bombed out - there is no work for the local people and despite all the promises, the Russians are still not paying any pensions. "Our children still find it difficult to sleep at night because of the shooting."

webTitle: Blair leads the fight to scale down charter

fields.headline: Blair leads the fight to scale down charter
fields.standfirst: UK opposition to 'new costs on business' wins backing
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday expressed strong opposition to  plans for a legally enforceable European charter of  fundamental rights - and won wide support from other  governments.
fields.byline: Ian Black in Santa Maria da Feira
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday expressed strong opposition to plans for a legally enforceable European charter of fundamental rights - and won wide support from other governments.

Reviewing progress at their Portuguese summit, EU leaders heard a report from the convention drafting the controverial document, but they did not resolve differences over the final outcome. With France calling for economic and social rights to be included in the text when it takes over the EU presidency next month, the long-running row is far from over.

French president Jacques Chirac said a charter of rights was needed to "increase popular understanding" of the EU, though it did not have to be part of a new treaty. Germany and Italy have been pushing hard for a binding text. But the discussion showed Mr Blair's line was firmly backed by Spain, Ireland, Finland, Sweden and Denmark.

Under the maximalist version of the charter, the brainchild of federalist minded Euro MPs, 50 basic rights enjoyed by the EU's 370m citizens would be codified and written into the Treaty of Nice in December. At its core will be the existing European Convention on Human Rights, drawn up in 1950 and shortly to come into force in Britain. But the charter will update the ECHR by also looking at bioethical, environmental, data protection and gender issues which cannot be resolved at the national level.

The current draft, littered with 1,000 proposed amendments, promises rights relating to employment, family life, discrimination, liberty and medical advances. These include an employee's right to join a union, to strike and to be protected against "unjustified" dismissal; a ban on cloning human beings; the outlawing of capital punishment; and a ban on extradition of criminals to countries - including the US - where they might be executed. Children would be treated as equals and consulted on matters affecting them.

Mr Blair told fellow leaders he would oppose the creation of new rights, anything that would impose new costs on business or create precedents that could bring new cases to the European Court of Justice.

Highly sensitive to Tory attacks over his EU policy - reinforced by the Euro-sceptic media - the prime minister has been arguing that the document should be only a "showcase" for existing rights, not a "launching pad" for new ones.

Launched by Germany at the Cologne summit last summer, the charter was intended to "consolidate" rights already applicable at EU level "in order to make their overriding importance and relevance more visible to the union's citizens". Lurking in the background were fears of the dilution of core values when the EU expands to include the former communist states of eastern and central Europe, where the memory of liberal democracy is dim or non-existent.

The drafting convention is composed, with a rare degree of legitimacy, of 62 representatives of the European Parliament, the commission, national governments and parliaments. Cologne did not agree on whether the charter should be a simple proclamation, a fine set of words with no legal clout, or a legally binding set of rights, enshrined in the treaties and justiciable in the European Court of Justice - as the European Parliament is demanding.

This is an area where the parliament really counts, since it has a veto on the final version of the charter, which it does not, by contrast, in the inter-governmental conference working in parallel to reform EU institutions and decision- making machinery to prepare for enlargement to the East.

Nicole Fontaine, president of the parliament, said Mr Blair had "underlined" British objections.

Keith Vaz, the foreign office minister for Europe, insisted that governments, not the convention, would have the final word on the subject. "This is going to be agreed by member states," he said.

But he came under attack by Timothy Kirkhope MEP, chief whip for the Conservatives in the European parliament. "Mr Vaz and his Labour counterparts are rapidly losing their grip on reality," he said. "The Charter of Fundamental Rights, in its present form, is a chaotic pick and mix, posing as new human rights, with conflicting means of redress through both the European Court of Human rights and the European Courts of Justice." Most of the charter is based on existing entitlements, with the articles dealing with economic and social rights the most contentious. Besides having the right to join unions and strike, workers would be able to demand a limit on their working hours, and enjoy "the right to reconcile their family and professional lives".

The draft also says member states must provide social assistance to guarantee their citizens a "decent existence". Elsewhere, the draft proposes bans on the cloning of human beings, genetic engineering involving humans, and the sale of human body parts.

webTitle: Straw in talks with ferry chief on port security

fields.headline: Straw in talks with ferry chief on port security
fields.standfirst:
Calls for stiffer fines and stricter checks

Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, held emergency  talks yesterday with Lord Sterling, the chairman of  P&O ferries, to improve security at Dover port as  politicians of all parties agreed on the need to increase  the priority given to tackling the "evil trade" of people  trafficking.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, held emergency talks yesterday with Lord Sterling, the chairman of P&O ferries, to improve security at Dover port as politicians of all parties agreed on the need to increase the priority given to tackling the "evil trade" of people trafficking.

Mr Straw told MPs that those who had died in the hermetically sealed refrigerated lorry "must have died a most terrible death". The government, he said, had long been concerned about the involvement of organised criminals who made huge profits out of smuggling illegal migrants into Britain.

"Let no-one be in any doubt that this is a profoundly evil trade whose perpetrators have no regard for human life. We have been determined to crack down on this trade," said Mr Straw. "I am afraid this terrible tragedy must serve as a stark warning to others who might be tempted to place their fate in the hands of organised traffickers. Those who died last night are the victims of those traffickers."

Increased pan-European co-operation in increasing checks on lorries and trains had already produced dividends, with an operation at the freight yards in Milan proving particularly effective in curbing the flow of eastern European migrants, said Mr Straw. He added that Tony Blair had raised the question of further measures at the European union council meeting in Portugal yesterday.

The home secretary acknowledged that one of the further tragic elements in this human trade was that those who were caught up in it were made all kinds of promises about the kind of life they would find when they got to Britain and "even if they do get through alive they are often sorely disappointed when they arrive here."

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, said she recognised that many people would regard the deaths as "tragedy waiting to happen" and suggested that the rigour of checking vehicles outside Britain was not what it might be. She particularly wanted to see immigration officials travelling on ferries which did not allow drivers to stay with their lorries for health and safety reasons. She also argued for "secure and well-lit areas" in ports so lorry drivers could check their loads.

The Liberal Democrats' Simon Hughes shared Mr Straw's determination to ensure the international police system tracked down the human traffickers "unto the ends of the earth" but said he was unhappy there was still no legal way for genuine refugees to apply for asylum in western Europe.

"Unless there is a lawful way of making an application and coming to a country that might accept you, by definition you are going to have to use illegal ways and you are likely to put yourself in the hands of those who will exploit you as we have seen yesterday."

MPs from all parties questioned whether the £2,000 per head fine for each illegal entrant discovered was a sufficient penalty in view of the profits that were to be made from such a lucrative trade. Mr Straw indicated he was "always open to review these fines".

The home secretary also agreed with David Winnick, the Labour MP for Walsall North, who declared: "While we recognise that immigration control is absolutely necessary, we shouldn't forget for one moment that these people wanted a better life and for that reason they died."

fields.headline: Prince Ernst August
fields.body:
Age: 45.

Pedigree: A direct descendant of George III; great-grandson of Germany's last Kaiser; third husband of Princess Caroline of Monaco; member of the British and German royal families (and probably a few more besides).

Appearance: A glamorously dishevelled cross between Roger Scruton and Jerry Springer, though more publicity-shy than either.

But his wife keeps the staff of Hello! in champagne and telephoto lenses, surely? The litigious prince prefers to sue glossy celebrity mags rather than invite them into his home(s). And then there's the small matter of the cameraman whose nose he broke with an umbrella in 1998, occasioning a bank-breaking fine of, erm, £6,000.

Doesn't go in for public exposure, then. So everyone thought until last week, when the scion of German royalty took a stroll around Expo 2000, the world fair, in his home town of Hanover. Caught short, the prince is reported to have relieved himself against the Turkish pavilion.

Not the kind of cultural exchange the Expo people had in mind. Indeed. A diplomatic incident has ensued: German newspaper Welt am Sonntag claims to have photographic evidence, and the Turks are demanding an apology.

They're pissed off about being pissed on? If you want to put it crudely. "The Turkish public is shocked," said Zeynel Yesilay, private secretary to prime minister Bulent Ecevit. "What an affront."

Presumably Princess Caroline is keeping well clear of this whole episode. Indeed - not that she had much choice. Rumour has it there was a 40-strong queue round the ladies' side of the pavilion.

It's not the only stain on the prince's character either, is it? You'll be referring to the accusations that his grandfather made a fortune by taking over Jewish companies confiscated by Hitler. Ernst denies every word of this, and he's got the expensive lawyers - sorry, hard evidence - to prove it.

Don't say: "I presume he used the royal wee?"

fields.headline: Going, going, gone
fields.standfirst: Damien Hirst's famous shark has been rejected by the  Louvre because it is decaying. So is it still the same  work Charles Saatchi bought in 1991? Jonathan  Jones reports on the perils of collecting perishable art
fields.trailText: Damien Hirst's famous shark has been rejected by the  Louvre because it is decaying. So is it still the same  work Charles Saatchi bought in 1991? Jonathan  Jones reports on the perils of collecting perishable art
fields.body:
Poor shark. What a shrivelled and, according to some accounts, stinking shell of its former terrifying self. The organisers of an exhibition at the Museum of Decorative Arts in Paris, in which Damien Hirst's 1991 sculpture was supposed to appear, claim the famous shark is now just too rotten to go on show. It smells, it's green and a fin has fallen off. The shark's owner, Charles Saatchi, says, on the contrary, it's in "fantastic condition".

Whatever the exact current state of the shark, there's no doubt that it has deteriorated. The wrinkly, leathery, dried-out remnant of a beast that appeared in Sensation at the Royal Academy in 1997 has little of the original terrifying appearance of Hirst's tiger shark. It has aged. Hirst called the work The Physical Impossibility of Death in The Mind of Someone Living. As the title implies, Hirst's artwork - which he made by commissioning an Australian shark-hunter to catch a full-grown shark - deceived the eye as to whether it was dead or not. When you stood in front of the tank of green liquid, and looked in the shark's grinning mouth, you could savour the illusion that a tiger shark was swimming towards you through the white space of the Saatchi Gallery. You were dinner.

Seeing the shark now is more like creeping down into the Bates fruit cellar and finding mother embalmed in her chair. It's shocking, but in a Grand Guignol way. No one is going to confuse this dessicated relic with a living beast. Oliver Crinnen, curator of fish at the Natural History Museum, says it was not preserved properly back in 1991. Hirst and his team failed to inject formaldehyde fixing agent into its internal organs and it has rotted from the inside out.

But if the shark is doomed, so are are many other contemporary artworks that are designed to collapse, fade and decay into the earth. Owning these artworks, whether you are Charles Saatchi or a museum, is a peculiar responsibility. You have to love them, nurture them, and yet accept that however much you spend on hi-tech storage your prized possession is, in the long run, doomed. Spare a thought for New York's Dia Foundation, which last year acquired Robert Smithson's 1970 artwork Spiral Jetty, a 1500ft earthwork in Salt Lake, Utah, that Smithson built without realising the lake was unusually low that year; because of his miscalculation, the Spiral Jetty has been submerged almost throughout its existence. People go on pilgrimages and come back saying they think they saw it.

But this was more than a mistake. Smithson believed modern culture is psychotically unable to accept the existence of mortality. Conceptual art - of which Smithson was a key theorist - can be understood as a systematic attack on this culture of immortality, aka capitalism, with its need to believe that commodities are infinitely renewable and markets go on forever. "Many would like to forget time altogether," wrote Smithson, "because it contains the 'death principle'." Conceptual art takes the odd forms it does - rotting sharks, lumps of fat, vanishing earthworks - as an attack on this illusion. When you buy such a work of art, it doesn't matter if you are as rich as Saatchi because what you are buying is an emblem of your own mortality.

This radical perishability has been relished by conceptual artists ever since Marcel Duchamp exhibited a urinal at a New York art exhibition in 1917. Duchamp made no attempt to preserve his urinal or any of the other "readymades" he exhibited around the time of the first world war, from a shovel to a bicycle wheel on a stool. When he became revered in the 60s, all his famous, iconic works had to be reconstructed because they had long since been thrown in the bin. Duchamp's masterpiece, The Bride Stripped Bare By Her Bachelors, Even, is a monument to time and fragility; when this large decorated glass panel was being transported from an exhibition in 1927, it was accidentally smashed to pieces. Duchamp hailed the breakage as a "chance completion" and although he meticulously reconstructed it, he did not attempt to hide the cracks and splinters, which are now part of its meaning (and what stops the Tate's replica being the original).

Some conceptual artworks are easier to own than others. Turner Prize nominee Tomoko Takahashi's installations of broken clocks, disgorged electronic circuits and loose wiring may look unwieldy, but for selling purposes they can be divided up into small, convenient chunks. If you want to own a work by leading artist Martin Creed all you have to buy is the text that describes it and that is, technically, the work. But what do you do once you buy Creed's most famous work of art to date, Work 201, Half the Air in a Given Space?

The lucky owner of this work gets the text, and the right to have the work installed. To install Work 201 you measure the air in a room, inflate large coloured balloons to consume exactly half that air, and that's your artwork. Obviously, it decays even more quickly than an improperly preserved shark. The more people enjoy the balloons, the quicker it all goes pop. Pop, pop, pop. That's the sound of time passing. In the end there's nothing but bits of torn rubber.

Creed's balloon installation is an emblem of mortality in the same way as a firework display or the aftermath of a party. Unlike Saatchi's shark, however, this art is easy to renew. You just inflate more balloons. The work can be owned forever - what you buy is an idea.

The Catholic church might wish Leonardo da Vinci had just issued them with a text describing the Last Supper, instead of painting it in unstable oil paints. Leonardo's wall painting in the refectory of the church of Santa Marie delle Grazie in Milan only exists today as a trace, a ghost of a painting; he used his own experimental methods instead of proper fresco techniques and so his painting is woefully mortal.

Art has always been perishable. Paintings disintegrate, colours fade - as the regular rows over whether paintings are saved or ruined by restorers show, we do not really know what any of the great European paintings looked like when they were first shown, not even the ones that survive, because colours fade over time.

The most revered artist in the Renaissance was Apelles, an ancient Greek painter none of whose works survived much beyond his own lifetime, and artists down the centuries have tried to recreate his works entirely from textual accounts. This is the supreme instance of the mortality of art, proof that the only perfect and timeless work of art is the one that has already disappeared forever.

fields.headline: My hero!
fields.standfirst: Guy Ritchie's one. So's David Beckham. Gallant men defending the little lady.  Polly Vernon asks what it's all about
fields.trailText: Guy Ritchie's one. So's David Beckham. Gallant men defending the little lady.  Polly Vernon asks what it's all about
fields.body:
There's something in the air. Something pungent, acrid and more than a little overwhelming. Something so heady, you half expect to see small dogs raise their hackles in response and old ladies faint full away in the street. It is - in case you were wondering - raw testosterone. Untempered, undiluted and, lately, so omnipresent and smog-like, you can taste it.

Consider the evidence. David Beckham, bare-chested and glistening in the half light of the stadium (I forget the precise location and I refuse to try to find out), offering a vicious finger to the crowd because they had cussed his wife . The press, generally so eager to vilify sweet Becks, found it in themselves to champion his cause because, after all, the England fans had said some truly mean things.

Next we have Guy Ritchie, up on an assault charge following an unseemly tussle with a fan on Madonna's doorstep. Your hasty conclusion that the individual in question's fanaticism was directed at Guy rather than Madonna is utterly founded. Guy, like Becks, was intervening on behalf of his lady.

Was I the only one to sense a whiff of disappointment hanging round Guy when the charge was dropped, a hint, in the droop of his shoulders, of a man deprived of an opportunity to parade the extent of his love for his woman? Oh, if only it had gone to court! He'd have been like a 21st-century knight, a prisoner of honour, a victim of his passion for his true love!

Maybe it's the football. Maybe it's the grinding, uninspired resurgence of Lock, Stock The TV Series-style machismo. Maybe it's the seed of gladiatorial aspirations that Russell Crowe planted in the souls of a million Odeon multiplex-bound men. Or maybe it's a backlash against Just Gay Enough, the very newest, most fashionable prototype for the ultimately desirable man, designed by women and currently bandied about in everything from Tina Brown's Talk magazine to Harper's Bazaar. (He is, for the record, the culturally homosexual, genetically straight love child of Jude Law and Jamie Oliver.) Whatever. One thing is evident: Britain is awash with a flood of ill-judged gallantry.

Does any woman ever want a man to hit someone else on her behalf? It's an immensely proprietorial gesture, an expression of ownership, thinly veiled as an uncontained explosion of caring. Offend my lady, offend me. She is, after all, an extension of me. Bruise her, upset her, mark her, and you spoil her for me. And, more darkly: she's mine to hurt, not yours.

I would hope that women don't want men to protect them so crassly, yet it's my experience that some of us, sometimes, are rather thrilled by the experience. I can't speak from personal experience, because I have yet to spark that kind of frenzy in a partner. I can only guess. Does it make you feel cosseted, prettily fragile and vulnerable, in need of protection and capable of inspiring violence? Or is it even more basic than that? A colleague, for example, once told me that she wished her boyfriend would grow his hair a little longer because she used to love the way it swung when he delivered a right hook on her behalf.

The greater problem of gallantry is that, like the tiresome expression "political correctness gone mad", it has become a stick with which feminists may be liberally battered. Do men stand up on buses to let women sit down or not? Oh, it's so confusing, let's forget it all, pretend all double X chromosome life forms are tiresome, contradictory muddles and go back to thinking about Kylie's tennis-skirted bottom.

As long as gallantry blots the copybook of contemporary gender etiquette with its foppish foolishness and its hardline views on what women need and, by extension, what women should be, those of us who stand up for ourselves will be perceived as troublesome. Take Belinda Sinclair, one-time training officer in the Met, who won £500,000 compensation in a sex discrimination case that hinged on her "confident and dominant" demeanour. It paid for her in the end, but we all know that society likes defenceless women better.

As for Guy Ritchie, I will choke back the suspicion that, if he'd been really honest, he might have aimed that punch more squarely at Madonna's vastly superior fame, at her iconic status, at her riches. So I'm not even contemplating the possibility that he was trying to redress the balance a little, offering up some brute force as a way of justifying his place in her life. Because that would be very cynical.

fields.headline: What price 25 years?
fields.standfirst: At 17, he was jailed for murder.  He spent a quarter of a century inside before  being acquitted - a record miscarriage of  justice. Now he's been paid a record £1m  compensation. Patrick Weir meets Andy  Evans
fields.trailText: At 17, he was jailed for murder.  He spent a quarter of a century inside before  being acquitted - a record miscarriage of  justice. Now he's been paid a record £1m  compensation. Patrick Weir meets Andy  Evans
fields.body:
Andy Evans was given £100,000 as an interim compensation payment when he was first released from prison. After 25 years inside, it was an unimaginable sum. "I started spending money like mad," he says. "I would give cab drivers £200 tips. I bought five computers - when one went wrong, I'd give it away and buy another. And my kitchen was full of God knows how many food blenders. If I couldn't be bothered to clean one or thought it was too loud, I'd get a replacement." He even bought himself 12 staple guns. "They were a status symbol inside - and hard to get hold of."

Today, two and a half years since walking free from Winson Green jail in Birmingham, Evans has "just the one" staple gun. He may have frittered away that early payout, but his money worries are probably behind him: 12 days ago he was awarded an extra £750,000 by the Home Office. He's now received around £1m, believed to be a record payment, but then Evans, now 45, served a record sentence: 25 years for a murder he did not commit, the longest anyone in this country has been imprisoned before being freed on appeal.

Evans' nightmare began one October morning in 1972 when - as "a crazy, mixed-up 17-year-old" - he walked into a Stoke-on-Trent police station and confessed to the murder of 14-year-old Judith Roberts.

"I didn't have any real friends and was a bit of a loner," he says. "I couldn't read or write properly, was taking valium for depression and waiting for a medical discharge from the army. I was also eaten up with guilt. Perfectly normal feelings towards the opposite sex played on my conscience. I was a mess." He says that a dream in which he saw "a hazy combination of images of women's faces" convinced him that he was responsible for the death of the local schoolgirl. "By confessing, I thought I'd be able to rid myself of all the crap going on in my head."

Judith's body had been found in a field only eight miles away from Whittington barracks, near Lichfield, where Evans was stationed. "When I woke up I decided to see the police and sort it out," he says. "I was living with my gran. When I told her what I planned to do, she told me not to be so bloody daft. When she fell asleep before lunch, I left the house." Evans was questioned for four days by the West Midlands serious crime squad, which has since been disbanded, without a solicitor or GP present. When he asked to see a photograph of Judith, he was told it would not help matters.

Then, due to a wretchedly improbable coincidence, he succeeded in providing details of the murder which detectives assumed could only be known to the killer. Six years before, Evans had been playing fireman's lift with a friend; the friend fell and suffered concussion. Evans still felt immense guilt about this and, in his confused state, told detectives Judith had sustained head injuries but had not been sexually assaulted, which the post mortem confirmed. The police thought they had their killer.

As his trial at Birmingham Crown Court approached, Evans "began to unravel everything in my head until I realised I hadn't done it. My confession, which the police helped me write, was a means of running away from myself. I retracted it."

At the time of the murder, Evans had been watching TV in barracks with another soldier, who had since been transferred to Germany. By chance, this soldier had the same name as a fellow soldier who had not seen Evans on the day of the murder - another fateful coincidence. Evans' solicitor interviewed the wrong soldier, leaving his alibi in ruins. With no eyewitnesses or medical evidence to link him directly to the murder, Evans was then given the now discredited "truth drug" brietal: "That really messed up me up and I thought I was on another planet."

Evans was sentenced to life. As a timid teenager labelled a child-killer, he found prison terrifying. "In the early days I was petrified," he says. "I tried to keep my head down, but it wasn't easy. When my conviction was reported on the news, I would be beaten up by other inmates. In fact, when any murder of a kid was on the television, I feared for my life. Staying alive was my only priority, as everyone inside thinks you're as guilty as sin."

At this point, Evans breaks down. "You learn to face facts, that this is it," he says. "You see the light die in people's eyes. You can spot the ones who will end up slitting their wrists, being raped or turning vicious." He takes a minute to compose himself. "You want to reach out, to help those who have spiritually died, but you can't. You can't appear weak."

He survived with the help of another inmate, also serving life for murder. "I nearly cracked up. I'd lost all hope. Some inmates would spit on my food and I'd still eat it. I didn't wash for weeks. Then this guy comes up to me and reminds me I'm human. He says he hates what I'm in there for and, whether I did it or not, it's my business. But of all the people inside, I'm the only one he'd like to meet outside. It might not sound impressive, but thanks to him I kept my sanity."

Many more years were to pass ("time doesn't crawl slowly, it grinds to a halt") before Evans gave any thought to appealing. But a chance meeting in 1993 with Steve Elsworth, a former Greenpeace member who was giving a lecture to inmates, was a turning point. "I happened to be chatting to him about my case," says Evans. "He told me he had friends in Amnesty International and promised to mention me. Over the next four years, the campaign for my release snowballed."

Kate Akester, of the human rights group Justice, took up Evans' case, as did the eminent Norwegian psychologist, Gisli Gudjonnson, whose research into false confession syndrome and interviews with Evans were to prove crucial. So he emerged from prison, in December 1997, a shattered man. He was completely out of step socially, the art of everyday chat beyond him. The bitterness in his voice is suddenly striking. "What had I to show for the last 25 years? Nothing. What had I done? Listened to too much screaming, that's what."

There are still bad days, and he receives trauma counselling. "The nightmares haven't stopped. I curl up into a ball and physically ache." But, slowly, he's made a life for himself. He met Sue, his "lovely wife", when she replied to an advertisement he placed at his newsagent for a cleaner. She seemed to vaguely recognise him, and he decided to show her the newspaper cuttings about his case. It was an oddly moving moment for both, one which created an immediate bond between two strangers. The two were married last month and are now looking forward to a honeymoon in the Caribbean, buying a house in Nottingham, and "having some fun".

webTitle: Answer me: getting personal with Ralf Little

fields.headline: Answer me: getting personal with Ralf Little
fields.trailText: Full Name: Ralf Alastair John Little
fields.body:
Full Name: Ralf Alastair John Little

Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why? No, because I couldn't think of anything which was weirder than Ralf Little.

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why? Yes, all the time. From when I was 15 to when I was 18 it was to get into pubs and clubs, and now I still have to lie if I want to go to an over-21 venue.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad? Talented, beautiful, intelligent, magnificent and modest.

What was the last illegal thing you did? Speeding.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did? I don't know. Isn't that bad? I'm sure I've done something but I can't remember.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with? I can't answer that. I'll never work again. No matter who I pick it's bound to annoy someone else.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with? GH.

Has a critic ever made you cry? No.

What would you advertise without a fee? Any charity or cause I thought was worthy.

What would you never advertise? Nothing. Everything has a price and I have no integrity.

What wakes you up screaming at four in the morning? Nothing short of a nuclear explosion could wake me up at four in the morning.

What takes you to a "happy place"? A car. Or a train. Sometimes a plane.It depends where I'm going.

Ralf Little stars in The Royle Family (Thursday, 9. 30pm, BBC 1)

fields.headline: Glass war
fields.standfirst: It's a woman's worst nightmare and a rapist's ultimate fantasy - and all it takes is one spiked drink.  Sally Weale reports on the results of the first detailed inquiry into drug-assisted sexual assault
fields.trailText: It's a woman's worst nightmare and a rapist's ultimate fantasy - and all it takes is one spiked drink.  Sally Weale reports on the results of the first detailed inquiry into drug-assisted sexual assault
fields.body:
In the bars and clubs of Merseyside, women are giving up drinking out of glasses. They're buying bottles - it's safer that way. Between each sip, they keep a finger over the neck of the bottle. That way they can be sure no one is slipping anything into their drink.

It's not just Merseyside, of course. Our fear of drug-assisted rape, it seems, has taken on epidemic proportions. But has the crime itself?

If the amount of media coverage it gets is any measure of its prevalence, there is justification for the alarm many young women feel. Drug rape is one of those subjects of which newspapers and documentaries cannot get enough: there's something vilely irresistible about the idea of a single act being both a woman's worst nightmare and a rapist's ultimate fantasy.

Earlier this month, writer and campaigner Andrea Dworkin wrote of her own experience of being drugged and raped in a European hotel. "Rape with amnesiac drugs is new," she wrote. "This is foolproof rape. The gang that couldn't shoot straight can do this kind of rape. You can do this hundreds of times with virtually no chance of getting caught."

Last month, there was the case of Kevin Cobb, a nurse who raped women after drugging them with a powerful sedative used in minor surgery. Before that there was DJ Richard Baker who was given four life sentences for a string of sex attacks - the pockets of his jacket were stuffed with pictures of unconscious naked women and packets of Rohypnol, the pills often associated with drug-assisted rape. In Merseyside there was a spate of attacks on women out for a drink who found themselves coming round, unable to remember events but with a used condom nearby. In one incident, a woman could not recall leaving the pub, but awoke in a field as she was being assaulted.

Tomorrow, the fear that already stalks Britain's pubs, clubs and bars will be stoked up again with the publication of the Sturman report into drug-assisted sexual assault - the long-awaited report on the first detailed inquiry into drug rape. The Home Office-funded research will conclude that drug-assisted rape is definitely on the increase but is not an epidemic. It will call for tighter controls on some of the drugs known to be used in rape cases and will make a series of recommendations designed to promote greater cooperation among the agencies involved in handling cases of drug-assisted rapes and to improve criminal investigations to ensure successful convictions. For while the government has admitted that drug-assisted rape is the fastest growing recorded crime against women, as yet there have been only a handful of convictions here compared with 1,000 in the US.

One helpline says it received 757 calls last year from people claiming they had been drugged and raped - a sharp increase from 507 in 1998. But according to women's rights campaigners, drug rape is nothing new. "Men have always drugged and raped women," says Julie Bindel of Justice for Women. "It's nothing new. These drugs just make it a little bit easier for them."

Peter Sturman, the Metropolitan police officer who led the research, spent more than a year travelling all over the UK, interviewing 123 victims of drug-assisted rape, as well as visiting America and Australia. He has since set up, with his wife, a charity called the Drug Rape Trust and has been rewarded for his efforts with a promotion to the rank of detective chief inspector. What he wants to see now, he says, is a more "victim-driven" approach.

Sue Lees, professor of women's studies and rape trial expert, recently interviewed a victim of a suspected drug-assisted attack who had passed out after a couple of drinks and came round while she was being assaulted. It took three or four months to get the forensic results back - after which it emerged that she had been raped by three different men. No evidence of drugs has yet been established. According to Lees, the forensic services are hopelessly underfunded and ill-equipped to cope with what appears to be a growing crime.

There is powerful evidence, she says, particularly in the US where the problem is more widespread, of organised drug-assisted rape. "Watching your drink is something you have to do nowadays. There's a lot on the net about drug-assisted rape in the States and there are some sophisticated serial rapists around."

But it's not fair and not enough always to put on women the burden of responsibility for protecting themselves. According to Lees, what is needed is a specialist police unit that can handle the forensic analysis involved in investigating drug-assisted rape and can deal sympathetically and skilfully with the women who come forward with complaints.

Betsy Stanko, professor of criminology, first gave lectures to police at Hendon training college 20 years ago. "There's been a fairly substantial turnaround in the Metropolitan police about how important it is to take sexual violence seriously," she says. "But the way they've dealt with that is to issue warnings - if there's a rape by a minicab driver, they say don't go in minicabs until we catch him. We end up never discussing what should be discussed: why men want to rape women. We are accepting a natural predatory state of maleness and letting men off the hook again."

Stanko is not exercised by the rise in drug-assisted rape. "I know there's been a lot of discussion about it, particularly in the US. Much of it focuses on the evilness of the drug, rather than the man using it," she points out, "which is very strange because it's not the drug that's evil. It's another variation, a new technology that assists men to commit sexual violence. There will always be new technologies that will do that."

Research by Zero Tolerance, the Edinburgh-based group that campaigns against domestic and sexual violence, suggests that one in two young men thinks raping a woman is acceptable in certain circumstances. "So some of them carry pills," Stanko says. "But quite frankly, drugs are not doing the raping. They may be doing some form of disarmament, but not the raping. The boys are doing that."

Whether the Sturman report will make any real difference when a woman comes to report a suspected drug rape remains to be seen. At a time when conviction rates for reported rapes are at an all-time low of 6%, it's certainly a tall order. Getting a conviction for a rape that does not involve drugs is hard enough; if the woman has little or no memory because she was drugged, it must be nigh-on impossible.

Who was it that said a life lived in fear is a life wasted? If we go on a night out, we can appoint someone to guard our drinks; we can clutch our beer bottles to us and never accept a drink from a stranger. The Sturman report has to be welcomed, but what will really make a difference for women is a seismic shift in the way the criminal justice system responds to rape - drug-assisted or not.

Between each sip, they keep a finger over the neck of the bottle. That way they can be sure no one is slipping anything into their drink. It's not just Merseyside, of course. Our fear of drug-assisted rape, it seems, has taken on epidemic proportions. But has the crime itself? If the amount of media coverage it gets is any measure of its prevalence, there is justification for the alarm many young women feel. Drug rape is one of those subjects of which newspapers and documentaries cannot get enough: there's something vilely irresistible about the idea of a single act being both a woman's worst nightmare and a rapist's ultimate fantasy. Earlier this month, writer and campaigner Andrea Dworkin wrote of her own experience of being drugged and raped in a European hotel. "Rape with amnesiac drugs is new," she wrote. "This is foolproof rape. The gang that couldn't shoot straight can do this kind of rape. You can do this hundreds of times with virtually no chance of getting caught." Last month, there was the case of Kevin Cobb, a nurse who raped women after drugging them with a powerful sedative used in minor surgery. Before that there was DJ Richard Baker who was given four life sentences for a string of sex attacks - the pockets of his jacket were stuffed with pictures of unconscious naked women and packets of Rohypnol, the pills often associated with drug-assisted rape. In Merseyside there was a spate of attacks on women out for a drink who found themselves coming round, unable to remember events but with a used condom nearby. In one incident, a woman could not recall leaving the pub, but awoke in a field as she was being assaulted. Tomorrow, the fear that already stalks Britain's pubs, clubs and bars will be stoked up again with the publication of the Sturman report into drug-assisted sexual assault - the long-awaited report on the first detailed inquiry into drug rape. The Home Office-funded research will conclude that drug-assisted rape is definitely on the increase but is not an epidemic. It will call for tighter controls on some of the drugs known to be used in rape cases and will make a series of recommendations designed to promote greater cooperation among the agencies involved in handling cases of drug-assisted rapes and to improve criminal investigations to ensure successful convictions. For while the government has admitted that drug-assisted rape is the fastest growing recorded crime against women, as yet there have been only a handful of convictions here compared with 1,000 in the US. One helpline says it received 757 calls last year from people claiming they had been drugged and raped - a sharp increase from 507 in 1998. But according to women's rights campaigners, drug rape is nothing new. "Men have always drugged and raped women," says Julie Bindel of Justice for Women. "It's nothing new. These drugs just make it a little bit easier for them." Peter Sturman, the Metropolitan police officer who led the research, spent more than a year travelling all over the UK, interviewing 123 victims of drug-assisted rape, as well as visiting America and Australia. He has since set up, with his wife, a charity called the Drug Rape Trust and has been rewarded for his efforts with a promotion to the rank of detective chief inspector. What he wants to see now, he says, is a more "victim-driven" approach. Sue Lees, professor of women's studies and rape trial expert, recently interviewed a victim of a suspected drug-assisted attack who had passed out after a couple of drinks and came round while she was being assaulted. It took three or four months to get the forensic results back - after which it emerged that she had been raped by three different men. No evidence of drugs has yet been established. According to Lees, the forensic services are hopelessly underfunded and ill-equipped to cope with what appears to be a growing crime. There is powerful evidence, she says, particularly in the US where the problem is more widespread, of organised drug-assisted rape. "Watching your drink is something you have to do nowadays. There's a lot on the net about drug-assisted rape in the States and there are some sophisticated serial rapists around." But it's not fair and not enough always to put on women the burden of responsibility for protecting themselves. According to Lees, what is needed is a specialist police unit that can handle the forensic analysis involved in investigating drug-assisted rape and can deal sympathetically and skilfully with the women who come forward with complaints. Betsy Stanko, professor of criminology, first gave lectures to police at Hendon training college 20 years ago. "There's been a fairly substantial turnaround in the Metropolitan police about how important it is to take sexual violence seriously," she says. "But the way they've dealt with that is to issue warnings - if there's a rape by a minicab driver, they say don't go in minicabs until we catch him. We end up never discussing what should be discussed: why men want to rape women. We are accepting a natural predatory state of maleness and letting men off the hook again." Stanko is not exercised by the rise in drug-assisted rape. "I know there's been a lot of discussion about it, particularly in the US. Much of it focuses on the evilness of the drug, rather than the man using it," she points out, "which is very strange because it's not the drug that's evil. It's another variation, a new technology that assists men to commit sexual violence. There will always be new technologies that will do that." Research by Zero Tolerance, the Edinburgh-based group that campaigns against domestic and sexual violence, suggests that one in two young men thinks raping a woman is acceptable in certain circumstances. "So some of them carry pills," Stanko says. "But quite frankly, drugs are not doing the raping. They may be doing some form of disarmament, but not the raping. The boys are doing that." Whether the Sturman report will make any real difference when a woman comes to report a suspected drug rape remains to be seen. At a time when conviction rates for reported rapes are at an all-time low of 6%, it's certainly a tall order. Getting a conviction for a rape that does not involve drugs is hard enough; if the woman has little or no memory because she was drugged, it must be nigh-on impossible. Who was it that said a life lived in fear is a life wasted? If we go on a night out, we can appoint someone to guard our drinks; we can clutch our beer bottles to us and never accept a drink from a stranger. The Sturman report has to be welcomed, but what will really make a difference for women is a seismic shift in the way the criminal justice system responds to rape - drug-assisted or not.

fields.headline: Web lines
fields.trailText: Helping working parents to balance their life is the aim of newly-launched site www.flametree.co.uk.
fields.body:
Helping working parents to balance their life is the aim of newly-launched site www.flametree.co.uk. Founded by management consultant Jayne Buxton and investment manager Rosemary Leith, both working mothers, the site takes its name from the African tree known for its illuminating foliage and offers "inspiring solutions" to balancing home and work responsibilities. An excellent "get things done" section gives links to organisations offering advice and support on practical issues such as childcare, flexible working and help at home.

Attention all tennis junkies - no need to leave your screens this Wimbledon fortnight as women's portal www.handbag.com will be offering full coverage. As well as daily reports hosted by tennis player turned TV presenter Annabel Croft, the site will also feature the latest results, news from the tournament and two interactive games.

Staying on interactivity, www.icircle.com is currently host to an intriguing webcam drama. Star of the show Caroline is a 27-year-old travel writer with a penchant for vodka. "She's got a groovy west London pad, a good-looking boyfriend and a boss who clearly has other things on his mind," reads the blurb, inviting visitors to become part of her life. As the drama unfolds, you can email Caroline relationship and careers advice, send virtual gifts and even help her decide what to have for dinner (anything but aubergine, apparently). Never mind Bridget Jones - this is the real thing.

If you're still struggling to fathom downloads from dot.coms, you may want to go to Brighton next month where the government's women's unit is hosting a seminar on women and IT. Part of a series of events to promote women's employment and entrepreneurship, the seminar will focus on using IT in business and e-commerce. It's at Sussex University on July 5. Details from www.cabinet-office.gov.uk

The wacky world of the web this month features ruses to please your partner. www.thriveonline.oxygen.com suggests surprising them when you are at the cinema: "Quietly remove your panties and place them in his/her hand without saying a word or altering your expression. Extra points if someone is sitting on your other side!" If that fails to impress, online dating diva Delilah has advice on finding a new mate.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Saving Private Ryan
fields.body:
Saving Private Ryan

(Steven Spielberg, 1998)

10pm, Sky Premier

Reactions to Spielberg's second world war epic ranged from best war movie ever down to cliché-ridden failure. The truth, inevitably, is somewhere in the middle. Yes, the plot - a platoon is detailed to find Matt Damon's Private Ryan and bring him back safely, because his three brothers have died in combat - is contrived comic-book stuff, but there are vivid, emotionally jolting scenes: the opening battle, which pitches us headfirst into the chaos and horror of the Omaha beach landing on D-Day; a knife-fight in a ruined house where you can almost smell the sweat and fear; and, more peacefully, the young GIs' faces angel-like in candlelight. Tom Hanks is a quietly noble platoon leader, Tom Sizemore his granite-like sergeant.

Casualties Of War

(Brian De Palma, 1989)

10.40pm, FilmFour

De Palma's Vietnam movie has similarities with Oliver Stone's Platoon, setting Good GI against Bad GI in a modern morality tale. Thus, Sean Penn's brutal sergeant kidnaps a Vietnamese girl for his squad's entertainment: they rape and kill her. Michael J Fox's appalled grunt is unable to stop them, but presses charges in the face of threats and unsympathetic authorities. A savage picture of war, with My-Lai and other atrocities in mind; it's a pity the leads lack the tangible mutual hatred of the Platoon pair.

Birdy

(Alan Parker, 1984)

11pm, Carlton Cinema

Rounding off our night of war is this sad, wingless creation adapted from William Wharton's novel. Matthew Modine plays a young Vietnam veteran who's traumatised by the war, flying, in his mind, with his pet birds. Nicolas Cage is the longtime chum drafted in to bring him back down to earth. Fine performances from the then up-and-coming leads make it a haunting experience. Alan Parker handles the cast with his usual professionalism

fields.headline: Remote control
fields.standfirst: A new webcast site, DVTV, it taking on broadcasters at their own game. Has the internet reached the point where it has become a serious threat to TV? And how long do traditional channels have left? By  Ed Waller
fields.trailText: A new webcast site, DVTV, it taking on broadcasters at their own game. Has the internet reached the point where it has become a serious threat to TV? And how long do traditional channels have left?
fields.body:
Streaming video from your website is a very sexy thing to be doing right now (and not just because it was originally developed to distribute pornography). Sizeable chunks of video are increasingly downloadable from entertainment sites and portals, so the desk-bound need never be too far from their favourite comedy sketch or animation. Atom Films' (www.atomfilms.com) site has hundreds of shorts and cartoons, like Rex The Runt and Angry Kid from the producers of the Wallace and Gromit films. Ha Ha Bonk's web-channel (www.hahabonk.com), launched last month, offers stand-up shows and original animation from the likes of Perrier Award winners Ben 'n' Arn, all at the click of a mouse.

The UK's latest webcaster, DVTV (www.dvtvchannel.com), sprang to life last Thursday at 11pm (timed to suit post-pubbers and the Stateside after-work crowd). Every week at this hour, the site's 60-minute flagship show, Big Mouth, is webcast live from Sheffield's National Centre for Popular Music. Fronted by D-Flava, former presenter of the Gatecrasher webcasts, and someone called Gemma, the show features chat, interviews and live music. TFI Thursday, if you like.

As well as the live show, an eclectic range of bitesize programming is uploaded to the site each week, to be viewed on-demand anywhere in the world. This week, for instance, visitors can enjoy Can't Stop, Won't Stop, a series about graffiti artists; and The John Mayatt Story, a documentary on the celebrated art forger. Forthcoming shows include Dawn Of The Dreads, about white cultures' appropriation of the Rasta hairdo; Garden On A String, documenting "the wonderful world of Wilford Baptiste's backyard"; Power Trip, about male violence; and Neon Lights, about how the Criminal Justice Act has affected travellers. So far, so very Channel 4.

"Cult and underground" is how the site's co-founder Mark Wilkinson describes the shows, perhaps reflecting his past - he launched dance music label, Liquid Records. Tucked further up his sleeve is a make-over clothes show called Gear Street, as well as stuff about clubbing, hip-hop and BMXs. Wilkinson is on the look-out for plenty more of these ten-minute documentaries from the me-and-my-camera school of TV: "anything from young people with good access". And, as well as offering all the usual chatrooms and gimmicky downloads, DVTV will continue a trend that began with Max Headroom right through to Lara Croft, Annanova and that busty toon from the Triumph ads: virtual presenters.

That most of DVTV's shows are ten-minute shorts is further evidence of the technology-led renaissance of this most neglected of artforms. Short films are ideal for web distribution because they're, well, so short. This allows quicker downloads and caters for the web audiences' notoriously gadfly viewing patterns. (Even cabsat broadcasters are now finding that they can hold viewers' attention for an average of just 12 minutes.) While DVTV's shows illustrate just how far away the web is from offering the joys of a full-screen televisual experience, with broadband internet around the corner this will change, and traditional broadcasters are no longer sitting comfortably. TV channels are already haemorrhaging viewers to video games, interactive TV and online fun. Hence the little me-too interactive gestures in much TV output: email voting, online debates and webcams (so de rigueur for kids' shows these days).

Hence, too, their increasingly aggressive stance when it comes to online rights to the shows they themselves commissioned in the first place. Not only are cheeky young pretenders like DVTV springing up and offering TV on the web, but so are the broadcasters' own trusted suppliers. Long-standing independent producer Hat Trick, makers of Have I Got News For You? (www.haveigotnewsforyou.com), incurred the BBC's wrath recently when they unveiled their own website for the show without the corporation's approval. Needless to say you won't find its URL tacked on the end of the BBC transmission, as so many are these days.

But Hat Trick is just one of many far-sighted TV producers who are looking forward to the broadband age, when they'll be able to entertain their audience directly via their websites, without being subject to the whims of TV commissioners and schedulers. Channel 4 - which is totally reliant on independent suppliers and perhaps most vulnerable to being by-passed in this way - is currently locked into a bitter row about online rights with the producers' trade association. Its members are all keen to shake off their long dependency on meagre commission fees and enter the wonderful world of e-commerce and pay-per-view.

But good old-fashioned TV channel controllers have more to worry about than just this - waiting in the wings is the intelligent set-top box. This wonderful device draws on servers full of TV archive and pipes the sort of shows it knows you already like directly to your telly, on a pay-per-view basis. A similar black box will scour the myriad TV channels out there on your behalf, leaving no corner of the spectrum unrifled, and record a TV schedule tailored to your own personal preferences. It all makes the broadcasters' arcane science of scheduling somewhat redundant. Content, goes the industry mantra, is king - and perhaps that's what the traditional broadcasters are now worried about.
