fields.headline: And for my next trick...
fields.standfirst: Michael Kaiser, aka Mr Fix-It, doesn't hang about once the job is done. So  Judith Mackrell  asks him why he has signed up for another season with the Royal Opera House
fields.trailText: Michael Kaiser, aka Mr Fix-It, doesn't hang about once the job is done. So Judith Mackrell asks him why he has signed up for another season with the Royal Opera House
fields.body:
On the day that Michael Kaiser started work as executive director of the Royal Opera House, his colleagues were marching on Downing Street to make a desperate plea for their future. It was just over 18 months ago and probably the darkest hour of the House's closure, with ballet and opera staff panicking about a complete shutdown.

But for Kaiser, the legendary Mr Fix-It of arts organisations, it could hardly have been better. Recalling that day in his immaculately ordered office, Kaiser insists: "I love problems. I love solving problems." And, looking back over the past successful season, he has done a classy job in sorting out the problems at the House. A few rumbles persist over ticket pricing and the malfunctioning stage machinery that jinxed the House's reopening, but the new building is slowly becoming an object of affection.

Kaiser is proud that the House's historic deficit has been paid off and that, against all expectation, the organisation broke even in the last financial year. Some ticket prices were cut and 40% of the audience during Kaiser's first season had apparently never visited the House before.

The staff seem happier, too. When he arrived, Kaiser says, the House "was in a state typical of troubled organisations everywhere. There was a lack of clear roles and people didn't know who was running the show." Now he believes almost everyone in the building "feels they have a vital role".

All this sounds like the triumph of some iron-willed troubleshooter, but Kaiser's story is more complex. His steady exterior is known to shelter a shy, emotional personality and it has been widely rumoured that he felt so browbeaten by the hostile British press, the politics within the House and the monumental labours of getting it reopened that he planned to resign at the end of this season. Kaiser tackles the claim head-on. "I expect you've heard all the rumours about my resigning," he says cheerfully, and goes on to say how seriously exhausted he is.

He came to Britain straight after leaving the American Ballet Theatre in New York, where he had spent three years turning the company around. Once here, he worked from 6am to midnight every day overseeing the myriad aspects of the reopening, from the new bar staff to the heating systems and the temperamental stage machinery. Asked what his doctor thinks, Kaiser, aged 46, shrugs. "Oh, I don't even have to go see him. I could just play the record: 'Get more rest... take a holiday... get more exercise... lose weight...'"

While Kaiser was slogging his guts out - along with fellow staff and board members, to whom he is quick to give equal credit - the press didn't stop hurling mud, and although he accepts that the House requires public monitoring, his frustration over the number of misleading and badly informed stories fuelled a desire to leave.

Now, though, he has signed up for another season - but for one only. This, he insists, is not a signal of his definite departure in 2001, only of his refusal to commit longer term, but it surely puts a question mark over the future. The board may not have to scrabble around for a replacement just yet, but there's a danger that Kaiser's temporising may unsettle the balance he has laboured to create. He could be gone before either the new ballet director, Ross Stretton, or the new music director, Antony Pappano, start their jobs.

Kaiser counters this by insisting that both men are already talking to staff at the House. And, he points out, he never works on a long term contract. Again, he offers his candour like an embrace - "Let me share a part of my emotional life with you"- confiding that he always burns out at the end of a season, and has to be sure he can regenerate himself before committing to another. He says, self-mockingly, that it wouldn't help any organisation for him to stay after the big issues were sorted, because he would start meddling with affairs that weren't his concern.

This might suggest Kaiser has a fear of commitment - that he gets excited by crises but lacks the staying power for daily, domestic detail. Yet this isn't exactly the case. Like a man showing photos of his children, he says that he keeps close contact with the companies where he has previously worked. Even more significant is the interest he takes in the working lives of his artists. As executive director, his style is neither bland suit nor flamboyant politician, but an idiosyncratic mix of amateur enthusiast and philanthropist.

It is a matter of pride to him that he can talk to artists intelligently about their work. And one reason why his days are so long is that he opts to watch most performances and discuss them with the performers. Before becoming an arts manager he trained as an opera singer - "My voice was terrible" - and he also took ballet classes for a year. He loves the joke of how unlike a dancer he looks. He beams plumply that he had "great turn out" but never got the hang of turning: "I kept going into the wall."

More hours are eaten up by his special interest, the development of new work, especially dance. When he agreed to join the House, Kaiser was fired by the promise of the Clore Studio and Linbury Theatre, small-scale facilities that would allow choreographers to make works away from the demands of the main auditorium. It scares him how expensive it has become to create ballets for today's big companies and how damaging this is to choreographers' development. "Ashton or Balanchine could create four or five works a year and think nothing of it," he says, "but today's choreographers can often only make one. It's become much harder for them to mature, to learn from their mistakes."

The Royal Ballet's New Works season is thus very close to his heart. It presents a mix of ballets by established choreographers and younger artists, and Kaiser hopes that its varied line-up and low ticket prices should "get different parts of the dance audience into the House, create links, and allow the company to loosen up a little."

It is, though, only the first move in a much larger push towards experiment. In collaboration with dancer Deborah Bull, Kaiser has created a timetable for choreographers, inside and outside the company, to develop work in the Clore Studio during the year, and a system to provide them with structured feedback. He thinks there's a critical lack of education among choreographers and believes there are some "wonderful minds in England who could come in and share their experience".

His prime motive is to widen the pool of artists able to create ballets for the Royal, but he takes a keen interest in the whole UK dance scene. He watches a range of smaller modern dance companies and is shocked by the talent wasted through poor management and underfunding. So he is helping two independent choreographers, Matthew Hawkins and Sheron Wray, teaching them about fundraising and marketing. The couple have been paired with two Royal dancers who are working as unpaid administrators (and, incidentally, picking up training for their own post-dancing careers).

Kaiser says simply: "It's painful to me to see talent being wasted because of a lack of support." And he is adamant it will continue after him. "You create a damaging lack of trust if you just do a little then take it away."

All this is genuine, big-hearted stuff, and though Kaiser may be driven by a private as well as a public agenda, there's no denying the infectiousness of his vision. It may be an accident of timing that he has led the House into the 21st century. But his dogged hopefulness is helping it to feel that it belongs there.

The New Works season is in rep at the Linbury Studio (020-7304 4000) till July 2.
fields.bodyText: On the day that Michael Kaiser started work as executive director of the Royal Opera House, his colleagues were marching on Downing Street to make a desperate plea for their future. It was just over 18 months ago and probably the darkest hour of the House's closure, with ballet and opera staff panicking about a complete shutdown. But for Kaiser, the legendary Mr Fix-It of arts organisations, it could hardly have been better. Recalling that day in his immaculately ordered office, Kaiser insists: "I love problems. I love solving problems." And, looking back over the past successful season, he has done a classy job in sorting out the problems at the House. A few rumbles persist over ticket pricing and the malfunctioning stage machinery that jinxed the House's reopening, but the new building is slowly becoming an object of affection. Kaiser is proud that the House's historic deficit has been paid off and that, against all expectation, the organisation broke even in the last financial year. Some ticket prices were cut and 40% of the audience during Kaiser's first season had apparently never visited the House before. The staff seem happier, too. When he arrived, Kaiser says, the House "was in a state typical of troubled organisations everywhere. There was a lack of clear roles and people didn't know who was running the show." Now he believes almost everyone in the building "feels they have a vital role". All this sounds like the triumph of some iron-willed troubleshooter, but Kaiser's story is more complex. His steady exterior is known to shelter a shy, emotional personality and it has been widely rumoured that he felt so browbeaten by the hostile British press, the politics within the House and the monumental labours of getting it reopened that he planned to resign at the end of this season. Kaiser tackles the claim head-on. "I expect you've heard all the rumours about my resigning," he says cheerfully, and goes on to say how seriously exhausted he is. He came to Britain straight after leaving the American Ballet Theatre in New York, where he had spent three years turning the company around. Once here, he worked from 6am to midnight every day overseeing the myriad aspects of the reopening, from the new bar staff to the heating systems and the temperamental stage machinery. Asked what his doctor thinks, Kaiser, aged 46, shrugs. "Oh, I don't even have to go see him. I could just play the record: 'Get more rest... take a holiday... get more exercise... lose weight...'" While Kaiser was slogging his guts out - along with fellow staff and board members, to whom he is quick to give equal credit - the press didn't stop hurling mud, and although he accepts that the House requires public monitoring, his frustration over the number of misleading and badly informed stories fuelled a desire to leave. Now, though, he has signed up for another season - but for one only. This, he insists, is not a signal of his definite departure in 2001, only of his refusal to commit longer term, but it surely puts a question mark over the future. The board may not have to scrabble around for a replacement just yet, but there's a danger that Kaiser's temporising may unsettle the balance he has laboured to create. He could be gone before either the new ballet director, Ross Stretton, or the new music director, Antony Pappano, start their jobs. Kaiser counters this by insisting that both men are already talking to staff at the House. And, he points out, he never works on a long term contract. Again, he offers his candour like an embrace - "Let me share a part of my emotional life with you"- confiding that he always burns out at the end of a season, and has to be sure he can regenerate himself before committing to another. He says, self-mockingly, that it wouldn't help any organisation for him to stay after the big issues were sorted, because he would start meddling with affairs that weren't his concern. This might suggest Kaiser has a fear of commitment - that he gets excited by crises but lacks the staying power for daily, domestic detail. Yet this isn't exactly the case. Like a man showing photos of his children, he says that he keeps close contact with the companies where he has previously worked. Even more significant is the interest he takes in the working lives of his artists. As executive director, his style is neither bland suit nor flamboyant politician, but an idiosyncratic mix of amateur enthusiast and philanthropist. It is a matter of pride to him that he can talk to artists intelligently about their work. And one reason why his days are so long is that he opts to watch most performances and discuss them with the performers. Before becoming an arts manager he trained as an opera singer - "My voice was terrible" - and he also took ballet classes for a year. He loves the joke of how unlike a dancer he looks. He beams plumply that he had "great turn out" but never got the hang of turning: "I kept going into the wall." More hours are eaten up by his special interest, the development of new work, especially dance. When he agreed to join the House, Kaiser was fired by the promise of the Clore Studio and Linbury Theatre, small-scale facilities that would allow choreographers to make works away from the demands of the main auditorium. It scares him how expensive it has become to create ballets for today's big companies and how damaging this is to choreographers' development. "Ashton or Balanchine could create four or five works a year and think nothing of it," he says, "but today's choreographers can often only make one. It's become much harder for them to mature, to learn from their mistakes." The Royal Ballet's New Works season is thus very close to his heart. It presents a mix of ballets by established choreographers and younger artists, and Kaiser hopes that its varied line-up and low ticket prices should "get different parts of the dance audience into the House, create links, and allow the company to loosen up a little." It is, though, only the first move in a much larger push towards experiment. In collaboration with dancer Deborah Bull, Kaiser has created a timetable for choreographers, inside and outside the company, to develop work in the Clore Studio during the year, and a system to provide them with structured feedback. He thinks there's a critical lack of education among choreographers and believes there are some "wonderful minds in England who could come in and share their experience". His prime motive is to widen the pool of artists able to create ballets for the Royal, but he takes a keen interest in the whole UK dance scene. He watches a range of smaller modern dance companies and is shocked by the talent wasted through poor management and underfunding. So he is helping two independent choreographers, Matthew Hawkins and Sheron Wray, teaching them about fundraising and marketing. The couple have been paired with two Royal dancers who are working as unpaid administrators (and, incidentally, picking up training for their own post-dancing careers). Kaiser says simply: "It's painful to me to see talent being wasted because of a lack of support." And he is adamant it will continue after him. "You create a damaging lack of trust if you just do a little then take it away." All this is genuine, big-hearted stuff, and though Kaiser may be driven by a private as well as a public agenda, there's no denying the infectiousness of his vision. It may be an accident of timing that he has led the House into the 21st century. But his dogged hopefulness is helping it to feel that it belongs there. The New Works season is in rep at the Linbury Studio (020-7304 4000) till July 2.

fields.headline: Inside Tate Modern
fields.standfirst: This week: Cell No 1, by Absalon, in the section History/ Memory/Society
fields.trailText: This week: Cell No 1, by Absalon, in the section History/ Memory/Society
fields.body:
Life-size constructions of wood, cardboard and white paint, Absalon's cells are mock-ups of solitary habitations. With its curved roof, a little like a wartime Anderson shelter, and its pill-box slit of a window, as well as its unavoidable similarity to a survivalist's nuclear bunker, it is hard not to think of Cell No 1 as a place to go in a life under siege. When Absalon made this work, he was already dying.

The door is ajar, but you can't go in, although this was Absalon's intention. Inside there is a kitchen and a work corner with table, chair and a bookcase "for books of average height". A mattress on top of the clothes cupboard, a shower and space for a lavatory. How can a life be lived here? And what kind of life? This is a sort of hermit's cell, so rationalist that Jeremy Bentham would have approved. The proportions of everything in the cell, and their arrangement, were measured in relation to Absalon's own body. Cell No 1, therefore, is Absalon-sized, a home for a disappearing man.

There is no wasted space, almost no space at all, yet the internal arrangement is so ergonomically precise that the cell seems to contain all the space one could need. I imagine lying on the mattress and looking up - the curved ceiling proposes a kind of optical infinity of whiteness. It is all so clean and white, hygienic, blank, inviolable, a kind of geometric minimalism for the human soul. It is the house of a nomad, a sort of sepulchre. Absalon, a French-Israeli artist, died, aged 29, just a year after completing his six cells.

webTitle: I've seen the future and it irks

fields.headline: I've seen the future and it irks
fields.standfirst: Young artists striking poses, egged on by their elders - New Contemporaries leaves  Jonathan Jones ill at ease
fields.trailText: Young artists striking poses, egged on by their elders - New Contemporaries leaves Jonathan Jones ill at ease
fields.body:
This year's New Contemporaries, the annual exhibition of students and recent graduates selected from Britain's art colleges, serves as a warning of what might happen to British art in the next 10 years. If the star in the 90s was the artist, now it is the museum. We live in an age of great exhibitions rather than great artists. But although we can live with curators imposing their vision on art history, what happens when they do the same with new art, and young artists are rewarded for second-guessing what might fit into a group show? There is no room for solitary brilliance.

When Damien Hirst showed his shark at the Saatchi Gallery in 1991, it had nothing in common with anything around it. Everything in New Contemporaries 2000 - supposedly a showcase of new talent - conforms to a preconceived idea of what art should be. This show is pleasant as a whole, weak in particulars, with no single work that takes your breath away. But art that takes your breath away is the only art you need.

This is not to say the very young artists in this exhibition are talentless, but there's something overbearing about the way the exhibition has been selected and the portrait it claims to paint of new art. This does not feel like an open exhibition, although it is one, with the selectors - critic Sarah Kent, artist Gavin Turk and curator Jeremy Millar - examining slides without any knowledge of the artist's name or college.

Entering the new Milton Keynes Gallery, it is immediately impossible to see this as anything other than a heavily curated group show exploring a specific theme: landscape, introspection, romantic inwardness. Almost everything here, from Justin Carter's Mobile Retreat, a portable tent/art studio in which he shelters in the wild and draws nature, to Josephine Butler's photographs of overgrown countryside, entitled City of London, touches on the inward life of the rural rambler. And you thought young artists spent their time in bars in Shoreditch...

Why does this open exhibition have such a strong theme? It might just be that art students are all obsessed with alpine kitsch and horse-riding. But I smell a curator. Millar, the brightest spark on this year's selection panel, has strong ideas about what he likes. He likes JG Ballard, American land artist Robert Smithson, Tacita Dean and the idea of entropy - of time running down and the art work running down with it. The huge amount of art here that exudes pastoral melancholy has his signature all over it.

A life-size wooden outline of a cable car by an artist identified only as Eric stands next to Jeff Ty Lee's intricate drawings of mountain scenery. Jennifer Beattie's Beautiful Trees (real uprooted trees with paper leaves) hang in front of Andrew Mania's wall-filling installation with werewolf-like figures and pastiched portraits and, dominating everything, a series of - you guessed it - mountain landscape paintings with a cute little ladder down to the ground.

Mania's installation is too aware of its own fine insanity to be convincing - the problem with a lot of the art here. When it comes to painting and drawing, young artists seem to expect their works to be seen in quotation marks as "paintings" or "drawings" - like Edward Weldon with his painting of Concorde without its nose. Ho ho.

Then there are pictorial tableaux, like Mick Peter's blue-painted Alpine house with sinister megaphone, or James Ireland's picture-postcard landscape with a "real" waterfall consisting of tap water running into a bucket. So dreamy, so self-consciously pathetic. These art works are overloaded with attitude, with ideas about nature and what we do to it. If they like nature so much, why don't they go and live there?

This exhibition is full of people striking attitudes - a natural student activity - but instead of keeping pretension in check, the selectors have rewarded every cool posture. This landscape stuff shrivels next to Smithson, who built Spiral Jetty, a vast earthwork that slowly sank into Salt Lake. Ilana Halperin photographs herself boiling some milk in a Scandinavian hot spring. Beata Veszely makes model heads of horses you can wear. These works are too easily translated into words and conscious of their weirdness.

In another context all this art might look much better. Here the artists who stand out are the ones whose work does not fit. Art that is not pictorial, that does not have an instantly decodable meaning, is like a fresh spring in this overcurated wilderness. Melanie Titmuss has drawn in pencil around the perimeter of a huge sheet of paper, and then cut away the paper. The grey rectangle on the wall, snaking out over the floor, shares some of the humour of the 60s postminimalist artist Eva Hesse in the way it plays on order and chaos. Marta Marce's paintings don't namecheck anyone, or picture anything, or evoke a mood. In one of them blackness radiates across the canvas. This is odd. The painting does not rush to tell you what it is about. Another painting resembles a multicoloured Scalextric set_ no, it doesn't resemble anything but the movements Marce made as she painted around cans placed on the canvas. I kept coming back to it, and it looked better every time.

Britain's love affair with modern art has never really been about the artists, but about what we get from looking at and arguing about their work. But as the catalogue essay for New Contemporaries gratuitously puts it, "Really, the work would not be there without those that make it." And if curators and selectors become the dominant force in the age of Tate Modern we may wander through our beautiful new public galleries without ever coming across that unplanned, unexpected, astonishing thing we were looking for.

New Contemporaries 2000 is at Milton Keynes Gallery (01908 676 900) till August 13.

fields.headline: For a few euros more
fields.standfirst: Who needs the Turner when you've got the Vincent?  Adrian Searle  on Europe's newest prize
fields.trailText: Who needs the Turner when you've got the Vincent? Adrian Searle on Europe's newest prize
fields.body:
The Turner has become the world's most famous art prize. Even the Golden Lion, presented at the Venice Biennale amid much pomp, fails to catch the popular imagination. This year's Turner shortlist - Japanese artist Tomoko Takahashi, German photographer Wolfgang Tillmans, Dutch painter Michael Raedecker and lone Brit Glenn Brown - has already raised attention with its inclusion of three artists who are not British but live and work here. "I thought it was meant for British artists," one peeved contender who failed to make the final four said last week. I found this reaction a bit unsettling. Art has never respected borders.

Medieval and Renaissance artists moved from court to court. Artists as well as their works migrate from city to city, taking up residencies, setting up stall in the art fairs and museums of the world. Everywhere is local, everywhere is international.

Ten days ago a show of works by artists shortlisted for a new European art prize, the Vincent, was launched at the Bonnefantenmuseum in Maastricht in Holland. The Vincent, worth 50,000 euros (£32,000), emulates the Turner, down to the appointment of Nicholas Serota as chair of the judging panel, which includes Swiss artists Fischli and Weiss, and Italian artist Luciano Fabro. The winner will be announced in September.

"In a world of global culture, individual countries no longer set the standards," writes the Bonnefanten's director, Alexander van Grevenstein, "and although there is no other continent that demonstrates so many views and self-inflicted differences, the Vincent is not designed to celebrate Europe's pre-eminent status, but rather to celebrate diversity."

The Vincent shortlist comprises Antwerp painter Luc Tuymans, Carsten Holler (Belgian-born, residing in Cologne), Warsaw sculptor Miroslaw Balka, film-maker Eija Liisa Ahtila from Helsinki, Lisbon artist Pedro Cabrita Reis and London-based, Nigerian-born film and installation artist Oladele Ajiboye Bamgboye. Cities are more important in Europe than countries. But at the press conference - attended mostly by Dutch critics and journalists - the question why there were no Dutch artists was foremost, predictably anticipating the peevish xenophobia in the complaints over this year's Turner line-up.

The Vincent is a terrific group show, even though the artists were not selected with a theme in mind. Ahtila's film installations manage to be arresting as environments and also maintain strong narrative drive, even though she refers to one work here as a "sketch". One of her multi-screen projections (an apt word) is displayed in a kind of analyst's room. You can lie on a couch, hear unseen voices, feel that you are projecting your own fantasies. Of Bamgboye's two video works, one was shot from a pay-to-view porn channel in a Canadian hotel, to which the artist declined to subscribe: fragments of bodies swoon amid the scrambled signals. Bamgboye will be seen at Tate Britain next month, in a show called Intelligence. The Vincent is more about the long-term vitality of an artist's work than it is about the novelty of this year's model. The show reflects this, even though Ahtila and Bamgboye have yet to develop a mature style.

Carsten Holler is the joker. His Giant Psycho Tank is a big, waxy white polypropylene bathing unit. You can float in a pool of heated water made twice as salty as the Dead Sea: so saline, you can almost walk on it. I declined a dip. His is a kind of psychological chamber, as is one of the two rooms dedicated to Miroslaw Balka. Familiar Balka elements - a head-high hawser (part of which is wrapped in human hair) crossing the space; an athlete's exercise bar below it, indented to accept an arm, a neck or a leg; a metal grille-like door leading nowhere - are arrayed around the room. On the floor is a grey box. In the box is a perfect mock-up of the room you are in, and its contents. Looking down into the box, you feel as if human scale has been somehow altered, like Alice presented with the bottle labelled Drink Me.

Pedro Cabrita Reis has hacked out the doorways to his room, and leant the wrecked plasterboard and door frames against the wall. He made a similar work in the new Serralves Museum in Oporto some months back. This particular series of works - leaving the architecture in a state of arrest between building and demolition, clean and dirty, finished and unfinished - is undoubtedly a metaphor for the creative process and the relation between the artist and the gallery. He is the only artist here never to have shown in Britain.

Luc Tuymans is well known, and one of the best painters working anywhere today. His small, history-laden, metaphoric and frequently nasty paintings are all about European-ness. Whether he is painting a dozing Nazi, a landscape, a corner of a bed or a fragment of a packet of Ecover soap powder, you know he has something furtive and unsettling in mind.

He is one of those artists I return to again and again, in the way one returns to certain poets, novelists, film-makers. They always give you the same story, whatever the imagery, the same emotional tenor, the same slant on the world. Their power depends on the richness of their language, how well they sustain their vision, the degree to which we want to return to them. These, surely, are the criteria. This, rather than nationality, is what we should care about, and attend to. If this is what the Vincent continues to be about, it deserves to succeed.

The Vincent shortlist is at the Bonnefantenmuseum, Maastricht (00 31 43 329 01900), till September 24.

fields.headline: Virtual teachers
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor visits the classroom of the future
fields.body:
If you asked a class of 10-year-olds in 1980 what their classroom would look like in the year 2000, they would probably have come up with a glowing, paperless room filled with brightly coloured screens and ceiling-high projections. Some might have predicted that teachers would no longer exist, or that they would appear on screen when pupils needed them.

None of these notions seem particularly strange now, although they are a long way from being fulfilled in many schools. What did strike visitors to this year's Bett exhibition in London as dazzlingly new was the virtual teacher - a hologrammatic projection described as "a bit like a teleported Dr Spock" and which enabled a London maths teacher to give a lesson to a class several miles away.

The company responsible, Edex, was demonstrating what can be done with broadband technology - that is, the ability to push large amounts of data down a high-speed line. The hardware needed can be carried around in a suitcase, but so far only 30 schools in the UK possess the broadband links that enable it to work.

The reason lies in the price. Broadband costs £15-30,000 per school each year. The director of education services at Edex, Adrian Carey, believes it would fall to around £2,000 if infrastructure providers (such as BT and Cable & Wireless, of which Edex is now a part) lowered their charges.

For Bridget Cooper of the Nimis project at Leeds university, the flesh-and-blood teacher is still a vital part of the classroom. At Glusburn primary near Leeds a class of 23 key stage 1 children are experimenting with a huge touch screen and five computers. During a lesson on shapes, for example, some of them draw on the screen with a finger while others manipulate shapes on the smaller screens with an electronic pen. According to Cooper, the children are far more confident than they would be at a blackboard.

Network Interactive Media in Schools in Leeds (Nimis), is funded by the EU alongside similar projects in Portugal and Germany. At £15,000 for the Glusburn set-up, it's cheaper than broadband but still beyond the reach of most schools.

But both Cooper and Carey are optimistic that the costs will fall. "Hardly anyone could afford the first calculators; now they're given away," says Carey. Roll on the classroom of 2020.

fields.headline: Outsiders
fields.trailText: In the current climate of hatred and hysteria everyone - especially children - needs to know why people leave their homes behind.
fields.body:
As the media case against asylum seekers gathers pace and is reinforced by vote-catching politics, everyone - especially children - needs to know something much closer to the truth about why people leave their countries and what the reality is when they come here.

Anyone trying to understand the complexities of life as a refugee child would do well to turn first to the winner of this year's Bisto Book of the Year Award. Marilyn Taylor's Faraway Home (O'Brien, £4.99) is a tale of Jewish children who came to safety on the Kindertransport after the rise of Hitler. Like the refugee children of today's conflicts, they had to make new friends who understood little or nothing of what they had been through. Based on a true story, it tells how Karl and Rosa adapt to life on a farm set up by the local Jewish community just outside Belfast. Their survival depends on building new trust and keeping hope alive.

Beverley Naidoo's The Other Side of Truth (Puffin, £4.99) comes much more from the present day. It tells how Sade and her younger brother Femi see their mother shot dead on the doorstep in Nigeria, the victim of their father's political enemies. With no time to mourn her death, the children are smuggled out of the country. Arriving in London, they are abandoned by their hired courier and left to fend for themselves in a country that is alien in every respect.

Helped by foster parents and the refugee services but, above all, by the moral courage inculcated by their parents, the children cope outwardly. Inwardly, however, the emotional toll tells in Femi's retreat into silence.

Sade tells the story of the disintegration of her world, a grief that is compounded by the hostile reception from her fellow pupils, ignorant of the upheaval she has been though.

In The Girl in Red by Gaye Hicyilmaz (Orion, £4.99) the arrival of a group of Romanian gypsies is greeted with violent abuse by the residents of Poets' Rise. Strange alliances build up between previously warring neighbours as they unite against the newcomers. To Frankie's shock, his mother becomes leader of the bigots, forfeiting her new boyfriend in the process. Frankie sees the Romanians only through his obsession with Emilia, the beautiful girl with the long plaits in a red dress and sandals who arrives in his class speaking no English.

Comparing his love with the boundary-crossing of Romeo and Juliet, he takes sides against his mother and allies himself instead with other, more compassionate adults.

Gaye Hicyilmaz's adolescent Frankie observes and learns, moved by compassion for an individual that leads him to reject the prejudice that surrounds him. Frankie's view lingers and informs.

Like Sade and Femi, Kaninda in Bernard Ashley's Little Soldier (Orchard, £4.99), has seen his family killed. He arrives in England alone, only holding himself together by his secret plans to get back home. Kaninda has been a gun-toting boy-soldier fighting for the rebels in East Africa: he has the scar to show for it. On the estates around his new school in east London he finds tribal warfare of a different kind - less bloody, but every bit as pernicious. Taking sides with Laura, daughter of his adopting family, he is sucked into new friendships, ties that help him to begin a new life.

 Children's Book Award 2000 has been won by Michael Morpurgo for Kensuke's Kingdom (Mammoth, £4.99). It also won the shorter novel category. The longer novel winner was JK Rowling for Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (Bloomsbury, £4.99) while the picture book category was won by Nicholas Allen for Demon Teddy (Hutchinson, £9.99). The Children's Book Award is given annually by the Federation of Children's Book Groups and is chosen entirely by children.

fields.headline: Dog handling
fields.trailText: Dog handling
fields.body:
Help! Don't move, sir. The dog won't hurt.

I can't move. It's got my sleeve in its jaws. No worry, sir, the dog will do what I tell it. Down, Ofsted! Heel. I said, heel!

Yaaargh! No sweat, sir, that sleeve will mend.

Not the jacket. My arm. I'm sure that'll mend too.

Does he ever do that to you? Never, sir, not to his handler. He's a real softy, aren't you, Ofsted. Owww!

Always a first time, heh? So what do dog handlers do? They work closely with specially trained dogs in protecting property, or in tracking or detection operations.

How closely? It is our job to control, encourage, lead and instruct the dog in what it has to do. We've got to be able to understand what the dog is trying to say by watching and interpreting the dog's actions in any situation.

Who employs you? Well, obviously the police, army and RAF use dogs for guarding sensitive buildings and military bases. They are trained by their handlers to use their strength, speed, sense of smell and sight to patrol the buildings, grounds and perimeter fencing.

Private security firms also use dog handlers. Spot on, sir, yes. In general, handlers work closely with specially trained dogs in protecting any property that needs it.

Is that it? Just protection? No, no. Handlers use dogs for a variety of tasks. Their keen sense of smell is invaluable for searching out and recovering illegal substances, such as drugs or explosives at ports and airports, and tracking down people on the run, or who have gone missing. Dogs are also used in situations where it is dangerous or difficult for humans to go in, for instance when tackling an armed person, or searching a burning building.

Not a nine-to-five job, then. Oh, no. Our busiest time is usually between 6pm and 6am. Working hours tend to be long and varied and often include weekends and nights.

What does the work require? Lots of walking, running, and sometimes chasing, mostly outdoors in all types of weather and environments. Basically, dog handlers need good physical and mental coordination and should be fit, strong, alert and observant. Patience, a responsible nature and the ability to use initiative and work unsupervised are pluses. Good dog handlers have a genuine concern for and a desire to work with dogs.

Any entry requirements? No specific academic qualifications. Dog handling is a specialised option which people usually branch into once they've joined the specific organisation. For the armed forces, their standard age and entry requirements apply. Experience with animals is not essential, but an interest in dogs is an advantage.

What about training? Organisations do things their own way. The forces and the police usually send trainees on residential courses that can lead to NVQ Level 2.

 Police Recruitment Department, PPTU, Room 514, Queen Anne's Gate, London SW1H 9AT Telephone: 0207 2733797

 Armed Forces Careers (NI), Palace Barracks, Holywood, Co Down BT18 9RF Telephone: 028 90427040

 Royal Ulster Constabulary (RUC) Recruiting Branch, Lisnasharragh, 42 Montgomery Road, Belfast, BT6 9LD Telephone: 028 9045 1881

 Scottish Home Office, Justice Department, Police Division, Room E1/7, Saughton House, Broomhouse Drive, Edinburgh, EH1 3XD Telephone: 0131 2442156

fields.headline: Insect vampires
fields.standfirst: Jerome Monahan looks at the myths and mysteries of the mosquito and midge
fields.trailText: Jerome Monahan looks at the myths and mysteries of the mosquito and midge
fields.body:
It's summer and the vampires of the insect world are out to get us. Happy days for those midges in their millions that gather in the dusk and the whining mosquito. But they deserve more than squashing. They are very good at what they do and their blood-sucking is only a part of a fascinating life-cycle.

Do all mosquitoes and midges feed on human blood?

No, for many mosquitoes and midges human blood is not the food of first choice. Not all mosquitoes need blood; some prefer specific animals such as birds, horses or cattle, and some will feed on almost anything. There are about 30 varieties of mosquito and hundreds of species of midge in Britain. The commonest British mozzie is called Culex pipens and it rarely bites people. Non-biting midges outnumber biters by over two to one.

Male mosquitoes and midges are harmless - they eat nectar from plants. The females need the blood before they can lay eggs, although some can lay their first batch without blood, so their survival is guaranteed.

How can you tell male and female midges and mosquitoes apart?

The males have feathery feelers (antennae). Male mosquitoes also make less noise. The females beat their wings about 400 times a second and create that characteristic whine.

Is it dangerous to be bitten by a mosquito or midge?

In many parts of the world it can be. Mosquitoes carry some of the planet's deadliest diseases, including malaria and yellow fever. It is estimated that over 400m people catch malaria every year and that nearly 2m people die as a result.

We are lucky in Britain. We only have four kinds of anopheline mosquito - the kind that can carry human malaria. But don't think you have to stay inside all summer. Malaria has died out in this country. Many of the wetlands which mosquitoes like have been drained and the temperatures here are too cold for the parasite that causes the malaria to survive.

It was not always so. Shakespeare is full of mentions of the "ague" and Oliver Cromwell may have died from the disease. Nowadays, the only outbreaks of malaria in Europe have occurred near airports thanks to infected mosquitoes hitching a lift here on aeroplanes.

Can you tell which mosquitoes are the anophelines?

At rest or when feeding, anopheline mosquitoes raise their tails in the air, while Culex mosquitoes hold their body parallel to the surface on which they stand.

How do mosquitoes and midges suck our blood?

Mosquito mouthparts are perfect for the job. They are needle-sharp. Mosquito and midge saliva contain chemicals that stop the blood from clotting so they can keep feeding. Mosquitoes also inject a kind of anaesthetic into us so we can't feel what is going on. Our bodies' immune system fights these chemicals and itchy lumps come up where we have been bitten.

Midges are less sophisticated. We can feel their bites because they have to saw their way into our skin with their stubby mouth-parts. Their advantage is that they are silent and small. In North America they are known as "noseeums".

Are some people more attractive to mosquitoes and midges?

Yes. Midges and mosquitoes seem to be attracted to the carbon dioxide gas we breathe out. They are also drawn to heat and to sweat. Research just out suggests that pregnant women are bitten more often - perhaps because they are generally hotter and smell differently or maybe because they have to get up more in the night.

How can you learn more?

You can find Culex pipens mosquito eggs and larvae in standing water - rainwater butts are a good place to look. Eggs can be found from April onwards forming rafts on the water surface. Collect them, keep them in a jar of water and watch their life cycle. Feed the larvae on small amounts of fish food, baby food or any other protein diet. When the mosquitoes appear, give them a stick to rest on and see if you can tell the males and the females apart. Put a few small holes in the top of the jar and place your hand over them. The females should fly up, attracted by the smell. It is not a good idea to let them feed on you!

There are mosquitoes and midges in literature. DH Lawrence wrote a poem to a mosquito, although he gets it wrong and calls the insect biting him "monsieur". John Keats writes about "a wailful choir" of small gnats in his Ode to Autumn.

Can you find any other references?

There are many midge, mosquito and malaria sites online.

 Search through the article archives

Malaria is explained at www.anopheles.com. Also see www.abdn.ac.uk/zoology. The Wellcome Trust magazine Wellcome News has devoted issue 21 to malaria and it includes an article about the history of the disease in England by Dr Mary Dobson.

 With thanks to Dr Peter Billingsley and Dr Jenny Mordue, both senior lecturers in the Department of Zoology at the University of Aberdeen.

webTitle: Ejércitos para la paz y para la guerra

fields.headline: Ejércitos para la paz y para la guerra
fields.standfirst: This year's military parade in Spain was outshone by a peace festival.  Eulàlia Furriol asks youngsters their views on the role of the army
fields.trailText: This year's military parade in Spain was outshone by a peace festival. Eulàlia Furriol asks youngsters their views on the role of the army
fields.body:
La polémica ha rodeado este año el tradicional desfile del ejército español en el Día de las Fuerzas Armadas. Más de doscientas asociaciones cívicas criticaron el desfile militar del 27 de mayo en Barcelona. Según ellos, era un "acto de apología militarista y de ostentación de armas".

Y contestaron la parada militar en Barcelona con la organización de un Festival por la Paz. El desfile fue contemplado por 20.000 personas. El Festival por la Paz reunió a 45.000 personas.

Cuál es la función y el futuro de los ejércitos en los países democráticos? Según el ministro de defensa del gobierno español, Federico Trillo, "ninguna democracia avanzada ha renunciado a sus fuerzas armadas. Cuando el sistema político es democrático y representativo, las Fuerzas Armadas defienden un Estado que representa a todos. Su tarea es la defensa de la comunidad". El ministro también defiende la contribución del ejército español "a la paz de otros pueblos".

Estás a favor de los desfiles militares? Por qué? Crees que los militares deben desfilar en las procesiones religiosas de Semana Santa?

Manuel Ortíz tiene 18 años, vive en Madrid y es militante de las juventudes del Partido Popular, actualmente en el gobierno: Estoy a favor de los desfiles militares. Es una tradición, y estoy a favor de mantener las tradiciones. Además en los desfiles la sociedad ve a dónde va el dinero de sus impuestos. En cuanto a las procesiones de Semana Santa, por qué no? Si es un ejército de paz, que tiene misiones humanitarias, entonces no hay contradicción.

Alex Pérez tiene 17 años, vive en Barcelona y pertenece al grupo scout de Sant Cugat del Vallés: Si un desfile es una demostración de poder y de armas, entonces no estoy a favor. Yo participé en el Festival por la Paz celebrado en el parque de la Ciutadella el día 27 de mayo. Mientras el ejército desfilaba en otro lado de la ciudad. Un ejército, en principio, es para defender a los ciudadanos. Pero en España, donde hay antecedentes de una dictadura militar, estos temas despiertan sensibilidades. Hay personas que interpretan el desfile militar por las calles de su ciudad como una amenaza al pueblo. En cuanto a las procesiones de Semana Santa, mezclar religión y armas es peligroso.

Qué función tiene hoy el ejército español? Qué función tienen los ejércitos en los países democráticos?

Manuel Ortíz: El ejército es la institución en España que más ha evolucionado desde la instauración de la democracia. Se ha adaptado al nuevo sistema y se ha transformado en un ejército de paz, que participa en misiones humanitarias. El ejército defiende el sistema democrático, sistema que defiende la gran mayoría de la sociedad española.

Además, el ejército hoy es nece sario para la protección de los ciudadanos. Tenemos que ser realistas. Ningún país está libre de un posible ataque por parte de otros países. También hemos visto la actuación del ejército en catástrofes, cuando hay una situación de alarma entre los ciudadanos, como inundaciones. Por último, el ejército tiene una labor de formación. Muchos jóvenes que quieren estudiar aviación o marina, por ejemplo, deciden entrar en el ejército. Es el único sistema para aprender a volar o navegar en un centro público. La alternativa es una escuela privada, donde cuesta unos ocho millones de pesetas.

Alex Pérez: El ejército tiene como función principal defendernos de cualquier ataque. Las acciones humanitarias es algo que se han sacado de la manga ahora los ejércitos. Para la solidaridad internacional no hace falta un ejército armado ni todo el dinero que cuesta. Si la misión principal es ayudar y construir una escuela, por ejemplo, lo pueden hacer personas que no estén preparadas para la defensa.

Crees que los ejércitos en los países democráticos deberían desaparecer en el futuro?

En España, por ejemplo, se dedican miles de millones al ejército y en cambio mucho menos dinero a la educación y a la sanidad. Los ejércitos deberían desaparecer y destinar sus presupuestos a educar en la paz. Este es el objetivo por el que deberíamos luchar. fields.bodyText: La polémica ha rodeado este año el tradicional desfile del ejército español en el Día de las Fuerzas Armadas. Más de doscientas asociaciones cívicas criticaron el desfile militar del 27 de mayo en Barcelona. Según ellos, era un "acto de apología militarista y de ostentación de armas". Y contestaron la parada militar en Barcelona con la organización de un Festival por la Paz. El desfile fue contemplado por 20.000 personas. El Festival por la Paz reunió a 45.000 personas. Cuál es la función y el futuro de los ejércitos en los países democráticos? Según el ministro de defensa del gobierno español, Federico Trillo, "ninguna democracia avanzada ha renunciado a sus fuerzas armadas. fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.trailText: What are the regulations on employing young people?
fields.body:
What are the regulations on employing young people? My daughter is 14 and has been working at the weekend as a waitress. Her employer would like her to work five days a week over the summer. Is this legal? I would like to know more about guidelines on hours and health and safety issues

The following guidelines are issued by the Department of Health, and cover the employment of children, ie those under 16 years old.

Children are not allowed to work at all before they are 13. At the age of 13, they will get an employment card issued by their local authority - no child can work without one of these.

Even at 13, children must not work for more than one hour before school, during school hours, before 7am or after 7pm. This may come as a surprise to some newsagents!

Children must not work for more than four hours without a break of at least one hour.

Children are prohibited from working in any "industrial undertaking" - eg in a factory, etc. Nor can they work in occupations prohibited by other legislation, such as in pubs. In general, children must not work in any job likely to be harmful to their health, well-being or education.

Local authorities can tell you about specific bylaws in your area. It is advisable to check the list of jobs your local authority permits, as no child may do any job unless it is on this list.

Budding actors or models, or other jobs in television, theatre or similar require a licence, issued by the local authority. Since 1998, this also applies to children employed in any sporting or advertising activity.

The law permits children to work for a maximum of only two hours on schooldays and on Sundays.

For children under 15, the law says they can work for up to five hours on a Saturday and/or weekdays during school holidays. For those of 15 or over, the maximum is eight hours. But both these are subject to an overall weekly limit - 25 hours for those under 15, 35 for those aged 15 or over.

Schoolchildren cannot work throughout the whole year. They must have at least two weeks off work during the school holiday.

A child may not legally leave school until the last Friday in June of the school year during which they reach the age of 16, or if his/her 16th birthday falls after that date but before the start of the next school year.

For young workers who are above the minimum school-leaving age but under 18, many of the same regulations apply as for adults, with some important exceptions. These come under the remit of the Department of Trade and Industry.

Amongst these is the fact that young workers are entitled to 12 uninterrupted rest hours in each 24-hour period in which they work.

Young workers are entitled to two days off each week. This cannot be averaged over a two-week period. If the nature of the job makes it unavoidable, a young worker's weekly time off can be reduced to 36 hours.

If a young worker is required to work for more than four and a half hours at a stretch, s/he is entitled to a rest break of 30 minutes.

If a young person is working for more than one employer, the time s/he is working for them should be added together to judge whether they are entitled to a rest break.

At present, the national minimum wage applies only to workers of 18 or over. The minimum hourly rate for 18- to 21-year-olds is £3.20 as of June 2000.

 For help on matters to do with working time limits and health assessments, contact the health and safety executive Infoline on 0541 545500, or the environmental health department of your local authority. Your local authority would also be the first port of call for help regarding employment card/licence inquiries and bylaws.

Next week's query

My daughter is extremely able, with ambitions to become a vet. I'm concerned that local state schools won't be able to give her the academic education that she'd enjoy and ultimately benefit from in terms of entering top universities. I'd like her to go to the excellent, local public school that many of her friends attend, but I cannot afford it, even with a scholarship. What can I do?

fields.headline: Trendsetter
fields.standfirst: John Crace meets a woman who has been going to college for over half a century
fields.trailText: John Crace meets a woman who has been going to college for over half a century
fields.body:
Malcolm Wicks wasn't even a twinkle in his parents' eyes when Elsie Pratt first grasped the concept of lifelong learning. In fact, Mr Wicks' parents may even have been at school themselves, though no one can be too sure as it was a long time ago and Elsie is a little hazy on dates these days. Suffice to say that Elsie is the wrong side of 90 and she turned up for her first evening class roughly 60 years ago.

Elsie was born and brought up near Wakefield and left school at 13. "I wanted to go into medicine and be a doctor or nurse," she says, "but my mother wanted me to go into weaving." Her father had been killed in a mining accident when she was six, and her mother's word was law. So weaving it was, and Elsie's lasting memory of the work is not the boredom, but the dirt. "The conditions were filthy," she remarks.

She got married at 19 and stopped work for a time while she brought up her children. Not that she was idle, though, as she was forever knitting, darning and mending clothes. But she never made anything from scratch, because no one had ever taught her how to. Until her mother died.

"My mother had this old treadle sewing machine that none of us knew how to use," she recalls, "and I ended up with it. I thought I'd better learn what to do with it. I was greatly encouraged by my next-door neighbour, who worked for Jessops, the local tailors. She was only allowed to do button holes at work and was very keen to learn how to cut patterns and make clothes, so she persuaded me to join her at evening classes in Batley".

If it was curiosity that got her through the classroom door, it was economic self-interest that helped to keep her there, as the results of her labours clothed herself and her children. In between returning to weaving and working as a barmaid after her husband died, Elsie continued to make appearances at various local evening classes and she has been a regular visitor to Dewsbury College ever since adult education became part of its remit in the early 1960s.

"Elsie comes in for sewing classes every Monday afternoon," says Dave Robinson, Dewsbury's adult education coordinator. "These days, I think, she comes as much for the social life as anything else, but she is a huge inspiration to our other older learners."

Social it may be, but Elsie is still pretty handy with a needle, and cutting out a pattern on the college tables is a great deal simpler than rearranging the furniture of a one-bedroomed flat and scrabbling on the floor. And she is prolific, as she seldom stops, even when she is watching TV.

Her only problem is that she is running out of people to make things for, as her grandchildren just don't recognise the name Elsie Pratt as a designer label. Which just leaves Elsie herself, and her flat is packed with three wardrobes of her own creations. "I don't like wearing the same things over and over again," she says ruefully, "but my son reckons that I'm running out of storage space."

fields.headline: Basic skills for society
fields.standfirst: Small print is best for boosting adult literacy, says  Andrea Mearing
fields.trailText: Small print is best for boosting adult literacy, says Andrea Mearing
fields.body:
The government is promising an extra £1m to boost basic skills through "financial literacy" and "citizenship". But what has citizenship got to do with the problem of the seven million adults with poor basic skills?

At the Basic Skills Agency we have been working in the community for long enough to know just how important "citizenship" and "community" are for encouraging people to learn.

Adults want to improve their basic skills for many different reasons; some to help them get a job or gain promotion, some so that they can read to their children and help with homework. But there are other important reasons that are not so obvious and straightforward.

People with poor basic skills are vulnerable consumers and they're often excluded citizens. They are likely to have the least money and the greatest need to be able to compare prices and read the small print. They are most likely to fall prey to loan sharks and dodgy deals. To get by in life a little better and not be exploited is a strong motivation to do something about your poor literacy or numeracy.

Life for a consumer is not simple. No longer do you sign up for your gas from the local gas board, but choose between 60 different companies. Being a tenant requires complex knowledge of rights and finances. Tenants need to read tenancy agreements and handbooks, fill in forms for utilities and benefits, deal with bills and negotiate with landlords over repairs and conditions. Increasingly, they are being encouraged to attend meetings, complete survey forms and get involved in community consultation exercises. People with poor basic skills are often intimidated by the reading and writing involved in all this and opt out altogether.

Poor skills stop people getting involved in their communities. Improving these essential skills, the agency's work conclusively shows, breaks down barriers to social exclusion. Through the Adult and Community Learning Fund, we have seen hostel residents with improved basic skills now willing to contribute to house meetings; parents on skills courses in family centres getting keen to organise a parent-toddler group; tenants who've done a meeting-skills course joining the residents action group; young probation clients on a basic skills and IT course producing an in-house newsletter; people completing a numeracy course being encouraged to join the credit union. These examples are commonplace.

With help from Citizens Advice Bureaux workers and Refugee Council tutors, the agency has developed Citizen 2000, a course which puts skills into context and motivates people to learn by making them real. To improve reading, the course uses material people come across every day - circulars, letters from social security, notices from local councillors and community newsletters. By giving people the skills to read and understand such literature, we know that they are more likely to respond to local campaigns, contribute to local initiatives, speak up at meetings, take on roles in local community groups and perhaps even vote.

Learners are prompted into debate and discussion, to use the web to find out more, to differentiate between fact and opinion, to write letters to officials, to take accurate minutes at meetings and much more.

To tackle the terrible basic skills problems in this country, learning must be taken into people's communities and made relevant to the people who are actually going to take part in it. Perhaps only then will we see the real sense of community re-established in Britain today and a level of literacy and numeracy that is acceptable for an industrialised country in the 21st century.

 Andrea Mearing is assistant director (Adult and Community Learning Fund) of the Basic Skills Agency.

fields.headline: In sickness and in health
fields.standfirst: It's not the ill who goes sick, says  Janet Jones
fields.trailText: It's not the ill who goes sick, says Janet Jones
fields.body:
"You are through to The College Sickness Line," says the recorded voice. It is the last place most of us would wish to be.

I did have one colleague whose father died three times - requiring him to get on the Sickness Line three times - which made a heavy demand on staff-room indulgence. And it's curious in retrospect how tolerant we were. I don't think we even discussed it. He might have been sired by a phoenix, after all. But most of us do all we can to stay off the Sickness Line and we can be found at work when we should be on the Sickness Line.

You can see us ailing all over the place: bent double, pale green, nursing parts of ourselves; pockets full of pills, resting on the staff-room floor; propped up by "lunch" in the pub, breathing fumes of alcohol and smoke; eyes dilating, hallucinating. But not on the Sickness Line. Not Off Sick.

Of course, nobody warms to us when we struggle in to teach with an "off-sickness" which, then, spreads itself among the rest of us: the gastric condition: "I had a bag ready for when I was sick on the train coming in," and a grimace of achievement; the cough and splutter: "I got it from my cousin at the weekend," and segments of damp tissue straying down the corridor; the unidentified blemishes: "Do you think it's ringworm?" and revelations of bare arm; an itchy scalp: "There are nits in the children's school." The pink eyes glued up with infection: "I can still see." Even, once, "I thought I would be all right this morning," as she is carried down the stairs on a stretcher to an ambulance waiting at the gate. And so we avoid off-sickness at nearly all costs.

We are strong on alternative health care: acupuncture, osteopa thy, health farms... herbal... colonic... And we are into alternative spiritual welfare, too: we retreat. We meditate.

We pay this price for a reason. We cling on through our own off-sickness to reserve our off-sickness for our children. An off-sick child has more power to bring a teacher to the Sickness Line than anything else I know. Who can abandon a child who is off sick? Who can walk out of their house to their college of further education leaving an off-sick child alone at home? Thus off sick remains, though off sick with our children rather than off sick with ourselves. It is a recognised status.

The off-sick house can be left to the faulty ballcock and the lightning and the burglars. The off-sick cat can be packed in a cardboard box in the car in the college car park. The off-sick elder can be tucked up by the kettle and the telephone and the television. But the off-sick child? You used to see them wrapped in a sleeping bag under a parental desk on a staff-room floor, cared for by whoever was in the room: "...a drink?... the toilet?... your dad won't be long."

Those were the days when further education was more laid back and less incorporated. There were no sickness lines then. And if you were the child of a phoenix you were ignored.

Who can walk out of their house to their college of further education leaving an off-sick child alone at home? Thus off sick remains, though off sick with our children rather than off sick with ourselves. It is a recognised status. The off-sick house can be left to the faulty ballcock and the lightning and the burglars. The off-sick cat can be packed in a cardboard box in the car in the college car park. The off-sick elder can be tucked up by the kettle and the telephone and the television. But the off-sick child? You used to see them wrapped in a sleeping bag under a parental desk on a staff-room floor, cared for by whoever was in the room: "...a drink?... the toilet?... your dad won't be long." Those were the days when further education was more laid back and less incorporated. There were no sickness lines then. And if you were the child of a phoenix you were ignored.

fields.headline: It's summer!
fields.standfirst: Nick Raistrick gives his revision tips for lifelong learners
fields.trailText: Nick Raistrick gives his revision tips for lifelong learners
fields.body:
Being an adult student can give you the advantage at exam time as increasing forgetfulness is offset by a mature approach to study, improved organisation skills, and general knowledge acquired through years of experience. Not to mention the fact that you get invited to fewer parties than you used to. Here are a few tips to get you through the revision.

First, stay focused. Being a "bit older" at exam time gives you a greater armoury of displacement activities than you had when studying for O levels. Avoid grill-cleaning, shed-tidying and taxation paperwork during revision time. Of course, there are bona fide distractions, such as family and work commitments, that need to be juggled. There is a real risk that your offspring will sue for emotional trauma and neglect in 20 years time, on the grounds that you elected to spend long periods of "quality time" preparing for examinations, instead of shopping for Pokémon cards.

Beware impractical advice. For example, "take a five minute walk around the block every 50 minutes" can easily become reversed, particularly when you get chatting to the newsagent/window cleaner/Jehovah's witnesses.

I have actually managed to find the mythical "quiet place to revise, free from distractions", but neighbours do tend to think you are an undercover policeman if you spend too long in the car.

Be honest with yourself, and work at your own pace. The timetable you drew up months ago should not dictate how long you spend on a topic, if you have not covered it adequately: remember this isn't a board meeting.

If you spend an evening multi-tasking (that is, listening to Radio 4, looking out of the window, and making telephone calls) as the margin doodles get bigger and more complex, don't fill in "five hours" on your time sheet (unless you are training to be an accountant). A syllabus is generally more realistic than a timetable, as you can't predict how long it will take you to learn something.

Use your life experience. If you are taking a course in, say, modern history, it can be helpful, though scary, to actually remember the events described in your textbook. In subjects where you need to learn a lot of dates, you will have more mnemonic material stored away somewhere. Linking the decline in the Callaghan administration to the 1978 World Cup will give you one up on students who can't remember life without answer machines, colour newspapers and TV remote controls.

The downside is that your head may get over full and, unfortunately, you can't (yet) erase irrelevant files from the hard disk of your brain, however tempting the idea might be.

Don't fight the system. How often in real life do you have to write down everything you know about a particular subject in a limited amount of time, whilst pandering to the whims and prejudices of an imagined reader you will never meet? It seems a poor preparation for any job, except journalism. The only solution is to approach exams with a zen-like calm, safe in the knowledge you aren't actually going to change the system. This, along with your neat, erect handwriting and awareness of apostrophes will set you apart from your peers.

Learn only the sections you are guaranteed to need for your exam, don't try to be too clever in your answers and ask your tutor for as many past papers as you can get hold of. Make sure you give yourself a "mock" - it's easy to forget how to write using a pen. Make sure you can find one that works on the day of the exam.

Finally, tell your friends. Unlike your younger classmates, it's likely the people around you aren't doing exams - they might even be interested in what you're up to. Grasp this opportunity. As you try to explain internal auditing/the repeal of the corn laws/whatever to your partner, you are actually testing your own knowledge as well as their patience.

A layperson's questions on what you are revising can highlight any areas that you don't fully understand. It also helps to counter exam apathy, a stage you are likely to reach. It could be that your "exam buddy" is the one who reminds you to turn up on the big day.

fields.headline: An injection of energy
fields.standfirst: In his second report from Japan,  Donald MacLeod discovers a yearning for creativity and relevance in once-stagnant universities
fields.trailText: In his second report from Japan, Donald MacLeod discovers a yearning for creativity and relevance in once-stagnant universities
fields.body:
Japanese students have a word for it. A "freeter" is someone doing a series of casual jobs after leaving university or high school, and staying free from a company career. It is a sign that things are changing from the days when graduates filed from campus into the most prestigious firm they could and stayed there. The job for life is disappearing and students know it.

So they are beginning to want more from university - traditionally seen as a four-year doss between intensive cramming at school and a workaholic career - and the government is certainly beginning to demand more from the country's higher education institutions. It wants to see more intitiative from academics when it comes to research and links with industry - at present, staff at the main public universities are civil servants - and it wants to see universities fostering the ability of students to think for themselves.

The 21st century will be unpredictable territory and, in one of the seismic shifts that seem to occur in Japanese society from time to time, schools, universities, government ministers and business leaders are all talking about the need to develop imagination and initiative. (The contrast with England's drive for basic skills measured by more and more tests is striking.)

"The future of this country depends on our brains - we have no natural resources," said Masao Homma, director general for policy at the education ministry.

Institutions will also have to think for themselves if the government's plan to make them independent agencies is carried through after this Sunday's general election. (A reshuffle of ministers but no great changes in policy is the most common prediction.)

The country's 650 universities are nervous about the future, it seemed to me. Not all are enthusiastic about the government's proposed reforms. Shigehiko Hasumi, president of Tokyo University, which is considered the most prestigious and difficult to get into, said he did not call them "reforms" because all the government's reforms had been unsuccessful. Being given the legal status of an independent body (as a British university has) would allow public universities to earn more income from research - at present it goes into to the coffers of the education ministry. But ministers' chief motive was simply to cut the number of civil servants by altering the status of 100,000 academics, said Hasumi. There would be a lot of upheaval with few results.

More fundamental is Japan's steeply declining birthrate. It has fallen from 13.6 per 1,000 of the population in 1980, to 10.0 in 1990 and 9.6 in 1998. Unlike Britain, which is struggling to raise participation in higher education to 50%, Japan has been at this level for years. In addition to the large number of universities - 80% of them private - there are about 600 junior colleges. Competition to get into the best universities has been intense, though work is said to slacken off once students arrive. University is hard to get into but easy to get out of (ie graduate from), say the Japanese. There is jubilation and despair when Tokyo University posts the lists of entrants - successful candidates are tossed in the air.

Tokyo is still a magnet but some universities are struggling to keep up admissions, and by 2009 there will be enough higher education places for every single 18-year-old. Clearly not all these institutions will survive. On one prediction, more than 100 will go bankrupt or be merged by the education ministry. Applications for some of the big private universities like Keio and Nihon have dropped by a third since 1992.

This is easing the exam hell for students. It is university entrance exams which dominate the senior years of high school. A typical student might sit four or five entrance exams at a cost of £250 each - a handy source of income for the universities and part of the country's large exam-coaching industry - and the exam format has reinforced rigid teaching methods in schools.

Some universities have reacted by cutting fees. (Japanese parents pay such whopping fees to both public and private universities - students themselves are not expected to go into debt - that it is tempting to speculate that it is the cost of higher education that has cut the birth rate so drastically.) The first year at Keio, a well respected university in Tokyo, would set you back £6,700 (including a £2,000 entrance fee); it is £4,800 at Tokyo University, one of the national (public) institutions.

Others, like Hosei, a 120-year-old private university in Tokyo, are relying on revamped courses to attract applicants. Its president, Tadao Kiyonari, is proud applications have held up and attributes this to new degrees like intercultural communication, and computer science. Numbers choosing traditional subjects like literature or economics have fallen as students and employers demand more vocational education.

None of the students I spoke to at Hosei expected to go into a company for life. The university is also offering a one-year masters for computer professionals, which has attracted a lot of 30-year-olds who had quit their firms, said Professor Kiyonari. He added proudly that a quarter of the students on the course were starting their own companies, and a third were women.

Hosei is starting an American outpost in California's Silicon Valley to tap into high-tech business and academic talent there. Professor Kiyonari thinks international collaborations will increase so postgraduates can do half their credits in Japan and half, say, in the US.

Few foreign students attend Japanese universities but the government wants this to change. Language has been a problem. British universities have been choosy about which institutions they associate with, believing the quality to be variable, and Universitas 21, the international grouping of leading research universities, has signed up three Chinese members - Beijing, Fudan and Hong Kong - but none in Japan. Talks are understood to be under way with Kyoto University.

When it comes to research, Japan has a reputation for checking and replicating results from scientists elsewhere, and it rankles with academics that companies award research contracts abroad. The pharmaceutical company Yoshitomi, for instance, recently opened a £2m laboratory with Glasgow and Strathclyde to develop drugs for schizophrenia.

The government's response has been to announce an assessment modelled on Britain's Research Assessment Exercise to sort out the wheat from the chaff, implying that government funding will soon become more selective. Teaching will also be evaluated. A succession of British vice-chancellors has been describing the pros and cons of the RAE and teaching quality assessments, but with a generally positive message.

Academics are nervous about this, admits Tsutomo Kimura, president of the National Institute of Academic Degrees and Evaluation. "We have evaluations of different countries and our conclusion is that the British system would suit us best."

Taking universities out of the civil service would mean academics could be paid more on merit and less on seniority, and give more power to principals. Would Japan see the growth of short-term contracts for researchers and lecturers? "The British system is a little too radical for us," said Kimura. He thought the American system where staff could work towards secure tenure would be better.
