fields.headline: Case shut
fields.standfirst: College's deal with ex-principal revives secrecy fears
fields.trailText: College's deal with ex-principal revives secrecy fears
fields.body:
Cricklade College has settled its former principal's claim for unfair dismissal but won't disclose details, despite ministers' demands that its governors and managers become more open with staff.

The college's acting principal Elizabeth Blakemore says she cannot discuss the case because of a confidentiality clause.

But sources stress that any financial payment to Richard Evans, the former principal, would have been very modest.

Evans was suspended in March 1998 after a police inquiry into information technology training projects paid for by the European Social Fund. No charges were brought, and when Evans was dismissed in July last year for bringing the college "into disrepute", the governors said they were satisfied that he thought he had been acting in its best interests.

Staff learnt last week that his claim was over in a one-sentence letter from the chair of governors. This merely said that the case against Cricklade by Evans had been "withdrawn".

The letter's brevity and choice of words led some staff to assume that the ex-principal had simply dropped his claim.

But when an official of Natfhe, the lecturers' union, then rang the employment tribunal at Southampton, where the hearing was due to start last Wednesday, he was informed that the case had already been "settled out of court".

This suggested to Natfhe officials that the college was flouting a key finding of a recent inquiry into Cricklade, which was ordered by the education secretary David Blunkett.

The inquiry, headed by Sir Patrick Lowry, former chairman of ACAS, the Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service, criticised the college for its lack of openness following the former principal's departure. Governors should have realised that "rumour, innuendo and gossip about sleaze and corruption would fill the vacuum" which their silence would create.

Sir Patrick's report, published at the end of May, recommended that the college review its policies on openness and on handling sensitive issues.

The report concluded that there had been mismanagement at Cricklade, but acknowledged that improvements had since been made.

Sources at the college said that under its acting principal, Elizabeth Blakemore, normality had been restored to Cricklade and that many staff were happy to accept the brief note about the conclusion of Evans' claim.

The letter, signed by the chair of governors, Paul Jarrett, said: "I'm writing to inform you that the employment tribunal hearing involving the former principal will not proceed and the case has been withdrawn."

But Natfhe members at the college voted at a meeting on Friday to seek more information from the governors.

One said: "It looks as if we're getting more of the same lack of openness highlighted in the Lowry report.

"The one sentence which is contradicted by what we've now heard from the employment tribunal is simply not adequate in an issue of such importance.'

Union members are particularly sensitive about any settlement with the former principal because the college recently won cases for unfair dismissal brought by a Natfhe negotiator Andrew Murray and two colleagues.

But college sources said that all tribunal claims against the college were handed over to its insurers and their lawyers. They took over the conduct of each case and would decide, for instance, whether it would be cheaper for the college to settle rather than bear the costs of a hearing, one explained. "Only they know the details of what has been decided in this case."

Tonight, the Cricklade governors meet to discuss the Lowry report's recommendations.

A DfEE spokeswoman said: "We would expect the governors fully to implement the recommendations of the Lowry report and be open and transparent in all issues, particularly in relation to staff and student matters."

fields.headline: A popular chap
fields.standfirst: A ukulele-playing music student is about to breach a formidable Oxford barrier
fields.trailText: A ukulele-playing music student is about to breach a formidable Oxford barrier
fields.body:
Another seismic tremor will rock Oxford University at about teatime this afternoon, when a student in academic dress flips open his ukulele case.

This latest upheaval will be less of a bang than a series of twangs and might not make quite the impact of the burning of the Oxford martyrs, or the first four-minute mile. But it will shake the university more than any wild words from Gordon Brown.

For Andy Eastwood, a third-year music undergraduate, has done the unthinkable. He has sought and won permission to perform and sing a medley of ukulele numbers, including some of the greatest hits by his idol George Formby and the Charlston, as part of his degree.

Performance is one of the optional final papers in the Oxford music course, which must be the most academic and dusty around. Students who opt to give a recital for the examiners have always played instruments used for what is loosely termed classical music. Most years see a fair bag of organ recitals.

Indeed Eastwood, a 21-year-old student at New College, had originally been sawing away for hours on his fiddle, preparing a recital programme which was to include the celebrated Franck violin sonata.

But the violin is his second instrument. His first love has been the ukulele, ever since as a tot he had heard his grandad play it. He has been playing it from the age of nine and, since his teens, has been much in demand to play the ukulele at parties and other social events. He wants to make a career of it and has cut his first CD, whose first track is the Formby classic: Leaning on a Lamp-post.

"My tutor one day asked me why didn't I play the ukulele for finals," Eastwood says. "I'd never considered it seriously. I'd simply assumed that it wouldn't be eligible. Nobody's ever done anything before which wasn't a classical instrument or classical singing. And the repertoire is completely alien to the course because it's all popular stuff."

After giving the matter further thought he came to the conclusion that there was no good argument against the ukulele.

"We can't ignore this repertoire today. It's part of history and part of musical language. There have been so many crossovers in music this century - it's got to be reappraised by musicologists."

All fine and reasonable, but would the examiners see it his way? He set out his arguments in a letter to the examiners in February.

According to Eastwood it would have been easy for the examiners to turn him down. He reckons that their brave decision now breaches what has effectively been a barrier against popular music in the Oxford course. "They took a little while to discuss my request, and then their answer came back. Fine. Go ahead."

So this afternoon, in the Holywell Music Room tucked away behind his college, he will launch into Leaning on a Lamp-post, When I'm Cleaning Windows, Little Ukulele and the rest of his programme from the instrument's heyday in the 1920s and 30s. Wearing a dark suit, white bow tie and gown - the Oxford subfusc (academic dress) which has to be donned for exams - won't bother him. He usually plays in a suit, or blazer - classic wear for the ukulele player of the Jazz Age. And given that his audiences are often studded with party frocks, he shouldn't be fazed by the gorgeous robes worn by the examiners, who will include at least two specialists in medieval music.

The former comprehensive schoolboy, who did his A levels at Bournemouth and Poole further education college, hopes friends will come along and support him. Audiences are permitted at the recitals, but they must wear academic dress.

Which will all be very grand for an instrument which, he says, takes its name from the Hawaiian for "jumping insect". Eastwood says "ukulele" rather than the often found "ukelele" is correct. The four-stringed instrument originated in Portugal, and from there it was taken to Hawaii in the late 19th century and became popular.

The ukulele featured in a Hawaiian exhibition in San Francisco in 1915 and before long it became popular in the US. This was the start of the Jazz Age and the ukulele became a jazz instrument. The invention of an offshoot, the ukulele-banjo, with a round not guitar-shaped body, boosted the craze. Since the second world war it has fallen into obscurity; in Britain it became an instrument almost entirely for amateur enthusiasts.

fields.bodyText: Another seismic tremor will rock Oxford University at about teatime this afternoon, when a student in academic dress flips open his ukulele case. This latest upheaval will be less of a bang than a series of twangs and might not make quite the impact of the burning of the Oxford martyrs, or the first four-minute mile. But it will shake the university more than any wild words from Gordon Brown. For Andy Eastwood, a third-year music undergraduate, has done the unthinkable. He has sought and won permission to perform and sing a medley of ukulele numbers, including some of the greatest hits by his idol George Formby and the Charlston, as part of his degree. Performance is one of the optional final papers in the Oxford music course, which must be the most academic and dusty around. Students who opt to give a recital for the examiners have always played instruments used for what is loosely termed classical music. Most years see a fair bag of organ recitals. Indeed Eastwood, a 21-year-old student at New College, had originally been sawing away for hours on his fiddle, preparing a recital programme which was to include the celebrated Franck violin sonata. But the violin is his second instrument. His first love has been the ukulele, ever since as a tot he had heard his grandad play it. He has been playing it from the age of nine and, since his teens, has been much in demand to play the ukulele at parties and other social events. He wants to make a career of it and has cut his first CD, whose first track is the Formby classic: Leaning on a Lamp-post. "My tutor one day asked me why didn't I play the ukulele for finals," Eastwood says. "I'd never considered it seriously. I'd simply assumed that it wouldn't be eligible. After giving the matter further thought he came to the conclusion that there was no good argument against the ukulele. "We can't ignore this repertoire today. It's part of history and part of musical language. There have been so many crossovers in music this century - it's got to be reappraised by musicologists." All fine and reasonable, but would the examiners see it his way? He set out his arguments in a letter to the examiners in February. According to Eastwood it would have been easy for the examiners to turn him down. He reckons that their brave decision now breaches what has effectively been a barrier against popular music in the Oxford course. "They took a little while to discuss my request, and then their answer came back. Fine. Go ahead." So this afternoon, in the Holywell Music Room tucked away behind his college, he will launch into Leaning on a Lamp-post, When I'm Cleaning Windows, Little Ukulele and the rest of his programme from the instrument's heyday in the 1920s and 30s. He usually plays in a suit, or blazer - classic wear for the ukulele player of the Jazz Age. fields.headline: Classic revival
fields.standfirst: It's high time the old favourites among children's books were resurrected; Jane Nissen is doing just that
fields.trailText: It's high time the old favourites among children's books were resurrected; Jane Nissen is doing just that
fields.body:
There's a notice outside Jane Nissen's 18th-century riverside home in west London: Please shut the gate. High tide today. Flooding. Sure enough, quite soon, the whole road is submerged and ducks swim merrily among the marooned cars. Immediately (if you're not in a hurry) there's a sense of adventure: the water lapping round the gateposts recalls the opening chapter of The Children of Green Knowe. And, inside, the clock in the cool stone-flagged hall makes me think of Tom's Midnight Garden.

Appropriate really, for, as Jane Nissen tells me, she's always been obsessed with children's books: they've been part of her life at every stage: as a "very bookish" child in America, as a mother (she married an Englishman and has four children) as a grandmother, and, of course, as a publisher with a long and distinguished career in children's books. She started off at Puffin. "Kaye Webb was a neighbour. She had acquired a boat and she knocked on the door one day, in the sixties, to ask if she could park it in our front garden, on the river. I said yes, if you'll take me on as a reader..."

Thirty years on, in 1998, when Jane retired from Hamish Hamilton, she had no intention of putting her feet up. With seemingly boundless energy, and in addition to the work she still does as a consultant and editor, she has set up her own imprint to revive a personal selection of books that are out of print but which, she believes, have a lot to offer today's children.

It's an enterprise well in tune with the times - the turn of the century has prompted many publishers to examine their backlists and even, as Fiona Kenshole at OUP tells me, to ransack their own bookshelves for ideas. "Classic is the new buzzword," she says and, across the board, dozens of modern classics have been given a new look. Ann Jungman's new imprint, Barn Owl Books, is bringing back relatively recent books that have gone out of print, and, increasingly, in new fiction there's a return to longer, literary books.

"I feel that quality is coming back into fashion," says Jane Nissen - "of course, we've always had a huge number of wonderful writers but, for too long, they've been up against a rising tide of, well, less 'challenging' books. And, while I'd certainly never condemn all those 'series' books - because they undoubtedly get children reading - I do think that there has been a radical change.

"Yes, certainly JK Rowling has made a huge difference, and another important factor was Philip Pullman's rousing acceptance speech when he won the Carnegie medal in 1996 with Northern Lights - and we should thank David Fickling at Scholastic for daring to publish that trilogy - which, in spite of its length and complexity, has proved that children can cope with long, demanding books. It allowed the doors to swing open, and it's clear that there's a hunger for longer, all-engrossing books by writers of real substance. And that's why I feel that it's now possible to bring back classics from the 1940s, and even earlier, which still have a lot to say. Of course there's an element of risk, but publishing's a risky business."

Nissen works from home, with a huge desk at the kitchen window. The four titles in the first batch of Jane Nissen Books are laid out on the kitchen table like freshly baked cakes - alongside their well-thumbed original editions. Apart from Alison Uttley's enchanting autobiographical book The Country Child (1931), with its beautiful Tunnicliffe illustrations, the books are all from the forties, and give intriguing insight into the preoccupations and curious freedom of children in that pre-TV world.

A feature - almost a prerequisite - of children's fiction of this period is the absence of parents; they're either dead, at war or away on long voyages. Their place is taken by governesses, maiden aunts and hopeless clergymen whose fate it is to be repeatedly out-witted by their charges.

Brendon Chase by BB (aka Denys Watkins Pitchford) is about two brothers whose parents are away in India. Scorning their aunt, they run away from home to live wild in the forest. Inspired by Robin Hood, and equipped not just with the knives that in those days were part of every boy's personal armoury, but also a rifle stolen from the gardener, the boys shoot birds, rabbits, a deer, a badger and a pig. With a ruthless efficiency that their fictional contemporaries, William Brown and his Outlaws, would have given their eye teeth for, the boys cook and eat their prey and make crude garments from the skins.

How attitudes have changed! In these days of gentle TV animal rescue programmes and ongoing concern over fox-hunting, it's hard to imagine a more challenging subject. As Philip Pullman writes in his enthusiastic introduction: "This is the sort of book that will never be written again..." And that's why it is such a bold, intriguing choice. The boys respond to their surroundings with a primeval survival instinct and BB (who also did the illustrations) magically combines a lyrical appreciation of the natural world with a practical, unsentimental understanding of it.

Interestingly, Jane Nissen read this very English book as an 11-year-old in America. "I was given it when I was sent away on my own to a ranch in Wyoming, to recover from an illness. I was thrilled by the idea of these boys surviving in the wild, it made a deep impression on me."

Another book she grew up with was Mistress Masham's Repose by TH White (though, again, very English, it was first published in the US). Full of classical/literary allusions, it's a fantasy about 10-year-old Maria, who discovers a community of Lilliputians in the grounds of her family estate. As Anne Fine says in her introduction, this was her "perfect" book. "It has everything I could have wanted: a resourceful orphan heiress, a hidden will, a sneaky, grasping vicar, a spiteful kitten-drowning governess, dangers and chases, imprisonments and revelations."

The funniest of these books is The Wind On The Moon by Eric Linklater - a wildly eccentric adventure of two sisters who set out on a complicated mission to rescue their father from prison in an enemy country. With a motley crew of characters, including not only the obligatory governess but also a splendid dancing master, this is a gloriously unpredictable tale of escalating bad behaviour, magical transformations, slapstick humour, sophisticated satire and, throughout, a war-time preoccupation with food, involving irresistibly detailed lists. With his customary wit and calligraphic elegance, Nicholas Bentley drew the pictures.

Offering adventure, fantasy, humour and romance, this is an inspired, unusual collection of books, with wide appeal (from around eight to adult) that goes way beyond the obvious lure of nostalgia, and Nissen talks about them with a protective passion. Hunting them down, and coaxing them out of retirement, has been hard work.

"I've learned a lot of things I didn't know before, about design, production and the actual physical making of the book." Wisely, she wanted neither newly commissioned artwork nor fusty facsimiles for the covers - instead, the designer, using modern technology, has created bold, beautifully coloured jackets from the original black and white illustrations. "I love the fact that we've been able to make something new from something old; and to see these books in the bookshop, ready for a whole new generation of readers is, I think, to see the future holding hands with the past."

 Mistress Masham's Repose by T H White, illustrated by Fritz Eichenburg; Brendon Chase by BB, illustrated by Denys Watkins-Pitchford; The Wind On The Moon by Eric Linklater, illustrated by Nicholas Bentley; The Country Child by Alison Uttley, illustrated by CF Tunnicliffe. All published by Jane Nissen Books at £5.99.

fields.headline: The fees facade
fields.standfirst: Fees are doing nothing to improve universities' financial crisis
fields.trailText: Fees are doing nothing to improve universities' financial crisis
fields.body:
Students are being shortchanged by tuition fees, student leaders have complained, as universities brace themselves for further cuts in teaching budgets when the Whitehall spending review concludes next month. Despite receiving an extra £400m a year in private contributions from student fees, university chiefs are warning that ministers plan to impose further cuts to the funds allocated per student over the next three years.

Already universities have to face annual 1% efficiency cuts in student funds. But according to academic leaders, treasury officials are now considering cuts of up to 3% as they finalise future spending plans for government departments. This will effectively mean that none of the revenue raised by charging tuition fees will be used to improve university facilities.

"Tuition fees have not solved the funding crisis in higher education," said Richard Darlington from the National Union of Students. "Under this government there have been cuts in funding per student which have only exposed the fact that fees are a failed policy. Clearly if there are to be further cuts students are going to be further shortchanged - they are getting less for their money."

Treasury civil servants believe that many universities can still reduce the costs of teaching students, particularly as student class numbers increase. A scrutiny of how academics split their time between teaching, research and other duties has revealed a wide variation in the time and money spent on teaching students in different institutions.

During the early stages of the government's spending review, there were promising signs that university research budgets might be boosted when a special overarching review panel was established to explore ways of exploiting science and research. But the purse strings were suddenly tightened when the prime minister, Tony Blair, announced new spending commitments to improve the NHS.

Unlike the previous spending review three years ago, universities will also not benefit from extra funds from the Wellcome Trust, which has said it will not support another joint government scheme for research facilities. Any extra research funds announced next month are likely to be targeted on specific academic topics: information technology, genomics, environmental science and business links.

Yet the spectre of further teaching cuts in particular has fuelled further calls to allow universities to charge higher fees than the current nationally set flat rate of £1,025 a year. At the end of this month the 19 elite universities of the Russell group will publish a report by economists. Among other funding options it will propose a free-market system for student fees and recruitment to avert a financial crisis in universities. Under such a system, students could eventually pay up to £50,000 in tuition fees for top university degrees as they do in the US.

One of the Russell group heads, University of Nottingham vice-chancellor Sir Colin Campbell, said that fees needed to be explored in the current funding climate. He was speaking during a debate at Nottingham last Friday organised by the Association of University Teachers.

MPs are due to hear evidence today from Peter Lampl, chairman of the Sutton Trust, a charity aiming to improve access into universities. The issue of whether students are getting value for money for the fees they pay, particularly if fees are to rise, will be investigated in the House of Commons education committee inquiry into the higher education sector.

fields.headline: All change for no change
fields.trailText: Regulations on performance management in schools will take effect in September. Governing bodies have a significant role.
fields.body:
Regulations on performance management in schools will take effect in September. Governing bodies have a significant role. They will have to construct a school policy that establishes an appraisal system for all teachers. This policy will:

 describe roles and responsibilities of key stakeholders - the chair, the head, middle managers, teachers and other governors;

 require two governors to carry out the appraisal of the headteacher by December 1 2000;

 require an external adviser to support the two governors through the process;

 require review officers who will hear complaints from teachers (including the head) who are dissatisfied with their appraisals - all of whom have to be appraised by February 28 2001;

 determine a fair system of resolving such complaints; and

 require an annual report from the head describing how the system (including arrangements for teachers to cross the threshold) has worked (or not).

This is a tall order for a bunch of volunteers. And the government has proceeded with the new system with unholy haste. Every governing body must identify three governors to receive training in early autumn.

Yet no arrangements have been made to ensure that governors are trained annually in appraising heads. Neither has the government proffered schools advice on how to conduct a fair hearing if the governing body receives a complaint from a teacher.

However, civil servants have produced excellent materials for trainers to train governors. They have also developed a model performance management policy for governors to "adopt and tweak" to suit their local circumstances.

The previous system was scrapped to make arrangements simpler. However, the documentation doesn't hold out much promise of this happening. The only change will be that governors will now carry out the work of local education authorities - gratis.

Is this a case par excellence of government exploiting governors' goodwill, the supply of which is rapidly diminishing?

 David Sassoon is an educational consultant and clerk to governors.

fields.headline: Profitable education
fields.standfirst: School meals, teacher recruitment, consultancy: the private sector is getting fat on the profits to be made.  Phil Revell explores the world of edubusiness
fields.trailText: School meals, teacher recruitment, consultancy: the private sector is getting fat on the profits to be made. Phil Revell explores the world of edubusiness
fields.body:
Companies that are offering services to schools and colleges are stock market high-flyers, according to a report that will make uncomfortable reading for ministers.

"The sector has continued to grow revenues at impressive rates of around 30% per annum," the City finance house Capital Strategies reports approvingly. "Since our first report in February 1999, the sector has witnessed some dramatic changes and significant merger and acquisition activity."

The UK education and training index measures the relative performance of stock market quoted companies with significant parts of their income derived from the education and training sectors. Since January 1 1996 the E&T index has out performed the FT-SE 100, which tracks Britain's top 100 plcs, by a factor of three. While £1,000 invested in the FT-SE all-share index at the start of 1996 would be worth £1,690 at the end of May, the same money invested in the E&T index would be worth an impressive £3,289.

James Tooley would approve. The right-wing professor of education policy at Newcastle University has consistently argued for more private-sector involvement in education.

The virtue of the profit motive, argues Tooley, is that it "can motivate investors... and inspire gifted school principals".

Tooley watched the government gingerly put a toe into the shark-infested waters of privately operated education. Education Action Zones were to be funded by industry, which would invest out of a spirit of altruism. Ministers waited for the rush of chief executives waving cheque books, but altruism was in short supply. The kind of high-profile multinationals the government had in mind were bemused by the prospect. "It's very hard to see how we could do it or what exactly we would get out of it," said burger giant McDonald's at the time. "It's just not our area of expertise."

Meanwhile, the companies with the expertise lobbied hard for a change of approach. The government needed to take the next step and invite the companies to manage education - and a year later, in 1999, ministers did just that, with advertisements inviting companies to express interest in contracts: "Which might be for consultancy... or for the provision of the education services themselves."

The growth of the edubusiness started in the early nineties, when the Thatcher government introduced local management of schools - and headteachers became responsible for a large proportion of their budgets. Labour have accelerated the principle. In September, under new "fair-funding" proposals, schools will be free to contract even more services out to the private sector.

Whether heads have either the time or the training to manage budgets on this scale is another issue. In independent schools a professional bursar would run the budget and deal with contractors. In state schools, the work is often done by an overworked head or deputy. The edubusiness companies include giants such as Capita. In October last year, the Capita Group acquired Capstan, which had been the largest privately owned recruitment specialist. Months later, Capita snapped up LHR Education, another supply agency.

SIMS, the management software used in 22,000 of the UK's 26,000 schools, gives Capita a massive profile in education and moving into teacher recruitment and supply was a natural step for the company, say the report's authors.

Capital Strategies predicts further mergers as the largest companies seek to consolidate their positions. The City finance house describes the favourable dynamics of the teacher recruitment business. Favourable for the companies, that is, rather than for the schools searching for staff.

Other lucrative areas of operation include school meals, where the UK market is worth an estimated £800m a year, and consultancy.

Cambridge Education Associates are co-ordinating the training for heads and management consultants implementing the government's performance-related pay package. The training, which has involved conference-style briefings at premier league football grounds up and down the country, is a multimillion-pound operation involving almost every education consultancy in operation. The costs are comparable to the pay award itself and the complexity and expense of the operation has infuriated heads, who would have preferred to see the money invested directly in schools.

Headteachers would also like to see more of the money that was traditionally routed through local education authorities - and there at least they are likely to get their way. Local authorities have been the latest group in the education arena to be given the named and shamed spotlight. David Blunkett's announcement at the National Association of Head Teachers' conference in May, where he indicated a more direct funding route between Whitehall and schools, could see many functions of the local authorities taken over by private contractors.

"We've been frustrated with the slow pace of change on this issue," says Charles Rigby of World Challenge. Rigby's company offers a packaged gap year experience to students, but he has recently become involved in two action zones and World Challenge is bidding to be one of the organisations to deliver the summer camp experience promised to all 16-year-olds by Blunkett earlier this year.

"All businesses like ours seek is a level playing field," Rigby says. "Good local education authorities like Birmingham and Leicestershire have reached out to the private sector, but we have had a long running battle with some authorities who have threatened schools with legal difficulties if they buy our services."

Some of the biggest edubusiness operators are not-for-profit organisations. CfBT is a charity with a £60m turnover. Its chief executive, Neil McIntosh, moved into education after spells with Voluntary Service Overseas and Shelter. He's dismissive of the argument that the private sector should have no place in schools or that money paid to contractors has in some way leaked out of the system to the detriment of schools.

"The state doesn't publish textbooks," he says. "Is that leakage? Look at other areas of social policy, like residential childcare. The proposal that the state should do it all would not be something the children in North Wales would be too happy about. What the public sector needs to do is develop a capacity to be a much more effective regulator."

Some of the pitfalls awaiting ministers are outlined by Kevin McNeany, the millionaire who runs the largest and arguably most successful of the edubusinesses - Nord Anglia Education.

"Some schools," he says, "are simply not equipped to deal with a funding flow." McNeany argues that small primary schools in particular need the support of a larger organisation, but it doesn't have to be the local authority. Clusters of schools could offer support to each other. A more fundamental problem is the flow of government initiatives.

"The Department for Education needs to realise that they must stop channelling policy through local authorities. You can't take their funding away and still expect them to implement a plethora of policies."

McNeany would like to see full control of schools, including ownership of their capital assets, offered to edubusiness along with a recognition that contracts need to have longer-term targets. Nord Anglia has stayed out of the bidding for some contracts because the targets were seen as unrealistic, but the education department is getting the message.

"The private sector has helped to shape government policy," he said. "The market brings in concepts of value for money and customer service. It wouldn't require an enormous percentage of schools to be run privately to make a big difference."

It's a message that rightwingers like James Tooley never believed a Labour government would be receptive to. "David Blunkett is continuing to support everything I have been talking about," he says. Whether Blunkett is happy to see private companies reap rich rewards from the sector is another matter. Either way, investors looking for a nice little earner might consider the E&T index the next time they check the market. Edubusiness is a growth area - for some.

Education's entrepreneurs

Nord Anglia

Led by Kevin McNeary, one of the few teachers to have become a millionaire working in education. He set up a chain of language schools and expanded into independent schools, Ofsted inspections and teacher supply. Went public in 1997. This year's turnover was up 11% to £1.2m with profits up 156%.

Chartwells

School caterers Chartwells signed a private financing deal last year in Lewisham, south-east London, to run the authority's entire catering operation - 67 kitchens catering for nearly 100 schools. The market for school meals is huge, with 80% still in local authority hands, but companies such as Chartwells are eroding that lead: "We operate in 1,330 schools," says Mike Sparrow, the managing director. "That's £40m turnover this year, a growth from £14m three years ago."

RM

Abingdon-based Research Machines is the leading supplier of software and IT systems to the education market, its current order book is worth more than £100m. RM's stock price hit £10 earlier in the year, but it's currently hovering around 700p - hit by the general uncertainty over technology stocks rather than by any trading weakness.

Capita

With a £327m turnover, Capita is one of the larger players in edubusiness. SIMS, the management software used in nearly all Britain's schools, is its core product, with teacher supply and management consultancy more recent ventures.

World Challenge

One of the smaller edubusinesses, but owner Charles Rigby is ambitious and World Challenge could be a company to keep an eye on. Originally a travel company providing a structured gap year for students, World Challenge now works in 15 of the government's action zones, providing youth development training. Current turnover is around £10m with annual growth running at around 30%.

CfBT

The Centre for British Teachers is a charity specialising in educational services. It's one of the biggest Ofsted inspection contractors and also provides consultancy and management. Until 1991, the charity worked overseas, but since it launched a British operation its turnover has increased from £8 m to £60m. Current chief executive is Neil McIntosh, a former director of VSO and Shelter.

 The Business of Education, a market report by Capital Strategies; tel: 020-7256 8000.

webTitle: Shakespeare as you've never seen him

fields.headline: Shakespeare as you've never seen him
fields.standfirst: Inspired by a new Romeo and Juliet, some Garvestone pupils are intent on writing their own play
fields.trailText: Inspired by a new Romeo and Juliet, some Garvestone pupils are intent on writing their own play
fields.body:
Readers may be familiar with the scandal created by Carol Vorderman when she was flummoxed on a special charity edition of Who Wants to be a Millionaire?. The maths intellectual couldn't identify which play the character Sir Toby Belch appears in (the answer is Twelfth Night). Ms Vorderman responded to her critics with "I don't read Shakespeare. I think it's dull as ditchwater."

Now, as many teachers (but possibly fewer pupils) up and down the land could have told the Countdown queen, Shakespeare should be seen performed, as it was intended, not read. Young people who get the chance to see the English Shakespeare Company's specially commissioned version of Romeo and Juliet certainly don't agree with Ms Vorderman's sentiments.

In Jeff Tear's production for seven- to 12-year-olds, a cast of five actors and three puppets re-tell many of the original scenes of the world's most famous love story through the eyes of the nurse/storyteller, who travels the world with her suitcase of stories. Using puppetry, music and circus, the storyteller creates two worlds - the world of the older generation who do not understand the other world, the world of youth. And then there is the friar, a misfit on a unicycle, whose heart is in the right place but who cannot alter the way the story must end. The warring families are represented by the huge puppets, while Romeo and Juliet are "real".

Last Thursday, five schools - from Grundisburgh in Suffolk, and Corpusty, Catton, Fleggburgh and Garvestone in Norfolk - visited the Maddermarket Theatre in Norwich, where they sat spellbound.

Jane Broscomb accompanied the 25 year 2 to year 6 pupils from Garvestone Primary. The school serves a small village just west of Norwich. Broscomb says the very experience of visiting a theatre was a treat in itself for her pupils. She says that they found the puppets easy to relate to, and when the actor playing the friar asked the youngsters afterwards why they thought he was shown on a unicycle, one child came up with the original suggestion that it was to make him nearer to God! The children, particularly the boys, were intrigued by the fight scenes and how they were arranged, from the swords to the retractable dagger that made it possible for Juliet to die dramatically time after time.

The benefits of a visit to a production like this are clear to Broscomb. She reports that on returning to school and discussing what they had seen, many of the pupils at Garvestone said they hadn't realised the Bard could be such fun. She says: "As a first experience of Shakespeare it is a positive one, which makes it easier to build upon in the future and enjoy. The children could see that the actors were also enjoying themselves, which is important."

The performance has also inspired a group of boys in years 4 and 5. They are planning to write their own play, to perform to the rest of the school later in the term. This came about partly from a discussion with their teachers, who explained that in Elizabethan theatre, men and boys would play all the parts, including the female roles. Broscomb is fairly certain that the Garvestone play will not have many roles for women or quite so much kissing as Romeo and Juliet, for that reason alone!

 The English Shakespeare Company's ActiveShakespeare production of Romeo and Juliet is now touring throughout England and Wales until July 13. For further information and to book tickets, ring the education unit on 020-7287 1113. There is also an extensive teachers' pack available for follow-up work.
